HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
The nation's trade deficit with Japan jumped sharply in September, even as the overall deficit narrowed to $8.31 billion. This was only a modest improvement from the August deficit. [D1.]
Top U.S. and European officials held another round of meetings aimed at averting a potential trade war. But neither side expressed any willingness to change positions. [D2.] 

The Economy
The Fed's chairman said a strong recovery remained elusive if banks are reluctant to lend and businesses are reluctant to borrow. Alan Greenspan advocated reducing bank regulations. [D1.]
The Commerce Department invited closer scrutiny of its methods for compiling reports on gross domestic product. The step was meant to show that data had not been manipulated. [D7.]
A former protege of Michael R. Milken will not go to prison for paying a kickback to a customer of Drexel Burnham Lambert. Louis L. Stanton received a one-year suspended sentence. [D7.]
Federal investigators have questioned state lawmakers as part of an inquiry into a series of 1989 votes about allowing out-of-state banks to operate in Connecticut. [A1.]
 
Companies
G.M.A.C. will no longer provide financing for non-G.M. models sold by dealers who also sell General Motors cars, and G.M.'s Cadillac division said it would drop its Allante two-seater. [D5.]
Hewlett-Packard's fourth-quarter net income plunged 46 percent. But its stock jumped $3.375 a share. [D5.]
Egghead Software's quarterly earnings plunged 75 percent, and its president, Matthew J. Griffin, resigned. [D5.]
A former Grumman chairman pleaded guilty to fraud charges growing out of a long investigation of military contractors. [D5.]
Allied-Signal sold 33.3 million common shares of Union Texas Petroleum Holdings for $585 million. [D6.]
Hollywood producers argued in a brief that a judge who wrote a decision favorable for TV networks was not impartial. [D19.]
The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reached a tentative agreement with teamsters, raising hope that a long strike may soon end. [D19.]
 
Markets
Japanese Government pension funds issued buy orders on Wednesday, propelling the Nikkei index up 4.9 percent. Nevertheless, gloom about the weak economy remained. [D1.]
The Japanese rally spilled over to Wall Street, where the Dow Jones industrial average gained 14.05 points, to 3207.37. [D8.]
Treasury prices rose and yields fell. Municipal bonds rallied as investors bought up North Carolina power bonds. [D16.]
Heating oil tumbled to its lowest level since early March, in reaction to further evidence that winter supplies are ample. [D17.]
The dollar finished lower, despite a report that the U.S. trade deficit shrank in September. Gold prices were mixed. [D17.]
 
Today's Columns
Westinghouse is exploring the sale of its broadcasting division, Wall Street executives said. The company is under intense financial pressure because of the poor performance of its credit division. Kurt Eichenwald: Market Place. [D1.]
Russia's shock therapy is a daunting test of a prescription for rejuvenating state-dominated economies, and some observers believe Boris N. Yeltsin must shift to a more gradual approach. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Sears, Roebuck will feature "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial" in its crucial Christmas shopping season promotional program for the second year in a row. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: A Retail Season of Hope and Caution

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
With their fingers tightly crossed and rabbits' feet stashed in their pockets, merchants are predicting healthy -- but not robust -- sales increases this holiday season.
Retailers are taking hope from their strong performances in the third quarter, when sales and profits increased for many. Also figuring into their estimates are the recent encouraging economic statistics, like stronger housing starts, rising consumer confidence and slightly lower unemployment and consumer debt loads. 
 And the calendar will work in their favor this year, giving retailers two days more than last year between Thanksgiving and Christmas to entice shoppers.
"I think Santa will arrive on time this year, if not a little early," said Robert E. M. Nourse, president and chief executive of the Bombay Company, a specialty retailer based in Fort Worth. "Last year he really didn't show up at all."
But the ghost of recent Christmases past, when sales failed to outpace inflation, still haunts many retailers.
"We're saying sales will be up 4 to 5 percent over last year," said John J. Schultz, president of the National Retail Federation, pausing a moment before adding: "But say four. Four's safer."
 
Playing It Safe
 While some investment analysts have projected 6 percent to 10 percent sales increases this season, a survey of 1,175 retailers by the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche found that 41 percent expected sales and profits to be flat or only as much as 3 percent higher than last year.
Playing it safe is the name of the game this holiday season, which begins in earnest the day after Thanksgiving and comes to a halt on Dec. 24. Retailers have ordered sparingly, choosing to sacrifice sales rather than be left with unsold merchandise. Merchants are also banking on dependable sellers from the past, like board games, educational computer programs and rugby shirts, to lead sales.
The merchants' caution is well founded. California will be their Achilles' heel this holiday. The chains all have at least 15 percent of their stores there, and even the most optimistic retailers see no turnaround in that state's beleaguered economy.
Malina Gerber owns Malina's, a children's clothing retailer with stores in Los Angeles and Santa Monica, Calif. She said sales in her two shops, as well as a line of private-label children's clothing she sells to stores like Neiman Marcus and Nordstrom, are off by about 25 percent this year. "I don't expect any miracles at Christmas," Ms. Gerber said.
Despite the surge in the consumer confidence numbers reported by the University of Michigan, interviews with mall shoppers in various parts of the country reveal an underlying sense of uncertainty that could undermine holiday spending.
In a survey conducted by Leo J. Shapiro & Associates Inc., the market research firm, in the five days after the election, 46 percent of the 450 responding households said they would spend less during the holidays this year than last.
"Although I am doing fine financially this year, many people are not doing as well, and that is scary," said Erika Peace, a 25-year-old systems analyst from Midland, Ohio. "Because of the economy, our jobs aren't that stable any more."
 
Ways to Limit Spending
 As was the case last year, shoppers are finding ingenious ways to limit holiday spending. Ms. Peace plans to buy most of the presents for her five family members with cash to avoid building up credit card debt and buying extravagant gifts.
Maria Wilson, a 27-year-old homemaker in Granada Hills, Calif., will make chocolate truffles and hand-made ornaments to give as gifts this year.
Mrs. Wilson did go to F.A.O. Schwarz, the Bentley of toy stores, to buy an anatomically correct male doll for her 18-month-old son, but not before trekking to Toys "R" Us and some local toy stores to compare prices. "I want quality at the best price I can get it," she said.
Attitudes like that are keeping Wall Street busy laying odds on how much discounting retailers will have to do this holiday. For the last several years, anxious retailers have slashed prices to drive holiday sales -- and slashed profits in the process.
This year, most have vowed to keep inventories lean to avoid such a reaction as Christmas Eve draws closer.
"The big advantage we have now is our inventories are better edited," said Carl Tooker, chairman of Rich's, one of the Federated Department Stores chains. "As a result, we can continually replace things that take off hard with fresh merchandise but not get stuck with things that don't move as well."
He estimated that Rich's sales would be 5.5 to 7 percent higher this holiday season than last year.
But a few analysts are less confident, noting that while October sales were very good, November got off to a slow start, although momentum has picked up again.
"Consumers are very value-oriented and price-sensitive still," said Thomas A. Filandro, a retail analyst at Gruntal & Company. "That will result in a retailing game of chicken: The consumer will sit at home waiting for prices to come down, and the retailer will flinch first. The consumer wins again."
At least one retailer was not waiting to encourage shoppers to its stores. Signs trumpeting "20 percent off almost everything Nov. 14 and 15 only" hung on the doors of Carson Pirie Scott & Company's flagship store on State Street in downtown Chicago.
"This Christmas is going to be promotional, no doubt about it, but I think it will be mostly planned promotions," said Wayne Hood, a retail analyst at Prudential Securities. "Of course, it all depends on what happens the week after Thanksgiving. If things are slow, everyone will starting slashing prices."
Other merchants are using increased advertising and direct marketing efforts to spur sales this year. Gordon Segal, the president of Crate and Barrel, the Chicago-based home furnishings chain, said he increased advertising expenditures by 30 percent this year. And unlike more cautious competitors, Crate and Barrel is banking on a 20 percent increase in sales during the holidays and has stocked 20 percent more inventory to meet the anticipated demand.
 
Computer Price Cuts
 Nathan Morton, the president of CompUSA, a computer super- store, said his company's sales had continued to ratchet up at the same rate as in the third quarter, when they increased 21.1 percent in stores open at least one year. Mr. Morton said families were taking advantage of recent price cuts on personal computers.
He believes the retail industry will see about a 5 percent sales increase this holiday, but he is also cautious.
"Everyone's bullish, yes, but with a tinge of conservatism," he said. "The last couple of years, Christmas just hasn't come, and it's difficult to say it's going to be a barn burner because all the cards aren't in yet."

NEW YORK CITY
 
SHOCK AND CAUTION AFTER A SHOOTING
A transit police detail, mistakenly convinced they were confronting a pair of armed robbers, opened fire on plainclothes colleagues outside a subway station in Canarsie, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, leaving one officer seriously wounded. In the wake of the incident, many plainclothes operations were suspended, and questions arose about whether the controversial new 9-millimeter Glock semiautomatic pistol the transit police are phasing in could itself have played a role in touching off the shooting. A1.
 
WHO ASKED THE QUESTION?
A bit of revisionist music history was made in a courtroom in lower Manhattan, with a ruling on the source of the lyrics of a simple, tender 1955 song: "Why Do Fools Fall in Love?" And now, a cab driver from Queens and an unemployed Washington Heights resident -- former members of Frankie Lymon and the Teen-Agers -- stand to collect millions of dollars from those who profited from the song. A1.
 
ON FIRST SEEING 'MALCOLM X'
The film "Malcolm X" has opened, and the debates it has ignited since its director, Spike Lee, began work on it were evident in the range of reactions of students who spilled out of a Harlem theater after viewing it. B4.
 
A, B, C OR D? NONE OF THE ABOVE
Disenchanted with multiple-choice tests, New York City schools will introduce new tests that emphasize the ability to solve problems rather than to choose the right answers. B3.
 
REGION
 
FEDERAL INQUIRY ON BANK VOTES
Federal investigators have questioned at least 18 present and former state lawmakers and searched the home and office of Connecticut's Republican Party chairman as part of an inquiry into a series of 1989 votes about allowing out-of-state banks to operate within the state. The investigation was made raucously public at a State Capitol news conference this afternoon by the Republican chairman. A1.
 
A bank merger's tough path. B6.
 
WOMAN DIED IN CRASH, OFFICIALS SAY
A Hillside, N.J., woman whose body was found in her car five days after she disappeared died instantly from injuries suffered when the vehicle plunged into a ravine, officials said. Her disappearance gained attention because of fears that she might have been a carjacking victim. B5.
 
BRIDGEPORT LIKELY TO TAKE ITS CHANCES
A second major casino operator, Harrah's Casino Hotels, made a presentation to business and political leaders in Bridgeport, Conn., making it likely that casinos will compete to open in this depressed industrial city if Connecticut legalizes casino gambling. B7.
 
PRISONER WITH AIDS APPEALS BITE CASE
A prisoner who has AIDS asked an appeals court in Newark to overturn his 25-year sentence for attempted murder for biting a prison guard, saying that he had been unfairly treated because of fears about the disease. B7.
 
STOLEN-CAR STING IN SUFFOLK
Posing as brokers for stolen cars, Suffolk County authorities recovered 42 cars and a cache of weapons in an elaborate three-month sting operation, and 34 people have been indicted on theft and fraud charges. B7.

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Links Tight Credit to Slowdown

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said yesterday that a strong economic recovery remained elusive as long as banks were reluctant to lend and businesses were reluctant to borrow.
He said that banks appeared to be making credit somewhat more available but that reducing bank regulations could encourage more lending. 
 Speaking to the Tax Foundation, the Fed chairman said the credit crunch had been caused both by banks' reluctance to lend and by weak demand from the business community to borrow.
 
 
'No Evidence of Worsening'
 "Fortunately, the credit crunch, which has been so debilitating to the economic performance in this country over the past two to three years, has shown no evidence of worsening in recent months and may finally be retreating." Mr. Greenspan said.
In his speech at the Walforf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan, he predicted there would soon be more bank failures, "perhaps some sizable ones," but he concluded that the banking community remained healthy enough to help lift the nation's economy.
"Although many problems remain before one can conclude that our banking system has fully weathered the storm of recent years," he said, "it certainly appears in sufficiently reasonable shape to assist in the financing of a sustained expansion in economic activity."
Copies of Mr. Greenspan's speech were made available to the press.
Mr. Greenspan said one root cause of the weak lending by banks was that businesses and households were reluctant to borrow because they were struggling to reduce their debt burdens, which swelled during the 1980's.
Trying to explain why the Fed's repeated interest-rate cuts have not done much to lift the economy, he said monetary policy could only do so much to ease these debt burdens.
"Monetary policy can only peripherally alter the perceived needs of businesses and households to strengthen balance sheets," he said.
The Fed chairman said that by cutting rates, the central bank made it somewhat easier for companies and families to handle their debt burdens, for example, by helping foster lower rates for consumer loans and home mortgages.
In ways, Mr. Greenspan seemed to try to take President Bush off the hook for the nation's protracted slump, suggesting that the Government could do little to overcome the reasons behind tight credit.
"Part of the so-called credit crunch problem reflects deep-seated economic forces which government policy can only tangentially affect," he said.
In dissecting the credit crunch, Mr. Greenspan said that "by far the greatest source of stagnant loan markets is weak demand." But on a modestly upbeat note, he suggested that loan demand, economic growth and consumer spending could pick up even before debt burdens were reduced to comfortable levels.
In his typically dense language, he said, "If, as balance sheets become more comfortable, businesses and households decide to reduce their excess debt more slowly, cash flows will be diverted to purchases of goods and services."
After banks and businesses have debated for months whether lenders were denying loans to worthy borrowers, Mr. Greenspan rendered a firm verdict that banks were indeed sometimes being too reluctant.
"An impressive number of worthy applicants have been rejected as banks pressed to rein in asset growth to preserve capital positions eroded by loan losses," he said.
He acknowledged that it was understandable for banks to tighten their lending standards after they had made so many bad loans, especially on commercial real estate, in the 1980's.
At the same time, he acknowledged that there was some legitimacy to bankers' complaints that regulators have tightened their standards, forcing banks to be more cautious in lending.
"Human nature being what it is," Mr. Greenspan said, "it is entirely understandable and credible that examiners have become tougher in evaluating loans as the consequences of earlier lax lending standards became apparent."
Mr. Greenspan noted that many banks were using their deposits to load up on Government securities instead of making loans, and he suggested this could make banks vulnerable to losses if interest rates rose suddenly.
"It is probably true," he said, "that greater interest-rate risks have developed of late because securities tend to have longer maturities than bank loans."

HEADLINE: Counties in New Jersey Retain Above-Average Credit Ratings

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Despite the region's deep recession, the 21 counties of New Jersey retain better credit ratings and sounder fiscal policies than most American counties, according to a profile of the state released yesterday by Moody's Investors Service.
Moody's, one of the nation's largest credit-rating agencies, said roughly half of New Jersey's counties maintained its highest ratings, Aa and Aaa. Nationally, only 18 percent of counties achieved those ratings. 
 The report released yesterday was the sixth in which Moody's analyzed all the counties in a state, and the first in which it studied a state in the New York metropolitan region. Moody's said it selected New Jersey for the study because few other states had undergone such profound economic changes since the early 1980's, first being swept up in booming growth, then battered by job losses, a depressed housing market and other recessionary woes.
The ratings save the counties money when they sell bonds to raise money because they pay lower interest rates than jurisdictions with less-favorable ratings.
In New Jersey, "the 1990's will be a period when the growth is over," said Michael Johnston, a Moody's vice president in charge of credit ratings in the Middle Atlantic region. As a result, he said, some or all of the New Jersey counties may have to reduce spending for recreation, parks, libraries or other services.
But for now, the report concluded, the finances of New Jersey counties are "substantially more favorable than for U.S. counties overall."
One reason, Moody's said, is that New Jersey has an average per capita income of $24,936, 33 percent higher than the national average, making it the nation's second-wealthiest state, following Connecticut.
Another reason for the high credit ratings, Moody's said, is a tradition of conservative fiscal practice by county officials, who in most cases have maintained larger budget surpluses than their counterparts elsewhere.
 
Nettlesome Problems
 Still, Moody's said, New Jersey's counties face economic hurdles. Among the most nettlesome may be solid waste disposal, which has already cost taxpayers dearly because counties have been slow to form working partnerships, the report found.
Other problems may lie in migration patterns, which have already reduced the populations and narrowed the tax bases of Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Union Counties, the urban and suburban corridor across the Hudson River from New York City.
Over all, the study said, New Jersey's population increased by 5 percent during the 1980's, compared with a 9.8 percent increase for the nation. New Jersey's most robust growth, fueled by a flight of business and families to lower-cost real estate beyond the New York City suburbs, came in Ocean, Somerset and Hunterdon Counties, where population grew by more than 18 percent.
On the other hand, Moody's said some dire predictions made in the early 1980's for New Jersey's old industrial cities had proved to be wrong.
"Some of the state's oldest cities appear to have reached some degree of economic stabilization," the report said. It cited Camden, Elizabeth, Jersey City, Passaic and Paterson, each of which showed gains in population during the 1980's.
Other analysts said they agreed with the Moody's conclusion that New Jersey counties were on relatively firm fiscal footing but faced more difficult times for the remainder of the decade.
"They are between the devil and a hard place," said David Listokin, a professor of urban planning at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. He said the counties would face increasing economic difficulty in maintaining roads, bridges and other physical structures, with some of the biggest bills coming due in counties that experienced high-growth levels in the 1980's.
The solid waste problem "is a crisis that has been mounting for years and could get worse," Mr. Johnston of Moody's said. It is particularly acute for New Jersey, the nation's most densely populated state, the report said, because the density means both vast amounts of waste and few suitable disposal sites.
"Counties will need to issue relatively large amounts of debt to finance landfills or waste-to-energy facilities," the Moody's report said.
The report criticized the counties for being slow to respond to the 1990 recommendation of a task force appointed by Gov. Jim Florio that they band together to finance and build waste-disposal plants. So far, it said, only three coalitions have been formed. The counties in one group are Warren, Somerset and Hunterdon; in another are Essex and Bergen, and the third joins Mercer and Atlantic.

HEADLINE: U.S. Officials Defend Data On Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Still smarting from election-week attacks on the integrity of Government statistics, the Commerce Department today took the highly unusual step of inviting closer scrutiny of its methods for compiling reports on gross domestic product, the broadest gauge of American economic performance.
Top officials summoned reporters from The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal to deny strenuously that there was any "cooking" of the data in the department's report on Oct. 27 -- the week before Election Day -- that the gross domestic product grew at a 2.7 percent annual rate for the third quarter. That was well above the 1.5 percent that expert consensus had predicted. 
 High figures for military spending, personal consumption and inventories -- all components of the G.D.P. figure -- met with skepticism among Wall Street and other private economists, leading to news accounts that raised the possibility that the Bush Administration had intervened in the process for political advantage. The strongest allegations were made in The New York Post, which also charged the Administration in a front-page article on Nov. 5 with subverting the employment data for September.
 
 
Television News Report
 Commerce officials said that Dan Rather, in his CBS news report the following evening, used a picture of The Post's article to help illustrate his report on the October employment figures.
Another prominent account appeared in The Christian Science Monitor on Nov. 2, the headline reading "Bush Team Said to Skew Latest Economic-Growth Data."
In response, various officials at the Commerce Department and Labor Department have insisted that there had been no effort to meddle in a process carried out at all stages by career civil servants; political appointees within the departments see the results only on the morning of publication. The officials also said that the system's internal checks made tampering virtually impossible.
Both departments have responded with plausible, generally persuasive, explanations of suspiciously high numbers over the last three weeks. But officials said they feared that confidence of was not fully restored in the Government data, which are closely scrutinized by the investment community for indications of the economy's strength.
 
 
'Very Serious Thing'
 "It's really a very serious thing" to be accusing the Government of, said Carol S. Carson, director of the Bureau of Economic Analysis. "It still hasn't been put to rest."
Robert P. Parker, associate director for national economic accounts, added that that while the economics fraternity might well come to accept the figures and be reassured, "Outside the Beltway, the notion that this could happen is not very far-fetched."
The allegations may have received more credibility than they normally would because of the Bush Administration's political use of some other Government agencies, most visibly the State Department's passport office, which investigated the files of President-elect Bill Clinton during the campaign.
 
Revisions Due Next Week
 Today's session took place in anticipation of the publication next Wednesday of revised figures for third-quarter growth but before officials had knowledge of what they would show. The figures are routinely revised, sometimes up and sometimes down, with the average change about four-tenths of 1 percent.
Still, a downward revision exceeding that average would almost certainly touch off a new round of questions about the reliability of the original data, since this would tend to support suspicions of overstatement in the closing days of the campaign.
Although the Wall Street G.D.P. consensus was generally too low, Mr. Parker noted that the 10 most optimistic forecasters polled by Blue Chip Economic Indicators offered predictions that on average called for a 2.9 percent rate of increase -- a figure even higher than the Government's. There are about 50 participants in this survey.
 
Ultimately, a Judgment Call
 The officials also described an intricate system for internal questioning of suspicious numbers and of cross-checking the results for consistency.
But they admitted it was often difficult to arrive at estimates for international trade and some other categories for which hard figures arrive too late for inclusion. The department, though it uses various rules of thumb to serve as benchmarks, ultimately relies on its best judgment, they said.
Assuming, for example, that missing figures for September would eventually prove to equal the average for July and August, would have resulted in a 4 percent G.D.P. rate of advance for the third quarter, Mr. Parker said. Extrapolating the rate of change from the preceding months, on the other hand, would have produced a figure of only 2.1.
The officials, using their judgment, selected a number in between those two extremes.

HEADLINE: 2d Casino Operator Woos Bridgeport in Gaming Bid

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 18

 BODY:
A second major casino operator, Harrah's Casino Hotels, made a presentation to Bridgeport business and political leaders today, making it likely that casinos will compete to open in this depressed industrial city if Connecticut legalizes casino gambling.
While Harrah's has not selected a site or sketched a plan, it said it wanted to invest $300 million in a 100,000-square-foot casino, a 1,000-room hotel, and restaurant and entertainment areas built around replicas of landmarks like the Parthenon, the Eiffel Tower, a Mayan pyramid and a Chinese temple. 
 To Harrah's as well as Mirage Resorts, which presented a plan here last week, Bridgeport's great attraction is its location: only 60 miles from New York City, on an interstate, with land available on the waterfront.
But other factors are also in play for casinos interested in the immense New York market, as the gaming industry searches for new opportunities beyond Las Vegas and Atlantic City. New Jersey will not allow casinos outside Atlantic City, and New York's parimutuel racing industry appears to stand in the way of any casino in that state.
It is far from certain that slot machines and table games will be legalized in Connecticut, either, where one casino is now operated by the Mashantucket Pequot tribe, but where Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has vowed to veto any bill allowing casinos off the reservation.
But if the economic lure of the gaming industry does prevail in the General Assembly, Bridgeport appears to have one more advantage: its residents, having seen their industry leave town and their government flirt with bankruptcy, are leaning toward welcoming a casino.
"We're looking at two nationally known, nationally respected, nationally recognized, quality casino developers and operators who have expressed an interest in Bridgeport," said Paul S. Timpanelli, president of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council, which sponsored the luncheon today where Harrah's made its presentation.
"When was the last time," he asked, "we had such capacity willing to look at the potential of investing $250 million to $300 million here?"
The put-upon self-image of the city was evident minutes later, when Michael D. Rose, chief executive of Harrah's corporate parent, The Promus Companies Inc., was asked how Bridgeport's experience might differ from that of Atlantic City, where New Jersey had hoped casinos would prove a catalyst for rebuilding the decayed resort town.
 
Looking for Positives
 "There's no comparison between Bridgeport and Atlantic City as it was in the mid-1970's," Mr. Rose began. "Atlantic City was in extremely dire straits." He was interrupted by a growing swell of disbelieving laughter. "A lot worse than Bridgeport," he tried again, evoking more laughter.
Bridgeport has not officially endorsed casino gambling. Instead, a task force established by the business council spent six months investigating the casino industry and its impact in other communities. In December the task force will recommend a position to the council's board.
The process is similar to one going on in Hartford, where many legislators are waiting for the conclusions of a legislative task force on gaming before committing themselves for or against casinos in the session that opens in January.
"The issue," Mr. Timpanelli said today, "is do we want it, and where do we want it, and how do we do it so it impacts our city in a positive way."
He said that a survey of council members one month ago found two-thirds favoring casino gambling, compared with slightly more than half in a survey five months ago.
Mirage Resorts and Harrah's are the only two major casino developers to express interest in Bridgeport. The task force, said its chairman, William A. Bevacqua, has already decided that any casino in the city "should be done by a major developer."
"Where development has come about as the result of someone other than major players," he said, "it's proven to be a much less satisfactory operation. The big people seem to be able to do the kinds of things that we're interested in seeing."
Harrah's and Mirage have proposed casinos of roughly equivalent scale. Mirage has entered a joint venture with Robert Zeff, owner of the Bridgeport Jai-Alai Fronton, thereby eliminating a potential foe while securing his land on the waterfront on the East Side, just north of the Connecticut Turnpike.
With Mr. Zeff, Mirage acquires a dog track he plans to build, an awkward fit in a fantasy-oriented amusement center that Mirage hopes will attract families as well as gamblers.
Harrah's today proposed a casino that would also face the water, though it has not acquired a site; one possibility is on the East Side just south of the turnpike. While the casino complex would feature extravagant fantasies like transporting the Parthenon to Bridgeport, Harrah's would not appeal directly to families.
"Casinos by their nature are not intended for children," Mr. Rose said, in response to a question from the audience. "We don't view this as a primary part of our market."
Mr. Rose said he hoped Harrah's would serve as an anchor for redeveloping Bridgeport's dormant harbor. He also pointed to Harrah's record of hiring, training and keeping local employees in Atlantic City, its financial contributions to community activities wherever it has casinos, and its programs for combating compulsive gamblers and under-age gamblers.
He also pledged not to seek tax abatements or other favors from the city, should a casino be permitted here (most people favor allowing only one casino in the city).
But to a city hoping for a savior, Mr. Rose offered the caution that Mirage's chief executive, Stephen A. Wynn, had issued a week before: "The one thing that you shouldn't expect from a casino operator is that they come in and solve all of your problems. We're not a panacea."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Allied-Signal Sells Stake in Union Texas

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Allied-Signal Inc. said yesterday that it had sold 33.3 million common shares of Union Texas Petroleum Holdings for $585 million, ending a relationship with the oil and gas exploration company that began three decades ago.
The stock was sold through a secondary public offering by a syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Allied-Signal announced earlier this month that it was planning the common stock sale. It follows Allied's redemption in September of a total of $355 million in Union Texas preferred stock and warrants. 
 Allied-Signal said yesterday that the nearly $940 million it received would be used to reduce debt and for other corporate purposes. A spokesman for the company said some of the money might be used for "future projects associated with productivity."
At the end of September, Allied-Signal's total debt was $2.4 billion. The company said it intended to pay down outstanding commercial paper and other short-term borrowings as well as long-term debt that can be repurchased "on an economic basis."
Allied-Signal, which is Based in Morristown, N.J., acquired Union Texas in 1962. As recently as the late 1970's the energy company was responsible for the bulk of Allied's earnings.
But in 1985 Allied-Signal decided to begin to ease out of the business and sold half the company to Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout firm. A subsequent public offering of Union Texas's shares cut Allied's stake to 39 percent.
Alied-Signal is an advanced technology company with businesses in aerospace, automotive products and engineered materials, and the range of its products stretches from jet aircraft engines to Fram auto filters and Autolite spark plugs to chemicals, fibers and other materials.
On Oct. 27 the company reported third-quarter earnings of $140 million, up 75 percent from levels a year earlier levels, on sales of $2.94 billion.
Allied-Signal has about about 90,000 employees. Its stock slipped 12.5 cents yesterday, to $55.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries and Municipals Gain

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Prices rose and yields fell yesterday across the board in the Treasury market. The municipal bond market also gained as investors bought up $1.26 billion in North Carolina power bonds.
Traders are not sure if this is a rally or just the other side of the sharp fall in prices at the end of last week. This will be answered in the next several days of trading, especially if the yield on the 30-year bond can break below the 7.50 percent it fell to yesterday. 
 But traders are a little more sure of some other themes. One is that the market should continue to be volatile until investors and traders know more about President-elect Bill Clinton's economic program and the people he will appoint to the important economic jobs in the new Administration.
 
Volatility Is Evident
 As a measure of volatility, take the new 5.125 percent three-year note auctioned last week. The average yield at the auction was 5.17 percent on Tuesday, it fell to 5 percent Thursday but jumped, as prices fell, to 5.20 percent Monday. It fell to 5.14 percent Tuesday, and yesterday as the price rose 6/32 , the yield dropped to 5.06 percent.
Another note heard in the market is that the rise in short-term interest rates has been greater than it should be because investors believe the Federal Reserve has decided not to cut short-term interest rates any further. On the three-month Treasury bill, the discount rate has jumped from 2.58 percent on Oct. 1 to 3.14 percent Tuesday.
David Ader, fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said the reaction would be justified only if the Fed was expected to raise interest rates soon. But that is not the case. This means the short-end issues could rally a little, as it did yesterday as the discount rate on the three-month Treasury bill dropped to 3.12 percent.
The third theme is that the longer maturities -- the 10-year note and the 30-year bond -- will be the best performers. So in the last several trading days, while the rest of the market has been bouncing up and down, the prices on these two securities have moved only upward.
One reason for this is that investors fear short-term interest rates will rise, prompting them to sell short maturities and buy longer. In addition, this move to the longer end has been supported by the most recent data showing that inflation continues to be in check.
Since the Treasury auction last week, both the 10-year note due in August 2002 and the new 7.625 percent 30-year bond have rallied strongly. The yield on the 10-year note has dropped from the 6.93 percent at the auction to 6.75 percent yesterday. And the yield on the 30-year bond is down from the 7.66 percent at the auction to 7.50 percent yesterday, when the price rose 13/32 .
In trading yesterday, the market got a lift from the Federal Reserve, when it bought notes and bonds as part of a regular effort to keep the right level of reserves in the banking system. The Fed does this buying so that seasonal demands for money by consumers will not push short-term interest rates higher than the target level set by the central bank.
 
Municipal Bonds
 Prices of actively traded bonds were up about 3/4 point, traders said. The market got a lift from the rally in the Treasury market and because after-tax yields in the municipal bond market are attractive and will be even more so if President-elect Clinton goes through with his proposal to raise taxes on families with annual incomes over $200,000.
The sale of bonds by the North Carolina Municipal Power Agency went so well that the lead underwriter, Goldman, Sachs & Company, repriced the issue late yesterday and lowered yields in a range of 4 to 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
One measure of the demand, said Richard Kolman, the manager of the municipal syndicate, was that the bond due in 2017 was expected to be priced to yield more than 6.60 percent last week. But yesterday it was priced to yield 6.48 percent.
The bonds due in 1994 were priced to yield 3.55 percent; for 1997 the yield is 4.65 percent; for 2002, 5.80 percent; 2009, 6.15 percent, and 2015, 6.43 percent.
Another sale that went well, despite the state's budget problems, was the $400 million in general obligations sold by California. Goldman, Sachs won the bidding for the bonds. the bonds were priced to yield 2.90 percent in 1993, 5.65 percent in 2002; 6.15 percent in 2009; 6.20 percent in 2011, and 6.15 percent in 2017. The taxable equivalent for the 10-year bond due in 2002 is 8.19 percent, which is 144 basis points more than the yield on the 10-year Treasury note.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Yields Off a Bit While Taxables Are Flat

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by tax-exempt money market funds moved slightly lower in the latest week, while taxable funds were unchanged, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report, which surveys more than 850 funds.
Tax-exempt yields declined for the second consecutive week, and the assets of tax-exempt funds declined by $449 million, to a total of $97.5 billion. The average number of days left to maturity of securities was down a day, to 63. 
 The seven-day average compounded yield fell to 2.21 percent, from 2.25 percent the previous week, while the simple yield slipped to 2.18 percent from 2.22 percent. Over 30 days, the compounded average yield was at 2.23 percent, and the simple yield was at 2.21 percent, both unchanged.
Assuming no state taxes, the taxable equivalent of the seven-day compounded yield for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket is about 3.07 percent and 3.20 percent for investors in the 31 percent bracket.
 
The Top Performer
 In surveying tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue's said the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund distributed by the Strong/Corneliuson Capital Managementwas the top performer, with a yield of 2.85 percent.
"In effect, little has changed from last week," said Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist. "But the heavy supply of new municipal short-term paper being priced this week may have some impact on money market fund yields next week."
The average seven-day compounded yield for a taxable money market fund was unchanged at 2.78 percent, and the simple yield was 2.74 percent, also unchanged. Over 30 days, the average compounded yield was 2.78 percent, and the simple yield was 2.74 percent, both down 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
Donoghue's analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in portfolios fell by 2, to 63. That is not much of a move, the analysts said, but a move into the mid-50's could be a signal that rates may be headed higher.
The Standby Reserve Fund, distributed by Cowen & Company in New York, the top yield producer the last few weeks, had the best return in the latest week, too, with a yield of 3.77 percent.
For government-only funds with assets less than $100 million, the United Services Government Securities Savings Fund, distributed by United Services in San Antonio, fell to 3.86 percent, from 3.95 percent the previous week.
Elsewhere, the average yield on a bank money market account was at 2.78 percent, down a basis point from the previous week.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. to Curtail Dealer Financing and Drop Allante

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

 BODY:
In another move to shore up its sagging finances, the General Motors Corporation notified its 9,000 dealers today that its General Motors Acceptance Corporation unit would no longer provide wholesale and retail financing for non-G.M. models sold by dealers who also sell General Motors cars.
Separately, G.M.'s Cadillac division said it was dropping its Allante two-seater luxury roadster next year, after a seven-year run in which it often fell short of Cadillac's, and owners', expectations. 
 The current level of wholesale and retail financing for non-G.M. cars amounts to about $6 billion, or 10 percent of G.M.A.C.'s $60 billion in worldwide automotive financing.
"Given our performance and the fact we're struggling on several fronts to be more productive," said John Rines, president of G.M.A.C., "we're focusing our assets primarily on G.M. products." Mr. Rines said he had spoken to about 30 dealers, "and my impression is this won't cause a big commotion."
 
2,000 Dealerships Affected
 A significant number of G.M. dealers also own non-G.M. franchises. A G.M. spokesman said about 2,000 dealerships nationwide would be affected, though banks and other financial institutions probably would be able to replace G.M.'s financing.
G.M. said its decision on retail financing would become effective Jan. 1 and on wholesale financing on March 1. The auto maker will continue to provide financing for non-G.M. used cars.
G.M. said its decision had been prompted by lowered credit ratings on its commercial paper, which are like corporate i.o.u.'s, and the prospect the ratings could fall further. "We want to make sure we prudently manage any liquidity risks," the G.M. spokesman said.
If G.M.'s credit ratings on commercial paper were to fall further, the auto maker might be shut out of that market, forcing it to borrow at a more expensive rate elsewhere. Thus, G.M. might not be able to lend except at rates that would preclude it from making money or might cause G.M. to lose money.
G.M. currently has borrowings of about $20 billion in the commercial paper market, down from about $28 billion last year, the spokesman said.
 
A 'Luxury They Could Ill Afford'
 In eliminating of the Cadillac Allante, Cadillac said the car was profitable but that sales of the $62,000 car had slowed with the sluggish economy. And the expensive manufacturing process -- undercarriages made in Detroit and flown to Italy, where the Pininfarina-built bodies and interiors are installed and flown back to the United States -- is out of step with the new management's eagerness to improve efficiency and focus on high-volume products.
"It was another luxury they can ill afford," said Thomas M. Dukes, director of competitive assessment for J. D. Power & Associates, an auto marketing consultant.
The Allante announcement disappointed many Cadillac dealers, who noted that the model brought additional business. But the car never created the halo with which Cadillac had hoped to illuminate the entire division.
 
A Roof That Annoyed
 The Allante's problems included a convertible roof that leaked and created bothersome wind noise. The manually operated roof was also a struggle for many owners, who believed the top on such an expensive car should operate with the push of a button. The newer models are semiautomated but still require manual help.
"I don't like to spend that kind of money and have a half-manual top," said Joel Must, president of Detroit City Dairy, who owned one before trading it for a Cadillac Seville.
Allante production has fallen since the 1987 model year, when 3,363 Allantes were made. In the first 10 months of 1992, Cadillac sold 1,844 Allantes, a 26 percent drop from the corresponding period in 1991. When it was introduced, Cadillac said it was prepared to build 7,800 of the luxury cars a year.
Although Cadillac introduced many technological innovations in the Allante, including its Northstar V-8 engine in April, the roadster did not measure up to many competitors in its handling and other performance characteristics. Mr. Dukes said the car's boxy body and square, button-laden dashboard also did not appeal to many consumers, who in general seem more taken with the flowing lines of many European and Japanese models.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished lower yesterday against most leading currencies, despite a report that the United States trade deficit shrank in September.
Gold prices were mixed. Gold for current delivery rose 80 cents an ounce, to $335.10, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. But in after-hours trading, the Republic National Bank in New York quoted a bid for gold at $334.75 an ounce, down 65 cents from Tuesday's late bid. 
 The dollar was mixed when foreign exchange trading wound down in Europe, but lost ground toward the end of domestic dealings.
"We are seeing a late selloff here," said Alan Jirkovsky, managing director of foreign exchange at the Continental Bank in Chicago. He attributed the late move to internal conditions in the currency market.
He said the report that the American trade deficit fell to $8.31 billion in September from $8.95 billion in August would normally have helped the dollar, particularly since it reflected an unexpected 6.8 percent rise in exports.
That is usually good news for the dollar because an increase in demand for American-made goods would mean more dollars would be required to make the purchases.
But Mr. Jirkovsky said the market shrugged off the report, possibly reasoning that export growth would not be sustained with recessions in Europe.
"It's good today, but what will it look like a month from now?" he asked.
John McCarthy, foreign exchange manager at ABN-AMRO Bank in New York, said the trade figures were essentially a nonevent for the currency markets, where attention was focused on trading among European currencies.
He said the Swedish krona, for example, was under severe pressure for most of the day with traders selling that currency for German marks.
"The dollar has been of secondary interest today," Mr. McCarthy said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.22 yen, down 0.34 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 123.85 yen. In New York, the dollar fell to 123.70 yen, from 124.35 yen late Tuesday.
The dollar also lost ground to the British pound. In London, the pound rose to $1.5230, from $1.5225 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Under Siege: A Muslim Family Survives, With Fear and Grace, in Sarajevo

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Nov. 18

 BODY:
It is cold now at the home of Amra and Sakir Dzirlo, bitterly so when the winter wind beats against the plastic sheeting that has replaced window glass broken by exploding shells. But the chill that pervades 27 Marshal Tito Street is deeper than the physical hardships of the Sarajevo siege.
As winter sets in, there is a bleakness of mood that pervades the old apartment, something that transcends the need to burn old furniture for heating and the dwindling food reserves that have cut the diet for the family of six to the meanest levels. 
 "There is a new saying in Sarajevo," Mr. Dzirlo said the other day: " 'We have all lived here together. We will all die here together.' "
 
An Intolerable Life
 The pressures from the Serbian nationalists who have besieged the city for seven months, reducing much of it to rubble with their artillery and denying supplies of food, electricity and water to the 400,000 residents, have made life for many intolerable.
Among the Dzirlos -- Sakir, a 44-year-old electrical engineer; Amra, a 42-year-old architect and interior designer, and their four children, two daughters and twin sons -- thoughts have turned to something that was once unthinkable: whether they should try to escape and join more than a million other Bosnian Muslims who have become refugees.
"Here is tragical situation, like Spania, when Ferdinand and Isabella say to Muslims, Jewish, 'Go out,' " said Mr. Dzirlo, who traces his family's roots to the last of the Spanish Moors. He continued in his fractured English: "But say me, where must we go if we cannot stay here -- to Libya or something? Maybe to Saudi Arabia or Kuwait? Are we complete rubbish people, to wander about for few hundred years, look for another place?"
 
Preparing for the Impossible
 For the moment, discussion of fleeing is moot, since the Bosnian Army defending Sarajevo has said it will permit no more evacuations, and the Serbian forces are seizing Muslims to exchange for Serbian prisoners.
The family's worst nightmare is that the city's defenders will crack and Serbs will pour into the city, exacting terrible revenge on the residents who have held out against them for so long. But many families, including the Dzirlos, have concluded that even if the defense holds, it may be impossible to survive the winter, with insufficient food and heat and with no way to seal the gaping holes in their roof and walls that have been made by Serbian shells.
To prepare for the moment when they can wait no longer, the family car has a jerrycan of gasoline, bought on the black market, and a new battery. Every document that could help the family resettle elsewhere has been pulled from dusty files, including the expired New York State driver's license that Mr. Dzirlo got during a year of graduate engineering studies at New York University.
 
A Funeral
The Adults Mourn, The Young Dream
 The turning point for the Dzirlos (the name is pronounced JEER-low) came two weeks ago, after their next-door neighbor and close family friend, Hamid Pasic, a 79-year-old retired professor of medicine at the University of Sarajevo, was killed by a mortar during an afternoon stroll.
As if to demonstrate that he, at least, would not be cowed by the shelling, Dr. Pasic had insisted on going out every day for a walk up and down Tito Street, visiting street-corner markets to see if there was any food that his modest pension could buy, consoling survivors. "Everything will be O.K.," he would say, chuckling.
After the mortar blast, it took two days for Mr. Dzirlo to trace his friend, telephoning police stations and morgues until officials at the old military hospital a mile away said a body fitting a description of the old man had been brought in.
A funeral was arranged in an old Muslim cemetery at Vrabanusja, up cobblestone alleyways that lead to one of the oldest Muslim quarters. Mr. Dzirlo was one of a handful of mourners, glancing nervously toward Serbian gun positions on the hills.
 
Allah's Will
 Afterwards, as he paced quickly back down the hill, the normally voluble Mr. Dzirlo was silent. The silence continued around the Dzirlos' cramped dining table, save for the studied cheeriness of Amra Dzirlo, who had laid on a late lunch of home-made quince juice and ustipak, the fried batter cakes that are a staple among the Muslims.
After a while, Mr. Dzirlo gave voice to his thoughts. "Who knows who will be next?" he asked. "You? Me? Amra? The children? Mrs. Pasic? We are alone now, except for Allah. If it is Allah's will, we will survive."
Mr. Dzirlo's remarks set off a brief debate, conducted in English out of courtesy to this reporter, who met the Dzirlos in early June and has spent weeks with the family, following their progress in several dispatches.
The 14-year-old twins, Mahir and Malik, were all for planning an escape. But Meliha, the 16-year-old daughter, demurred. "What is the point to talk about things that are impossible?" she asked.
Lejla, her 10-year-old sister, asked for a translation. "I would like to go to New York, maybe Hollywood," she said, reeling off names learned from television programs that have been mostly a memory since Serbian forces cut off electricity in July.
 
The Crossroads
Revenge Stains The Old Tolerance
 Sarajevo is at the northern fringe of the zone where the worlds of Europe and the Orient meet, and the city's ethnic heterogeneity is a testament to the fact that diversity was tolerated during much of its history.
Serbian nationalists have now seized much of Bosnia and Herzegovina for a Serbian mini-state that as been "ethnically cleansed" of Muslims and Croats. But the Ottoman Turks, the Muslims who ruled Bosnia for four centuries until they were driven out in 1878, tolerated Roman Catholic Croats and Eastern Orthodox Serbs, as well as Jews.
How completely the cultures blended is apparent after one mounts the darkened stone stairwell to the Dzirlos' second-floor apartment.
Inside, there is a foyer where shoes are removed in the Muslim tradition, and carpets where the family kneels at 5 A.M. for the first of five daily prayers. Beyond is a living room filled with filigreed screens and tables from Turkey, the home of Amra Dzirlo's ancestors, and delicate oil paintings of wooden vessels with graceful sails moving down the Nile.
But along with these, there is also a Viennese grand piano dating to the 1880's. On nights of intensive shelling, Meliha, considered one of Sarajevo's most promising young pianists, plays Beethoven sonatas and the twins play classical guitar.
In such a home there is no need to belabor points that Muslims in Sarajevo are often keen to make: that by standards of education and professional skills and cosmopolitan tastes, they have no reason to feel inferior to the Serbs, and that while they observe traditions of Islam engendered in the Middle East, they consider themselves no less European than, say, Germans or Italians, and in any case no more strangers here than Serbs.
As a matter of ethnicity the point is irrefutable since, unlike the Dzirlos, most Muslims in Sarajevo are Slavs, like the Serbs. The Slavic Muslims converted to Islam under Ottoman rule, filled many of the civil-service positions under the Ottomans and developed into a class of educated, urban landholders, more and more distinct from the predominantly rural, agricultural and less educated Serbs.
 
'Genocide' Against the 'Filth'
 But the Serbian nationalists accuse the Muslims of being traitors to the Slavic people, and such denunciations have been used to justify, and perhaps to inspire, the "ethnic cleansing" that has driven more half of Bosnia's Muslims from their homes, and killed and wounded tens of thousands.
The Serbian militiamen who have done much of the killing refer to Muslims as borije, or filth, and say their job will be done when Muslims revert to being Serbs, or are eliminated.
To Sakir Dzirlo, this amounts to "genocide," requiring Muslims to fight back as long as it takes to avenge what has happened in the war. But Amra Dzirlo takes the lead in citing the Koran's teachings on tolerance. "Tomorrow, I forget all, if war is stop," she said.
 
Interethnic 'Honesty'
 What all the Dzirlos agree on is that Sarajevo should be neither a Muslim nor a Serbian city, but a place where all groups co-exist.
Within the family, the war is seen as being not so much between between Serbs and Muslims and Croats as between raja, a Bosnian term meaning honest people of any ethnic group, and papak, literally the hoof of a farm animal, a disparaging phrase to refer to people hostile to urban mingling. Few things please Mr. Dzirlo more than meeting a Serbian friend and proclaiming: "This man is raja."
In contrast, he denounces Radovan Karadzic, the Sarajevo psychiatrist who is leader of the Serbian nationalist party in Bosnia. Mr. Karadzic came to Sarajevo as a boy from a mountain village in Montenegro, the smaller of the two remaining republics of the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav federation, and Mr. Dzirlo delights in mocking him: "Karadzic is papak, he come from mountains, from sheep, and he want to be king."
 
A Gadfly
Beseeching Serbs, Beseeching Bush
 Until the outbreak of the war, Mr. Dzirlo took little interest in politics. As long as Yugoslavia was under Communist rule, Mr. Dzirlo, like many professional people here, concentrated on his work and his family, privately disparaging the Communist system but avoiding open opposition.
But since the siege began, the apartment on Tito Street has become a sort of unofficial citizen's bureau. Before the Serbian forces cut off telephone links with the outside world, Mr. Dzirlo tried to dial President Bush, President Francois Mitterand and other international figures, seeking their intercession in the war.
"My name is Sakir Dzirlo, and I am writing to you in the name of all honest citizens who stayed in ruins in Sarajevo," he wrote to Mr. Bush in June. "This is crime war from robbers of Serbia, Montenegro and Yugoslav Army on citizens of Sarajevo. You could stop this holocaust but you did not, and we don't know why."
In the early weeks of the siege, when the Serbian officers commanding Yugoslav Army units shelling the city were still in nearby barracks, Mr. Dzirlo walked to the barracks, argued his way in and confronted Gen. Milutin Kukanjac, the army commander.
"What do you think you are doing?" he asked, according to a friend from Tito Street who was present. "Are you mad or something?"
 
The Children
The Cruel Lessons Learned Under Fire
 For the Dzirlo children, the war has meant an end to schooling. But it has not meant an end to learning: their mother takes them to libraries and borrows books from friends on languages and science and literature, reminding the children of the Koran's insistence on the need for study. Anything about the United States is encouraged, particularly books dealing with American liberties.
"It is reason why America go straight up, in economy, in politics, because you are watching individual," Mr. Dzirlo said.
Education of a more unusual kind has come from dodging from doorway to doorway under shellfire, and dashing across intersections to avoid Serbian snipers.
Mahir and Malik have been on the streets almost every day, usually accompanying their father in a daily round of fetching water from the mosques, visiting Mr. Dzirlo's ailing mother, who lives nearby, lining up for bread and scouring the city for increasingly scarce bundles of wood.
Now, when the neighborhood is hit by a shell, the boys identify it instantly. "That was PAM," Malik said one day, using the Yugoslav military term for 40-millimeter antiaircraft guns.
 
Making Do for Food
 On other occasions, when sniper bullets have whizzed overhead, the twins have talked like battle veterans, advising on routes that narrow the snipers' field of fire. "Fast here!" they will shout, springing across a roadway, or "Keep down!"
Usually, the daughters stay inside, helping their mother, and it is to them, as much as to the men, that the family will owe its survival if it makes it through until spring. For months, they have been preparing stocks of food, discreetly, so as not to stir resentment among neighbors.
They will not estimate how long they can hold out on their reserves of flour and cooking oil, tea and toilet paper and candles and soap. A hint has come from Meliha, but it has been grim. "Until January, if we are still alive by then," she said, with a grim chuckle.
It is a tribute to Amra Dzirlo's ingenuity that the family has anything to eat but bread, pasta and rice. She has scoured the city for rose petals and herb grasses and fruits of every kind, apples and quinces and pears, to make jams and preserves, as well as delicacies like kiflice, a sweet cake.
 
Generosity Through Sacrifice
 Visitors are treated to generous snacks and meals, and she waves away compliments as if anything less would be a dereliction of hospitality.
Often, visitors eat alone. Even at mealtimes, the family's habit is to say that they have already eaten, although the absence of any dirty plates suggests otherwise, as does the fact that Amra Dzirlo has lost more than 30 pounds during the siege.
But it is part of the protocol of the siege, and of the Dzirlos' family pride, that visitors accept the hospitality without demurral. Sooner than eat herself, Amra Dzirlo will frequently offer a second helping.
 
25 Funerals, and More
 Little is said about the Dzirlos' economic losses in the war, which include the disappearance of tens of thousands of dollars in savings from the Sarajevo branches of banks with headquarters in Serbia.
The family has lost count of relatives and friends and neighbors who have been killed, including friends of the children. Mr. Dzirlo has attended at least 25 funerals, and those were only the ones that he could get to when he was not at work.
His job, as an executive of the Sarajevo electricity utility, Elektroprivreda, has been a source of relentless frustration. Every time transmission towers and transformer stations attacked by the Serbian forces are repaired, they are attacked again, so the city never has more than a fraction of its peacetime electrical power, and often none at all.
In September, the utility's headquarters was destroyed by fire, along with its records. Now, going to work is largely a formality for Sakir Dzirlo.
Before the war, Amra Dzirlo also juggled her career with her family; now, like most Sarajevans, she is out of work.
"We are sitting and we are watching," Mr. Dzirlo said.
 
'A Little Trick' Goes Awry
 Mostly, his inventiveness goes into schemes to keep the household working. Candles have been made from strips of polyethylene cut from lighting fixtures in abandoned buildings, or from shoelaces floating in cooking oil. To assure getting news after the batteries in their transistor radio ran out, an old car battery has been hooked to a Sony Walkman. One of the children tunes into Radio Sarajevo or the British Broadcasting Corporation, listens through the headphones and relays items to the others.
Sometimes, Mr. Dzirlo's efforts go awry, as they did when he announced that he had organized "a little trick" that would divert a small amount of emergency electricity to the family from a local distribution board.
The plan was for the power to be fed to the home of a friendly neighbor, from there to Dr. Pasic's apartment, and by a cable through Dr. Pasic's back window to the Dzirlos. Each apartment along the way would get power, so neighbors would not accuse Mr. Dzirlo of abusing his position at the utility.
But the scheme went wrong when a technician routed the power to an apartment of a family the Dzirlos hardly knew. Mr. Dzirlo, frantic, ended up stringing cables from a balcony overlooking Tito Street, with a crowd of eager onlookers shouting queries about where the power was coming from.
By the time he had strung cables to every neighbor who needed mollifying, there was only enough left for the Dzirlos to light a single table lamp and the children's fish tank.
Pretty soon, even that supply failed. Weeks later, the family was still laughing over the incident.

GRAPHIC: Photo: While Sakir Dzirlos, left, contemplated evacuating his family from embattled Sarajevo, a moment away from the bleakness was found in their icy apartment under a candle's dim glow. His 16-year-old daughter, Meliha, led an evening of music from the family's piano. (Peter Kullmann for The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: November 19, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 11; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 697 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Backing Serbian President's Internal Foes

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Having failed to budge President Slobodan Milosevic from his position as Serbia's strongman with economic and political sanctions, the United States is now trying to increase pressure for his ouster by supporting Serbian opposition to him, especially on Yugoslav television.
While the Bush Administration is pushing to tighten enforcement of a United Nations embargo against Yugoslavia, it is seeking an exemption to the sanctions to permit the export of communications equipment to independent television stations in Belgrade, the Serbian and the federal Yugoslav capital. 
 On Monday the Security Council passed a resolution, proposed by the United States, to enforce the embargo with a naval blockade of Yugoslavia's Adriatic ports in an effort to halt the smuggling of crucial goods like oil.
Administration officials said the effort on behalf of the independent Studio-B channel and TV-Politika in the Serbian capital is intended to assist forces opposed to Mr. Milosevic, who faces an election in about a month.
Mr. Milosevic is perceived here and in other Western capitals as the principal architect of the seven-month-old campaign against Bosnia and Herzegovina and the war last year in Croatia.
Senior State Department officials have said privately that the ousting of the Serbian President is a basic policy goal, although the Administration has avoided saying this in public. Although it has promoted harsh economic and political sanctions, the United States has done little to support Serbian forces opposed to Mr. Milosevic.
His Socialist Party won office in December 1990 largely because his supporters dominated not only the principal Belgrade television network, but also the major Serbian newspapers.
The Milosevic monoply in the print media was largely eliminated during the summer by the staffs of the dailies Politika and Borba and of the weekly Nin. But Belgrade's Channel 1 television, the principal source of information for the nearly nine million Serbs, remains firmly in the hands of the Milosevic Government.
The main television alternatives is Studio-B, a small station with rudimentary equipment whose range is limited to a radius of about 40 miles, reaching a maximum of barely two million Serbs.
"We strongly support the effort to help Studio B and the other free media," an Administration official said today. He said Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Acting Secretary of State, was personally backing the proposal. It also has the support of Cyrus R. Vance, the former American Secretary of State who is now the special United Nations envoy for the Yugoslav conflict.
The drive to increase the strength of independent broadcasters was stepped up last week by Milan Panic, an American-Serbian who is Prime Minister of federal Yugoslavia, consisting of Serbia and Montenegro. On Nov. 11, Mr. Panic wrote the 15-member Sanctions Committee of the United Nations Security Council saying, "I request your urgent consideration of this request of my Government to import the television equipment."
He said it was needed "to provide all of Yugoslavia's political parties with a television capability equal to that of Serbia's ruling regime, which now controls the only television broadcasting transmitters powerful enough to reach the entire nation." Otherwise, he said, the Milosevic Government will retain "unfair advantage."
Mr. Panic put a price tag of about $5 million on the equipment required, although technical specialists said the enhancement plan could probably be accomplished for far less. The equipment needed consists mainly of repeater stations and antennas.
The proposal for an embargo exemption was initially opposed by Britain, a permanent member of the Security Council. Administration officials said they were hopeful that they could obtain unanimous approval by the Council by the end of the week.
The embargo exemption received the endorsements in recent days of Representative Lee Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs Committee, and Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana. Two foreign policy advisers of President-elect Bill Clinton have also voiced support for the idea.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Redoubling the Efforts At Teaching Geography

 BODY:
Students in Allyson Geary's ninth-grade class at Central High School in Independence, Ore., watch the Los Angeles Dodgers on television at home. But when Ms. Geary asked them in September where Los Angeles was, most responded with blank stares.
Alarmed that her class knew more about bunts than borders, Ms. Geary turned to the National Geographic Society for help. That help has now arrived in the form of the 160,000 geography teaching kits that the society sent to schools earlier this month for use during National Geography Awareness Week, Nov. 15-21. 
 "By the end of the week the class will know where Somalia, Yugoslavia and even Switzerland are," Ms. Geary said.
She said that as part of National Geography Awareness Week, designated by Congress in 1988, she would divide her class into sections representing different continents. The students will analyze the politics and geography of each continent and discuss how its resources should be allocated.
National Geography Awareness Week was ordered by Congress to combat a widespread ignorance of geography. A survey of 12,320 people in 10 countries conducted by the Gallup Organization for the National Geographic Society in 1988 found that Americans 18 to 24 years old ranked last in geographic knowledge. A quarter of the Americans could not find the Pacific Ocean on a map.
Gilbert M. Grosvenor, the president and chairman of the society, said that after World War II, many schools stopped teaching geography as a separate course, folding it into social-studies classes, where it was given little emphasis. "Geography is not just about memorizing state capitals," he said. "Do you know from what major city in the United States you can drive south and enter Canada? Do you know the fourth-largest state in the United States? Most Americans don't know the answers to these questions."
As part of its own efforts to help re-educate people about geography, American Express has established a toll-free phone number that will operate through Feb. 28: (800) 395-4562. The line is open from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. E.S.T. Monday through Friday.
And the answers to Mr. Grosvenor's questions? Detroit and Montana.
