HEADLINE: To Be Rescued, Historical Society May End Up Joining Its Savior

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
The board of trustees of the New York Public Library approved a plan to assist the financially troubled New-York Historical Society yesterday. The directors of the library will consider lending the society about $1.5 million and will enter into formal discussions that could result in a merger of the two institutions.
"We don't know exactly where this will lead," said Dr. Timothy S. Healy, the president of the library. "The possibilities range from folding the society to merge with us to finding a white knight and not needing our help. 
 "We're very pleased. The society has a collection that dovetails with ours."
 
Fine and Decorative Art Objects
 The society is housed in a four-story limestone classical landmark at 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street, and is among the first cultural and educational institutions established in the United States. The collections include 1.6 million fine and decorative art objects and nearly three million manuscripts, maps and historical documents.
The society's research library, which has 650,000 volumes and nearly three million manuscripts, maps and historic documents, focuses on the early years of the United States and the Civil War.
Typically, about 200 objects are on display in the society's galleries. These include such permanent exhibitions as 40 Tiffany lamps and windows, 40 Audubon watercolors and many paintings, including Thomas Cole's five-part allegorical series, "The Course of Empire."
Marshall Rose, the chairman of the library, said, "This agreement gives both of us enough time to see what the proper solution will be."
He added that since the library's endowment is $225 million, a loan of about $1.5 million to the hard-pressed society is reasonable.
 
The Need for Money
 Norman Pearlstine, the chairman of the society, said that six weeks ago he approached Dr. Healy and Mr. Rose with a proposal when it became clear that without an emergency infusion of cash the society would have to close. The society's board formally approached the library on Monday.
On the verge of financial collapse and under investigation by the State Attorney General for the mismanagement of its collections in the summer of 1988, the society replaced its directors and most of its board. Over the last four years, the new leaders raised more than $22 million, secured the collections and reduced the deficit by half, but that was not enough.
"We have made considerable progress over the past few years in preserving our collections and making them more available to the public," Mr. Pearlstine said, "but the plain fact is that we have run out of cash and we have run out of time."
He added that although a loan from the library would enable the society to get through its current fiscal year, which ends on June 30, he did not think it would be possible for the society to remain "independent and viable" beyond then.
Mr. Pearlstine, a former executive editor of The Wall Street Journal who has been a board member of the society since 1985 and its chairman since 1989, said he had approached the library after coming to the belief that the library provided the best hope for preserving its collections and keeping them in New York City.
 
'To Consider Appropriate Options'
 "The library's assistance," he said, "will give us time to consider appropriate options, including possible affiliations with the library or some other institution."
He said that the library's approval of the proposed loan would permit the institution to remain open after December, but that the society would continue to pursue plans to temporarily close its exhibition galleries in January.
"The society's collections are uniquely complementary with those of the library," he said.
The New York Public Library consists of 82 branches, which circulate materials, and four research centers, including the Central Research Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, the annex on West 43d Street, the Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center and the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Lenox Avenue, at 135th Street, in Harlem.
In May, the library bought 213,000 square feet of space in the old B. Altman Building at 34th Street and Madison Avenue, and plans to move its science and business collections there in 1995.
 
With Various Options
 One possibility to be studied, Mr. Pearlstine said, would be to move the society's library to space vacated in the Central Research Library when the science and business collections are moved out in 1995, and to combine the society's newspaper collection with that of the library's extensive newspaper collection housed in the 43d Street Annex.
In addition, he said, the society has a strong collection of 19th-century black-history materials, which might well be moved to the Schomburg Center.
"These are exciting possibilities," Mr. Pearlstine said, "but I think the final decisions in such matters are better made by curators than by administrative heads of organizations."
In recent years, the society has lurched from one crisis to another. In 1982, Dr. James B. Bell, then the director, became embroiled in controversy because of his treatment of a senior employee. He had dismissed Mary Childs Black, the highly regarded curator of sculpture, painting and decorative arts. Mrs. Black protested the abrupt dismissal and this was widely supported throughout the museum world. The matter was finally resolved when the society agreed to pay Mrs. Black, who died last February, the back pay and vacation owed to her together with her pension.
 
With Dismissals and Fewer Hours
 Six years later, the society found itself on the brink of bankruptcy. A mounting budget deficit, a dwindling endowment and everything from a leaky roof to storage conditions that were steadily destroying the collection forced the society to take drastic action. In June 1988, the trustees ended Sunday visiting hours, closed two of the museum's four floors and dismissed nearly a quarter of the institution's 106-member staff.
The next month, after disclosures in The New York Times revealed the woeful state of the collection, Dr. Bell resigned and his deputy was dismissed.
Also that year, the society had a brush with the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, whose work was soon to become notorious. Mr. Mapplethorpe, acting as the executor of the estate of Samuel Wagstaff Jr., sued the society for the return of a silver collection that Mr. Wagstaff had lent it in 1986. Eventually, the society returned the silver and Mr. Mapplethorpe dropped his lawsuit.
In April 1989, a largely new board and staff came in with Barbara Knowles Debs, a former president of Manhattanville College who was named director and president of the society.
 
Despite Some Improvements . . .
 Within a few months, Ms. Debs was able to announce the results of a successful fund-raising drive, which included a gift of $2.5 million from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation and a $1.8 million contribution from the DeWitt Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund. The roof was repaired, conservation studios were opened, and the collection seemed secure, at least for the time being.
But financial problems continued to bedevil the society. In the fall of 1991, Dr. Mary Schmidt Campbell, then the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, suggested that a financial crisis might be avoided if the society were to merge with the Museum of the City of New York.
Trustees and board members of the two institutions met in January to consider the proposal. Advocates of the merger said it would save administrative costs and create a worldclass historical museum, research library and archive, but the costs of combining the two institutions proved unexpectedly high and in March the parties announced that the merger would not take place.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
On the Argentine Economic Miracle

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Probably no one explains economics to the American public in simpler, more vivid half-hour television bites than Adam Smith. But simplicity seems to have worked against Mr. Smith in his latest effort, a two-part series that tries to explain Latin America's latest surge toward prosperity. The answer never quite emerges from the talking heads that he has chosen to interview or from his own narrative.
Perhaps Mr. Smith attempted too much. Three years ago, he had traveled to Argentina to report on that nation's violent hyper-inflation. The inflation has since disappeared, and Mr. Smith returned recently to explain how President Carlos Saul Menem had achieved this goal. The first show, broadcast last Thursday night, answered this question. The second, to be shown tonight at 8 on Channel 13, should have explored who got hurt in Argentina from Mr. Menem's solutions and why those solutions might therefore be short-lived. Instead, Mr. Smith wanders off into a survey of Latin economics and the program loses its edge. 
 There is a "Nightline" quality to Mr. Smith's Latin reporting, almost as if he could have done the shows from New York, with a few feeds from Buenos Aires and other Latin American capitals. More than once, Jorge Casteneda, a Mexican economist temporarily at Princeton, and Susan Kaufman Purcell, a Latin expert at the Americas Society in Manhattan, come on camera to explain or warn about the future.
Absorbed in offering crystal clear explanation, in the talking-head interviews and in his own narrative, Mr. Smith fails to tell a more powerful story through film. Mr. Menem's economic anti-inflation program is essentially an austerity program: cut the budget to eliminate the deficit, lay off Government workers, cap pensions and other entitlement programs, sell off money-losing state companies, freeze the peso-dollar exchange rate and hope that a balanced budget and the new stability will persuade the private sector to invest and hire the people that the Government laid off.
That has not happened, and Argentines are getting restless. But only briefly do we see crowds of the elderly demonstrating angrily for larger pensions or the Rev. Julio Cesar Grassi walking through a muddy shantytown, greeting residents and explaining, "They don't have inflation, but they also haven't had any raises in salaries or wages, or any new jobs."
The Argentine economic miracle that Mr. Smith describes is beginning to fray at the edges and unravel, as similar solutions in the past have unraveled. Just as television images from Iraq or Yugoslavia make those countries vivid for Americans, so can scenes in Buenos Aires explain the unnerving dimensions of the Argentine economic solution. But Mr. Smith, preferring crystal clear narrative to film, misses this opportunity. And Mr. Menem, in the brief interview with him in the Casa Rosada, is never cross-examined on the shortcomings of his economic program.
Still, Mr. Smith suggests the shortcomings. The pensioners do appear. So do hard-pressed middle-class people. And Father Grassi. And then unfortunately, Mr. Smith veers off into his Latin survey, reviewing such standard issues as corruption and militarism.
If only he had given more time to a character who obviously caught his attention, an Argentine comic named Tato Bores whose Sunday night program has for 32 years been satirizing Argentine officials and their policies. For a few tantalizing moments at the end, we get a suggestion of Mr. Bores's skill at dissecting Mr. Menem. His humor has more to tell us about Argentine -- and Latin -- economics than Mr. Smith's talking heads.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Being Beautiful, Being Practical

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Looking Around
A Journey Through Architecture
By Witold Rybczynski
Illustrated. 301 pages. Viking Penguin. $22.
The fun and stimulation of reading Witold Rybczynski is that he sees objects in the framework of time. For example, in "Good Housekeeping," one of the early essays in his new book, "Looking Around: A Journey Through Architecture," he notes the growing luxuriousness of bathrooms and kitchens in contemporary houses. 
 Why should this be? he asks. The rise of the kitchen can be seen as a shift from a backstage space where the help once did the work, to a more public space where families increasingly live and entertain. As for the bathroom, he writes: "It is truly a place for self-presentation -- of oneself, to oneself. A fitting sign of the self-absorbed, individualistic 1980's."
Meantime, the living room has diminished in importance because, according to one authority Mr. Rybczynski cites, the automobile has come to serve as a "portable facade" that publicly expresses social standing. "Cars and car travel also diverted time, attention and money away from parlor life."
The three-dozen pieces in this collection were published in a variety of publications, from the magazine Wigwag (now defunct), where Mr. Rybczynski served as architecture critic, to Art and Antiques and The New York Review of Books, among others. And although their subjects are equally various, their themes are of a piece and reflect some of the obsessions that the author exercised in previous books like "Home: A Short History of an Idea," "The Most Beautiful House in the World" and "Waiting for the Weekend."
One of his chief concerns is what the balance between art and utility in architecture should be ("If a Chair Is a Work of Art, Can You Still Sit on It?," "Should Suburbs Be Designed?," "But Is It Art?" and "Reprise: The Art of Building, or the Building of Art?"). It almost goes without saying that he admires the beauty of well-designed buildings. In "Listen to the Melody," he celebrates the "music" of "successful cities."
In "How to Pick an Architect," he describes how Phyllis Lambert, the daughter of Samuel Bronfman, went from success to success by selecting first Mies van der Rohe to design the Seagram Building in New York City, which Mies's biographer called "the most important tall building of the post-World War II period," and then Peter Rose to create the Canadian Center for Architecture in Montreal, of which Mr. Rybczynski writes, "The building raises my spirits each time I pass it."
Yet it vexes him that in the journal Progressive Architecture, below a photograph of a house designed by Richard Meier for a couple with an extensive collection of art and craft objects, "the caption notes that because the architect did not approve every artifact in the collection, some pieces were temporarily removed when the photographs were taken." He concludes, "Le Corbusier's famous statement that 'life always has the last word' appears quaint and old-fashioned in this context."
Again and again in this volume Mr. Rybczynski is assailed by considerations of the practical tests that architecture must pass. Why do single-family dwellings continue to be so large when the average size of the North American family is shrinking? He has no particular problem when largeness is clearly necessary, as he makes evident in various instructive pieces about campuses, museums, art galleries, embassies, airports, shopping malls, municipal buildings and the Richard Nixon Library.
Still, he wonders why -- at a time when land values are rising, when construction costs and the prices of existing homes seem impervious to recession and when shrinking families have shown a willingness to make do with less space -- "municipalities, reflecting the attitude of homeowners, have staunchly resisted the idea of modifying zoning regulations to permit the construction of smaller houses or to allow the subdivision of land into smaller plots."
He concludes, "The chief reason is, sadly, selfish: smaller, less expensive houses are perceived as a threat to property values and to community status, even though housing in the $50,000 to $80,000 range, 'less expensive' by today's standards, is still accessible only to solid middle-class citizens."
Occasionally, the brevity of these essays is frustrating. You would like him to have explored more deeply and imaginatively the history and appeal of toy building materials, which he traces somewhat desultorily from Anchor Stone Blocks, manufactured by Richter in Germany from 1879 to 1963, through Lincoln Logs, which "smelled good," to "a more refined architectural toy" called Bayko ("Little Architects, Little Architecture").
You wish he had explained at greater length why a revisit to Moshe Safdie's Habitat shows that the experimental housing project in Montreal that resembles a mountain of shoe boxes has successfully withstood the test of time ("Habitat Revisited").
But of course the answer to this last question is everywhere in "Looking Around." It lies in the author's observation that "unlike books, completed buildings should be a little dog-eared before they are reviewed" ("The Birthplace of Post-Modernism"). It lies in his piece called "The Seven Implants of Post-Modern Architecture," which updates a famous talk given by Philip Johnson at Harvard, "The Seven Crutches of Modern Architecture," which in turn was a lampoon of John Ruskin's "Seven Lamps of Architecture."
You only have to look around to see how thought-provoking these essays are.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Bonds Now 2 for 3 in M.V.P. Titles for the 90's

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
No one ever confused Barry Bonds with Mr. October, but he has gained the right to be dubbed Mr. November.
For the second time in three years, Bonds was named National League most valuable player, winning easily yesterday over Terry Pendleton of Atlanta, who edged him a year ago. 
 The 1991 vote was so close -- 274-259 -- that if two voters had reversed their selections for first and second on the 10-place ballot, Bonds would have won and would now be the m.v.p. an unprecedented three years in a row.
"What was done was done," he said yesterday when asked about last year's outcome. "I'm very proud of Terry Pendleton for winning it."
 
Hardly a 'Fluke'
 Winning the award for a second time, on the other hand, was important for Bonds, who is a free agent after seven seasons with the Pirates. "It's something I've been able to accomplish once and I didn't want anyone to think it was a fluke," he said from his agent's office in Los Angeles in a telephone conference call. "I set my goals to win it. Once you climb the mountain, it's harder to stay. I want to stay."
Bonds, 28 years old, is the 10th player to win the N.L. award at least twice. Stan Musial, Roy Campanella and Mike Schmidt each won three times. Previous members of the Pirates who were the league m.v.p. were Roberto Clemente in 1966, Dave Parker in 1978 and Willie Stargell (co-winner with Keith Hernandez) in 1979.
In the balloting, which was completed before he suffered his third successive poor playoff performance, Bonds received 18 of the 24 first-place votes from the Baseball Writers Association panel. He was second on four ballots and third on the other two for a total of 304 points. Pendleton, whose performance this year mirrored his effort with the Braves in 1991, compiled 232 points based on four firsts, 16 seconds and four thirds.
Gary Sheffield of San Diego, who made a remarkable run at the Triple Crown (batting average, home runs, runs batted in), finished third with 204 points. He received the other two first-place votes. Andy Van Slyke, Bonds's outfield mate in Pittsburgh for six years, was fourth with 145 points, and Larry Walker of Montreal was fifth with 111.
 
Gets a Bonus
 Bonds will receive a $250,000 bonus from the Pirates for winning the award, raising his season's income to $5.15 million. That's the fourth highest in baseball behind three New York players, Bobby Bonilla, Danny Tartabull and Dwight Gooden.
Bonds's agent, Dennis Gilbert, who also represents Bonilla and Tartabull, said he didn't think the award would result in a more lucrative contract.
"The people in the bidding already were cognizant of Barry's ability," Gilbert said. "Getting an extra award or two won't change anything."
Gilbert said he thought Bonds would receive more than Bonilla's $29 million for five years, but he declined to answer when he was asked if Bonds would surpass Ryne Sandberg of the Chicago Cubs, who has a $7.1 million-per-year contract beginning next year.
When Bonds was asked if it was important to him to be the highest paid player, he said simply, "No." But Gilbert quickly said: "It's important to me. I want to do the best job I can for my client. The best should be paid the best."
Gilbert said he has spoken with seven clubs about Bonds and eliminated two. He wouldn't identify the remaining clubs, but it was clear that the Yankees, the Atlanta Braves and at least one of the Chicago teams were among them. The Pirates, unless they have a sudden economic change of heart, are not.
Bonds said he has sold his house in Pittsburgh but denied having already bought one in Atlanta, which some people there have said he has done.
Gilbert said he has had contact with the California Angels and the Los Angeles Dodgers, "but they have not shown interest to date."
 
Wants a Winner
 "By this time next week, the picture will be a lot clearer and we'll narrow this down considerably," Gilbert said. "There's no reason why we can't get it done before the winter meetings."
Asked what his priorities were in selecting a team, Bonds said, "a team that's committed to winning." Gilbert added, "Barry Bonds will be playing next year for a team that is a contender."
Bonds played a vital role in making the Pirates successful contenders the past three seasons. He provided a vivid five-week exhibition of his value from Aug. 25 through the day the Pirates clinched their third consecutive division championship. In that span, he batted .426 (43 for 101), hit 11 home runs, drove in 31 runs, scored 34 and had 12 stolen bases in 31 games.

GRAPHIC: Photo of Barry Bonds. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (88%);

HEADLINE: Save the Peace Dividend

SERIES: Bill's List

BYLINE: By Richard Nixon; Richard Nixon, the former President, is honorary chairman of the Fund for Democracy and Development.

DATELINE: WOODCLIFF LAKE, N.J.

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton deserves high marks for aggressively addressing a number of important issues during the transition period. But as was the case during the campaign, the most important issue since the end of World War II has received minimal attention.
It may be politically shrewd to give domestic policy, as it affects an economy just beginning to recover from recession, a higher priority than foreign policy. But the collapse of Boris Yeltsin's pro-Western, democratic Russian Government would have a far greater impact on the American economy than anything the new Administration could do at home. 
 The Yeltsin Government is in mortal danger. The National Salvation Front, an unholy alliance of ex-Communists and ultra-nationalists, have boldly demanded Boris Yeltsin's resignation, a return to authoritarian rule and the restoration of the Soviet Union within its 1991 borders. That would be a prescription for the beginning of cold war II.
The peace dividend, which the Clinton Administration is counting on to help finance its new domestic policies, will be down the tube. Instead of cutting the defense budget, it will be necessary to increase defense spending by billions of dollars.
It has been projected that the United States over the next 10 years can save between $250 billion and $300 billion in defense expenditures if present trends continue. A new Russian nationalist authoritarianism government, heavily controlled by the military and shorn of the failed faith of Communism, would be a greater threat to the forces of peace and freedom in the world than the old Soviet totalitarianism.
What are the chances that the Yeltsin Government will survive? On the minus side, Russia is plagued by massive corruption and runaway inflation. Bloody ethnic conflicts are on the rise. The gridlock in Moscow between President Yeltsin's Cabinet and the heavily Communist Parliament he inherited from the Soviet era is much worse than anything ever witnessed in Washington.
On the plus side, Mr. Yeltsin has proved to be a skillful politician and formidable statesman. His popularity, at a time when his country is suffering not just from a recession but from a deep depression, is still above 50 percent.
Russia is a rich country; we are not dealing here with a nuclear-armed Bangladesh. Ninety-five percent of the Russian people are literate, and 90 percent of the Russian work force has graduated from high school. The press is free, and Mr. Yeltsin has acted as its greatest defender against undue interference from both conservatives in the Parliament and his own Government. There is considerable progress in overall judiciary reform. Most important, in foreign policy, both vis-a-vis the West and the newly independent post-Soviet states, Mr. Yeltsin has consistently acted with enlightened moderation. He needs our help and he deserves it.
It is essential that we be understanding and tolerant as he tries to find a new way of ruling the country through a compromise with the centrist forces organized under the umbrella of the Civic Union. I personally know some of the top leaders in this diverse coalition. While questioning many of the current Government tactics, they have a fundamental commitment to democracy and a free-market economy and are loyal to Mr. Yeltsin as the Russian President. If he makes a compromise with the Civic Union, there is no need to panic and to perceive it as a mortal blow to the Russian democratic experiment.
One of the most effective ways we can help Mr. Yeltsin survive is to champion the rights of the 25 million Russian-speaking people in the Baltic and the other post-Soviet states -- both bilaterally and in international forums. The Russian people should be able to feel that their human rights are a priority for American diplomacy. This will be a constructive way to respond to xenophobic Russian nationalists who are paranoid and suspicious of the West and violently opposed to President Yeltsin.
The Yeltsin Government will not survive unless it receives a major new economic assistance package. The Freedom Support Act was a positive first step, but it has been overtaken by events. Urgent action on three fronts is required.
1. The $80 billion debt that Mr. Yeltsin inherited from Mikhail Gorbachev must be rescheduled for 15 years as Mr. Yeltsin has requested.
2. There must be a substantial bridge loan from Western governments to help the Russian people through a cruel, cold winter and to assist the transition from a command to a free-market economy that is unprecedented in a major country.
3. Russia needs massive investment from the private sector in the West. Government aid is limited by budgets. Investment from the private sector is limited only by opportunity. If Russia adopts the same legal guarantees for private property as we have in the West, it has been estimated that $300 billion would be invested over the next five years, dwarfing the $25 billion in Western government aid currently allotted.
4. As Senator Sam Nunn has recommended, responsibility for the aid program should be given to one high-level individual reporting directly to the President who would act as the principal coordinator of all U.S. Government efforts. This individual should be of sufficient stature so that he can talk to Mr. Yeltsin and to Western leaders as an equal.
None of these things will happen unless the President plays a direct role. Only he can persuade the Europeans to accept debt relief, force the American bureaucracy to shape up and get Congress to approve foreign aid appropriations.
What's in it for us? If Mr. Yeltsin fails, we will again live in a dangerous world with the threat of nuclear war hanging over our heads. The wave of freedom sweeping the world will ebb and we could get caught in the undertow. If Mr. Yeltsin survives, and freedom and democracy succeed in Russia, we will live in a safer world.
We will also live in a richer world. A vigorous free-enterprise economy in Russia will mean billions of dollars in trade and hundreds of thousands of jobs for American workers. We will live in a freer world because the success of democracy and free markets in Russia will be an example for China and other dictatorships around the world to follow.

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
Correction on Mara Letica

 BODY:
An item in Topics of the Times on Nov. 2 incorrectly described Mara Letica, President Bush's nominee for ambassador to the former Yugoslav state of Croatia.
The article gave two grounds for opposing her nomination. It referred inaccurately to her father as the chief U.S. fund-raiser for Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman. 
 Her attorneys say that neither she nor her father has ever raised money for Mr. Tudjman, his party or his Government. And the editorial described her, also incorrectly, as the niece of a longtime Tudjman adviser.
We regret these errors. At the same time, we remain of the opinion that Ms. Letica lacks the independence such an appointment calls for. Her father has served officially as a special representative of President Tudjman for economic matters. And Ms. Letica was described warmly as "a passionate lobbyist for Croatia" in an Oct. 25 article in a Croatian weekly by Slaven Letica, a former adviser to Mr. Tudjman though no relation to Ms. Letica.
"I understood she was named Ambassador of Croatia to the USA. when I finally understood [she] was the US ambassador to Croatia," Mr. Letica wrote, with those emphases, "I decided that this was the most beautiful diplomatic gesture of the American Administration in the last two years." President Bush, and the public, would be better served by less gesture and more disinterest.

HEADLINE: Breast Cancer Research Must Have the Funds;
Projects Lack Money

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Medical Madness on Capitol Hill" (editorial, Oct. 29), you state that cancer research "is already well funded." This is both untrue and dangerously misleading. 
The level of public and private funds available to support cancer research is indeed higher than ever before. However, these funds can support fewer and fewer research projects because of inflation and the high costs of the new technologies.
The American Cancer Society, as an example, could finance only 9 percent of new project grant proposals last year. We would have to double the research budget of nearly $100 million to finance all the grant applications that were rated as "excellent." The Government's cancer program at the National Cancer Institute mirrors this strained situation.
We have built a base of knowledge about cancer by supporting basic science and clinical research. This knowledge is the foundation for all advances in clinical practice. But unless support for cancer research grows substantially, we will not merely be standing still, but will even fall behind.
Americans have defined cancer as their greatest personal health concern today. With the major predictable demographic change toward lower birth rates and older citizenry, the impact of cancer could become even more devastating unless we find the means to make great forward strides in cancer research.
The opportunities are enormous but they are certainly not well funded.
 
WALTER LAWRENCE JR., M.D.
President, American Cancer Society
Atlanta, Nov. 6, 1992

HEADLINE: Catholic Bishops in U.S. Reject Policy Letter on Role of Women

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The nation's Roman Catholic bishops refused today to adopt a proposed pastoral letter on the role of women in the church and society, a document nine years in the making that had ended up being dominated by traditional church views.
The vote marked the first time since the National Conference of Catholic Bishops was formed in 1966 that the nation's Catholic hierarchy failed to reached a two-thirds majority consensus on a proposed pastoral letter, the bishops' weightiest form of policy statement. 
 In a debate before the vote, the bishops' comments revealed a broad dissatisfaction with the document as incomplete and likely to alienate many women.
Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee issued a dramatic warning that passage of the letter could create a reaction in the church as vast as that caused by "Humanae Vitae," the 1968 papal encyclical prohibiting the use of contraception by Catholics.
 
'Another Tremendous Crisis'
 "It would add another tremendous crisis to the church," he said, "We would lose another generation, especially another generation of very wonderful women."
Bishops who supported the document warned that a rejection would be seen as disloyalty to church precepts, particularly on the question of ordaining women to the priesthood. In fact, however, very few of those who voted against the document wanted to see women as priests; among the bishops, that is the position of a small minority and was never seriously considered.
The tally, taken by secret written ballot, fell 53 votes short of the two-thirds majority of the active hierarchy necessary to approve a pastoral letter. Favoring the text were 137 bishops. Voting against it were 110 bishops.
 
Most 'Nays' Ever Cast
 No previous pastoral letter has ever been opposed by more than 30 votes. Because the church hierarchy puts a high value on consensus, it usually succeeds at refining texts so that the bishops can rally behind them.
For example, despite fierce public disputes associated with the 1983 pastoral letter on nuclear weapons and with the 1986 letter on economic issues, only nine negative votes were cast against the final drafts of each.
The letter voted on today, like three previous drafts of the same document, had been produced by a bishops' committee headed by Bishop Joseph L. Imesch of Joliet, Ill. All four drafts affirmed the equality of men and women and condemned sexism as a "moral and social evil." The letter deplored violence directed at women, the high rates of poverty among single mothers and elderly women, abusive or broken family relationships and discrimination in the work place.
The final draft also retained some criticism of the church's insensitivity to women and endorsed a widening of nonliturgical opportunities for women in the church.
But the letter could not be read apart from its own history. Under Vatican prodding, later drafts adopted an increasingly guarded tone. The fourth draft warned, for instance, that "to identify sexism as the principal evil" harming women socially would be "to analyze the underlying problem too superficially."
Whereas the first draft, issued in 1988, highlighted statements by women who had testified in hearings held by the bishops, the fourth draft highlighted Pope John Paul II's view that equality of the sexes should not rest on minimizing the differences between them.
The pastoral letter was brought to a vote today, the third day of the semiannual meeting of the bishops, despite the efforts of Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago to avoid a showdown. On Tuesday he suggested that instead of issuing the document as a pastoral letter, it be turned over to committees that could pursue some of the stated objectives at a less authoritative level.
This morning, Cardinal Bernardin announced that at the request of the conference's top leadership, he was withdrawing his proposal temporarily. But after the pastoral letter was defeated his suggestion was revived and was approved as a way of salvaging some of the bishops' work and of indicating that the hierarchy remained determined to deal with questions of discrimination and sexism.
The bishops also authorized publication of the present text as a simple report from the drafting committee, without the authority of a teaching document.
 
'We Need to Speak'
 Although pastoral letters do not automatically bind Catholics in their entirety, they frequently contain binding precepts, and always set out positions that Catholics are obliged to consider seriously. Pastoral letters also set policy for all the Church's national agencies.
The bishops, all dressed in similar black suits and seated behind long rows of white-draped tables in the Regency Ballroom of the Omni Shoreham Hotel, spoke at several microphones in well-modulated tones. But the outward appearance of order and serenity did not disguise the intensity of today's debate.
The bishops were divided over different notions of how to carry out their responsibilities as teachers and pastors rather than over the question of whether women should be ordained.
Conservative bishops insisted that despite the danger of stirring a hostile reaction among many Catholics by approving the fourth draft, not passing it would do greater harm by creating the impression that the bishops did not support the church's teaching.
"I find myself identifying with Jeremiah the prophet, saying I'd rather not speak on this," Bishop John G. Vlazny of Winona, Minn., said. Nonetheless, he concluded, "We need to speak."
Archbishop Oscar H. Lipscomb of Mobile, Ala., said the bishops had to teach the "hard truth about ordination," regardless of "the added pain and controversy it might cause." Not passing the letter might only feed false hopes of change in the church's position on ordination, he said, and result in greater pain later.
 
Greater Division Feared
 "We have set the stage for teaching, and we should teach," said Bishop John J. Myers of Peoria, Ill., noting that ordinary pastors, when asked difficult questions by parishioners, can not escape by referring them to a committee.
But Bishop Pierre R. DuMaine of San Jose, Calif., argued that the problem was "not with what we are teaching but how we teach, not with orthodoxy but pedagogy." The fourth draft, he said, had not succeeded in conveying its message, "and we won't succeed just by repeating ourselves or turning up the volume."
Rather than fulfilling the letter's purpose as reflected in the fourth draft's title, "One In Jesus Christ," Bishop Michael D. Pfeifer of San Angelo, Tex., said, "The contrary will happen: we will be more divided." He said the letter, if approved, would "further distance the bishops from the many voices of women who have spoken to us."
 
Not a Closed Issue
 Bishop after bishop stated that he supported the teaching. "If the media chooses to disregard that, it is just a misrepresentation of the fact," Archbishop Lipscomb said at a news conference following the vote.
Only a handful of bishops have indicated that they favor a change in the church's ban of ordaining women priests. But Bishop DuMaine said that although "everyone accepts and will uphold" the present teaching, there is a range of views on whether it could ever be changed.
Bishop Imesch added that many bishops were also uncomfortable with the idea that discussion of the issue is closed. Passage of the letter, Bishop DuMaine had told the bishops earlier, would not "end or frame the debate, but only take the bishops out of it."
The bishops will meet once more on Thursday before adjourning.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 20, 1992, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A caption yesterday with a picture by The Associated Press about the National Conference of Catholic Bishops referred incorrectly in some editions to two bishops. They were Bishop Joseph Imesch of Joliet, Ill., left, and Archbishop Edward McCarthy of Miami.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bishop Joseph Imesch of Joliet, Ill., left, and Archbishop Edward A. McCarthy of Miami at a news conference yesterday during the National Conference of Catholic Bishops in Washington. (Associated Press) (pg. B9)
 
Chart: "Struggling With Words: The Bishops' Letter on Women"
For nine years, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops have been trying to draft and approve a pastoral letter about the role of women in the church and in American society. Four drafts of the letter were prepared, as a committee of bishops struggled to reach closer compliance with Vatican teachings.
Although the issue of ordaining women to the priesthood played a central role in the letter, changes in the drafts can also be seen in the way the committee handled the question of opening other ministerial offices to women, ranging from the major ordained office of deacon to that of acolyte or altar server.
 
1988: The first draft urged a quick study of ordaining female deacons, indicated its positive attitude toward that change, and strongly recommended opening the other roles.
 "In particular, we recommend that the question of admission of women to the diaconal office . . . be submitted to thorough investigation... We urge that this study be undertaken and brought to completion soon. Women serving in pastoral ministry accomplish, by virtue of some other title or commission, many of the functions performed by ordained deacons and are capable of accomplishing all of them. The question of women being formally installed in the permanent diaconate arises quite naturally, and pastoral reasons prompt its evaluation.
"Even more compelling is the question of women being installed in the lay ministries of lector and acolyte. The exclusion of women and girls from certain aspects of service at the altar likewise raises concern...
"For this reason, we recommend that women participate in all liturgical ministries that do not require ordination."
 
1990: The second draft called for a study of ordaining female deacons but dropped the implied endorsement. It no longer called allowing women in other ministries "even more compelling".
"We recommend that the question of admission of women to the diaconal office . . . be submitted to thorough investigation... We urge that this study be undertaken and brought to completion soon. We support further the study for admission of women to the lay ministries of lector and acolyte. The exclusion of women and girls from certain aspects of service at the altar likewise demands consideration. . . For this reason, we encourage participation by women in all liturgical ministries that do not require ordination."
 
April 1992: The third draft dropped the call for a study on the diaconate and contained only a reduced reference to the need for "continuing dialogue and reflection".
"We also recognize the need for continuing dialogue and reflection on the meaning of ministry in the church, particularly in regard to the diaconate, to the offices of lector and acolyte, and to servers at the altar."
 
September 1992: The fourth draft repeated the third draft's language but added a caveat about respecting the official teaching of the church.
"We recognize the need also for continuing reflection on the meaning of ministry in the Church, particularly in regard to the diaconate and the offices of lector, acolyte, and servers at the altar. Such study should proceed with an objectivity and serenity whose necessary context is respect for the authority of the magisterium of the Church." (pg. B9)

HEADLINE: Dow Posts 14.05 Gain; Volume Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
A powerful rally in Tokyo spilled over to the United States yesterday, where a snapback in oil and technology stocks enabled the market to rebound from Tuesday's losses.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed 14.05 points higher, at 3,207.37, after a 12-point drop a day earlier. 
Advancing issues outpaced those that declined in price by a ratio of nearly 2 to 1 among common stocks on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading was extremely active, with 219.1 million shares changing hands on the Big Board.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 3.58, to 422.85, with international oils, telecommunications and health-care stocks leading the way. The Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter shares leaped 7.79, to 634.86.
 
More Optimism
 "There's a little more optimism out there," said Ronald Doran, director of institutional trading at C. L. King & Associates. "After yesterday's mini-correction in the Nasdaq, it's back up again. We had a good jump in the Japanese market, and I'm sure that helped us a little bit."
In addition, recent economic reports in the United States have been encouraging, traders said. The Commerce Department said yesterday that the merchandise trade deficit narrowed by 7.1 percent in September. The report touched off a brief dip in Treasury bond prices, before the market reversed course amid talk that the recovery was spotty enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates again.
The stable Treasury yields prompted investors to funnel money into stocks like oils, whose prices have tumbled in recent sessions, traders said.
"If rates are coming down, and Exxon and Mobil are yielding about 5 percent, that's pretty attractive in this environment," said Bob Aquilina, who trades oil stocks for Lehman Brothers.
Reflecting lower fuel costs, the Dow Jones transportation average rose 13.90, to 1,355.13, led by airlines and trucking companies.
Specialty retailers were another bright spot, with Gap, the Limited and Merry-Go-Round all scoring gains. Positive analysts' comments, coupled with some better-than-expected earnings and anticipation of better Christmas sales than in the last few years, attracted institutional investors, traders said.
Costco slipped 7/8, to 25, after Alex. Brown removed the stock from its "strong buy" list on lower growth assumptions. It was the most heavily traded over-the-counter stock, with more than 5.9 million shares changing hands.
Hewlett-Packard jumped 3 1/2, to 58 7/8, despite a 46 percent plunge in fiscal fourth-quarter net income as analysts focused on the company's vigorous order momentum.
Apple Computer gained 2 1/2, to 57 3/4, on news of a 10-million-share stock buyback.
 
Gloomy Projection
 Moorco International, an industrial products company, plunged 6 1/8, to 16 7/8, on its projection of lower second-quarter earnings.
Republic Capital soared 4 1/8, to 30 5/8, after TCF Financial said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Republic for stock valued at $34.50 a share, or a total of about $62 million.
Anthem Electronics skidded 4, to 37 1/2, after Smith Barney cut earnings estimates.
Watkins-Johnson climbed 2 1/8, to 13, after the electronics company received a new purchase recommendation from Paine Webber.
Andrea Electronics, up 6 5/8, to 23, continued to gain in the wake of the company's disclosure that it was negotiating to sell some businesses. The stock jumped 6 on Tuesday.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 21, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about Wednesday's stock trading misstated a disclosure by Andrea Electronics. The company said that it was negotiating to sell its active noise cancellation products to several telecommunications companies and that it had named John and Douglas Andrea as co-presidents to succeed their father.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Jacobs Engineering Names New Chief Executive Officer

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Joseph J. Jacobs, the 76-year-old founder and chairman of the Jacobs Engineering Group Inc., said today that he was turning over the chief executive reins to a successor before ill health or a crisis forced him out.
Noel G. Watson, who became president and chief operating officer of the company in 1987, will take on the additional duties of chief executive, effective Thursday. Mr. Jacobs will continue as chairman. 
 "The business is so mature, it should be run by someone who has his management qualities," Mr. Jacobs said. "I don't have the patience with all the details of running a company of this size."
In an effort to groom a successor since the mid-1970's, Mr. Jacobs brought in three successive chief operating officers. Mr. Watson, who is 56 and has been with the company since the early 1960's, became the fourth heir apparent.
 
Growth of a One-Man Operation
 Mr. Jacobs started the company, based in Pasadena, Calif., from a one-man consultancy in 1947. His management was marked by risk-taking, ingenuity and integrity. When a client had trouble starting up a fertilizer plant in Vicksburg, Miss., Mr. Jacobs worked shifts alongside an engineering team for six months to get it running. "I don't believe you succeed as an entrepreneur unless you bust your gut to make it work," he said.
Today, the company employs 12,500 people and has become a force in environmental cleanup, including work restoring Energy Department sites contaminated with radioactive materials. The company had revenues of $1.1 billion in the year that ended Sept. 30.
Like other engineering and construction concerns, Jacobs was hurt by the collapse of oil markets in the early 1980's. The company's revenue fell, losses piled up and overhead and payroll were cut.
"Restructuring is a gut-wrenching emotional thing for any feeling executive," said Mr. Jacobs, who came out of semiretirement to oversee the cutbacks.
 
Successful New Directions
 As a consequence of the shake-up in the late 1980's, the company has improved its profitability and has not so far been hurt by the current recession, John Simon, an analyst with Seidler Amdec Securities in Los Angeles said. He credited Mr. Watson with picking sectors like environmental cleanup and refinery building, which has offset declining business elsewhere. But he expects the company's earnings growth to slow.
Richard J. Sweetman, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody, said he did not expect a turbulent management transition: "Strategy has become the guiding light, not the entrepreneur."
The company stock declined 12.5 cents a share yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $27.
Mr. Watson, who was not available for comment, is expected to press the company into new growth areas, like building laboratories for biotechnology companies. He first joined the company in 1960 as a process engineer and except for a three-year stint in the early 1960's has been with the company ever since.
Mr. Jacobs, whose first book, "Anatomy of an Entrepreneur: Family, Culture and Ethics," was published in 1991, plans a second, tentatively titled "Compassionate Conservative."

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: The President-Elect;
CLINTON SAYS BUSH MADE CHINA GAINS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton, who accused President Bush during the campaign of coddling China's dictators, suggested today that Mr. Bush's policies toward China were showing signs of reducing human rights and trade violations.
Mr. Clinton did not explain his sudden, striking difference in tone, which came one day after he held a long chat with President Bush, mostly about foreign affairs. Many analysts had warned during the campaign that some of Mr. Clinton's more idealistic foreign policy proposals would need to be moderated in a new administration to prevent disruptions in relations with important countries. 
 Mr. Clinton made his remarks after spending his morning holding talks with Democratic and Republican leaders on Capitol Hill, talks in which both sides pledged an end to the gridlock in Congress. It was another whirlwind day for the President-elect, who went from breakfast at a McDonald's near the White House to lunch with the power barons in Congress to dinner with the Washington social elite at the Georgetown home of a Democratic Party fund raiser, Pamela Harriman.
He also met for an hour with Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, for the first time since the general warned about the Pentagon's opposition to Mr. Clinton's plan to lift the Pentagon's ban on homosexuals in the military.
Mr. Clinton said afterward that he liked General Powell "very much" because he "laid it on the line and did not fudge one of our disagreements."
"He said exactly what he thought but then he said, 'You're the boss,' " Mr. Clinton related.
Mr. Clinton's message to Congress was a mixture of gentle lobbying for his proposals to restructure the economy and the health-care system, combined with some pointed observations about controlling soaring government health-care costs.
Two of the Congressmen who met with Mr. Clinton today said there was a general agreement that without harnessing automatic benefit programs -- which include Medicare, Medicaid, Social Security, food stamps and farm subsidies -- it could be impossible for Mr. Clinton to finance his programs and still fulfill his promise to begin cutting the deficit.
While Mr. Clinton stressed that in his view the best way to begin was by getting control of health-care costs, he nevertheless seemed willing to look at the possibility of cutting or taxing these entitlement programs if he could find no better way to pay for his programs, the lawmakers said.
During his news conference at the Capitol, Mr. Clinton was reminded that Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, had called the Bush Administration's policy toward China "immoral" and declared that Washington should withdraw favored-trade status from China to force it to comply with human-rights standards.
 
Applauds Recent Events
 Mr. Clinton said, "I noted with satisfaction that in the last several months, when the Bush Administration, for whatever reason, maybe because of the changing political climate, took a tougher line on goods made with prison labor, on unfair trade practices, we began to have more moderation.
"China now has a $15 billion-a-year trade surplus with us," Mr. Clinton continued. "I know we create a lot of jobs with trade with China, but they've got a $15 billion surplus. They have a big stake in that. We have a big stake in not isolating China, in seeing that China continues to develop a market economy. But we also have to insist, I believe, on progress in human rights and human decency. And I think there are indications in the last few months that a firm hand by our Government can help to achieve that."
On Oct. 1, in a speech in Milwaukee, Mr. Clinton said: "There is no more striking example of Mr. Bush's indifference toward democracy than his policy toward China."
"Today," he continued in that speech, one of the major foreign-policy addresses of the campaign, "we must ask ourselves, 'What has the President's China policy really achieved?' The Chinese leadership still sells missiles and nuclear technology to Middle Eastern dictators who threaten us and our friends. They still arrest and hold in prison leaders of the pro-democracy movement. They restrict American access to their markets, while our trade deficit with China will reach $15 billion this year."
He added, "I do believe that our nation has a higher purpose than to coddle dictators and to stand aside from the global movement toward democracy."
The Bush Administration's policies toward China that Mr. Clinton seemed to endorse today were a year old, and first came to light when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d visited Beijing last November.
On the domestic front, the President-elect pointedly relayed to the Congressional leaders what he heard from the breakfast crowd at McDonald's and during his walk Wednesday through a polyglot Washington commercial strip.
"The sense I get from the American people is that they don't expect miracles from us but they do expect progress," Mr. Clinton told the Congressional leaders during a post-lunch news conference. "They want the finger-pointing and the blame-placing to stop."
For today, at least, that spirit of bipartisanship reigned, as everyone from Mr. Clinton to the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, exchanged warm compliments and vows of cooperation. Vice President-elect Al Gore said, "If you listen carefully, you can hear the first sounds of gridlock loosening."
 
'Knows His Oats'
 Many legislators also commented favorably on the command Mr. Clinton displayed on a wide range of domestic policy problems. Mr. Clinton, they noted, talked about domestic policy with the grasp and verve that Mr. Bush reserved for foreign policy.
"This guy knows his oats," said Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, the Democrat who heads the Budget Committee.
Senator Dole, the de facto leader of Republicans in Washington, had greeted Mr. Clinton's election with a harsh pledge to block his "awful" programs. But he has softened his oratory in recent days, and today he promised: "We're going to have a lot of areas of agreement, we're going to have some areas of disagreement. But our common interest is in moving the country forward, about jobs, the economy, health care, deficit reduction, whatever it may be."
Mr. Dole couldn't resist enlivening his remarks, though, with a special thank you to Speaker Thomas S. Foley "for the lunch -- when you're a Republican these days, you take all you can get."
 
Seeing the Dilemma
 Representative Steny Hoyer of Maryland, chairman of the House Democratic Caucus, said there was a general sense that automatic spending programs might have to be reined in to cut the deficit. Every year, Medicare and Medicaid eat up increasing portions of the budget.
Mr. Hoyer said "the President-elect brought up entitlements," as did several other lawmakers, but there was no detailed discussion. Mr. Hoyer said Mr. Clinton's view was that "we need a comprehensive approach to dealing with health-care costs and not just controlling Federal expenditures."
"If I would sum up some of the exchanges that took place," said Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House minority leader, "the President-elect is quite conscious and well aware of the dilemma of attempting to stimulate the economy on one hand without exacerbating the deficit problem that confronts."
Mr. Clinton promised to try to solidify his economic proposals in advance of his Jan. 20 inauguration and would then work with Congress on a program that reflects "the consensus of where we ought to go."
Mr. Clinton, who made plans to fly back to Little Rock, Ark., tonight, said after his get-acquainted meeting with General Powell:
"We called the meeting because when I become President he'll be the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs," and that General Powell would be a person "that I'll have to rely on for military advice."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Disney Net Up on U.S. Theme-Park Results

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company reported today that fiscal fourth-quarter net income increased 29 percent, mainly because of strong attendance at United States theme parks and the success of animated films.
For the quarter ended Sept. 30, Disney, based in Burbank, reported earnings of $223.7 million, or 42 cents a share, compared with $174.1 million, or 33 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue rose 21 percent, to $2.08 billion from $1.72 billion. 
 For the 1992 fiscal year, net rose 28 percent, to $816.7 million, or $1.52 a share, from $636.6 million, or $1.20 a share, in the 1991 fiscal year. Revenue grew 23 percent, to $7.5 billion from $6.11 billion.
But the entertainment company said Euro Disney, the new theme park near Paris, had a $35.1 million loss for the year. Since it opened in April, Euro Disney has attracted fewer customers than expected.
Disney owns a 50 percent stake in the French theme park, but its share of the loss from Euro Disney was offset as royalties and interest income from the venture generated $11 million in profits for the full year, the company said.
Analysts said the results were consistent with their expectations and noted that screenings and sales of videos and merchandise relating to Disney's animated films, including "Beauty and the Beast" and "Fantasia," were particularly strong.
"Their film business is still on a hot streak, and park attendance continues to be strong -- those positives offset the Euro Disney negative," Alan Kassan, analyst for Morgan Stanley, said.
Disney's shares rose 62.5 cents today, to $40.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Revenue for Disney's filmed-entertainment segment rose 6 percent, to $785 million, for the quarter, from $737 million. Operating earnings grew 21 percent, to $121.5 million. Disney said the results reflected the success of its animated releases and its theatrical films, including "The Hand That Rocks the Cradle."
In the theme park and resorts segment, Disney's revenue jumped 26 percent, to $996.2 million, for the quarter. Operating profit rose 44 percent, to $213.9 million. Attendance at United States parks and resorts was higher, and increased per capita spending at theme parks contributed to improved operating results, the company said.
Consumer product revenues rose 54 percent, to $294 million, for the quarter, and operating profit climbed 18 percent, to $60.4 million, because of brisk sales of merchandise related to "The Little Mermaid, "101 Dalmatians" and "Beauty and the Beast."
Separately, Disney said it was negotiating to build a new marine theme park in Tokyo. The company had planned to build a similar park, called Disney Sea, in Long Beach, Calif., but abandoned the project because of the weak economy. A Disney spokesman said the company was negotiating with the Oriental Land Company, which owns Tokyo Disneyland, to build the marine park.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Olympia & York lawyers are preparing new proposals to give its creditors the freedom to seize some of Canada's prestigious office buildings. The bankrupt developer had been warned by banks that its previous plans would be rejected by creditors. [Page D1.]
A.T.& T. plans to sell 15 percent of its equipment-leasing subsidiary to the public by mid-1993. A.T.& T. Capital has more than $7 billion in assets and $1 billion in revenue. [D1.] 
 KLM gave a boost to Northwest's attempt to line up fresh cash by agreeing to put up $50 million. And all six unions at Northwest said they saw a need to grant the airline concessions. [D2.]
Transamerica will spin off its subsidiary that provides property and casualty insurance through an initial public offering. [D2.]
Walt Disney's net income jumped 29 percent in the fourth quarter, mainly because of strong attendance at its theme parks in the United States and the success of animated films. [D2.]
Occidental Petroleum will cut $155 million from operating costs next year by dismissing 500 workers and freezing the salaries of its highest-paid employees. [D2.]
MGM Grand Air will halt its scheduled flights between Los Angeles and New York at year-end. The luxury airline intends to redeploy its seven aircraft as an all-charter service. [D3.]
Dell Computer's profits more than doubled in the third quarter, and its shares rose sharply. [D3.]
Steven J. Kalagher was named president of House of Seagram, the United States spirits subsidiary of the Seagram Company. [D3.]
 
The Economy
New claims for unemployment benefits jumped sharply early this month and housing starts fell in October, the Government said, in reports generally seen as only a temporary setback for the economy. The number of Americans filing unemployment claims shot up by 31,000, to 386,000, as of Nov. 7. [D1.]
Thousands of American workers may not receive benefits they were promised, the Government pension agency warned. It found a 13 percent rise in guaranteed benefits not backed by money. [A21.]
 
International
Japanese depositors are abandoning banks and putting their money in the Government-controlled postal savings system. Japan's private financial institutions held a public rally to attack what they described as unfair competition. [D1.]
No agreement was reached on the farm subsidy dispute that could provoke a trade war between the United States and the European Community. But both sides said they had made progress at talks in Washington and would meet again. [A10.]
 
Markets
Enthusiasm for smaller stocks fueled early gains, but the Dow Jones industrial average rose only 2.16, to 3,209.53, largely because of a plunge by I.B.M., which fell to a 10-year low. [D6.]
Bonds fell, ending a rally that lasted several days. Among the explanations that traders offered were a sale by a big speculator and a surprising jump in the money supply. [D12.]
Sweden gave up the fight to defend its krona after a long and expensive battle and allowed it to fall in value. [D13.]
Lumber futures prices rose to a seven-month high on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange because of tight supplies. [D13.]
 
Today's Columns
Jerry Della Femina is back, with an agency called Jerry Inc., and his first client is Newsweek. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D1.]
The climb in short-term interest rates is raising eyebrows and fears on Wall Street. Kurt Eichenwald: Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees 'Good Progress' on European Trade

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The United States and the European Community failed again today to reach an agreement on a farm subsidy dispute that threatens to explode into a trade war. But at the end of the talks here, both sides said they had made progress and would meet again soon.
For two years, the dispute has blocked world trade talks aimed at reducing international trade barriers and stimulating the global economy. 
 Officials on both sides have announced progress after every meeting, but sounded somewhat more optimistic today than after their last round ended on Nov. 4 in Chicago. Trade disputes are almost always resolved on the eve of a deadline, if at all; a little more than two weeks remain to strike a deal.
 
 
To Confer by Phone
 An American official said tonight that Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan would telephone Ray MacSharry, the European Community's agriculture commissioner, early Friday morning. The two men will try to settle a few of the details left outstanding today, and will schedule the next round of face-to-face talks, said the official, who insisted on anonymity.
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, promised two weeks ago to impose 200 percent import taxes on Dec. 5 on white wines, rapeseed oil and wheat gluten from the European Community if the community did not agree to reduce its subsidized production of soybeans, rapeseed and sunflower seeds.
"We've made very good progress today," Mrs. Hills told reporters after the two days of talks ended late this afternoon. "In fact, I can go so far as to say we're quite close together, and we're going to continue to work."
Frans Andriessen, the European Community's Commissioner of External Relations, added, "We had a good conversation, which contributed largely to find solutions to points we have still pending between the United States and the European Community."
 Mrs. Hills said the two sides needed to gather more data and they had not yet set a date for further negotiations.
 
 
Progress in Other Areas
Today's talks produced progress not only on soybeans but also on two other disputes: reductions in the tonnage of the European Community's grain exports and compensation payments to farmers who will be losing subsidies, the official added, while declining to elaborate. The United States has been concerned that the compensation payments not be disguised subsidies for yet more farm production.
The Administration contends that if European subsidies did not exist, American farmers would sell an extra $1 billion a year worth of soybeans in Europe and that other food exporters like Brazil would sell an extra $1 billion annually of soybeans. The community contends that the lost sales amount to only a few hundred million dollars a year and that subsidy reductions are not politically feasible because of protests by farmers.
France is Europe's largest producer and exporter of food, including oilseeds, and its farmers have been the fiercest opponents of European concessions. The Associated Press reported today that about 300 French farmers had torched an American flag and stirred the embers with a pitchfork outside the American Embassy in Paris in a protest that left about 20 people injured in clashes with the police.
The French Government has followed its farmers' wishes in vigorously fighting concessions in meetings of ministers from European Community nations. Alarmed that the dispute could scuttle the world trade talks, Britain and the Netherlands have fought back at these meetings and have increasingly enlisted German support since Mrs. Hills announced the prospective taxes on white wine.
Mrs. Hills also announced on Nov. 5 that if the dispute was not resolved soon, she might impose additional taxes on up to $1.7 billion worth of imported industrial goods, many from Germany. German industrial groups have become increasingly active in lobbying for a settlement.
Administration officials publicly deny that they deliberately instigated a crisis within the community in an attempt to resolve the dispute. But a few officials say privately that the threat of a trade war has succeeded beyond their expectations in forcing the community to confront its divisions.
 The oilseeds dispute is not the only farm subsidy issue dividing the United States and the community. And even if all subsidy issues are resolved together, as Mrs. Hills and her European counterparts have sought, many other sticky issues remain that could hold up a successful conclusion.
The United States and the community are still divided over maritime services and competition in the market for telephone calls. The two sides are also united in urging Japan to drop its ban on rice imports and want developing countries to open their insurance and banking markets to competition.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The United States and the European Community have still not been able to reach agreement on a farm subsidy dispute that is threatening to explode. A French farmer carried the remains of an American flag that was burned during a protest outside the American Embassy in Paris. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Olympia May Yield Real Estate

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Warned by Canada's leading banks that its three-week-old plan to restructure debts would be rejected, Olympia & York is preparing sweeping new proposals that would allow its creditors to seize some of Canada's most prestigious office buildings, lawyers for the insolvent Canadian real estate giant said today.
The forced change of direction represents another striking setback for the world's largest real estate developer, which has been a participant in property markets for the last two decades, building up assets once calculated at more than $20 billion. 
 The newest proposals suggest that the real estate development company, owned by the Reichmann brothers of Toronto, would turn itself into what would basically be a property management company. Some experts have estimated that it would retain ownership of only 10 percent of the Canadian holdings.
 
 
New Vote Is Planned
 A lawyer who spoke only on condition of anonymity said Olympia & York would ask an Ontario bankruptcy court on Monday to extend its protection of the company's assets by about a month, to Jan. 31, to permit a vote on the new plan sometime in mid-January. Olympia's Canadian operations have been under court protection since its original bankruptcy filing on May 14.
The May 14 filing covered Olympia and 28 subsidiaries. Five of those companies have sought protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code. But Olympia is still seeking to restructure the debts of its main United States properties outside the bankruptcy courts.
The new submission would mark the third time that Olympia's management has tried to win over its creditors with a complex plan to reorganize the company. The most recent plan, which was presented on Oct. 27, ran into a storm of opposition. The company had asked creditors to suspend for five years their rights to seize property put up as loan collateral.
In warning about the Oct. 27 plan, the four Canadian banks -- the Royal Bank of Canada, the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, the Bank of Nova Scotia and the National Bank of Canada -- suggested that creditors who so desired would be allowed to walk away with their collateral.
 
 
A 3d Level of Claims
 The four banks have securities in First Canadian Place, a 72-story tower in the heart of Toronto's financial district, in return for a $131 million loan they made earlier this year to Olympia. This represents a third level of claim against the building, after $10 million of first-mortgage and $475 million of second-mortgage bonds.
The same four banks also have claims against two other neighboring skyscrapers, Scotia Plaza and the Exchange Tower.
The three towers include 5.3 million square feet of rentable space and have combined debts of $1.3 billion. Built to warm praise, they helped power the Reichmanns empire's growth of during inflationary times but also positioned the brothers -- Paul, Albert and Ralph -- for their deflation-induced fall.
Although details of the new plan are not available, lawyers from Olympia and from some of the creditors who are familiar with its details said it would allow the most secured creditors to vote to seize the properties against which their loans are secured.
An Olympia lawyer said the company would probably announce on Friday its intention to seek extension of the bankruptcy court's protection.
Under the current schedule, which the court is being asked to revise, 34 groups of creditors are to vote, between next Wednesday and Nov. 30, on the proposals that were presented on Oct. 27.
A lawyer who represents a leading bank creditor, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said he understood that the new plan would provide not only for greater freedom of action by the secured creditors but greater involvement in management by the creditors.
Asked whether there would be a widespread seizure of assets, he said that would be a "premature conclusion."
"Each creditor group will look at individual circumstances, including cash flow," he said.
But he acknowledged that the aim, over the long term, would be to proceed with an orderly liquidation of most of the company's Canadian property empire.
It is unlikely, lawyers and other experts said, that in the present depressed market for commercial real estate, any efforts would be undertaken to sell any seized real estate.
"It is a question," one creditor lawyer said, "of whether you would want the Reichmanns as managers or whether you think someone else will do a better job."
