HEADLINE: Panel Proposes New Rockets to Keep U.S. Competitive

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The United States should move quickly to develop a new, more economical and safer family of rockets for launching space payloads to decrease dependence on its current fleet of dated rockets, a special White House panel said today.
The panel, consisting of experts commissioned by the National Space Council, a policy group whose chairman is Vice President Quayle, said the Air Force should be allowed to develop a modular system of rockets. They say this Spacelifter system could cut by half the cost of launching payloads into space. 
 The panel, part of the Vice President's Space Policy Advisory Board, said the new rockets would eventually replace the Delta, Atlas and Titan rockets and the space shuttle. These vehicles form the backbone of the current launcher fleet and are all based on 1950's and 1960's technology.
The panel also discouraged the use of surplus space rockets available from Russia as well as the use of the United States' own surplus of decommissioned ballistic missiles as launching vehicles. Disarmament has made hundreds of such missiles available, but the panel expressed concern that they, like Russian launchers, would compete with rockets produced by the nation's commercial launching industry, which already faces excess capacity and competition.
The panel, headed by Edward C. Aldridge Jr., a former secretary of the Air Force and president of The Aerospace Corporation of El Segundo, Calif., recommended using giant Russian boosters, but only for missions that required a payload greater than 50,000 pounds, the maximum for both the shuttle and the proposed Spacelifter family of rockets.
If the space agency formally proposes the Spacelift program, it will require Congressional approval.
 
Competitive With Ariane
 The Spacelifter, capable of launching light to medium-heavy cargoes of 20,000 to 50,000 pounds into near-Earth orbit, could be used by the nation's military, civilian and commercial space programs to fly payloads as cheaply and efficiently as new rockets being developed by competitors, like the Ariane V of the European Space Agency, the panel said.
"Without the introduction of a new launch vehicle that meets cost and performance goals, we can write off future U.S. competitiveness in this area," the panel said.
If started now, the new rockets could be phased into use between the years 2005 and 2010, Mr. Aldridge said at a briefing. The group gave no cost estimate for the program, but similar proposals for new rockets in the past have put the figure at about $10 billion. Independent space experts say the Spacelifter system could cost slightly less because it does not include a heavy-lift booster for payloads of up to 100,000 pounds, as other plans have.

 
Replaces 1990 Proposal
 The Spacelifter system would replace the New Launch System, or N.L.S., which the National Space Council has backed since 1990, but which Congress effectively killed in October. The N.L.S. proposal called for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Air Force to develop a family of rockets around a giant booster capable of launching 100,000 pounds.
The proposal lacked industry support and was not backed enthusiastically by either NASA or the Defense Department.
Mr. Aldridge said Spacelifter could get the support N.L.S. lacked because it would have a narrower focus, would be open to design ideas and bids from the entire aerospace industry and would be built by the Air Force, which has a clear need for a new rocket.
 
Reduction of Shuttle Flights
 The plan calls for NASA to develop a manned module to enable the new rockets to carry crews to the proposed Space Station Freedom, and an unmanned "Cargo Transfer and Return Vehicle" to service the station.
NASA could pay for its part of the program with savings in its shuttle operations, by increasing economy and reducing flights, the panel said.
"The shuttle is very expensive relative to its role in the U.S. space program," the panel's report said. At $5 billion a year, the shuttle program consumes about one-third of NASA's $14.3 billion budget to support seven or eight flights a year, it said.
The panel, composed of industry executives, retired military officers and civilian space specialists, said it was "extremely important that a consensus be developed between the current and forthcoming Administrations, the affected Government agencies, Congress and industry for the nation's new space launch program."
 
'Like N.L.S. Repackaged'
 John E. Pike, director of space policy for the Federation of American Scientists, said the proposal "seems a lot like N.L.S. repackaged."
"I'm not sure this proposal will get a good reception in Congress," Mr. Pike said, "With only a limited amount of money available, it might be better spent in upgrading existing rockets and developing a new crew capsule that can be used on a Titan rocket to reduce use of the space shuttle."
In addition to the Spacelifter rocket, the panel recommended creating a single, independent "space launch authority" with one person in charge of all military, civilian and commercial rocket launchings. As a stopgap, the panel recommended upgrading current rockets and space launching operations to make them more economical.

HEADLINE: YELTSIN PLANS END TO A-SUB PROGRAM

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Seeking to persuade South Korea of Russia's peaceful intentions in Asia and around the world, President Boris N. Yeltsin told the National Assembly here today that his country would halt the production of nuclear submarines in two or three years.
Mr. Yeltsin, who is on a three-day state visit here, said Russia was cutting in half its production of new submarines and indicated that still more reductions in the military were planned. "I think in two or three years' time, we will stop making submarines for military purposes," he said, according to news agency translations of his speech. 
 In a gesture of particular interest to his hosts, Mr. Yeltsin also gave South Korea the flight recorders from the Korean Air Lines flight that was shot down by a Soviet fighter in 1983, killing all 269 people on board, and expressed condolences to relatives of the victims. "I can assure you that such a criminal action will not happen again," he said.
 
Pledges to Reduce Arms
 In saying Russia would halt submarine manufacturing, Mr. Yeltsin was apparently trying to reassure South Korea and other Asian countries that Russia wanted to preserve peace in the region. Mr. Yeltsin is trying to integrate his country into fast-growing East Asia in hopes of attracting trade and investment that could help Russia's ailing economy.
Earlier in the day, in a two-hour meeting with President Roh Tae Woo, the Russian leader made other pledges on arms reductions, according to the summary of the meeting providing by the Korean Government.
Mr. Yeltsin told Mr. Roh that Russia hoped to sign an agreement with the new Clinton Administration calling for a 60 percent reduction in strategic weapons. President Bush and Mr. Yeltsin have already agreed in principle to the pact.
But even before such a treaty is signed, Russia will unilaterally halt the production of medium-sized bombers and continue to dismantle SS-18 intercontinental ballistic missiles, he said. He also said that Russia and the United States would continue a freeze on nuclear testing until July 1993 and that he would urge China to do the same when he visits Beijing next month.
 
Re-examining K.A.L. 007
 The presentation of the flight recorders from K.A.L. Flight 007 came as something of a surprise to Korean officials. As late as Wednesday morning, a few hours before Mr. Yeltsin arrived, Korean officials were not sure whether Mr. Yeltsin would indeed bring the "black boxes."
"I have something for the Korean people," Mr. Yeltsin told Mr. Roh during their meeting, according to summaries by Korean officials. Mr. Yeltsin then presented a gray suitcase with the cockpit voice recorder and the flight instrument recorder.
South Korea has long been pressing for access to the recorders, in hopes of answering questions like why Flight 007 veered hundreds of miles off course and passed over Soviet territory. However, it is unclear whether anything new will be learned.
Recently Russia provided South Korea with transcripts of the cockpit voice recorder and expressed regrets about the incident, but South Korean officials were not sure they were getting complete information.
On Wednesday, 40 relatives of the victims held a protest here demanding compensation.
 
Strengthening Relations
 During their talks, Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Roh signed several agreements, including one setting out the basic framework for relations between Russia and South Korea. Another called for the exchange of military personnel, perhaps a first step toward more military cooperation. Mr. Yeltsin also offered to sell South Korea weapons or military technology, and Mr. Roh said he would study the offer.
The former enemies established diplomatic relations only two years ago. Since then Russia has grown more distant from North Korea, although it still maintains relations with the Communist country. Today, Mr. Yeltsin told Mr. Roh that Russia would review a 1961 agreement with North Korea that calls for each country to come to the other's aid in a war.
Mr. Yeltsin thanked South Korea for agreeing to resume $3 billion in aid that had been suspended because Russia had fallen behind on its interest payments. He also proposed many areas of cooperation between Korean and Russian companies in areas like development of natural resources and science and technology.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Seoul yesterday, President Boris N. Yeltsin gave President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea the flight recorders from the Korean Air Lines flight that was shot down by a Soviet fighter in 1983. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: United Way Says Slump and Scandal Are Bringing Sharp Dip in Donations

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Wrestling with the effects of a sluggish economy and of the corrosive scandal at its national association this year, officials at the United Way say they fear that 1992 will bring the sharpest decline in donations in more than 40 years.
The early returns from the fall campaigns of 2,200 local United Ways are mixed, but individual fund-raisers in several large metropolitan areas say the overall numbers are dipping below earlier years. Total contributions fell in each of the last two years. But when the figures are adjusted for inflation, not since World War II have they dropped in absolute dollars, too. 
 In Cleveland, pledges are down about 9 percent, from $51.3 million in 1991 to $46.3 million this year. In San Diego, a United Way spokesman, John Liarakos, said, "We're at the midpoint of our campaign and we're running 6 to 8 percent behind last year."
At the United Way of America, the national association of all the local United Ways, Bob O'Connor, a vice president, said, "We'd feel very happy if we came out even with last year."
 
Frustration and Fury
 It was the national association whose former president, William Aramony, was forced out last winter after disclosures of his hefty expense accounts and the financial manipulations that created a series of profit-making spinoff organizations.
While the scandal was a source of frustration and fury throughout the winter and spring, fund-raisers in several local offices called the economy the year's chief villain.
Jim Ridge, vice president for operations at the United Way for Southeastern Michigan, said: "We've got a lot fewer jobs in this community, and that translates into fewer people to solicit and fewer people to give. It's not only the jobs that have been lost, but people's attitudes. With corporations downsizing, many people don't know if they're going to have a job tomorrow, and they are concerned about that."
He added that with the recession, the needs of the charities to which the United Way contributes are greater. "That's obviously what we're concerned about," he said.
 
Growth for Some Funds
 It is unclear whether the problems of the United Way, the nation's largest network of charities, have been felt by other charities. A recent survey by the journal The Chronicle of Philanthropy indicated that giving had increased 5.8 percent in the last year, but many of the participating charities were citing figures for the fiscal year 1991, which ended almost 18 months ago.
A more dramatic comparison is offered by the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy, which contends that 164 "alternative" funds seeking work-place donations have far outstripped the United Way in growth, averaging increases of 42 percent over the last three years, as against a 7.8 percent increase for the United Way.
The group's executive director, Robert O. Bothwell, has said for a decade that the United Way is too exclusive, too hidebound in its attitude toward alternative charities and too unresponsive to donor concerns.
His comparisons tend to favor statistics showing percentage growth, a measure that makes small, fast-growing organizations look better than their large, established counterparts.
 
Environmental Philanthropies
 A new report by Mr. Bothwell's organization was made public on Wednesday, saying that "corporations in areas like Boston, Minneapolis-St. Paul, Seattle and San Francisco seem particularly willing to open their campaigns to alternative funds."
Environmentally oriented philanthropies, only occasionally included in local United Way efforts, have been among the fastest-growing of the charities that solicit work-place donations. The report by the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy projected that revenue raised by nine environmental funds would increase by 50 percent from 1991 to 1992.
The charities supported by the United Way tend to be more traditional human-service groups like the Red Cross, the Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts and the Salvation Army. Support for more politically controversial groups has sometimes caused rifts that hampered local fund-raising efforts. For example, the Rochester United Way, traditionally among the most successful local United Ways, had a 5 percent dropoff in contributions in their major campaign earlier this year.
Unlike most other members of the network, the Rochester group does its most intensive fund raising in the spring. The vast majority of campaigns involve companies soliciting their workers and executives for United Way payroll deductions from September to December.
 
Double Trouble in Rochester
 In Rochester, fund-raisers were asking for donations just when the headlines about the United Way of America were most prominent and most damaging. At the same time, the local offices of Planned Parenthood, which had been part of the campaign for 20 years, announced the opening of an abortion clinic. This prompted anti-abortion groups to mount a "de-pledge" campaign to deny donations to the local United Way.
The Rochester group, which also runs a smaller fund-raising campaign in the fall, said that its latest campaign is doing better than it had last year. "We've been trying to be very aggressive," said Diane Ryan, a spokeswoman for the Rochester group.
"There's not much we can do about the economy," she said. "But certainly, we can do something about the United Way of America issue. We're very pro-active in letting the community know that the United Way of America issue has been resolved, that a new president has been named."
Ms. Ryan also noted that, as the nation's workplace changes, with growth in the number of retired people, small businesses and services like health care -- all groups usually outside the ambit of the United Way -- the network of charities is rethinking its basic fund-raising strategies.
 
New Markets and New Venues
 Robert M. Beggan, a vice president of the United Way of America, said: "We're not only looking at new markets, but at new venues -- how we can help people in carrying out their caring. The retirees are one of the fastest-growing segments of our market. We would like to go with pension checkoff and pension deduction."
He also said there had been a recent push for big donors.
Expanding on this theme, Tony DeCristofaro, spokesman for United Way of America, said: "We have over 4,000 individuals giving $10,000 or more. We have 70 to 80 people giving $100,000. In the 10,000-and-above category , 4,700 individuals gave $75 million last year."
At the United Way of King County, in Seattle, William Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, offered a $1 million challenge grant to match the contributions of donors giving $10,000 and more.
Metropolitan areas like Seattle, in fact, are defying the general fund-raising doldrums. "Last year we raised $45.5 million," said Lynann Marcellis of the United Way of King County. "Right now we're at $46 million and our campaign goes through Dec. 9."

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: Social Scene;
The Clintons Are in Town, and Washington Is Ready to Party

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The economy wasn't the only thing that went into decline under George Bush. When it came to partying, he turned out to be a real pooper, throwing only the required bashes, hardly ever venturing to the salons of Georgetown and hurrying off to Camp David on weekends.
That didn't stop the partying, of course. But it set the tone for entertainment that was as soporific as a church supper, especially with drawing rooms filled with faces that had been hanging around Washington since Ronald Reagan, who imported old Hollywood buddies and pinstriped businessmen for his parties. Before that there was Jimmy Carter, who took a dim view of strong drink. 
 But take heart, Washington. With the Clintons, the new power couple, in town -- just for a two-day "drop-by," in Washington party argot -- already the party pace is picking up.
 
'We've Come Alive!'
 Or, as Esther Coopersmith, a local socialite who hosts more than most, put it: "We've come alive! Alive! Alive!"
Consider:
Thursday, Day 1, President-elect Bill Clinton and his wife, Hillary, had been in town only a few hours when they attended a fund raiser for one of their favorite charities, the Children's Defense Fund, and then moved on to the home of Vernon E. Jordan, head of the Clinton transition team, for some power dining with the likes of Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat; Lane Kirkland, the president of the AFL-CIO; Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee; John Hechinger, a Washington businessman; James Wolfensohn, the chairman of the Kennedy Center, and Ted Koppel, the television journalist.
There were people waiting in the cold, wet street to spot the arrival of the President-elect and the other guests. There were reporters. And photographers. And television teams.
Tonight, Pamela Harriman, the British transplant whose elegant Georgetown fund raisers helped hold the Democratic Party together during the lean Reagan-Bush years, invited the Clintons for drinks and dinner, along with another group of legislators, culture mavens and journalists. Again people and reporters waited in the cold and damp to see the guests arrive.
 
'All the New Faces'
 "It's been a long time since that kind of thing last happened," said Mary Hoyt, who served as Rosalynn Carter's friend-in-waiting and press secretary and who knows Washington at work and at play, not that there is any real difference.
"It's exciting, all the new faces and the energy and the comings and goings," Ms. Hoyt added. "The fact that the Clintons are getting out and about right at the start is a good sign that this town is springing back to life and ready to party. And last night's guest list: now that tells you that not only are the Clintons people who like ideas and issues but that their friends and guests will be idea and issue people who'll come from everywhere. This is going to be fun after what we've been through."
 
Wandering in the Wilderness
 Because the Democrats have been out in the political cold for so many years, they also have been out in the social cold. When you're out of power in Washington, you're off the party A-list, no matter your breeding, your school or your previous contribution to mankind.
A few Democrats have had the political adeptness during this period to work both sides of the ideological fence partywise. Robert S. Strauss, the Ambassador to Moscow, is one.
Others, mainly Congressional leaders, have retained their place on the A-list by virtue of their power on Capitol Hill. Still, most Democrats have been wandering in the wilderness for the better part of 12 years, reduced to chicken-in-the-pot lunches at Duke Zeibert's and misery-loves-company suppers with fellow also-rans.
 
The Changing Scene
 But while the general expectation is that the return of the Democrats will make for a livelier scene in the capital -- the Clintons have led an active social life in Little Rock -- hardly anybody expects the basic style of Washington partying to change.
The glittering but impersonal White House state dinner and the quiet private party for a dozen at the home of a Cabinet member or senator or lobbyist will almost certainly continue to be the staple form of socializing, as will the larger party for, say, a hundred at the homes of wealthy, involved people like Mrs. Harriman and Mrs. Coopersmith.
There will probably be some quiet competition for a reputation as host or hostess with the mostest, but nothing in the nature of Perle Mesta, since party givers these days tend to be mainly interested in causes rather than pure socializing.
But the huge, costly bashes of yore at sprawling private homes and at diplomatic residences have given way to charity fund raisers sponsored by corporations and sometimes embassies. Congressional leaders and Cabinet members, maybe even the President or Vice President, sign on as co-hosts for such events, but all guests contribute for the privilege of mixing and, more often than not with the intent to make a contact or press a cause.
"Parties, whatever kind they are, help make Washington go 'round, and there are a lot of people out there right now who can hardly wait to get back into swinging where it counts," said Alma Viator, a public events organizer and publicist who specializes in putting together theater openings and other events.
"No matter whether you're a Republican or a Democrat, it's been dull, dull, dull for many, many, many years," she said. "Now we've got a young, energetic, enthusiastic President coming in. And away we go!"

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasuries Move Lower

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market yesterday continued to sound its one sure theme -- volatility.
After a rally in the short end of the market on Wednesday and a rally for several days in the price of the 10-year Treasury note and the 30-year bond, investors did an about-face and sold. 
 Among the explanations that traders offered were a sale by a big speculator in the morning and the surprising jump in the money supply reported by the Federal Reserve in the afternoon. And there is usually selling ahead of Treasury auctions, with the sale of two-year and five-year notes coming up Monday and Tuesday, respectively.
But the bottom line is that this is just an uncertain period for the market. While the economy is growing, its strength is unknown. President-elect Bill Clinton has yet to make any key appointments or given the details of his economic plan. The market is getting thinner as traders and investors think of taking profits and closing their books for the year.
 
Waiting for News
 In this atmosphere, the market is likely to jump around, often moving in unexpected directions, as it waits for news or data that could put it on a surer footing or even a new course.
In trading yesterday, the 7.625 percent 30-year bond was down 15/32 to yield 7.54 percent, up from 7.50 percent Wednesday. The prices of notes were also off, from 11/32 for the 10-year note due in August 2002 to 4/32 for the two-year note.
In trading in the pre-auction, or when-issued, market, the yield on the two-year note to be sold Monday was up to 4.69 percent, from 4.60 percent Wednesday, and the yield on the five-year note to be sold Tuesday jumped to 6.07 percent, from 6.00 percent the day before.
The discount rates on Treasury bills also rose, with the rate on the one-year bill finishing at 3.58 percent, up from 3.51 percent.
Traders said two economic reports yesterday that might normally have supported the market were ignored. They both showed the economy was weak, with new-home construction declining 1.1 percent in October and initial claims for unemployment compensation rising 31,000, to 386,000, in the first week of November.
So what pushed the market around, several traders said, was a sale of longer maturities, like the 30-year bond and the 10-year note, by a very large speculator in the market.
Jay Goldinger, a trader at Capital Insights in Los Angeles, said the speculator was undoing a trade in which he had bought longer maturities and sold shorter ones. This maneuver, which is called a flattening trade, is done when investors think that short-term interest rates are going to rise.
Mr. Goldinger said it appeared that the speculator decided to take his profits in the flattening trade, but that because his position was large and trading was getting thinner, the move had an impact on the market, forcing others to follow suit.
In the late afternoon, the market also got a small downward push from the weekly money supply report from the Federal Reserve. It showed that M-2, which includes currency in circulation, checking accounts and savings accounts, rose $6.6 billion in the week that ended Nov. 9, far more than the forecasts of about a $1 billion increase.
More important, the annual growth rate in M-2 is now at 2.5 percent, the bottom of the Fed's target range. This is the first time in six months that the growth rate has been near target, which decreases the likelihood of another cut in interest rates by the Fed.
 
Move by Sweden
 The American bond market was not affected by the devaluation of the Swedish krona by about 8 percent yesterday. But European buyers of $2 billion of dollar-denominated Swedish three-year bonds earlier in the week were not blamed for feeling pretty bad, if not a little betrayed.
At the time of the sale on Tuesday, the issue was priced to yield 5.636 percent, or 46 basis points more than the yield on the three-year Treasury note. Because of the devaluation, that spread jumped to as much as 58 basis points, or hundredths of percentage points, in trading in London yesterday and closed at around 54 basis points over the three-year Treasury note.
The issue was already having problems selling before the devaluation because the spread had risen to 50 basis points yesterday morning. This could all add up to losses for the underwriters, J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. and Credit Suisse First Boston.
 
Corporate Debt
 In trading in the corporate market, the prices of bonds issued by financial institutions were a little weak, in part because about $800 million in such bonds have been issued recently.
But Citicorp did set a milestone of sorts with its sale of $150 million in subordinated notes. The sale was the first since February and was aimed at taking advantage of the narrowing spreads between the yield on Citcorp paper and the Treasury market.
The yield on the 10-year Citicorp notes was 8.636 percent, 185 basis points over the yield on the 10-year Treasury note. The spread was as wide as 300 basis points a year ago, when the bank's financial outlook was much more shaky.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Sweden Abandons Its Effort To Prop Up the Krona's Value

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
After a long and expensive battle against the markets to maintain the strength of its currency, Sweden gave up the fight today and allowed the krona to fall in value.
The surrender came after an unsuccessful attempt to head off speculators by raising Sweden's benchmark interest rate to 20 percent from 11.5 percent earlier in the day. After giving up and allowing its currency to float in value, the Government pushed the interest rate back down to 12.5 percent. 
 The Swedish action, which left the krona worth about 8 percent less against the dollar and against most European currencies by the end of the trading day in Europe, came amid recurring speculation that the European monetary system will soon agree to a revaluation involving the Spanish peseta, the Portuguese escudo and perhaps the Irish punt, all of which are considered by analysts to be overvalued.
 
Had Taken Extreme Steps
 Sweden had taken one of the hardest lines in Europe against devaluation, and had gone to extreme lengths to avoid it in September when it pushed marginal interest rates up to 500 percent at one point during the economic crisis that nearly ripped apart Europe's monetary system.
Although not yet a member of the European Community, Sweden under the Conservative Government of Prime Minister Carl Bildt has been working to get its financial house in order and to join Europe's system of semifixed exchange rates.
But speculative pressure against the krona has been mounting in the last few days, with investors betting heavily on a further drop in the currency's value. And with Sweden's economy extremely weak, economists said, Mr. Bildt had little leeway to raise interest rates for any sustained period.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Dollar in Broad Loss
By The Associated Press
The dollar lost ground yesterday against most other leading currencies for the third consecutive session as new Government reports suggested weakness in the American economy.
But initially, the dollar was up, a move that coincided with news that the Swedish Government had effectively devalued its currency. In late New York trading yesterday, the krona was down, selling at 6.5635 to the dollar, compared with 6.0900 on Wednesday.
Gold prices edged up in domestic trading after falling in Europe. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery rose 20 cents an ounce, to $335.30.

HEADLINE: 2 Reports Indicate Setbacks for Economy

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
New claims for unemployment benefits jumped sharply early this month and housing starts fell in October, the Government said today in reports that were seen as evidence of a temporary setback for the economy.
The number of Americans filing unemployment claims shot up by 31,000, to 386,000, for the week that ended on Nov. 7, the Labor Department said. It was the biggest increase in three months and the highest level of claims in six weeks. 
 Housing starts fell 1.1 percent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.23 million, the Commerce Department said. Housing starts had risen in August and September.
Both the housing and employment reports were unexpectedly bleak, but they did not shake analysts' belief that the economy is growing gradually and will continue to improve during President-elect Bill Clinton's first year in office.
Overall housing starts strongly advanced in the Midwest in October, but were unable to overcome declines elsewhere.
An 11.8 percent plunge in the volatile apartment sector more than offset a modest increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent in construction of single-family homes.
The Commerce Department said the September advance was revised to eight-tenths of a percent, a rate of 1.24 million, smaller than its original estimate last month of 1.4 percent.
Starts of single-family homes increased seven-tenths of 1 percent, to a 1.07 million rate, the third straight advance. But apartment construction fell for the second straight month, down 11.8 percent, to a rate of 157,000.
David F. Seiders, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders, said a survey of home builders in late October and early November found "some perking up," particularly in expectations for six months in the future.
Applications for building permits, which some economists consider a barometer of future activity, rose 1.1 percent in October after jumping 4.6 percent a month earlier.
Regionally, starts rose only in the Midwest, gaining 10.4 percent, to a 307,000 annual rate. In the Northeast, they dropped 7.3 percent, to a 127,000 rate. after surging 23.4 percent a month earlier. That had been the largest increase in the region since a 31.5 percent gain in June 1991.
Starts were off 4.8 percent in the South, to a 511,000 rate, and 2.4 percent in the West, to a 284,000 rate.
The jump in unemployment claims came after they had fallen in five of the previous six weeks. And a moving four-week average, although higher, remained near a two-year low. The average was 369,250 for the latest period, up from 364,500.
Before the report was released, economists were expecting the level of claims to remain unchanged from the previous week. They cautioned, though, against reading too much into unexpected weekly movements in the claims number. They said that the number of new claims probably reflected, in part, temporary layoffs of construction workers after an early snowstorm in the upper Midwest.
Despite the increase, new benefit claims are still well below the 440,000 to 460,000 they averaged in the first three months of this year and the 410,000 to 430,000 range that held through much of the summer.
In the first week of November, 18 states reported increases of 1,000 or more claims. The three states with the biggest rise in claims were California, with 10,148; Minnesota, 5,031, and Pennsylvania, 4,300.

HEADLINE: TENNIS;
Amid All the Smoke, the Ethics Are Indistinct

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
This is about smoke and coke, proud sponsors of American sport.
Smoke, the legal product, is the cloud on which women's tennis floats. A premier event, the $3 million Virginia Slims Championships, is in town this week. This has always seemed to be the most cynical promotion in professional sports, one whose slogan should really be "You've come a lung way, baby." 
 "They're cleaning up their image and killing women at the same time," said Phyllis Kriegel, editor-in-chief of the feminist bimonthly New Directions for Women. "But what money isn't tainted these days?"
Crack cocaine, the illegal product, is the concrete under many inner-city basketball tournaments. Dope dealers probably buy more trophies for teen-agers than Nike does. Why not? They probably have more discretionary money and fewer advertising outlets.
"Now let's not go blaming women's tennis or these tournaments," said Dean Meminger, who played on the Knicks championship team in 1973. "What other alternatives do they have? Who else is going to support them? People will do what they must to survive."
So much for voices of reason. Back to smoke. According to the United States Centers for Disease Control, more than 50,000 women will die of lung cancer this year. The disease has become the leading cancer killer of women, passing breast cancer. Critics of the tobacco industry's involvement in sponsoring women's political and business conferences and organizations, as well as sports, say that cigarette companies have been successful in the women's market because they play on fears of getting fat and the desire for independence.

 We go from the slime to the ridiculous. With the Slims in town, this has been a week of breathless reams and reels on Jennifer Capriati's teen-age angst and Martina Navratilova's middle-aged consciousness-raising. We can assume neither of them inhales, but who knows? Maybe that's how Jennifer really lost those 20 pounds; maybe that's how Martina relieved the stress of her fiscal-sexual traumas. Neither has made major statements to their fans that their relationship to cigarettes is purely mercenary.
It is disappointing to see newspapers, including the best, carrying advertising for the Slims tournament, even with the Surgeon General's warning attached, and covering it so ingenuously. Worse yet is television coverage, sleazing around the ban on cigarette advertising.
Women in tennis get testy about this issue. Last year, Pam Shriver, president of the Women's Tennis Association, snapped: "We are offering a healthy image here. No one in the company has ever asked us to smoke or endorse cigarettes."
Kriegel snorted. "Some image," she said. "I see more and more young women smoking all the time."
What if New Directions for Women were in trouble and tobacco money were offered?
Kriegel sighed. "Maybe it's not so terrible in an imperfect world," she said. "How pure can you be? Probably we wouldn't take the money. But we haven't faced it."
Meminger said: "More important than the blood money sponsoring the event is that the dope dealer becomes the hero. He's the one the kids look up to. And eventually go to work for."
Dean the Dream is 44 now, working for the New Jersey State Department of Labor and still trying to get his own community-help group into the air. He has been concerned about this issue for years; in fact this conversation the other day was the continuation of one started several years ago during one of Micheal Ray Richardson's last comeback attempts from drug abuse.
Since then, the hundreds of tournaments for youngsters that faltered after Reagan-Bush defundings of inner-city programs became even more vulnerable to the big spenders who rolled up in their Jeeps and Beamers, dripping with gold and cellulars and sycophants and the ready-to-buy shirts and hardware and, most important, referees. The dealers, who are already crucial to the neighborhood economy, now become patrons of the playground arts.
It gets worse, according to Meminger. Because so many young athletes are "processed" through the educational system without real family, school and community support networks, when they finally drop the ball, in high school or college, they return to their neighborhoods as "liabilities."
"Who hires them?" asked Meminger. "The big dealers hire them. Athletes make great dope pushers. They're well known in the community. They've got leadership qualities. They have a platform."
If the dealers are power brokers in these neighborhoods, consider the clout of the smoke peddlers, who also filtered several million into the recent Presidential campaigns. The tobacco industry has been criticized for its cynicism in subsidizing black music groups, stock-car racers and, of course, women's tennis. Early on, when no one else wanted to foot the bill, Philip Morris made the women's tour possible. A few women got rich.
The illegal peddlers uptown probably made it possible for a few youngsters to get out of the playground and into college and on with productive lives.
The solution, please. Money, of course. Uptown, local businesses, city, state and Federal governments and corporations can take the tournaments back from the dope dealers.
Downtown, it might be easier. Millionaire female tennis players with all their corporate connections can stop betraying their fans by playing with smoke. Just say no.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:
During the heady boom years of the late 1980's, when auctions became public spectacles and prices rose to heights that astonished even the experts, some in the art world bemoaned the fact that it was no longer the art that mattered. Record prices were what made headlines. "There were too many people who had no idea what they were buying," one dealer proclaimed; caught up in the excitement and frenzy of buying at public auction, they were "simply bidding on pretty colors across a crowded room." 
 As the two most important weeks of fall auctions in New York ended on Wednesday night, price was still foremost in everyone's mind. But in the more sober 90's, the discussions take a decidedly different spin. "We have to adjust to a new price structure," the SoHo dealer Mary Boone said after Christie's sale of contemporary art on Wednesday night. "Now $100,000 is a lot of money."
Buyers today are approaching auctions the way they shop at tag sales: hunting for quality but buying only if it involves a bargain. Indeed, the speculators who drove up prices in the late 80's have totally disappeared from the auction salesrooms. The old collectors are back, wiser than ever. Buyers this fall tended to ignore the estimates that both Sotheby's and Christie's put on works of art. Instead, they fixed what they considered a fair price in their minds and, for the most part, stuck to it.
Works by artists like Picasso and Degas, Roy Lichtenstein and Malcolm Morley were snapped up for considerably less than they would have been at the peak of the market. And many works failed to sell at all. The sales totals of the last two weeks reflected the market's new levels. Sotheby's sales totaled $73.4 million, below the $110 million to $148 million the house had expected. Christie's sales totaled $104.6 million, not far below its estimated $107.4 million to $142.6 million.
"In the contemporary field, I'd say we are back where we were in 1987," said Christopher Burge, the president of Christie's in New York. "For Impressionist and modern art, we're ahead of the first half of 1988."
That's not to say there weren't some bright spots over the last two weeks. Just six months ago, works with estimates of more than $1 million were almost impossible to sell. This fall, at Sotheby's sale of contemporary art on Tuesday night, seven works sold for more than $1 million each, and Christie's boasted four works that fetched $1 million plus. At the sales of Impressionist and modern art, Christie's sold seven works for more than $2 million, and Sotheby's sold four.
In May, the top price paid in New York for a painting was $7.7 million for Braque's "Studio VIII," sold at Christie's. Last week, Christie's fetched a record $14.5 for Matisse's "Harmony in Yellow," sold to an unidentified telephone bidder. (The previous record for a Matisse was in 1989, at the height of the market, when "Woman With a Red Umbrella Seated in Profile" (1919-21), sold at Sotheby's in New York for $12.4 million.) Another surprise came when Monet's "Water Lily Basin," from 1919, sold for $12.1 million at Christie's on Nov. 11, way above its estimate of $7 million to $8 million.
"It's safe to come back into the market again," said David Nash, the director of Sotheby's department of Impressionist and modern art. "It's healthier than it has been for two years. And insiders, who know what things are worth, are pleased by the results."
Mr. Burge also took the last two weeks as an optimistic sign. "Sure, the market is delicate, but people want to collect again at prices that make sense," he said. "The biggest difference between this fall and last is that now there was bidding at every level." Mr. Burge also said bidders weren't simply private collectors; dealers, too, were participating again. Often they started bidding but dropped out when prices began to rise. "Dealers are realizing the only way to make the market work is to start having new things to sell again," Mr. Burge said.
Predictably, Matisse upstaged every other artist over the last two weeks. It has been years since an important Matisse was offered at auction. This fall, both by the coincidence of estate offerings and a hefty number of collectors trying to cash in on the success of the blockbuster Matisse retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, 28 works by Matisse were up for sale.
In addition to "Harmony in Yellow," another important work, "Asia," from 1946, sold at Sotheby's for $11 million to the New York dealer William Acquavella, who was bidding for the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth. The work, which was sold by the estate of the fashion designer Mollie Parnis Livingston, far exceeded the auction house's estimate of $7 million to $8 million.
But many Matisses sold at or below their low estimates, and some didn't sell at all. At Sotheby's, "The Red Beach," from 1905, sold from the estate of Wright S. Ludington, founder of the Santa Barbara Museum of Art in California, fetched $1.37 million, not far above Sotheby's low estimate of $1.25 million. "Pink Shrimp," a 1920 work being offered by the Everhart Museum in Scranton, Pa., never found a buyer; bidding stopped at $1.6 million, far short of Sotheby's low estimate of $2.6 million. At Christie's, "Still Life With Pitcher and Fruit," painted in 1898 in Toulouse, France, and estimated to bring $500,000 to $700,000, sold for just $451,000, and "The Bridge from Sevres to St.-Cloud," from 1917, estimated at $550,000 to $650,000, was not sold. Bidding stopped at $380,000.
At both Sotheby's and Christie's, the works that sold underscored how prices have fallen since the height of the market.
Renoir's "Young Boy With a Cat," from 1868-69, which had been sold at Christie's in 1988 to a Japanese collector in London for $2 million, was bought at Sotheby's this fall by the Musee d'Orsay for $797,500.
At Christie's, Picasso's "Yellow Iris," from 1901, which sold at Sotheby's in May 1989 for $2.2 million, fetched $935,000 this fall. And Monet's "Spring in Giverny," which sold for $1.38 million in a Sotheby's London sale 10 years ago and fetched $3.3 million at another Sotheby's sale in London three years ago, sold this fall for $1.76 million.
The same downward slide occurred at the contemporary-art auctions. Contemporary art has always been the most volatile of the markets for paintings, showing dramatic inflation when times are good and the quickest drop when the going gets rough. At both Sotheby's and Christie's, it seemed as though estimates meant nothing. Buyers brazenly bid exactly what they felt like bidding, regardless of what the estimates suggested. And surprisingly, some works sold for half their predicted prices. Each sale's outcome had a lot to do with the level of the reserves (the secret minimum prices agreed upon by the seller and the auction house). Christie's sold 81 percent of its offerings, while Sotheby's sold only 65 percent.
Many works went for low prices. At Sotheby's, Malcolm Morley's realist painting "S.S. Amsterdam in Front of Rotterdam," from 1966, offered by the advertising magnate Charles Saatchi and estimated to bring $700,000 to $800,000, was sold for $440,000 to Jeffrey Deitch, a New York dealer. Another good buy from the same seller was Roy Lichtenstein's "Girl With Piano." Estimated at $3 million to $3.5 million, it was sold for $1.8 million to an unidentified American collector.
There were bargains at Christie's, too. Willem de Kooning's "Abstraction," from 1948, was bought for $440,000 by a Chicago dealer, Richard Gray; the estimate had been $600,000 to $800,000. Anselm Kiefer's "Markischer Sand V," estimated to bring $100,00 to $150,000, was bought by a telephone bidder for $77,000.f
By far the star of the contemporary sales was Andy Warhol's "Marilyn X 100," a 1962 silk-screen that sold at Sotehby's on Tuesday night for $3.7 million. This was not far short of the artist's record of $4.03 million, paid in 1989 for "Shot Red Marilyn," a 40-inch-square painting from 1964. At Christie's Wednesday night, it was Jasper Johns who brought the highest price. "0 Through 9," from 1961, estimated at $2.8 million to $3.5 million, sold to a telephone bidder for $2.1 million, just under Christie's low estimate.
For now, auction houses are pleased that works sell and that interest in the market is back. "There's no question the market is going to stay this way for another season," said Mr. Burge of Christie's. "But if we can just repeat our performance in the spring, I'll be happy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Roy Lichtenstein's "Girl With Piano" was considered a good buy at $1.8 million Tuesday night at Sotheby's auction of contemporary art. (Sotheby's)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
MGM Grand Shifting to All-Charter Flights

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19

 BODY:
MGM Grand Air, the luxury airline that pampers its customers with caviar and Champagne, said today that it planned to halt its flight schedule between Los Angeles and New York on New Year's Eve.
In discontinuing its money-losing scheduled passenger service, the airline will cut its work force by 155 people, to 167 employees. 
 The airline intends to redeploy the seven aircraft it operates as an all-charter service. Since the company began offering flights for hire in 1989, it has won a number of high-profile contracts to ferry rock groups and professional athletic teams including the Boston Celtics and New York Knicks.
"This appears to be a market they are set up to do, and they will be taking less risk with long-term contracts," said Willard Brown, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds.
MGM Grand anticipates that its charter revenue, estimated at $18 million in 1992, will increase more than 50 percent next year. "By redeploying our assets from an unprofitable division to a profitable one, we will be in a better position to enhance value for our shareholders," said Robert Maxey, the company's president and chief executive.
MGM Grand's scheduled passenger service had losses of $4.9 million in the first nine months of 1992, said Alex Yemenidjian, an executive vice president of the airline. Scheduled service, which began in 1987, was profitable only in 1988 and 1989 and has since piled up losses. "Economic conditions changed," he said.
 Not only did the economy slump, but half-price fare wars in the airline industry made MGM Grand's $1,600 one-way first-class tickets seem especially extravagant. (In contrast, discounted round-trip tickets on some other airlines have been offered for less than $350.) Most recent flights have been half full.
The airline has two nonstop flights leaving daily from New York and Los Angeles. Passengers board DC-8's, which normally seat 189 people. On MGM Grand, the plane carries only 71 passengers, who are seated in spacious, living-room-like areas and lavished with seven-course meals prepared by a chef on board.
Other amenities include a choice of three movies, freshly baked chocolate-chip cookies handed out at the end of the flight and baggage claim in less than seven minutes.
MGM Grand, a hotel and airline company in which the financier Kirk Kerkorian has a 76 percent stake, expects the conversion to all-charter service to result in a $1.5 million charge against earnings in the fourth quarter. The company already expected a year-end loss from operations and interest expenses on construction financing.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Occidental to Cut 500 Jobs And Freeze Many Salaries

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it would cut its operating costs by about $155 million next year by dismissing 500 workers and freezing the salaries of high-paid employees. The company also intends to reduce capital spending by $150 million.
The planned cuts represent a second round of cost-cutting by Occidental since 1991 and should result in a $10 million charge against earnings in the fourth quarter. 
 Analysts said Occidental's move was based on the expectation that slow economic growth would last another eight months or so. Economic lethargy has particularly hurt the profitability of the company's petrochemical business. Analysts said the moves should permit the company to channel more money to oil and gas exploration.
 Robin Shoemaker, an oil industry analyst with Lehman Brothers, said the potential benefits of Occidental's cost-cutting drive could be offset by soft business conditions. "Any fundamental improvement will be late in 1993, '94 or '95," he said.
The salary freeze, which is effective immediately, will remain in place through 1993 for all salaried employees earning more than $40,000 a year; about a third of the company's work force of 24,700 people will be affected. These people represent 80 percent of the company's outlay for salaries, said Ray R. Irani, the chairman and chief executive.
Salaried employees who earn less than $40,000 will receive a 3 percent increase on April 1 to offset inflation, compared with previous raises of about 5 percent. Unionized workers are not affected.
The company expects to save $55 million from the salary freeze. Another $100 million is expected to be saved from 500 unspecified job cuts.
Occidental, based in Los Angeles, began a restructuring in 1991 that has improved net income by an estimated $350 million. The company has reduced its revenue to $10 billion, from $21 billion, mostly from the sale of its stake in IBP Inc., a beef packer, and has cut debt by $3 billion.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Brokerage Accounts
Q How do the managed accounts offered by brokerage firms work?
 
MARY ANN HILTERHAUS, GLEN RIDGE, N.J.
 
A Managed accounts are often called wrap accounts because they wrap the investment adviser's fee and stockbroker's commission into one all-inclusive fee. 
 "No matter how much or how little trading is done, you pay just one annual fee, so that the broker's interest is the same as the client's interest," said James L. Melcher, president of Balestra Capital, a New York money management company. "Usually a brokerage firm offers clients a shopping list of investment advisers to choose from, sometimes even including an in-house asset manager."
Most wrap fees start at 3 percent of assets and decline as the account increases in size. You usually need at least $100,000 to open a wrap account and can sometimes obtain a lower fee because of competitive pressures, Mr. Melcher said.
 
Safety of Bank Vaults
?
Q What happens if a bank vault box is rifled or destroyed by a natural catastrophe or in some other way?
 
ESTELLE YELLIN, ORANGE, N.J.
 
A Items in a safe deposit box in a bank are not covered by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. "But items are safer in a safety deposit box than lying around the house because of bank alarm systems," said Don S. Tokunaga, vice president of First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles.
If property in your safe deposit box is stolen or otherwise lost, it may be covered by your homeowner or personal floater policy, Mr. Tokunaga added. In addition, you can purchase special insurance policies tailored for the valuables placed in a safe deposit box. Insurance for any cash in a box is specifically excluded from these policies.
Some victims of safe deposit burglaries have sued banks in an attempt to recover their losses. But a suit may be costly and time-consuming.
 
Savings Bonds for Elders
Q Are United States Savings Bonds a good investment for people over 60 years old?
 
IRMA ROSENTHAL, HARTSDALE, N.Y.
 
A When you do not want to put your money into an investment with risk, Series EE Savings Bonds are a good choice for older people, said Janet Briaud, president of the National Association of Personal Financial Advisers.
"If you retain them for at least five years, the return is a guaranteed 6 percent -- about 3 percent above inflation, which historically is very high," she said. "But Savings Bonds would not be appropriate when you need income."
If you hold Savings Bonds for less than five years, a market-based interest rate, which had been 5.58 percent until the beginning of this month and will be 5.04 percent until April 1993, is used.
As long as you have owned at least $500 worth of Series EE bonds for at least six months, you can exchange them for Series HH bonds, which pay semiannual interest at the rate of 6 percent. By doing so, you can defer the Federal income tax that has accrued on the Series EE bonds until you dispose of the Series HH bonds.

HEADLINE: HOW THEY DO IT;
A Family's Savings Strategy Spreads College Costs Over 20 Years

 BODY:
Mark Schiess, 40, a medical technologist in Carmel, Ind., and his wife Christine, 38, a nurse, have charted a long-term savings plan to finance the college education of their two children. Their goal: $150,000 for each child, to meet the projected cost of four years of college. 
 They began by opening savings accounts for the children at birth - the first for Maris, their daughter, now 21 months old; the second for Justin, now 3 months old. Recently, they made a bolder move; they refinanced their home mortgage to restructure expenses and, in the long run, add more to the college fund. The main components of their long-term savings plan are described below.
 
Long-Terms C.D.'s
 
Automatic monthly payments, drawn from the couple's checking account, go into certificates of deposit for each child. Interest is variable, and is pegged to fluctuations in U.S. college tuition rates. $500 is added quarterly to Maris's account; $250 monthy to Justin's. Annual savings: $5,000 excluding interest. In 20 years: $100,000 excluding interest.
 
Mutual Funds
 
Shortly after Maris was born, the Schiesses selected a mix of stock funds, using two different families of funds for greater diversity. An automatic pay-in plan adds a total of $400 a month to the funds. Annual contribution: $4,800. In 20 years: $96,000 (Dividends not included).
 
Refinancing The Mortgage
 
In September they refinanced the $130,000 mortgage on their home, changing from a 30-year to a 15-year term. Lower interest rates decreased monthly payments from $1,500 to about $1,250; they are using the savings to make extra payments on the principal and further shorten the term to 11 years. The mortgage should be paid five years before Maris starts college, leaving more for savings. Potential annual savings (after mortgage is paid): $15,000. In 5 years: $75,000.
 
Life Insurance
 
Mr. Schiess is now paying into three life insurance policies. He plans to cash one in at maturity in eight years, when it should be worth $20,000, and reinvest the proceeds. The policy's proceeds: $20,000.
 
How It All Adds Up
 
Projected savings by the 2012. Interest and dividends are unknown, and are not included. Even at modest rates of return, and with taxes on earnings, the fund can be expected to reach the $300,000 goal.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Schiess family, Mark and Christine holding Maris and Justin. (Megan Jaegerman and Andree Brooks/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

 COMPULSIVE GAMBLING: SIN OR SICKNESS?
The question of whether pathological gambling should be considered a disease or a moral weakness is a matter of much debate in academic and addiction-treatment circles these days. The answer will likely have major implications for how money is spent on research into compulsive gambling and for employers and insurers who have resisted paying for intensive inpatient treatment. Page 1.
 
 NEW YORK CITY
 
 GRIDLOCK ALERTS
RUN OFF THE ROAD
Yes, the end-of-the-year gridlock alert day, a New York holiday fixture for a decade, has been discontinued, a victim of the recession and its own effectiveness. The city Department of Transportation says traffic has declined enough to make the public announcements urging motorists to stay out of Manhattan unnecessary. Page 23.
 
 OFFICIALS ORDERED TO SLEEP IN OFFICES
A state judge, ruling that the Dinkins administration has repeatedly failed to adequately shelter homeless families, fined the city yesterday and ordered four officials to spend a night in the same city offices where hundreds of homeless families have had to sleep. Page 1.

HEADLINE: Mexico's Leader Seeks to Address Clinton's Concerns on Trade Pact

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 20

 BODY:
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, seeking to calm President-elect Bill Clinton's concerns about the free-trade agreement with Mexico and Canada, says he is eager to negotiate a solution to problems created by the accord soon after Mr. Clinton takes office in January.
In an interview Thursday evening, Mr. Salinas said he shared Mr. Clinton's belief that steps must be taken to protect the environment from damage that might be caused by the accord known as the North American Free Trade Agreement. 
 "We are open to this issue of the environment, which interests both countries," Mr. Salinas said.
He said that it seemed "natural" that the environmental issues be negotiated by a standing commission of Mexican and American officials who meet periodically to discuss differences between the two countries.
"If that is the scheme that suits the new Administration of President Clinton, then with great pleasure," Mr. Salinas said.
But he said that the Binational Commission, which was scheduled to meet next in March, should also take up Mexican concerns. Among them, he said, were his Government's desire to ease restrictions on the flow of Mexicans into the United States and improve the way they are treated by the American authorities.
 
Broad Bilateral Agenda
 Other officials said Mexico would also renew its demands for permanent assurances that the United States not try to kidnap criminal suspects abroad.
President Bush made a personal pledge to that effect in June after Mexicans were enraged by a Supreme Court decision upholding the United States Government's kidnapping of a doctor from Mexico wanted in the killing of an American drug agent. But Mr. Bush would not write the assurances into a treaty.
"The bilateral agenda is very broad," Mr. Salinas said. "I am ready for us to immediately begin the dialogue with the Administration of President Clinton on those issues of the complex bilateral relationship."
Even if Mr. Salinas and Mr. Clinton resolve their differences on the trade agreement, there might be problems standing in the way of its approval in the United States. Bush Administration officials said that approval of the North American treaty might have to be delayed if the Congress also has to consider approval of a separate international trade agreement being negotiated under the so-called Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Mr. Salinas was careful to indicate that how and when issues surrounding the North American Free Trade Agreement were discussed would depend largely on Mr. Clinton.
At times in the interview, Mr. Salinas spoke warmly about the Arkansas Governor, whose election he was said by aides to have hoped against. The aides said that in part, the Salinas administration feared that Congressional approval of the free-trade agreement might be more difficult with a Democratic President.
Asked what similarities he saw between himself and Mr. Clinton, Mr. Salinas said first, "His spirit of change.
"He is a modern man, brave," the 44-year-old Mexican President said. "He conducted a very brave campaign. He appears determined. Warm in his attitude. Also, his interest in being close to the people, in traveling inside his country. In forming a domestic economic council. I have now had 172 meetings of our economic Cabinet. Tomorrow I have another."
 
Environmental Safeguards
 The North American Free Trade Agreement was concluded in August after more than a year of intensive negotiations. It would reduce tariff barriers to American and Canadian markets for Mexican fruits, vegetables and other commodities while making it easier for Americans and Canadians to sell their products and invest in Mexico.
But the accord has raised fears that American industries in particular will relocate to Mexico to take advantage of cheaper labor costs and looser environmental regulations, creating a border haven for polluters.
After the accord was reached, Mr. Clinton took some time to decide whether to support it. Finally, he said he endorsed the treaty in principle but said it would have to be accompanied by measures to safeguard the border environment and help American workers who might lose their jobs.
Mr. Salinas said he had not yet discussed with President Bush, Mr. Clinton and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada when the trade agreement might be signed, a step that effectively sets in motion a countdown for its consideration by the United States Congress. But senior Mexican officials indicated that Mr. Salinas would prefer to sign it with Mr. Bush before Mr. Clinton takes office.
 
'This Is What I Got'
 Under the "fast track" negotiating authority granted by the Congress last year, the agreement cannot be signed before mid-December. But from the moment of its transmission to Congress, which could occur any time after the treaty is signed, the Congress will have only 90 working days before it must bring the agreements' enabling legislation to a yes-or-no vote.
A senior Mexican official speculated that Mr. Clinton might want President Bush to sign it.
"It suits him because he receives it finished," he said. "And he can say, 'Gentlemen, this is what I got.' "
Mr. Clinton has not addressed the issue in detail since his election. He was asked at a news conference on Thursday whether he would make the trade agreement a priority for his first 100 days in office.
 
Renegotiation Opposed
 "Yes, it is a priority," the president-elect said. "And I expect it will have to be because of the time frame for consideration of the treaty by the Congress and for the President's authority to negotiate with Mexico."
Mexican officials said Mr. Salinas's suggestion of the commission reflected Mexico's desire to move as quickly as possible toward United States Congressional approval of the trade pact and to redraw the agenda of issues that surround it.
Mr. Salinas reiterated his strong opposition to any renegotiation of the trade agreement. He also insisted that the problem of how to aid workers who lost their jobs because of the accord was one for each country to deal with on its own.
While Mexico has long accepted that some agreements beyond the treaty will be the price of its passage by the United States Congress, Mr. Salinas was emphatic.
"We are totally committed and determined in favor of the environment," he said. "We are going to invest more resources and government determination, and encourage peoples' participation. Mexico's commitment to the environment is complete because it is a demand of the Mexican people."
 
Mexican Border Access
 Mr. Salinas's senior aide in charge of environmental policy, Social Development Secretary Luis Donaldo Colosio, said Mexico would seek agreements to strengthen its environmental enforcement capabilities in particular. He said the United States might be asked for assistance in training Mexico's new force of environmental-protection inspectors and for technological help in areas such as emissions control.
Mr. Salinas did not explicitly link Mexico's support for new environmental safeguards under the trade agreement to the resolution of its complaints with other American policies related to the accord. But he said he hoped that with a new Administration in Washington, the two countries would be "able to deal with different aspects of the bilateral relationship."
In particular, the Mexican President argued that Mexicans should be allowed to travel freely to the United States and assured of humane treatment there.
"We are very concerned about abuses that are committed against Mexicans when they are working as migrant workers in the United States," he said. "It seems that the law already establishes that they should be protected, but in practice they are not."
The Bush Administration has sought to keep immigration issues outside the purview of the trade agreement.
 
Gortari's Political Changes
 But the Mexican Government has continued to push for measures like an increase in the number of Mexican border residents allowed to work or shop in the United States. By accepting such cross-border movements as inevitable and effectively decriminalizing them, Mexican officials contend, the problems of abuse against immigrants by American law-enforcement authorities could be sharply reduced.
In his first detailed discussion of his proposals for political changes in Mexico, Mr. Salinas also said he would support a public accounting of where political parties get their funds and limits on how they spend them in election campaigns. He also endorsed some sort of independent oversight to insure that what parties spend matches the amounts they raise.
Mr. Salinas indicated that he was less willing to try to impose new regulations on Mexican newspapers and television stations in order to equalize the access of political parties to news organizations, as demanded by some proponents of changes in the Mexican political system.

HEADLINE: Arabs' Warning to Clinton: Prod the Israelis Over Talks

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Staking out their negotiating position vis-a-vis the Clinton Administration, Arab delegates to the Middle East peace talks warned today that unless the new President moves quickly to prod Israel into concessions, they would abandon the discussions early next year.
But at the same time, the head of the Syria's delegation to the talks signaled his country's willingness to take part in another round of negotiations next month. 
 The mixed messages put forward by the Arab delegates seemed intended to serve two purposes. The virtual acceptance by Syria of an invitation to another rounds of talks insures that momentum in the negotiations will be maintained until the new Administration takes office.
But coupled with that was a clear warning shot across the bow of the incoming Administration by the Arabs who want to see, at the very least, if they have the diplomatic influence to win an early focus on the Middle East.
 
Little Progress So Far
 "Our patience cannot last forever," the Syrian delegate, Muwaffiq al-Allaf, said at a news conference today. "We are the parties whose territory is under occupation, so waiting is not in our interest."
Mr. Allaf's statements were typical of the frustrations voiced by all parties to the latest round of the peace talks, which ended on Thursday with little progress having been achieved and with many of the negotiators appearing to want to wait and see what policies or positions would be forthcoming from the Clinton Administration.
Yossi Gal, spokesman for the Israeli delegation, told reporters on Thursday that the pending change in Washington should not influence the talks. "I think that we should all concentrate on the process without any delays," Mr. Gal said, "that too much is at stake, that the future of our region is at stake, and negotiations should continue regardless of developments anywhere in the world."
Mr. Allaf said Syria would give "reasonable time" to the Clinton Administration to pursue the peace efforts begun by the Bush Administration in the wake of the Persian Gulf war. But he added, that "three or four months after the arrival of the new President to the White House," if there is no progress toward a comprehensive settlement, "then it will be time to reconsider the whole thing."
But for the shorter range, Mr. Allaf added that he had been authorized by his Government to say that if all the other parties to the talks agree to meet again in Washington, his country would attend. Arab foreign ministers are scheduled to meet in Beirut this month to decide whether to accept an offer to resume negotiations in Washington on Dec. 7. Israel has already said it would return to the table.
After the news conference, Mr. Allaf told a reporter that "while it was not within my competence" to predict what other Arab delegations would do, he thought it was "very likely" they would agree to come back to the talks.
Maintaining the appearance of momentum in the talks could be important since there are a number of forces in the Middle East -- from hard-line Arab opposed to talks to hawkish Israelis -- who would use the collapse of the discussions to increase their influence in their governments or movements.
During the Presidential campaign, Bill Clinton took a staunchly pro-Israel stand.
In an interview with the French quarterly Politique Internationale that was published on the eve of the election, Mr. Clinton accused President Hafez al-Assad of Syria of "territorial ambitions" and said the "tyranny" he exercises in his own country "should lead us to be more prudent in our relations with him."
In another interview, published in the November-December issue of Middle East Insight magazine, Mr. Clinton said he does "recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital," though he would not move the American Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem during the negotiations.
Arab nations have consistently rejected Israel's claim to Jerusalem, and the United States has not recognized the city as Israel's capital.
The comments by the leaders of the four Arab delegations came a day after the end of the latest round of discussions, which saw little progress on the central issues of possible Israel withdrawal from territory conquered during the 1967 war and incursions into southern Lebanon, some form of self-rule for the Palestinians and a cessation of the state of war that has existed between Israel and its Arab neighbors since 1948.
The latest round was also marked by new violence in the region, particularly on Israel's northern border with Lebanon. There, guerrillas from the Party of God, a pro-Iranian organization, fired rockets at Israeli settlements. In response, the Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin massed troops on the border, but members of the Israeli Cabinet reportedly persuaded Mr. Rabin not to conduct a strike across the border.
Bush Administration officials insist that while the general perception is that the parties in the negotiations were marking time until the new President takes office, progress, albeit incremental progress, was being made.
Edward P. Djerejian, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, told reporters this week that the most substantial progress was made between Israeli and Jordanian negotiators who were "engaged in in-depth work on key issues" involving water, energy, economic relationships and the environment.
Mr. Djerejian, a former Ambassador to Syria, acknowledged that "much hard work remains on the road ahead."

HEADLINE: NATO and European Warships Blockade Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Both NATO and the Western European Union ordered their warships in the Adriatic today to carry out a full naval blockade on the former Yugoslavia to enforce a United Nations embargo.
The effect of the naval action remained unclear, however, because only a small limited amount of the strategic trade to Serbia and Montenegro covered by United Nations embargoes arrive by sea, diplomats in Rome said. 
 Most shipments of oil and other supplies covered by the sanctions are believed to reach Serbia and Montenegro, which are the only two republics left in what was once Yugoslavia, by road or by barge along the Danube, the diplomats said.
Technically, the measures agreed today will give warships of NATO and the Western European Union the same powers to stop and search merchant shipping as the Western allies used to impose United Nations sanctions against Iraq during the Persian Gulf crisis.
 
Seeks to End Bosnia War
 Diplomats in Brussels said North Atlantic Treaty Organization ambassadors in Brussels agreed that the new measures, intended to interdict shipping of banned goods and thereby increase pressure for an end to the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina, should be carried out as soon as possible.
In Rome, foreign and defense ministers of the Western European Union, enlarged today to 10 members with the accession of Greece to the organization, announced that they committed aircraft and naval vessels to insure "strict implementation of the embargo at sea."
At a news conference, Defense Minister Volker Ruhe of Germany said the decisions would permit Western European Union vessels to fire warning shots to halt suspect vessels "but they are not allowed to destroy ships." The same rules of engagement are expected to apply to NATO vessels.
The Western Economic Union, long a moribund organization with only a nominal role in Western Europe's defense during the cold war, has emerged since the fall of Communism as the potential military arm of the European Community. However, its precise role, both in relation to the Community and to NATO, with whom the organization's members largely overlap, remains ill-defined and disputed.
At present, the Western European Union has five warships assigned to patrolling the Adriatic, but until today they were permitted only to question suspicious vessels about their origin and cargo. NATO has seven warships in the region from its Standing Mediterranean Fleet, and the two fleets have shared duties of monitoring shipping to Yugoslavia since July.
The United States guided-missile frigate Halyburton is one of the seven NATO vessels that have been ordered to enforce the embargo. In addition, two Sixth Fleet ships -- the cruiser Wainwright and the amphibious assault ship Guam -- have been taking part in surveillance operations in the Adriatic, but are not part of the NATO operation.
A NATO statement in Brussels said that "all ships entering or leaving the territorial waters of the former Yugoslavia will be halted to inspect and verify their cargo and destination."
Italian officials said the coordinated deployment of warships of NATO and the Western European Union to enforce the new measures would probably begin next Tuesday after officials had worked out details on Monday.
 
Appeal for More Ships
 Defense Minister Salvo Ando of Italy, said, however, that "this new operation will require more resources" and urged West European nations to send more warships to the Adriatic. The Italian official said the existing number of allied warships in the Adriatic was not enough to enforce the embargo. Last week, NATO said the number of its ships would be reduced, but there was no word tonight whether this decision still held.
A further impediment to the new measures is that, of the seven NATO vessels, the German destroyer Hamburg is barred by German government policy from doing more than asking merchant ships to identify themselves and their cargo.
"For German foreign and defense policy, the fact that we cannot participate fully in these operations is unfortunate," Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel of Germany told the Rome news conference.
Also in Rome, the NATO Secretary General, Manfred Worner, urged coordination between the two fleets. His presence at the Rome meeting was the first time a NATO Secretary General had attended a high-level Western European Union gathering.
The United States has accused the two Western European members closest to Yugoslavia -- Greece and Italy-- of permitting supplies of fuel to be shippied to Serbia via Montenegro.
A week ago, the American delegate to the United Nations, Edward J. Perkins, publicized a list of companies in Greece, Italy, Egypt and Malta accused of delivering supplies to the former Yugoslavia in violation of United Nations embargoes.
"These are completely unsubstantiated," an Italian official spokesman said of the accusations. "These suspicions have not been substantiated and the same is true for Greece."
Mr. Perkins had said an Italian shipping company had agreed to take 8,000 tons of coke to the Montenegran port of Bar, while a Greek shipping concern had delivered 200,000 tons of petroleum products to the same port since June.
