Serbians Launch New Attack
 SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, (Reuters) -- Serbian forces began a heavy artillery assault on the Bosnian town of Travnik today in an apparent attempt to open a new corridor toward Sarajevo.
A barrage of constant shelling could be heard around nearby Vitez, a major refugee center that is defended by Muslim and Croation fighters.
The offensive was begun as the commander of United Nations peacekeeping forces in Bosnia, Gen. Philippe Morillon, met the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, to urge his side to honor a cease-fire.
A Croatian military commander acknowledged two days ago that Serbian forces had broken through the front line near Travnik and had the town, 50 miles northwest of Sarajevo, at their mercy.

HEADLINE: THE TRADE ACCORD;
Excerpts From Joint Statement by U.S. and Europe

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the text of the joint statement issued by the Commission of the European Community and the United States on the completion of their trade negotiations, as transcribed by The Associated Press:
The United States and the Commission of the European Community intend to pursue a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round. As a result of our discussions, we believe that we have achieved the progress necessary to assure agreements on the major elements blocking progress in Geneva, notably in agriculture, services and market access. A successful outcome will be a positive factor for the trade and economic growth of the economies of the world. 
 Our negotiators are returning to Geneva to work together to build the comprehensive, global and balanced package we both seek. . . .
In agriculture we have resolved our differences on the main elements concerning domestic support, export subsidies and market access in a manner that should enable the Director General to move the negotiations to a successful conclusion. . . . We are in full accord that an effective agreement on agricultural reform requires the participation of all countries in the negotiations.
The United States and the E.C. Commission agreed how to resolve the oilseeds dispute.
On market access, the United States and the E.C. Commission have found the basis to achieve an ambitious result that meets their respective objectives as follows: detailed negotiations will continue on specific sectors or products in order to make progress towards the completion of a substantial and balanced package. Tariff reductions will be maximized, with as few exceptions as possible, including the substantial reduction of high tariffs, the harmonization of tariffs at very low levels, and the elimination of tariffs in key sectors. . . .
However, participation of third countries -- not only the developing countries, but other industrialized countries -- and elimination of nontariff distortions are considered to be of essential importance, and both parties will continue efforts to achieve maximum results in this regard in Geneva in the coming weeks. . . .
In services, we are in strong agreement that the market-access offers must form an integral part of the ambitious result we seek. We have now agreed to take a common approach on financial services. In addition, we discussed improvements in our respective offers, and have agreed to seek maximum liberalization and minimum exemptions. . . .
We have full expectations that the breakthrough we have achieved will unblock the negotiations and provide new impetus necessary to complete the Round. We encourage our trading partners to return to the negotiating table in Geneva, prepared to show the necessary flexibility to bring these negotiations to a close.
Earlier this year at the Munich Economic Summit, G-7 leaders called for conclusion of the Uruguay Round by the end of the year. Time is short, but negotiators are returning to Geneva confident that substantial progress can be achieved to meet the intent of the G-7 leaders' commitment, provided other countries are prepared to work with us to secure an ambitious and far-reaching result to these important talks.

HEADLINE: Plane Noise Faces Limits From F.A.A.

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday announced measures intended to better protect residents of the New York region, who live beneath the busiest airspace in the world, from aircraft noise.
The measures, which will affect people from Newburgh, N.Y., to Newark, include shifting aircraft approaches to La Guardia and Kennedy International Airports, making helicopters fly higher over Westchester County and making air traffic controllers more solicitous to residents' eardrums. 
 The changes are not expected to increase delays at area airports, the F.A.A. said.
The steps, some of which have already been put into effect, came after a yearlong review of air-traffic noise within 75 miles of La Guardia Airport. The review, which included 18 public hearings, was mandated by Congress.
 
'This Balancing Act'
 As it issued its findings to Congress yesterday, the aviation agency made it clear that there was only so much it could do.
"The problem is we have 6,000 aircraft that fly in that airspace a day, so you're never going to get rid of air traffic noise, period," said Paul Steucke, a spokesman for the agency. "We're trying to juggle this balancing act of providing the services that everybody needs, and reducing the noise."
Bill Cahill, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns Newark, La Guardia and Kennedy Airports, said the authority had not yet analyzed the measures. "The only thing I can tell you at this point is that the only Port Authority involvement was providing some data from our flight track noise monitoring system," he said.
 
New Steps to Come
 The major measures that have not yet been put into effect include these:
*Testing to see if planes can be better dispersed as they land and take off from Kennedy and La Guardia Airports so that the same neighborhoods are not always subjected to the noise.
*Charting a new approach into Westchester County Airport that would bring flights in over Long Island Sound.
*Establishing a second instrument landing system at Stewart Airport in Newburgh so that planes can take more than one approach.
*Increasing the amount of noise reduction training for air-traffic controllers.
*Asking pilots flying out of Newark to use their on-board computers to keep a precise heading over the Arthur Kill waterway, to avoid straying over Staten Island.
Two other changes have already been made. Six weeks ago, the aviation administration began amending flight patterns at La Guardia to keep as many planes as possible over Long Island Sound during approach and landing.
Dan Andrews, a spokesman for Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens, who has long sought a reduction in air-traffic noise, said that he was surprised to hear of the change, and that he did not think residents had detected a difference.
But, he said, Ms. Shulman was pleased that the F.A.A. was taking steps to disperse aircraft better. The second measure that has been started affected Westchester County. There, helicopter pilots voluntarily began flying 600 feet higher several months ago after a public hearing established that helicopter noise was a major concern.
Joel F. Russell, manager of the Westchester County Airport, said that step had helped reduce noise and that a second planned change, creating a new approach over Long Island Sound, was already in informal use.
 
Quieter Planes Coming
 Mr. Steucke of the Federal agency said that, through noise reduction training, air traffic controllers are reminded of ways to protect residents from noise. For instance, he said, a controller, concerned about guiding the next aircraft, might simply send an outgoing plane over the most obvious route. Instead, Mr. Steucke said, "If he had flown 1.5 minutes longer, he could have been out over water rather than over houses."
The most significant reduction in air traffic noise, Mr. Steucke said, will take place gradually over the next eight years, as the airline industry phases out noisy aircraft in favor of quieter ones, in compliance with Federal regulations.
By the year 2000, he said, the number of people in the region exposed to "significant aviation noise" will decline from about 700,000 to 100,000.
The Port Authority is studying the economic impact of requiring that the quieter planes be phased in faster, said Lloyd Schwalb, a Port Authority spokesman.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Point Man on Economics

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
From among a welter of advisers, a noneconomist -- Robert B. Reich of Harvard's Kennedy School of Government -- is emerging as one who has President-elect Bill Clinton's ear on economic policy.
The two are struggling with ideas that appear to go well beyond the market-oriented economics that became standard in the Reagan and Bush years. 
 After little more than a week as chief of the team preparing a menu of economic actions for the President-elect to choose from, Mr. Reich is the only economic adviser with daily access to Mr. Clinton, people in the Clinton camp say. Mr. Reich has worked with the President-elect in Little Rock, Ark., since last weekend and traveled with him to Washington on Wednesday.
Mr. Reich says that he and Mr. Clinton have engaged in a running discussion about economic policies and politics since their days together as Rhodes Scholars at Oxford and classmates at Yale Law School. The President-elect has read Mr. Reich's books and articles. Mr. Reich's key role in Mr. Clinton's thinking is likely to continue, the President-elect's advisers say, even if Mr. Reich returns to Harvard in January, as he says he will do.
 
Candidate to Head Council
 But Mr. Reich has been mentioned as a candidate for chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, which under Mr. Reich would undoubtedly take on a bigger role in a Clinton Administration, similar in stature to what it was when Walter Heller was chairman under President John F. Kennedy and Kennedy's most trusted economic adviser.
Mr. Reich's new position and his ties to Mr. Clinton clearly suggest that the President-elect is already relying on Mr. Reich as his chief thinker on economics. "He wanted someone he could trust and who could mediate among a wide array of advisers," Mr. Reich said of the President-elect.
Inevitably, Mr. Reich's priorities seem likely to appear in the brokerage process, and those priorities have begun to take Mr. Clinton in a different economic direction from that of the Reagan and Bush years.
In the Reich scheme of things, evident in Mr. Clinton's campaign literature and now in the post-election planning, interest rates, for example, cannot be separated from education or job training, highway repair from product prices, taxes from trade policy, or Government-financed research from Corporate America's competitiveness.
The Reagan and Bush Administrations, in contrast, concentrated on taxes, interest rates, the budget deficit, the unemployment rate and inflation -- the standard themes of America's mainstream economists. The hope was that if economic policy could get these elements right, then the private sector would boom and take care of all the other issues.
"Certainly for the last 12 years, the message has been only for the Government to get out of the way, and here is a message that now says it should get involved," said Robert Z. Lawrence, a Harvard economist. "Reich represents that approach as well as anyone in the country."
Some economists point out that Mr. Reich is not alone in developing a broader economic menu, though he is Mr. Clinton's main representative in the process and his frequent appearances as a television talk-show guest have popularized his economics. "I think that we have been crossing an intellectual watershed in economic policy, away from a belief in the magic of the marketplace toward a belief that markets are very good but not perfect things and they sometimes need a little help from Government," said Paul Krugman, an economist at Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Mr. Reich's contribution to this process is most evident in his book "The Work of Nations," published in 1991. It argues, in effect, that for the United States to prosper, it must become a center for the most advanced production. Companies, both foreign and American, will locate such operations here only if the nation offers components like highly educated people, advanced technology and much-upgraded transportation and communications systems -- all projects that require a government role.
Although the general approach of Mr. Reich is increasingly shared by others, his specific work has nevertheless been criticized by trained economists, mostly on the ground that he is a lawyer, not a Ph.D. in economics, and his insights lack the rigor and precision that economists provide through their training in mathematics and economic theory.
That criticism has been one reason that Mr. Reich, who is on leave from Harvard, has failed to get a tenured professorship at the Kennedy School, where he has been a lecturer in political economy for more than a decade, under a contract renewed every few years. In the last year, the school offered Mr. Reich a lifetime contract as a lecturer, no longer subject to faculty review. Mr. Reich has not yet responded to the offer, which falls short of full tenure.
"We would be delighted to have him stay until he retires," said Albert Carnesale, dean of the Kennedy School.
Still, the criticism of Mr. Reich's credentials in economics has intensified with his appointment last week as chief of the economics transition team. He has countered by declaring that he is seeking advice from numerous trained economists and is relying in particular on Lawrence Summers, who began a leave of absence on Thursday as chief economist at the World Bank to join Mr. Reich.
"All of us hold Larry Summers in high regard, and he will be very important," said Gene Sperling, who was Mr. Clinton's economic coordinator in the Presidential campaign and is now Mr. Reich's deputy. And from Robert Hall, a Stanford University professor and often a spokesman for university economists, came this expression of relief: "Reich is an enigma to economists, and I am glad Larry Summers is there. I have a great deal of confidence in Larry."
 
Skepticism On Wall Street
 Mr. Reich is also criticized on Wall Street. Any policy that seems to get away from inflation or the threat of it as the main economic issue tends to make the nation's security markets nervous, and Mr. Reich, for this reason, is not a favorite on Wall Street.
"I was surprised at his appointment," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment firm. "My own sense was that Mr. Clinton would make a real effort in the transition to broaden his base. And he is not going to get that with Reich."
In an interview, Mr. Reich, 46 years old, offered an example of the questions his team is trying to answer for Mr. Clinton. The President-elect's infrastructure program includes as one possibility a new national fiber-optics telecommunications network. Would private industry undertake the project if the Clinton Administration "unknotted" regulations that companies consider costly obstacles?
If not, what is the minimum the Government must spend to get the network started in 1993 or 1994? Would a fiber-optic network have a greater multiplier effect -- create more jobs and more economic growth -- than highway repair or a high-speed rail system? Each of these options will be subject to the sort of technical analysis that Mr. Summers represents. And under Mr. Reich's direction, similar alternatives and answers are to be developed in other fields, like labor, education, health insurance and trade policy.
Despite the criticisms of Mr. Reich heard in the economics establishment, there are those within it who stand up for him.
"I have had to do a lot of defending of Bob Reich to my professional colleagues in the last few months, and one thing I have said is that the Reich of 1992 is not the Reich of 1982, who stood much more for an industrial policy in which cutting-edge industries were targeted for special government help," said Alan Blinder, a Princeton University economist and a sometime adviser to the Clinton camp. "My defense is greeted with different degrees of skepticism."

HEADLINE: Experience Required, but Not Too Much of It;
For Job Applicants 55 and Over, the Search for Employment Is Often Frustrating

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
Thomas McGovern walked into the job fair in midtown Manhattan clutching his glossy leather briefcase and chasing a dream he had deferred for decades. Since he sold his liquor business two years ago, he has been searching for a job as a paralegal, to get a start in the profession he was too poor to join as a young man with family obligations.
Now, at the age of 63, after about a hundred unsuccessful applications, he wonders if he waited too long. 
 "I don't know if it's because of age," Mr. McGovern said. "They haven't said anything, but you always get a feeling, the way the interview goes."
The special disadvantages -- and, they would hasten to add, the considerable advantages -- of being an aging job applicant were very much on the minds of Mr. McGovern and more than 900 others who attended the job fair for people 55 and older, held at the Roosevelt Hotel this week. They were not frisky college graduates: Some had white hair, canes and a need every now and then to sit and rest. But they also had decades of experience and a finely honed work ethic.
Economists say that the corporate restructuring that took place in the New York City region during the 1980's, which has accelerated during the current recession, has particularly affected aging workers. Traditionally such workers have held onto their jobs, even in tough times, because of seniority.
But as companies restructured to cut costs and compete better, they began thinning out the ranks of middle managers.
"Middle management tends to be middle aged and older," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "So the shifts in corporate structure have hit particularly hard at men in the middle ages and older."
Once out of a job, older people have a harder time finding a new one. "There's still a lot of prejudice against older people," said Patricia A. Dorin, coordinator of the New York State Department of Labor's Older Worker Program. Almost 500,000 of the city's workers are 55 or older.
Unemployment among people 55 and older in New York City remains lower than it is among all workers. But it has risen in recent years. Although unemployment overall in New York City declined by 4.4 percent, to 8.6 percent, between 1981 and 1991, it jumped by 61 percent in the older group, to 6.3 percent, according to Mr. Ehrenhalt.
Nationally, unemployment also rose among people 55 and older, though less markedly -- from 3.6 percent in 1981 to 3.9 percent in 1991. In October, it stood at 5 percent, compared with 7.4 percent for the population as a whole.
Robert Rheinstein, who is 63 and was laid off as a construction company project manager, did not express his loss in macroeconomic terms.
"I got satisfaction out of work and enjoyed the challenge and personal relation that went with it, and I'm not ready to give that up," he said. Plus, he said, "I need the money."
He came to the job fair seeking "work which is challenging, responsible and that can use my 40 years of experience." But he had held only two different jobs during those 40 years, he said, and he didn't really know how to find a new one.
Even for people who voluntarily leave the work force, retirement can be a disappointment. "If you're just going to sit down and suck your thumb, you might as well give up and take a cyanide pill," said Thomas Sheehan, 64, a former executive in an automotive-leasing company who, after a heart attack and two strokes, came to the fair leaning on a cane.
Since the work force is expected to shrink as the baby boomers age, pushing people to retire by age 65 seems not only unfair but economically wrong headed, some economists and advocates for the elderly said.
"We have a whole set of institutional assumptions about age and retirement that date back a half century," said Mr. Ehrenhalt, who is 67.
Some, of course, cannot afford to retire. Olympia Kitchen, who is 78, quit her job as a computer programmer in Tallahassee, Fla., in 1981 and moved to New York City to take care of her ailing mother. Her mother lingered nine years, exhausting Ms. Kitchen's savings. Her rent consumes most of her Social Security.
She came to the job fair wearing her "corporate outfit" -- pinstripe suit, grey blouse, red cloth rose peeking out of her breast pocket -- but she was not aiming high.
"To survive, to meet my expenses, I have to work, so I don't become homeless, so I don't get put on welfare," she said, beginning to cry. "I'll do anything -- I'll sell apples on the street corner. I have damn good experience, and this is what it's resolved to."
Case studies released last year by the Commonwealth Fund, a nonprofit research foundation, found that, contrary to stereotypes, older workers learned to use computers as quickly as younger ones, stayed on the job longer and took fewer sick days. Employers at the job fair said those were the sorts of benefits they hoped to cash in on.
"They know what to expect," said Leslie Julich, senior human-resources specialist for Empire Insurance Company. "You're not going to be in love with your boss, you're not going to be best friends with everyone you work with."
The only problem older applicants posed for her, she said, cropped up in the interviews. "A lot of times they treat me as if I'm their daughter," said Ms. Julich, who is 30. "That respect thing sort of goes out the window."
For the most part, people were not hired at the job fair. Instead, they had the chance to drop off their often lengthy resumes with 35 different employers, from the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell to the Ford Foundation. In addition, the New York City Department for the Aging, which sponsored the fair, offered seminars on polishing a resume and other marketing techniques.
The backgrounds of those who attended the fair ranged widely, but the ambitions of most did not seem grandiose. Jin Zhenduo, a 61-year-old Chinese immigrant who was a chemical engineer in his native country, came to the fair hoping to find work as a handyman or an elevator operator. Phyllis Black, 57, who has been trained in a computer class run by the Department for the Aging, said she would "love to do anything with computers."
"I don't want to set the world on fire," she said. "I just want to do a good, competent job."
Some, like Jagen Gulati, were looking to stick with a career they already knew. Mr. Gulati, 65, was a legal secretary in India before immigrating to the United States in 1991. He carried photocopies of his Bachelor of Arts degree from an Indian university, said he could type 75 words per minute and take down 125 in shorthand and, like several others at the fair, asked a reporter if he might have a job for him. "I am very proficient in my work; I've worked all my life," he said.
He said that he suspects his age is stopping employers from hiring him. "I am feeling very bad; in a country where opportunity is advertised, there is nothing," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: More than 900 people age 55 and older attended a jobs fair this week at the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan at which 35 employers took resumes. Luis Medina, 76, who has been out of work for more than a year, sought work as a bookkeeper. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fed Policy Left Unchanged

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
A divided Federal Reserve policy-making panel decided at an Oct. 6 meeting to leave monetary policy unchanged, although it leaned toward lower interest rates if the economy showed signs of ebbing, according to minutes released today.
Members of the Federal Open Market Committee reviewed information suggesting that "economic activity was expanding at a subdued pace," the minutes of the meeting said. 
 But they "generally agreed that current uncertainties made an assessment of the economic outlook and determination of an appropriate course for monetary policy particularly difficult," the minutes said.
Because of the uncertainty, the panel, by an 8-to-4 vote, said it supported a directive that left monetary policy unchanged but "included a decided presumption of some easing" if the economy did not improve.
The Fed has not acted to lower interest rates since the meeting. The central bank may have been influenced in October by the approach of the elections on Nov. 3. Many analysts had said any action by the Fed before the elections would have had political implications.
The Open Market Committee met again this week, but its meetings are closed to the public. Minutes of this week's meeting will not be released until late December.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: The Economy;
Aides Say Clinton Might Back Deficit Spending as Growth Stimulus

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 20

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton might favor increasing the budget deficit in this fiscal year to stimulate the economy and generate new jobs quickly, members of his staff said today.
George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's spokesman, told reporters that the President-elect and Congressional leaders had agreed during Mr. Clinton's visit to Washington this week on a two-pronged approach: an economic stimulus, like new public works spending, to give an immediate jolt to the economy combined with deficit reduction "over the long haul." 
 Mr. Stephanopoulos and others on the transition staff said no decisions had been made about how to achieve those two goals or whether increasing the short-term deficit would be wise. They suggested that to help the economy this winter the new Administration could take some quick steps that would not affect the annual deficit. One such step would be to speed the spending of highway construction money that is now scheduled to be spent later in the fiscal year that ends Sept. 30.
 
Few Tools Available
 In the past, such modest measures have proved to have little effect on the economy. As an economic rule, the only tools Mr. Clinton and lawmakers will have to spur growth quickly and induce a sudden surge of new jobs will be overall tax cuts and spending increases that would raise the deficit in this fiscal year.
When pressed, Mr. Stephanopoulos acknowledged that Mr. Clinton had not ruled out an increase in this year's deficit. But he said Mr. Clinton was determined to fulfill his campaign promise to halve the annual deficit, now nearly $300 billion, by the end of his four-year term.
Mr. Clinton arrived here in a downpour early this morning after spending two days in Washington meeting with President Bush, Congressional leaders and other officials and attending social functions in the evenings.
The President-elect made no public appearances today and plans none for the weekend. On Monday, he is flying to Georgia to campaign for Senator Wyche Fowler Jr., the Democrat in a run-off election on Tuesday.
 
Going Over the Cabinet
 Mr. Stephanopoulos said Mr. Clinton met today with Warren M. Christopher, the transition director, "to go through Cabinet departments one by one and look at memorandums."
Mr. Clinton's economic advisers continued to review the state of the budget and to prepare a strategy for dealing with the economy immediately on taking office.
In theory, Mr. Clinton and Congress could lock themselves into procedures that guaranteed deficit reduction, say, in 1994 and 1995, while allowing the deficit to rise in 1993.
But in practice, previous attempts to legislate deficit reduction years down the road, no matter how well intentioned, have proved futile. The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings laws of 1985 and 1987 set five-year deficit ceilings that seemed plausible when they were enacted but were quickly breached.
Similarly, the deficit has continued to rise yearly despite rigid controls enacted in the budget law two years ago.
If Mr. Clinton does allow the deficit to rise in this fiscal year and if the markets doubt that his long-term plan to lower the deficit will work, then interest rates are likely to rise. Higher interest rates would inhibit business activity, and that could offset the President's efforts to create jobs.
Mr. Clinton's capacity to reduce the deficit would be seriously hampered if he sticks by his campaign pledge to give tax cuts to families with incomes below about $80,000 a year, but Mr. Stephanopoulos said the promise had not been abandoned.
"Governor Clinton said throughout the campaign that it was his plan to put people first, and he intended to propose a middle-class tax cut, and there's nothing to change," the spokesman told reporters.
On another matter, Mr. Stephanopoulos said that Mr. Clinton, like his recent predecessors, would accept private donations to help finance the transition. Under a 1964 law, Mr. Clinton is entitled to $3.5 million to cover transition expenses, but in the last several transitions that amount has proved insufficient.
Mr. Stephanopoulos said a limit would be placed on how much donors could contribute.

GRAPHIC: Photo: George Stephanopoulos, spokesman for Bill Clinton, said yesterday in Little Rock, Ark., that the President-elect and Congressional leaders had agreed to use an economic stimulus like new public works spending combined with long-term deficit reduction. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Freeing Drivers From the Ghost of Gridlock Past

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
As surely as snow will fall in Buffalo and squirrels will hide nuts, November brings signs of what every New Yorker fondly knows as the Holidays. A Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center. Menorahs in store windows. Gridlock alert days.
Alas for the harried commuter: one of these is no longer. (Hint: the tree is up and no embargo has been declared on menorahs.) 
 Yes, the end-of-the-year gridlock alert day, a New York holiday fixture for a decade, has been discontinued, a victim of the recession and its own effectiveness.
The city Department of Transportation says traffic has declined enough in recent years to make public announcements urging motorists to stay out of Manhattan unnecessary.
"It doesn't take a rocket scientist to know the traffic is heavy" during the holidays, said Joseph DePlasco, a spokesman for the Transportation Department. "People aren't flying at radar speed, but traffic is moving."
Created in 1982, gridlock alert days grew as Manhattan traffic became increasingly congested in the booming economy. By last year, there were 14 gridlock alert days, 9 of which fell between mid-November and the New Year. By city tradition, yesterday was the first of the holiday season. Over the years, officials have noticed a significant increase in traffic on the Friday before Thanksgiving.
But in the last two years, as jobs have been lost, traffic has declined by 2 percent, Mr. DePlasco said. Holiday traffic, usually 10 percent heavier than the daily average of 870,000 cars, is down even more, he said.
Gridlock alerts will not vanish completely: the city will issue a warning for Dec. 2, when the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree is lighted. It will continue to issue warnings for special events, like visits by the President.
Yesterday, there was both praise and criticism for the demise of a holiday tradition.
For the owners of parking garages and midtown Manhattan businesses, the annual traffic warnings meant their most car-dependent customers would be driven away. They were delighted to see gridlock alert go.
"In parking garages, business was down 30 percent on gridlock alert days," said Hugh M. Heller, general counsel to the Metropolitan Garage Owners Association, which has been lobbying for an end to the public announcements for six years. "Instead of relatively fewer people, nobody came in. I would always drive on gridlock alert days."
But some fans of gridlock alert, dubbed "traffic mavens" by the Department of Transportation, asked whether the city let itself be swayed by business interests to the detriment of environmental concerns.
"Traffic levels may have flattened out, but that just means we are frozen at record levels," said Gene Russianoff, a lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, an advocacy group for mass transit. "I'll be sorry to see them go. They had a certain New York quality to them."
Samuel I. Schwartz, who helped initiate gridlock alerts in 1982 while he was Deputy Commissioner of Transportation, said he plans to continue issuing the holiday warnings in his traffic column in The Daily News.
"Traffic did go down on gridlock alert days," Mr. Schwartz said. "But we weren't creating a ghost town in midtown Manhattan. People were switching to mass transit. And that is a good goal."
Mr. DePlasco said the city was "conscious of the recession" when it decided to discontinue the holiday traffic alerts. "But there was nothing conspiratorial about it," he said.
So, was midtown traffic any worse yesterday in the absence of a gridlock alert? No, said parking lot managers. Yes, said drivers.
"Every day is gridlock to me," said Ron Roth, an insurance broker from Manhattan as he sat in a line outside a West 46th Street parking garage. "People don't drive in Manhattan because they want to, they drive because they have to."

HEADLINE: Unhappy Accord in Trenton on Health Care for Indigent

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Ending weeks of frequently strained negotiations, Gov. Jim Florio and the Republican leaders in the Legislature today announced a plan to divert $1.6 billion from the state's unemployment insurance fund to restore New Jersey's outlawed system for financing health care for indigent patients.
The plan, under attack from labor and business groups alike and called "inadvisable" by the Federal Department of Labor, now goes before both houses of the Legislature for a vote on Nov. 30. The outcome has grown increasingly uncertain. 
 Conceding that the plan "may not be anyone's first choice," Mr. Florio said that he "cannot let the entire health-care system in this state collapse," and therefore would sign the legislation if it reached his desk unless a workable alternative was presented within 10 days.
In a separate statement, the Republican leaders, Senate President Donald T. DiFranceso and Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, said, "Shifting money earmarked for the unemployed from the compensation fund to a hospital fund that pays bills for the unemployed and working poor is an appropriate use."
 
Hospital Rates Deregulated
 The plan agreed upon today would create a new health-care tax while lowering unemployment taxes by the same amount, and its supporters say it would raise $1.6 billion over three years. If the unemployment fund, now at $2.4 billion, drops below $1.5 billion, the unemployment tax on employers will increase by six-tenths of 1 percent of their total payrolls.
The plan would deregulate hospital rates and impose limits on hospital revenues, requiring all but urban and teaching hospitals to absorb into their basic rates the costs of bad debts and charity care.
The plan drew wide criticism. "It is not popular with the business people; it is not popular with labor," said Bruce Coe, president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, a lobbying group. "They have come up with the only thing politically they can do at this time."
Mr. Coe's group initially objected to some parts of the plan, but he left today's meeting supporting the idea after officials said they would impose a three-year limit on the use of the unemployment fund.
 
10 Days Before Deadline
 The compromise came just 10 days before the Nov. 30 deadline Mr. Florio, a Democrat, and the Republican leaders had imposed on themselves for approving a new plan to deal with the health-care crisis.
There are 823,000 indigent people without health insurance in New Jersey. Their hospital bills have been paid through a 19.1 percent surcharge on the hospital bills of insured patients. But the system, known as the Uncompensated Care Trust Fund, was thrown into chaos in May when Judge Alfred M. Wolin of Federal District Court in Newark, acting on a lawsuit brought by 14 unions, barred the state from imposing the surcharge on self-insured groups. Those groups account for 40 percent of all insured patients.
People covered by Medicare, who account for another 40 percent of insured patients, were not required to pay the surcharge. That meant that the remaining 20 percent of insured patients, most of them individual policyholders, would have to pay about $900 million this year for indigent patient care.
Mr. Florio, Mr. DiFrancesco and Mr. Haytaian announced the compromise after a two-hour meeting with labor and business leaders that one of the non-governmental officials involved described as "highly intense."
 
Foes Equally Unhappy
 James Kirk, vice president of the State A.F.L.-C.I.O., left the meeting stony-faced and visibly angry.
"Labor is not happy with the compromise," said Mr. Kirk, who was joined in his criticism by William R. Healey, an assistant vice president of the State Chamber of Commerce.
"We are together on some things, and this is one of them," said Mr. Healey. "We felt a sales tax would be the fairest possible way."
The chamber had enthusiastically backed the Republicans in June when they overrode a gubernatorial veto and rolled the sales tax back from 7 percent to 6 percent. "But the Wolin decision came about a week later," Mr. Wolin added.
New Jersey is one of only three states -- the others are Pennsylvania and Alaska -- in which employees as well as employers contribute to the unemployment insurance fund.
 
Least Onerous Solution
 The idea of tapping into the fund has been seen as the least onerous of several solutions the Governor and legislative leaders have considered since Judge Wolin invalidated the 12-year-old health care system. But the compromise plan has an uncertain chance of success.
The idea that two of the state's most powerful lobbying groups, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Chamber of Commerce, are aligned against the bill is enough to give some legislators pause. Even more troubling to lawmakers is a concern that the plan could imperil the unemployment insurance fund.
The $2.4 billion unemployment insurance fund is the second biggest in the country, after California's, according to the Federal Department of Labor. But it is ranked 33d in its reserves after paying claims, according to a Labor Department formula, and a bipartisan state commission recommended in 1988 that the fund be increased to $3.7 billion.

HEADLINE: A Trade War Averted

 BODY:
The trade deal reached yesterday by the U.S. and the European Community ends a bitter six-year dispute over European farm subsidies. The agreement not only averts a ruinous trade war, but also unleashes the all-important international trade talks, known as the Uruguay Round, that were stalled by the farm dispute. Yesterday's settlement will benefit consumers around the world.
Though details are sketchy, the agreement appears to be a reasonable compromise. Neither France, the most recalcitrant of the European nations, nor the U.S. got everything it wanted, but each got something important. 
 The French largely prevailed on soybeans, whose subsidized production by the Europeans violated previous trade commitments with the U.S. Soybean acreage will be limited, but not soybean production, an approach the U.S. fears won't produce sufficiently large cutbacks.
But disputes will be settled by binding arbitration -- a mechanism the U.S. had sought but the E.C. had refused to accept. And on grain production, the U.S. won substantial cutbacks in subsidized E.C. exports, providing ample relief for beleaguered American farmers.
The agreement represents a major achievement for the Bush Administration in its waning days. The Administration gambled by imposing stiff tariffs on selected E.C. exports, including white wine, in retaliation for Europe's refusal to live by its commitments on soybean production.
That introduced the very real danger that the European Community might retaliate with its own tariffs on U.S. exports -- igniting a trade war that could devastate economies already on the brink of recession.
With yesterday's agreement, however, the danger is over. Now Mr. Bush can move swiftly to settle the Uruguay Round negotiations. That would strip away protectionist barriers in all 108 of the world's trading partners, generate $200 billion of new international trade -- and provide a glorious end to Mr. Bush's reign.

HEADLINE: Veto the Chiropractors' Power Play

 BODY:
Score one for the special-interest lobbyists. The New York State Legislature has sent to Gov. Mario Cuomo a bill that would require group health insurance policies to include unlimited chiropractic services. The bill has everything to do with the lobbying power of the American Chiropractic Association -- and nothing to do with proper health care. It deserves a swift veto.
Recent studies in Britain and the U.S. show that chiropractic care for some types of lower back and other musculoskeletal pain is cost-effective, but that other services are not demonstrably better than a placebo. Currently, insurers can let customers decide which, if any, chiropractic services they want covered. But if the Legislature gets its way, everyone in a group plan will be forced to pay for the entire range of chiropractic services. 
 The bill would add an estimated $160 million a year to premiums of Blue Cross and Blue Shield subscribers. It would drive up health care costs, at a time when those skyrocketing costs are already the number one domestic financial crisis. By adding to insurance costs the bill would drive some employers to drop group insurance, leaving families vulnerable to financial disaster from the next medical catastrophe.
The bill should make chiropractors deliriously happy. Once workers are covered for an unlimited range of services, they can be expected to start using them. And even though employers pay the premiums, they take the extra costs out of each worker's paycheck.
This bill reeks of special pleading. Governor Cuomo: Show no mercy.

HEADLINE: Rooting for Russian Reform

 BODY:
Soaring inflation and plunging production have provided opponents of reform in Russia with plenty of ammunition with which to attack President Boris Yeltsin and his reformist allies at the upcoming Congress of People's Deputies. But don't count Mr. Yeltsin out yet. He is allying with reform-minded industrial managers in an effort to beat back the hard-liners.
Last weekend he lashed out at "scandalous" opposition groups backed by "practically no social base, and not many ideas" who "seek to sow panic, to destroy reforms, to wring from that some political capital." That was a bold rebuff to the hard-liners. But it was also a caution to the industrial managers not to demand too high a price from him for their support. 
 If Mr. Yeltsin succeeds, he could keep market reforms from being destroyed by hyperinflation. And he could keep the checks and balances of crude democracy from being overwhelmed by resurgent authoritarianism.
The 1,000-member People's Congress convenes on Dec. 1. Like the Parliament, its deputies were chosen before last year's abortive coup and the breakup of the Soviet Union, even before Mr. Yeltsin was elected President. The Congress is packed with former party hacks, who have joined with nationalists to form the National Salvation Front in opposition to Mr. Yeltsin.
President Yeltsin tried to keep Parliament from convening the Congress, but failed. And he hasn't dared to dissolve it and call for new elections. Instead he's been enacting reforms by decree, which Parliament has criticized but not overruled. His authority to issue such decrees lapses the day the Congress convenes.
Despite the talk of coups, the real danger is a vote of no confidence in Prime Minister Yegor Gaidar's Government, which would be tantamount to repudiation of reform.
The reform-minded industrialists may settle for less drastic personnel changes. But they also need to give up easy money policies. Such policies may be keeping many state-owned factories afloat for now, but could generate hyperinflation that would force a shutdown of production.
Mr. Yeltsin's coalition with the industrialists won't keep the Congress from trying to throw more sand in the gears of reform. But it could keep the reform process from grinding to a halt. Americans, lacking leverage, can do little more in this winter of Russian discontent than root for reform.

HEADLINE: Reform Defense Now

BYLINE: By Gary Hart; Gary Hart, a Democrat and a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee from 1975 to 1987, is co-author of "America Can Win: The Case for Military Reform."

DATELINE: KITTREDGE, Colo.

 BODY:
If war, to paraphrase Clausewitz, is the continuation of national policy by other means, then the triumph of democracy in the cold war without bloodshed must rank as one of history's greatest military victories. The question now is what to do with our military. There are three options: our military structures can be maintained, they can be reduced or they can be reformed. The Clinton Administration should choose reform.
This option sounds easier than it is. No modern nation has reformed its military without a major military defeat. The military is a disciplined, well-entrenched bureaucracy with enormous economic and industrial power. George Bush's promise of new contracts for F-15's and F-16's for foreign sales and Bill Clinton's support for those sales along with his commitment to the Seawolf submarine and the V-22 Osprey -- none of which are necessary for our future security -- testify to the military's power. 
 To complicate matters further, defenders of the military cite the success of the Persian Gulf war as evidence that the armed forces don't need reform. But if victory is defined by the achievement of the strategic objective -- the removal of Saddam Hussein -- then Desert Storm cannot be considered a major victory.
The military must be reformed to prepare the U.S. for the post-cold-war world. The Clinton Administration has an opportunity to carry out these reforms. Indeed, given fiscal realities, it may have little choice.
Reformers believe that our national security priorities are people, then strategy, tactics and doctrine, and, finally, weapons. People win wars, weapons don't. This truth was lost or misplaced in the cold war because of the intense political hypnosis such high-tech weapons as Aegis cruisers and "smart" bombs produced. This mismatch of technology to threat is illustrated by our use of F-117 stealth aircraft in the Panama invasion.
Military educational institutions -- from West Point to the National War College -- must learn to stress military history and theory instead of engineering, math and rote learning. Annapolis requires only one semester of military history for graduation. West Point requires two.
Contrary to present practice, officers must be promoted on the basis of leadership in combat and in the field and for their willingness to innovate under pressure. Right now, it's easier for officers to get ahead by carrying out routine staff assignments.
Moreover, enlisted personnel switch companies too often. These high troop rotations should be replaced with a type of regimental system, which would keep servicemen and women in one place long enough to develop esprit and comradeship. Currently, our turnover rate of 25 percent per quarter in an infantry company is one of the highest rotation rates of any military power in the world.
The best personnel must have the best military doctrines. Maneuver warfare, with its emphasis on initiative by local commanders, decentralized command, mobility and goal orientation, must replace the traditional attrition doctrines that emphasize trading men and materiel with the enemy. Our strategies must also take advantage of our natural maritime circumstances. We are an island nation, but our forces are structured as if we were a land power.
Even if people and doctrines are reformed, we are still stuck with weapons designed for a confrontation with the former Soviet Union and Warsaw Pact. We have a huge Air Force and giant ships, as well as tanks and other land weapons designed to fight a war in Central Europe.
The threat of the future is in regional and local conflicts (possibly nuclear), guerrilla insurgencies and terrorist operations. Thus, we need versatile weapons that will work on the varied battlefields of the future. Our Navy should be expanded to include a coastal fleet of amphibious ships, minesweepers and small diesel-powered submarines. We can increase our flexibility on land with light-armored vehicles and aircraft, such as the A-10, that are designed for low-altitude bombing and strafing.
Even before the cold war's close, our armed forces were in desperate need of reform. Now, Bill Clinton has a historic chance to carry out major military reforms without bloodshed or political recrimination.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: THE TRADE ACCORD: EUROPEANS AGREE WITH U.S. ON CUTTING FARM SUBSIDIES;
FRENCH WITHHOLD SUPPORT;
2 SIDES COMPROMISE

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
After six tortuous years of confrontation, the United States and the European Community found a compromise today on how to reduce farm subsidies, clearing the way for broader world trade talks to proceed.
 In France, which has been uncompromising in its opposition to American demands, Agriculture Minister Jean-Pierre Soisson quickly said he could not accept the deal. But he stopped short of saying his country would invoke its right under community rules to veto the agreement. 
The Bush Administration, which is eager to see the trade talks progress, sought to play down the likelihood of a French veto. Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan said tonight that he had been assured by Europe's negotiators that the French objections would not derail the deal.
 
French Vow to Protest
 France is the community's largest producer and exporter of food, and its farmers, a potent political force, have vowed to organize demonstrations against the deal across the length and breadth of the country.
 But Mr. Madigan, in his optimistic appraisal, noted that the European Commission, the executive branch of the community, had endorsed the agreement today. The commission is headed by Jacques Delors, who is expected to run for president of France in 1994 and who has been accused in recent weeks by some Europeans of undercutting trade negotiations to advance France's cause.
 Today's compromise calls for deep cuts in the European Community's subsidized grain exports and subsidized production of soybeans and other oilseed crops. It averts a trade war that would have started with punitive American taxes on European white wine, and might have spread to many other products.
 
Imperiled Global Talks
 Facing a Dec. 5 deadline, when the American import taxes of 200 percent would have taken effect, both sides blinked. The United States accepted far more modest subsidy restraints than it had initially sought, and the Europeans agreed to across-the-board limits on farm subsidies, which they had refused to consider for more than two decades.
 The imposition of sanctions would have killed the prospects for broader world trade talks, which began six years ago in Uruguay and have tried to stitch the world's economies more closely together by eliminating barriers to trade in corn, wheat and a broad range of goods and financial and telecommunications services.
 But the progress announced today does not assure that these broader negotiations will be successfully concluded.
 Among the remaining obstacles are disputes between the United States and the European Community over shipping and television programs, Japan's refusal to drop its ban on rice imports, and the reluctance of poor countries to allow entry to banks and other financial institutions from wealthier countries.
 The announcement of the compromise on farm supports was made almost simultaneously in Brussels, by Frans Andriessen, the community's Minister of External Affairs, and at the White House by President Bush. It represents a poignant achievement for Mr. Bush, coming 17 days after his re-election defeat and a day after the death of his mother.
 Three months ago, Mr. Bush announced the completion of a North American Free Trade Agreement, which would eliminate tariffs and other trade barriers among the United States, Canada and Mexico. The two accords, if eventually confirmed by all parties, would lay the foundation for the most sweeping change in world trade rules since President Harry S. Truman oversaw the establishment of the current system after World War II.
 President-elect Bill Clinton and most Congressional leaders said today that they would have to study the details of the arrangement before they could endorse or condemn it. The American Farm Bureau Federation, the broadest American farm group, criticized the provision that limits European subsidies on oilseeds, which are used to make vegetable oils and animal feed, while giving lukewarm praise to the compromise on grain exports.
 The politically powerful American Soybean Association strongly criticized the agreement, saying it accepted European oilseed production "above any position supported or endorsed by any U.S. farm group."
 But Gary P. Riedel, the association's chairman, predicted that his group, which is based in St. Louis, would eventually support the pact.
 
Action Shifts to Geneva
 The deal annnounced today included a binding agreement on production of oilseeds and a separate, draft agreement with many provisions on broad farm subsidy issues.
 The next step is for trade officials from the United States, the 12 nations of the European Community and 92 other countries to descend on the GATT headquarters in Geneva and begin trying to pound out the details of the overall pact.
 The draft agreement, which calls for a 21 percent reduction in the international tonnage of subsidized grain exports, now goes to Geneva. The United States and the community hope it will be adopted as the main text of the agricultural section of the overall GATT agreement.
 The pace of the approval process is important. In March, 18-year-old American legislation will expire that has allowed Presidents to negotiate trade agreements and submit them for consideration by Congress with no amendments permitted.
 But while the United States has been eager to press ahead, France has been reluctant to draft an overall agreement before its general elections in March.
 And some European officials have been nervous that the Clinton Administration might not seek a renewal of this "fast track" legislation, or might carry through on campaign promises to pursue a more confrontational approach on trade.
 During the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton expressed support for the broad goals of liberalizing world trade, but also said he believed the United States should take strong action against nations whose trade barriers block American exports.
 With so much at stake and so many competing national interests, it is far from clear whether the many remaining obstacles to an overall deal can be cleared away before President Bush leaves office. If a deal is reached after that point, Mr. Clinton would have to decide whether to support it or seek renegotiation.
 Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, has feared that if a world trade agreement and the North American pact go to Congress at the same time, lawmakers will have the opportunity to be free traders on one but vote onbehalf of local protectionist interests on the other. A North Carolina representative, for example, might vote for the North American agreement, which textile interests support, but against a GATT agreement, because it would expose textile companies that are currently protected to open competition from India and other poor countries.
 Even if compromises can be reached quickly in Geneva on the outstanding disputes, the necessary legal language will take at least two more months to draft.
 Before today's agreement, professions of optimism have alternated for months, even years, with unsuccessful negotiations on liberalizing world trade. At three different economic summit meetings of heads of state, and at innumerable meetings of trade officials, talks started, sputtered and ended in deadlock. Other trans-Atlantic pacts, such as one earlier this year on aircraft production subsidies, have fallen apart after they were announced and had to be stitched back together.
 In the end, the United States, which began by calling for an end to all farm subsidies, made significant concessions today on oilseeds in order to strike a better deal on grain-export subsidies and other issues.
 The United States had sought a European promise to reduce oilseed production to 8 million metric tons, from 12.8 million tons last year. But American officials settled for a European commitment to reduce the acreage reserved for oilseeds by 15 percent next year and by at least 10 percent permanently.
 Mr. Madigan said that provision -- combined with changes last year in the structure of European subsidies that discourage producing a lot of food on each acre -- would cut output to 8.5 million to 9.7 million tons. But European yields per acre this year, after the change in the structure of subsidies, suggest that actual production may be at the high end of this range.
 On grain, the United States had been seeking a 24 percent reduction over six years in the tonnage of European subsidized exports, while the European Community had advocated a reduction of only 18 percent. The final figure of 21 percent over six years appeared to split the difference, and was presented as such by Mr. Madigan.
 But the final deal also used a new system for calculating the reduction, making it the equivalent of 23 percent in terms of the previous offers.
 The effects of today's agreement in the United States will vary by region. South of an east-west line that runs through Indianapolis and Springfield, Ill., soybeans are commonly planted in early summer after the harvest of spring wheat. So the same farmers who lose from the soybean concessions will tend to gain from the arrangement on grain-export subsidies.
 North of that line, the summer is usually short for two crops and farmers usually have a choice of planting corn, which will benefit from the agreement, or planting soybeans.
 The least happy farmers may be in certain sections of the Southeast, particularly parts of Georgia, where corn does not grow well and farmers tend to have a choice between cotton and soybeans. Trade negotiators have already agreed tentatively to new rules for trade in raw cotton, textiles and apparel that will expose American cotton farmers to more international competition.
 Asked whether the United States had quietly wrung an unusually broad deal out of the Europeans, Mr. Madigan, in a telephone interview, replied: "The better part of being a negotiator, I think, is knowing when not to brag. If somebody else wants to make that observation, they can, but I'm not going to say that."
 American and European officials agreed on the change of method during two days of talks this week at Blair House, the White House's residence for visiting dignitaries. The United States also made a last-minute concession, agreeing that a small quantity of oilseeds could be planted on the acreage taken out of general cultivation, provided the oilseeds were used for industrial purposes, like paint manufacturing.


GRAPHIC: Chart: "Questions and Answers on Trade"
Photo: President Bush announcing a compromise between the United States and the European Community on farm subsidies. With him were Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan and Carla A. Hills, trade representative. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)(pg. 36)
What is GATT?
GATT is the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a Geneva-based organization with 105 member countries that have committed themselves to expanding free trade. GATT adjudicates trade disputes among member nations and oversees periodic rounds of negotiations to reduce trade barriers like tariffs and subsidies.
What is the Uruguay Round?
It is the eighth round of negotiations to lower trade barriers in the hope of spurring global economic growth by increasing world trade. The current round of talks began in Punta del Este, Uruguay in 1986.
What issues are being negotiated?
The talks seeks to reduce trade barriers in farm products, banking, telecommunications and apparel from developing nations. The talks also seek to reduce tariffs, accelerate hearings on trade disputes and establish worldwide rules to protect patents, copyright, trademarks and trade secrets.
Why have the talks dragged on for six years?
The main obstacle to an accord has been a bitter dispute between the United States and the European Community over subsidies to farmers. Washington sought far swifter cuts than the Europeans want in the subsidies farmers receive to grow and export certain crops.
How do farm subsidies hurt Americans?
American farmers complain that Europe's subsidies and quotas make it harder for them to sell their grain and other goods in Europe and around the world. Export subsidies also cost taxpayers around the world billions of dollars, as many nations seek to give their own farmers the upper hand in the export market.
What is the European Community?
The Community, founded by the Treaty of Rome in 1957, now is a group of 12 nations with close economic and political ties. The countries have eliminated tariff barriers among themselves and share a common foreign policy on several matters, including trade; they are also developing common rules in areas like antitrust law and the environmental protection. The 12 nations are Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain.
Why did the United States threaten to impose punitive taxes on European white wines and some other goods?
The punitive taxes were designed to pressure France to back down from its steadfast opposition to trimming farm subsidies. Washington announced the taxes after GATT twice ruled that that European subsidies to farms of soybeans, rapeseed -- which is used to make canola oil -- and other seeds used in animal feed have hurt American farmers' access to European markets.
What is the next step in the trade negotiations?
The European Community will first put Friday's agreement to a weighted majority vote, and it is expected to pass despite France's objections. But the French can exercise a veto by by declaring that the farm issue is a matter of vital national interest. Should the French not veto the agreement despite their complaints, then the broader GATT talks are likely to proceed, seeking common ground in other areas. (pg. 36)
Table: "Stubling Toward a Trade Deal"
 As diplomats have tried for years to agree on ways ton increase world trade, their efforts have sometimes seemed like the Perils of Pauline.
 At the latest round ot talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, begun in 1986, negotiators from 105 countries work to find ways to lower trade barriers between nations, hoping to promote world prosperity.
 Meanwhile, the United States and the European Community squabble over Europe's subsidies to growers of soybeans and other oilseed crops. Washington says the subsidies violate a 1962 agreement and deprive American farmers of sales abroad.
 A GATT panel rules twice, in 1991 and again this year, that the community is in the wrong. But rather than risk angering its politically powerful farmers, especially those in France, the community makes only token changes in the subsidies.
 The United States treatens to impose 200 percent import taxes on French white wine and other goods from the community. The GATT talks come to a halt in the face of the logjam over agricultural trade.
 A flurry of high-level talks yields a compromise. The community agrees to limit the land used to grow oilseed crops. But France continues to object. It is uncertain whether a trade war has been averted or whether France will veto the compromise. (pg. 36)

SECTION: Section 7; Page 31; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: The Many Shades of Bigotry

BYLINE: By Lena Williams; Lena Williams is a style reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE COLOR COMPLEX
The Politics of Skin Color Among African Americans.
By Kathy Russell, Midge Wilson and Ronald Hall.
200 pp. New York:
Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $21.95. 
 LIKE most African-Americans, I find that my skin crawls at the mention of black-on-black skin-color discrimination. It is difficult to understand how a people who share a history of oppression based on skin color would do unto members of their own race what others have done to them for centuries.
In past years, such racial conflict and questions of racial definition have seldom been discussed outside the black community, lest whites learn of what many blacks describe as "our dirty little secret." Yet few blacks would deny that intraracial prejudice based on skin color has been prevalent since the time of slavery.
In "The Color Complex," Kathy Russell, Midge Wilson and Ronald Hall examine how differences in color and facial features have played and continue to play a role in the socioeconomic status, family and personal relationships, and professional lives of many black Americans. Their analysis, at times funny, at others painful, presents a powerful argument, backed by historical fact and anecdotal evidence, that color prejudice remains a devastating divide within black America. The strongest chapters are those that explore the historical legacy of color discrimination.
"Throughout American history degrees of skin coloring and kinkiness of hair have had the power to shape the quality of black people's lives," the authors write. "Social scientists have advanced various theories to explain the widespread preference for light skin and straighter features. The first theory contends that the 'establishment' sets standards for behavior and appearance and that those who strive for success must conform accordingly. Standards change only after enough members of a subordinate group have moved into positions of power."
The authors have various professional backgrounds: Ms. Russell, a scriptwriter and poet, works for I.B.M.; Ms. Wilson teaches psychology and women's studies at DePaul University in Chicago, and Mr. Hall teaches social work at Augsburg College in Minneapolis. But writing from personal experiences and social observations, they note that the book is intended to "raise awareness" of the controversial issues surrounding physical appearance, especially skin color, in the African-American community.
While the title suggests that the book will primarily examine "colorism" and its impact on blacks of varying skin shades, the authors explore other examples of intraracial prejudice based on physical characteristics like hair texture, eye color and the contour of one's mouth and nose. For example, a woman in her 20's says that the man she had fallen in love with rejected her because of her color. "You're pretty smart and you're a lotta fun," she reports him as saying, "but . . . I just can't get too serious with a dark-skinned woman. It's important to me to have light-skinned children."
In no way is colorism one-sided. During the 1960's, darker-skinned blacks found themselves being touted and embraced by the black power movement for reflecting the true heritage of the race; many lighter-skinned blacks were rejected because of their complexions. "Increasingly," the authors write, "the color complex shows up in the form of dark-skinned African-Americans spurning their lighter-skinned brothers and sisters for not being black enough."
The authors stress in their epilogue that the book is "not the final word" on intraracial skin-color discrimination, "nor was it ever meant to be." Despite the disclaimer, many readers may be left unsatisfied. Such a broad, complex issue cannot really be reduced to fewer than 200 pages of analysis. The final chapter, crammed with titillating examples from contemporary life -- everything from Michael Jackson's physical alterations to the tendency of rappers to use lighter-complexioned women in their music videos -- reads more like a magazine story than a serious discussion.
One longs for more: how, for example, the continued emphasis on skin color may be exacerbated by this country's growing ethnic diversity; the impact skin color and physical traits have on the psychological development of black children (the chapter dealing with this issue is one of the most interesting in the book); and the extent to which color discrimination plays a role in employment, housing, politics and criminality.
One senses that the authors became overwhelmed with their material. In a somewhat cursory fashion, they offer five recommendations for both blacks and whites to "minimize the damage that colorism will inflict on future generations," from therapy to bringing the issue out of the closet. But readers who want to know more will have to rely on the many sources cited in the book.
Many blacks say that African-Americans cannot afford to waste time on such superficial issues when so many of them face a multitude of problems like unemployment, drug abuse and homelessness. But "The Color Complex" clearly illustrates that in order for blacks even to begin to tackle such deep-rooted difficulties, they may first have to shed some burdensome psychological baggage.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 43; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1448 words

HEADLINE: People of Distinction

BYLINE: By J. Jorge Klor de Alva; J. Jorge Klor de Alva, a professor of anthropology at Princeton University, is writing a book on multiculturalism in the United States, Britain and France. He is the editor of the forthcoming "American Identities: Traditional, Contested and Imagined."

 BODY:

LATINOS
A Biography of the People.
By Earl Shorris.
520 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $25. 
 SINCE the 1960's, when non-European immigrants began to surpass in number those coming from Europe, the United States has undergone the most dramatic cultural and demographic shifts in its history. Not only has it become an immigrant nation once again, with close to 11 percent of the population foreign born, but, of greater importance, today nearly one in four Americans is of African, Asian or Hispanic ancestry. And among these, Latinos, as many Hispanic people prefer to be called, are by far the fastest growing. Demographers expect them to number at least 39 million by 2010, which is likely to make Hispanics, Mr. Shorris observes, "the largest group of minorities in the United States." But who are these peoples? No book answers the question better than "Latinos."
Earl Shorris, the author of three novels (including "Under the Fifth Sun") and four works of nonfiction (among them "The Death of the Great Spirit" and "Jews Without Mercy") and a contributing editor of Harper's Magazine, notes that he waited 20 years for a book like this to appear. It didn't, and, fortunately for us, he decided to wait no longer. By combining his skills as a journalist and a novelist to weave well-annotated sketches of Latino individuals and families and the predicaments they face into a single, compelling story, he has shown how much journalism can contribute to the making of ethnographies of complicated societies. Without Mr. Shorris's eye for the telling detail and the summarizing symbol, his capacity to mold wide-ranging data into concise narratives and his keen interviewing skills, this credible profile of the cultural world of more than 20 million people intermixed among 226 million others would have been impossible.
A sizable part of his book concerns the histories of the Latino communities, going back to their Spanish and African roots. But like most journalists, Mr. Shorris deals with the present better than he deals with the past. For instance, what he says about the Aztec language and culture, and their supposed influences on Mexican character, is usually wrong and best skipped ("macho" does not come from the Nahuatl "to know"). On the other hand, his discussion of the cultural role of multilinguality in the United States is well informed and remarkably free of the partisan baggage the topic usually carries. Along with other experienced observers (including anyone who rides the subways of New York), he argues that the nation is becoming linguistically bicultural with or without bilingual education, and no matter what English-only policies are adopted.
He goes even farther. Using the comedian Paul Rodriguez as an example of the bilingual television host who can move easily from one cultural sphere to another, he advances a conclusion familiar to anyone with cosmopolitan experience: an ability to use two languages makes one more social and less ignorant, helpless and isolated.
The author sheds a much-needed light on many other related issues that are currently unhinging less knowledgeable observers. Among these are the persistence of ethnic identity, the failure of the old model of immigrant assimilation to hold true in the case of many Latinos, and the assumption that multiculturalist initiatives could lead to the disuniting of America.
Concerning the first two issues, Mr. Shorris makes the necessary but usually neglected distinction between the motives and experiences of turn-of-the-century European immigrants and those of Latinos. With no intention of returning, immigration for the Europeans was an end to an old world. Their goal as "real" immigrants was a new social contract in which language, culture, names and even lives would be sacrificed for liberty, equality, food and the promise of wealth. But for many Latinos, racism, proximity to their homelands and their status as exiles have intervened, making a similar social contract possible for only a few. When a "true" immigrant experience (one in which some form of equality and economic mobility is achieved) fails to materialize for the first generation, Mr. Shorris maintains, it may not occur at all. The devastating result, he asserts, is that "the second generation -- the hope of the immigrant, the generation in which the great social and economic leaps most often occur, the dream incarnate -- is born dead."
In agreement with much contemporary scholarship, Mr. Shorris points to the crucial errors of mid century sociology that established as truth the immigrant paradigm of inevitable assimilation in the course of three generations. He argues that the proponents of this model, like Nathan Glazer and Daniel Patrick Moynihan in their book "Beyond the Melting Pot" (1970), failed to understand Latinos and blacks, passing over the importance and tenacity of culture while greatly underestimating the importance of race. "From the vantage of an aerie at Columbia or Harvard the prognosis of one immigrant group looked a lot like that of another," he writes. But reality was otherwise. For most blacks and Latinos, poverty followed each generation. And for many among the Latinos, he maintains, the closeness to the ancestral land, the continuous arrival of new immigrants and the isolation engendered by racism all contributed to the maintenance across the generations of the Spanish language and Hispanic cultural traits.
Does this mean unassimilated Latinos are fragmenting America? Not according to Mr. Shorris, who is quick to note that neither poverty, discrimination nor neglect have discouraged the overwhelming majority of Latinos from seeking their version of the American dream. Except for a few young activists in the 1960's and 70's, Latinos have not advanced a separatist agenda. They are instead, the book suggests (Mr. Shorris makes the process of assimilation the book's "core" issue), doing much to help themselves gain a greater share of wealth, power and visibility. After all, E pluribus unum is a Latin, not an Anglo-Saxon, motto.
Mr. Shorris, who was raised in El Paso and is married to a Hispanic woman, is an affectionate and sensitive observer of cultural differences. But he is not an ethnic cheerleader, and he is too preoccupied with covering all sides of the story to be concerned with the orthodoxies of political agendas. The Hispanic as well as the non-Hispanic origins of the predicaments of Latinos are given their proper due. His many references to the insidious nature of the prejudices and discriminations practiced among Latinos (which he labels "racismo") and the racism practiced against them leaves no doubt that he believes both sides of the Rio Grande handle the question of race with dirty hands.
The search for cultural unity in the face of historical, socioeconomic and racial diversity, a burden common to all comparative studies of Hispanics, is undertaken by Mr. Shorris with great hesitation. Having studied Latinos in depth from coast to coast and class to class, he refuses to romanticize the possible links and instead identifies them as no more than a complex of peoples, sharing in different degrees vocabularies, values and feelings toward European-Americans. His reluctance is also informed by an awareness that cultural distinctions and stereotypes can easily be confused. Considering the wide range of topics covered -- history, religion, politics, education, business, the arts, music, literature, employment and world view -- Mr. Shorris does a laudable job of maintaining the boundary between the actual and the stereotypical. Nonetheless, many readers, especially Latinos, will be unforgiving when they meet occasional questionable depictions of, say, Mexican fatalism or Cuban fanaticism.
Still, "Latinos" is a powerful, beautifully written and thoughtful book that is likely to remain unequaled in its sweep and profundity for some time to come. It is also a timely education for Americans of all nationalities, classes and races. "A snapshot of America taken now," he observes, "would reveal strong Latino influences in language, cuisine, music and entertainment. These are not signs of conquest, however; history is not a matter of repetitions." At a moment when much divisive propaganda is parading in the guise of concerned scholarship, it is good to know that on the basis of actual empirical research someone can credibly assert that "civilization need not be a zero-sum game." Mr. Shorris is wise to argue that "the victories of Latino culture are victories of pluralism. . . . Nothing is taken in return for this enrichment; it is, by definition, a gift."
