HEADLINE: WINTER IN THE SNOW;
Skiing: Finding the Price That's Right

BYLINE: By STANLEY CARR

 BODY:
OPERATORS of ski areas have long encouraged the idea that skiers can cut costs by adopting various strategies -- seeking out discounted lift tickets, for example, or buying packages that combine tickets and lodging , or avoiding holiday periods, and even weekends. The ski operators generally leave it to hotels and spas to suggest that skiing can be high style, too, and that one can enjoy luxurious quarters and elegant dining near the slopes.
Both ends of the sport have something to be pleased about. A survey conducted by the United Ski Industries Association, which represents most major ski areas, reported that last winter skiing bucked the recession after a three-year decline. During the 1991-92 season the number of skier visits (a skier visit is one person visiting a ski area to ski part of the day or night) rose 8.8 percent over the previous season. Visits went up to 50.8 million from 46.7 million. Attendance at beginner lessons, the report said, surged 21.2 percent. 
 The rebound helped spur investment at some ski centers, notably at Vail-Beaver Creek, where $8.5 million has been spent on four lifts and expanded terrain. Two other Colorado resorts were among the big spenders this year, Steamboat adding two quad chairlifts and Crested Butte one. Many mountains extended their snowmaking equipment, among them Sun Valley and Deer Valley in the Rockies, and Sunday River, Me., and Waterville Valley, N.H.
Another sign of confidence: a new Ritz-Carlton Hotel, with rooms starting at $325 for two most of the season, opens Dec. 12 in Aspen, between the two base lifts serving Aspen Mountain. That is not a choice for budget skiers, but even at Aspen, people save money by going in the low part of the season. Many ski areas make 15 to 25 percent of their annual lift revenue in the high-season period just before and just after Christmas; hotels at ski resorts make from 40 to 50 percent of their revenue between Dec. 19 and Jan. 15, according to a spokesman for the Denver-based Colorado Ski Country USA.
The single day lift price at the slopes at Aspen from Dec. 19 to Jan. 2 will be a whopping $45; at Breckenridge a single day ticket is $38. Across the country as a whole, according to a Ski Industries Association survey, only 37 percent of skiers pay full price for a weekend day ticket. Most people pay less by buying a multiday or half-day ticket or a discounted ticket at a grocery or ski store. Flexible pricing systems for lift tickets, in which skiers pay for what they ski on a point system rather than a flat rate, are likely to spread, ski officials say. The idea has been adopted by Loon and Attitash in New Hampshire, Ski Roundtop in Pennsylvania, and Mount Bachelor in Oregon.
Wherever they go, skiers on a budget will have to think twice not only about the Christmas and New Year's period but also President's Week when Lincoln's Birthday (Feb. 12) and Washington's Birthday (Feb. 15) combine to create a rush to the slopes. When calling reservation services, ask how high and low season are defined at the resort at which you plan to ski. In the Rockies, the low, or off, season is generally described as between Nov. 25 and Dec. 19, and between March 28 and April 11, when the slopes close, not usually for want of snow, but for lack of skiers. The change in seasons is most complicated in Canada: Mont Tremblant in Quebec says low season is before Dec. 25 and from Jan. 3 to Feb. 13 and then from March 21 until skiing ends. For groups, Mont Tremblant also has both regular and high season lift prices. Some lodges follow suit with their rates.
In Canada, a 7 percent Federal tax is applied to most goods and services. There are also varying provincial sales taxes. In Quebec it's 8 percent on goods including meals and 4 percent on services including lodging; in Alberta, there is no provincial sales tax, but there is a 5 percent tax on accommodations. Visitors from the United States can get the Federal and provincial taxes on lodging and goods -- but not meals -- refunded by filling out required forms, thus saving a substantial amount.
Skiers who belong to the electronic bulletin boards of Prodigy or Compuserve (requiring a monthly fee) can look for deals there. Prodigy's on-line ski guide gives information about resorts, and its sports club bulletin board exchanges information about ski resorts. You don't have to belong to Colorado Travel bank to make contact and scout for cut rates, either through modem, (303) 671-7669, or voice, (303) 320-8550.
The following survey offers a selection of ski areas in the West, Northeast and Canada and suggests how visitors following the budget or the deluxe trail might approach them.
 
THE WEST
 
CALIFORNIA
SQUAW VALLEY USA
Squaw Valley, Calif. 95730
(916) 583-6955: central reservations, (800) 545-4350
Budget -- Squaw Valley offers a lot of skiing for the money. A lift pass -- the regular day rate is $40 for an adult -- gives access to six mountains serviced by 33 lifts, and lift passes include unlimited use of the cable car. For $1, skiers can buy a guarantee that allows them to ski free if they average more than a 10-minute wait on lift lines. (Their lift pass fee is refunded.) Management keeps track of the lines and keeps records if people have to wait.
One of the best deals at Squaw Valley is for children under 13 and people over 65, who can purchase lift tickets for $5 every day. There are many packages that include skiing at up to seven other Tahoe area ski resorts, and accommodations if required, that bring the lift price down. Squaw Valley also offers first-time skiers a free lift ticket, free ski rentals and a free ski orientation.
If you take your own sleeping bag and are willing to share a bathroom, the Hostel at Squaw Valley provides shelter for as little as $35 a night off-season and $40 in peak times like Christmas and Easter weeks and on weekends. The dormitory-style rooms with three to eight beds in each come with pillow, pillowcase and towel. The Hostel, (800) 544-4723, is within easy walking distance of the main lifts; make reservations early.
Squaw Valley's new "Ski Your Pro" instruction system costs $25 for up to a day; participants can join any one of the four levels of lessons at any time during the day and stay with it until the lifts shut down.
Inexpensive diversions off the slopes include ice skating on top of the mountain at the Olympic Ice Pavilion, which costs $5 and has a view over Lake Tahoe.
Deluxe -- Although Squaw Valley USA as a whole is focused more strongly on terrain development and access than on pampering, guests at the Resort at Squaw Creek, (800) 327-3353, are offered in-room ski and boot fitting. The Resort is the only hotel in the Lake Tahoe region given four stars by the American Automobile Association.
Most of the 405 rooms are suites. The hotel has four restaurants and in-house masseurs; a high-speed lift ascends directly from the Guest House building.
Apres-skiers can contemplate the waterfall that emerges from beneath the smoked-glass lobby building as they steam and soak in the various outdoor hot tubs and swimming pools. Daily room rates at the Resort at Squaw Creek start at $135.
For skiers who prefer to remain on the slopes all day, lunch doesn't have to be a microwaved chili-dog and a chocolate bar. Alexander's is a full-service restaurant on the middle of the mountain at 8,200 feet, serving lunch at about $15 and dinner at $25.
 
COLORADO
ASPEN
Aspen Skiing Company, Post Office Box 1248, Aspen, Colo. 81612
Information and snow report, (303) 923-1220 or (800) 525-5200; central reservations, (800) 262-7736
Budget -- In Aspen economical folk have always mingled with extravagant ones, and, at about $100 a person daily, the typical ski vacation strains the definition of the word budget. But Aspen does offer affordable pleasures for the cost-conscious.
To save, begin by going in the off-season. In Aspen, off-season is generally Nov. 25 to Dec. 19, and March 28 to April 11, when the slopes close. Off-season packages start at $186 a person for three nights' lodging and lift tickets. Visiting at the slowest times of the year may offer such bonuses as signing up for a group lesson at $48 a day, but getting a private lesson, which ordinarily runs $130 for two hours, if nobody else shows up.
Nothing says you have to buy your lunch at the high-altitude restaurants; since these are built on National Forest land you can take a lunch of your own and still eat inside any restaurant, or at one of the picnic tables outside. For about $6, such delis as the Jour de Fete, 710 East Durant Avenue, (303) 925-8691, or the Charcuterie, 520 East Durant Avenue, (303) 925-8010, prepare a lunch you can carry in your fanny pack.
Where skiing is concerned, multiday lift tickets purchased in advance are always less expensive than those bought at the ticket window. A ticket good for six out of seven days for Aspen, Snowmass and Buttermilk is $228; single day tickets cost $43, or $258 for six days, most of the season. Skiers under 6 and over 70 ski free.
Aspen has a number of low and moderate priced restaurants. Kids love the pizza, $2.10 a slice, at New York Pizza, 409 East Hyman, (303) 920-3088. Su Casa, 315 East Hyman, (303) 920-1488, serves quesadillas and enchiladas for about $7. The Red Onion, 420 East Cooper Avenue, (303) 925-9043, has chicken wings at $2.50 and onion rings at $1.75.
The Innsbruck Inn, 233 West Main Street, (303) 925-2980, offers large rooms and a full breakfast served in an Austrian-style dining room, $154 a night for a family of four. Just outside of town and along the free bus route is the Alpine Lodge, 1240 East Cooper Avenue, (303) 925-7351, offering rooms for two with shared bath for $68 a night, with private bath for $80 or $85. This Bavarian-style lodge built 100 years ago is white stucco with dark brown wood trim; all the rooms have down comforters. Breakfast is an extra $5 a person, and dinner, $14.
Close to town are 80 kilometers of free groomed, public cross-country ski terrain, and of course there are hundreds of square miles of White River National Forest for the more experienced back-country skier. Indoor ice skating in town is $5.50 including skate rental.
Deluxe -- If vacationing off-season is the best way to beat the highest prices, visiting at Christmas time assures you will pay them. The opening of the Ritz-Carlton, 315 East Dean Street, (800) 241-3333, on Dec. 12 heightens yet again Aspen's notoriety for being chock-full of rich people, especially when you are informed that every one of the hotel's 257 rooms and suites, priced from $475 to $3,000 a night, is booked through Jan. 2. Rates then begin at $325. The staid, red-brick building with dark green trim is two blocks from Aspen Ski Company's Silver Queen Gondola, so it does not offer the ski-in access of its closest rival, the Little Nell. Nevertheless it provides a fitness center with a host of body treatment rooms.
Down the street, the Little Nell, 675 East Durant, (303) 920-4600, with more than 100 rooms, boasts of being just 17 steps from the gondola. Rooms with a town view begin at $335 a night, and its two-bedroom suite goes for $2,100 nightly. The contemporary Nell, is booked solid through New Year's Day for several years to come.
The 100-year old Sardy House, 128 East Main Street, (303) 925-2525, offers 20 rooms and has a private brick mews. The red-brick house has pretty porches, bay windows and a cone-shaped tower. Rooms run between $240 and $550 a night during the regular season, $100 more a night at Christmastime.
For expensive, exquisite dining, Szygy, 520 East Hyman Avenue, (303) 925-3700, fits the bill. Its stark interior is offset by dramatic dinner presentations that combine elements of French, Italian, Oriental and Southwestern cooking. About $130 for two with wine. The equally elegant Renaissance Restaurant, 304 East Hopkins, (303) 925-2402 -- it reopens Dec. 11 -- features a fixed-price menu that changes daily, $95 a person with wine. The menu, which changes frequently, offers a wide variety from finely prepared lamb and veal to scallops.
The latest peak experience is a four-day course in paragliding, $375 for a group lesson or $450 a day for a private lesson. (303) 925-7625.
 
COPPER MOUNTAIN RESORT
Post Office Box 3001, Copper Mountain, Colo. 80443
(800) 458-8386
Budget -- For the budget-minded, the best place to stay is in Frisco or the Dillon and Silverthorne area, which are six miles east of Copper Mountain, and are the centers of activity in Summit County.
The Holiday Inn-Summit County in Frisco, (303) 668-5000, has regular reason room rates that range from $95 to $145 a night, compared with rates of $145 to $470 a night at the resort. The Alpen Hutte Lodge in Silverthorne, (303) 468-6336, is another choice for skiers willing to forgo the benefits of the resort. This European-style ski dormitory offers queen-size bunk beds that go for $20 to $23 a person a night during the height of the season. It's comfortable and clean, not fancy, not a party place, and popular.
Equipment rental and lift tickets are also cheaper away from the resort. Many rental places charge $11 to $14 a day for skis, poles and boots, which cost $21 at Copper. Adult, single day tickets go for $30 at rental shops, gas stations and grocery stores, and $37 at the resort.
Copper is part of the Ski the Summit lift ticket package that offers access to Copper's 1,330 acres of skiing and the Breckenridge, Keystone and Arapahoe Basin ski areas. These packages start at $132 for four days.
For skiers who want to stay at the resort, Copper offers packages that include lodging, daily lift tickets and access to the athletic club. Family packages range from $85 to $105 a person a night during regular season; $88 to $125 during the holidays, and from $59 for early and late season skiing. A new single occupancy package starts at $86.
Club Med, (800) 258-2633, operates a resort at Copper, with seven-night rates, starting at $900 a person, double occupancy, Dec. 6 to 13, rising to $1,390 for the week beginning Dec. 27. An early season deal: from Dec. 6 to 20 you can get 10 nights for $900. All rates include three meals a day, wine or beer at lunch and dinner, and one-week lift ticket.
Dining at Copper is somewhat limited, with O'Shea's Copper Bar, (303) 968-2882, ext. 6504, serving American and Mexican food upstairs and featuring live music in the bar downstairs. Prices for main courses range from $5.95 to $12.95. In the Dillon area, dining ranges from a plethora of fast-food places to restaurants like Charity's in Frisco, (303) 668-3644, which serves international cuisine in a former bordello. Entrees range from $6.95 to $14.95.
Deluxe -- Copper offers everything from single rooms at $99 to $190 to four-bedroom condos that go for $350 to $625 a night, rates depending on date. Three-bedroom penthouses are from $280 to $565. The Telemark Lodge, with one-bedroom units, is one of the most comfortable complexes.
A wide variety of skiing instruction ranges from introductory cross country skiing on a 25-kilometer track to all-day private lessons in downhill skiing that go for $285. Sleigh rides, ice skating and shopping are also available.
Colorado Heli-Ski in Dillon, (800) 435-4754, has daily packages that go for $330 to $400 a day, and include five runs in the Arapahoe, White River and San Isabel National Forests, a buffet lunch in the back country and guide.
Rackets, at the resort's athletic club, (303) 968-2882, ext. 6386, is one of the fancier restaurants, with Southwestern dishes from $13.95 to $26.95.
The Briar Rose Restaurant at Breckenridge, (303) 453-9948, serves such items as frogs' legs in garlic butter, moose steaks and veal medallions in lemon butter. Prices for entrees range from $13 to $26.
 
SNOWMASS
Snowmass at Aspen, Post Office Box 1248, Aspen, Colo. 81612
(303) 925-1220 or (800) 525-6200
Budget -- The Aspen Skiing Company, which owns and operates Aspen Mountain and Tiehack-Buttermilk Mountain in Aspen, also owns the vast Snowmass area, and offers a lift ticket that entitles skiers to ski any of its four properties. A free shuttle bus runs between Snowmass and Aspen, 12 miles away. More than 50 percent of the skiing in Snowmass is rated intermediate.
Most Snowmass visitors stay in condominiums or homes, since there are relatively few hotels. Many of the accommodations allow ski-in, ski-out access, and virtually all have at least a three-day minimum stay. For condominium prices call Village Property Management, (800) 525-9402.
One of the least expensive places to stay in Snowmass is the Stonebridge Inn, (800) 525-4200, a short walk from the lifts. The Stonebridge package rate is $786 a person for a seven-night visit, including lift tickets. Rooms are comfortable though simple.
Slopeside, and across from the Snowmass nursery and children's ski school, is the Pokolodi Lodge, (800) 666-4556. It offers a five-night package of $844 a person including lift tickets.
If you have a car, the best budget accommodation is the Aspenalt Motel in Basalt, (303) 927-3191, about a 20-minute drive from the Snowmass shuttle bus stop. Here, long-term parking is available, and be forewarned: it is next to impossible to find parking nearer the ski area. The 35-room Aspenalt, a Best Western, costs $75 a night for two people in a room on the creek, and $65 a night for two in a room away from the creek. Prices between Dec. 18 and Jan. 2 are $90 a night for two, and there is a three-night miniumum. All prices include Continental breakfast.
The Snowmass pedestrian mall offers several budget-minded restaurants open for lunch and dinner. The Stewpot, (303) 923-2263, serves hearty stews and, with salad and bread, the price is about $8.25. At La Pinata's, (303) 923-2153, Mexican specials start at about $9.
If you want to be frugal in Snowmass and stay off the slopes, visit the renowned Krabloonik Kennel free. You take the free shuttle bus to the top of the village to hear and see more than 200 huskies and malamutes, many of which take part in dog-sled races. Call (303) 923-3953 for information.
Deluxe -- The Silvertree Hotel, (303) 923-3520, is the only full-service deluxe hotel in Snowmass Village, and offers a ski-in, ski-out location. Rooms between Dec. 19 and Jan. 2 run from $270 to $375 a night, and are $100 less in the regular ski season. Suite prices are available upon request.
The Snowmass Lodge and Club, (800) 262-7736, which bills itself as Snowmass Village's other exclusive hotel, is owned and operated by the Aspen Skiing Company. Accommodation packages at the Lodge include two lift tickets, and begin at $325 a room a night during the Christmas season, or $230 a night afterward. One-bedroom villas that sleep four are $460 a night with two lift passes during Christmas week, and $280 afterward. The Snowmass Club also provides a full-service athletic center, with weight and cardiovascular workout rooms, aerobic classes and a heated outdoor lap pool. While still considered part of Snowmass Village, the Snowmass Lodge and Club is about six miles from the slopes. A free shuttle bus runs frequently.
The frequency and ease of bus transportation to Aspen gives Snowmass visitors the opportunity to go to town for an elegant dinner, but there are comparable restaurants near at hand: Chez Grandmere, in the village, (303) 923-2570, prepares Continental dishes in a cozy yellow house, $110 for two, with wine, and Krabloonik at the top of the village, (303) 923-3953, is a gourmet restaurant as well as a kennel. Its menu features specialty game and fish entrees, $120 for two, including wine. A two-hour dog-sled ride, with driver and four-course lunch, is $175 a person. Wine is extra.
For off-slope thrills, visitors to Snowmass can enroll in Aspen's paragliding school, a bus ride away. A four-day course is $375.
 
VAIL
Vail Associates, Resort Information, Post Office Box 7, Vail, Colo. 81658
Reservations, (800) 525-2257; snow report, (303) 476-5601
Budget -- Vail has a value season like Aspen and Snowmass', and such cost-saving measures as signing up for a group lesson at unpopular times (when you may be the only student), work equally well here. During the more affordable times (Nov. 25 to Dec. 18, April 3 to 18), a five-night stay with four days of lift tickets starts at $417 a person in Vail, $514 down Interstate 70 in Avon, and $647 at Vail's luxurious sister resort, Beaver Creek. Through the Vail-Beaver Creek reservations system -- (800) 525-2257 for Vail travel packages, and (800) 622-3131 for Beaver Creek packages -- skiers can do everything from checking airline availability to reserving a spot for their children in ski school.
Inexpensive dining spots are scattered along the I-70 corridor. Among them are Cassidy's Hole in the Wall in Avon, (303) 949-9449, which serves breakfast through dinner, with entrees such as hamburgers and Southwestern specialties, $5 to $15. A good place to eat on the pedestrian mall in downtown Vail is bright and contemporary Blue's, (303) 476-3113, which serves innovative dishes like smoked trout, hash and eggs for breakfast at $6.25. A Jamaican-spiced Rasta sandwich in a tortilla at lunch is $5.95; the mustard pepper steak at dinner is $11.95.
Skate indoors at the Dobson Ice Arena, for $5, or outdoors, free, in Beaver Creek. Cross-country skiers can take a short day trip up from Vail Pass to the popular Shrine Mountain Hut, one of the stopping places on the 10th Mountain Division Memorial Ski Trail.
Deluxe -- The 190-room Sonnenalp Resort, (800) 654-8312, opens a number of new suites this season, which cost from $340 to $1,050 a night from Christmas to New Year's, and $290 to $900 thereafter. The new suites have gas fireplaces. Hotel rooms are available during Christmas for $255 to $285 a night, and from $225 to $255 in the regular season. Full buffet breakfast is included in all rates. The Sonnenalp has four restaurants, an outdoor heated pool and a health spa offering hydrotherapy tubs, facials and massages. The resort is a four-minute walk from the nearest lift, the Vista Bahn quad.
The Christiania at Vail, (303) 476-5641, offers elegance on a smaller scale, and it has an outdoor heated pool and a sauna. The big plus about the Christiania is that it's 100 yards from the Vista Bahn chairlift. Its 22 rooms cost $200 to $300 a night during the Christmas season, and from $160 to $250 thereafter. Suites begin, in the low season, at $250, rising to from $300 for regular season. At holiday times they start at $350.
Ten miles west in Beaver Creek, the former $20 million Shearson Lehman Executive Retreat has been transformed into the Saddleridge at Beaver Creek, an enclave of 12 villas connected to a private club. Each villa features a river-rock fireplace and antique furnishings, with prices starting at $1,000 a night for a two-bedroom villa at Christmas. After the holidays rates fall to $475 for a two-bedroom, $600 for a three-bedroom. Information, (800) 352-7557.
Perhaps the best ski instruction available at Vail is embodied in Pepi's Wedel Weeks (named for wedeln, a short parallel turn) returning for its eighth year. For $1,375 a person, in double occupancy, the four scheduled Wedel Weeks -- the first from Nov. 30 to Dec. 6 -- include a comprehensive teaching program, lodging at Vail's best hotels, a Bogner fashion show and farewell dinner. Information, (800) 323-4386.
To pamper yourself after a punishing day on the slopes you can take the free shuttle to the Cordillera, (303) 926-2200, a small lodge and spa posted on 3,200 acres high in the Sawatch 20 minutes from Vail in Edwards, Colo. Its $195 day-away package is open to nonguests, and includes lunch, hydrotherapy, exercise instruction and a facial massage. For those who wish to stay over, the Cordillera's 22 rooms range from $175 to $400 a night.
Diners at the lodge's restaurant, Picasso, which is open to nonguests, can see three original Picassos hanging in the dining room. They also pay $75 a person for the set-price, four-course dinner. The style is nouvelle cuisine and pureed vegetable sauces are a specialty.
Back in Vail, the Sweet Basil, 193 Gore Creek Drive, (303) 476-0125, is known for its cheerful atmosphere, nouvelle-style cuisine and fanciful desserts. $100 for two, not including wine.
 
WINTER PARK
Winter Park Resort, Post Office Box 36, Winter Park, Colo. 80482
(303) 726-5587; reservations, (800) 453-2525
Budget -- Winter Park's innovative lift-ticket pricing structure allows skiers to pay $3 to use the Galloping Goose beginner's lift; $15 for a mini-mountain ticket (five lifts), and $24 for either morning or afternoon for all 20 lifts. You can also pay $30 a day for a multiday ticket, valid from two to six days. Then skiers can save $6 by buying off site. There are $30 tickets for the entire mountain for a day that are sold at more than 150 outlets in the Denver area. A regular all-day ticket at the slopes is $36. Children age 5 and younger, and seniors 70 and older ski free.
The all-area tickets let skiers reach the resort's new Timberline double chairlift, which climbs to the 12,000-foot summit of North Cone, opening up the 1,038 vertical-foot Parsenn Bowl and its more than 200 acres of above treeline and glade skiing. (Winter Park's vertical is 2,220, and the adjacent Mary Jane has a 3,060 vertical.)
Those who have never skied before get their first ski lesson free with the purchase of an adult all-day lift ticket. First-timers' packages, which include three days' lifts, three nights' lodging at a mountain inn, breakfast and dinner daily, and three four-and-a-half-hour ski lessons, start at $357 a person, double occupancy. Rentals are extra.
The National Sports Center for the Disabled, at Winter Park, has a $35 half-day, one-on-one lesson, including lift ticket and adaptive equipment.
During White Sale season, Jan. 4 to Feb. 12, vacation packages offering seven nights' lodging with breakfast and dinner daily, and six days' lifts start at $635 a person, double occupancy, in a mountain inn and from $467 in a bed and breakfast. During regular and peak seasons, Dec. 14 to Jan. 3 and Feb. 13 to April 4, the price is $656 in a mountain inn, $467 in a bed and breakfast. For inexpensive food, look for daily specials at mountain restaurants where entree, drink and side dish costs under $5. You can use the Pizza Hotline atop the mountain to have a pizza waiting for you at the midmountain Mama Mia pizzeria.
The hottest (and reasonably priced) apres-ski spots include the Derailer Bar in the ski area's base lodge, the Slope and the Stampede. For dinner, try the Last Waltz, (303) 726-4877, the Crooked Creek, (303) 726-9250, Dino's Mountain Bistro, (303) 726-5332, or Finnegans on the Fraser, (303) 726-9845, all serving American food. A meal is from $10 to $20, plus wine.
Off-slope activities include cross-country skiing and tubing on a tow-serviced hill. For tubing, call (303) 726-5954; it cost $9 an hour last year.
Deluxe -- The Iron Horse, (800) 621-8190, and the Vintage Hotel, (800) 472-7017, are about as upscale as it gets in Winter Park. At the Vintage, rates run from $105 a night for a hotel room to $360 for the tower suite in regular season. The Iron Horse is the only ski-in, ski-out property (the Vintage is close and other lodging properties are in town, about two miles down the road). In regular season, which at the irson Horse means Jan. 29 to April 2, prices are $140 a night for a studio to $370 for a two-bedroom, three-bath suite. Visitors should ask about suites with fireplace and kitchen.
The well-appointed C Lazy U Ranch, (303) 887-3344, a half hour away, has cross-country skiing and offers daily shuttles to Winter Park. Depending on the date, rates are from $90 to $165 a person a night for lodging, all meals, cross-country equipment and cross-country lessons on the ranch.
The dining room at the dramatic new mountaintop Lodge at Sunspot serves pasta and game for lunch. Ask about sleigh ride dinners to Sunspot; they cost $49, including the sleigh. At dinnertime, Gasthaus Eichler serves German fare, Restaurant on the Ridge offers Continental cuisine and the Divide Grill (not fancy but a nice atmosphere) has steaks, fish and a loaded salad bar. Prices for dinner at these are from $15 to $30.
Off-slope activities include dog sledding through the Arapahoe National Forest, or snowmobiling up onto the Continental Divide. Dog sledding, (303) 726-8301, $80 for two for 90 minutes. Trailblazer Snowmobile Tours, (800) 669-0134, charges $33 a person for a one-hour trip.
 
IDAHO
SUN VALLEY
Sun Valley, Idaho 83353
Reservations at Sun Valley Resort (800) 786-8259;
reservations through Sun Valley-Ketchum Chamber of
Commerce (800) 634-3347
Budget -- The resort's theme weeks are packaged to offer savings over regular rates, and include lots of special events. Prime Time Special Week, Jan. 1 to 9, is for skiers aged 60 or older. Seven nights' accommodations at the Sun Valley Inn (see reservations number above), a five-of-six-day lift ticket and a week with parties and activities costs $318 a person, double occupancy. The same package with accommodations in the more luxurious Sun Valley Lodge is $332. If you're 59 or younger, the packages are $388 at the inn and $402 for the lodge.
Skiers attending the 19th annual "It Happened in Sun Valley" singles week, Jan. 9 to 16, do almost as well. Packages start at $378 for seven nights' lodging, a five-of-six-day lift ticket and events and parties.
Packages start at $378 for Sun Valley's Winter Sports Week, Jan. 16 to 23, with a communitywide smorgasbord of winter sports opportunities like skating and cross-country skiing. Packages for Western Ski Week, Jan. 23 to 30, including swing dance lessons and other activities, are also from $378.
Other inexpensive lodging choices include the Lift Tower Lodge, (208) 726-5163, a four-minute shuttle ride from the new high-speed River Run quad chairlift. A tidy little motel with hot tub, it charges $69 a night for a double room. The Ketchum Korral Motel, (208) 726-3510, has a $45 nightly room rate ($65 over the holidays).
One child per parent, aged 17 and under, stays free in the same room with parents at Sun Valley Resort. If you book a one-bedroom condo with a separate living room, costing $160, or $260 for the deluxe units, one child could sleep free in the living room. Youngsters aged 17 and under also ski free from Nov. 26 to Dec. 19, Jan. 2 to Feb. 6, and March 20 to closing (around May 1). Many lodges in Ketchum also allow children 17 and under to stay free. The same program is available at participating Wood River Valley lodges.
Budget dining choices include The Konditorei, (208) 622-2235, in Sun Valley Village, which has great pastries, and Gretchen's, (208) 622-2144, in the Sun Valley Lodge, which serves salad dishes for around $6.50 as well as chicken and shrimp plates at lunch. Entrees at dinner, including pasta and New York sirloin, range from $14 to $17.50. Also Louie's Italian Pizza, (208) 726-7775, and the bar menu at the lively Sawtooth Club, (208) 726-5233. both in Ketchum. Dinner at these spots can be had for under $15.
Top spots for inexpensive apres-ski life include listening to Mike Murphy's guitar at The Ram, the Vuarnettes at Creekside and the Drifters at the Elkhorn Saloon. Whiskey Jacques has dancing and hot bands.
Deluxe -- The elegant Sun Valley Lodge is sold out for Christmas Week but for the rest of the season rooms for two are available at $125, $150 and $172. Ask about upgrading to a parlor suite, such as No. 206 where Hemingway wrote parts of "For Whom the Bell Tolls." The parlor suites, which have a sitting room as well as a bedroom, are $275 a night.
Some guests request a room overlooking the ice-skating rink. They can also sip an apres-ski drink while soaking in the huge round, outdoor heated pool.
A day of helicopter skiing in the Sawtooth Mountains with Sun Valley Helicopter Ski Guides, (208) 622-3108, costs about $400 a day -- the exact price has yet to be set.
A skier can dine luxuriously in the Sun Valley Lodge's old-world dining room, or go to the Sunday buffet brunch ($14.95), which is elegantly served by the staff behind the laden tables, even though guests dress casually in ski clothes. Dinner in the dining room will cost from $25 to $50. Chez Michel, (208) 726-3032, in Ketchum, serves French cuisine, with dinner costing about $20. A sleigh ride can be taken to dinner in the rustic Trail Creek Cabin, little unchanged since Hemingway and Gary Cooper partied there a few times on New Year's Eve. The sleigh ride is $12 and $10 for children under 12; dinner prices range from $16 to $22; children's portions available at reduced prices. (206) 622-2135.
Visitors exploring Ketchum should visit Aventura (exclusive women's European clothing); the Galleria (smart shops displaying Western wear and jewelry), and the many art galleries, including the American West Gallery and the Roland Gallery.
 
MONTANA
BIG SKY OF MONTANA
Big Sky, Post Office Box 160001, Big Sky, Mont. 59716
(406) 995-4211 or (800) 548-4486 for information and reservations
Budget -- Children 10 and younger (up to two per adult) ski free here, and they stay free in some lodges too. (Lift tickets are half the adult rate for additional children.) At the ski-in, ski-out Huntley Lodge, children 10 and under stay free in the same room with parents. When parents reserve a one-bedroom condo at the neighboring Shoshone Condominium Hotel, children can sleep on the Murphy bed in the living room.
The budget-minded adult crowd books into the three-story Mountain Lodge, a five-minute walk from the lifts, which has sleeping rooms for up to four people. Each room has its own shower. For two people in a room it's $22 a person, and for four, $15 each. The Mountain Lodge, (800) 831-3509, also has condominiums with kitchenette that run from $95, for a unit sleeping up to four, to $400 for a three-bedroom unit with Jacuzzi bath and sleeping up to eight. The Mountain Lodge has a pub with live country and rock music, a TV and game room and an outdoor Jacuzzi bath.
The early season Right Turn package, good Dec. 11 to 25, include four nights' lodging at Huntley Lodge, three days' lifts, breakfast buffet daily and a 50 percent discount on rental equipment. Prices start at $234 a person, double occupancy, for the package, which also includes daily ski lessons, a ski race and awards party.
The Lookout Cafe, the skiers' cafeteria at the base, has hearty breakfasts. For light fare you can visit the New York Deli. These two have the same number, (406) 995-4211. Levinski's Pizza, (406) 995-4646, is a popular lunch spot. At all three you can eat well for about $7.
There is free cross-country skiing at Yellowstone National Park; trailheads are about 20 miles from Big Sky.
Deluxe -- One option is to check into a seventh-floor loft unit or a Shoshone suite at the Shoshone Condominium Hotel (call Big Sky), a ski-in, ski-out property with a pool, health spa and fitness club. A unit on the higher floors has the best views of the slopes and surrounding wilderness of snowclad, jagged peaks and lodgepole pines. The Shoshone Suites have a living room with a Murphy bed and gas fireplace, kitchen, private bedroom and two bathrooms. The loft units also have a second bedroom (partially open) with private bath in the loft.
In prime season, Jan. 3 to March 27, the package rate for seven nights' lodging and five days' lifts in a Shoshone suite is $1,067 a person, double occupancy. The prime season nightly rate for loft units (up to six guests) is $365 a night plus tax. You could book a private instructor for your group. Private all-day lessons are $225 a person; $20 per additional person.
The Huntley Lodge buffet breakfast has omelet and waffle bars. The cost is $8.95; children, $6.75.
Andiamo, (406) 995-2220, serves Italian cuisine; the Cafe Edelweiss, (406) 995-4665, for German and Austrian dishes. Dinner at these restaurants runs between $10 and $20 plus wine.
A sleigh ride dinner at Lone Mountain Ranch, (406) 995-4644, has to be reserved way ahead -- book when you make your lodging reservations. The sleigh, pulled by Belgian draft horses, heads to a log cabin where dinner is cooked on a century-old stove. Afterward, an entertainer spins yarns and croons Western ballads. The cost of the dinner and ride is $42; children, $37.
One of the most extraordinary nonskiing activities in ski country is a snowmobile (or a snowcoach) ride through Yellowstone National Park. West Yellowstone, where you pick up the snow vehicles, is about 50 miles from Big Sky. In the winter, elk, bison and trumpeter swans collect around the thermal geysers framed by rime-coated trees. Daylong trips go to Old Faithful or Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone. The trips cost $58.50 for snowmobiling, for one or two riders; from $55 a person for a snowcoach ride. These trips can be booked through the concierge at Huntley or Shoshone.
 
OREGON
MOUNT BACHELOR
Mount Bachelor, Post Office Box 1030, Bend, Ore. 97709
(503) 382-2442; central reservations, (800) 829-2442
Budget -- In addition to the usual daily passes, weekly passes and season tickets, Mount Bachelor also offers the Flextime Point Ticket. The Point Ticket is sold in two versions: 200 points for $33 or 400 points for $65. Each time a skier boards a lift, 13 to 20 points, depending on the length of the lift, are deleted from the ticket. A ticket is good for three years or as long as it takes for you to ski up your points, whichever comes first. The resort also allows skiers to share tickets.
Of course, if you plan on skiing more than 10 long runs a day, a normal day pass for $31 makes more sense. But the Point Ticket is good for late-risers, early-retirers, and couples who feel that the mountain isn't big enough for both of them.
Children 6 and under ski -- or can play on the slopes -- free. Children 7 to 12 pay $17.50 for a one-day lift ticket.
Fifteen dollars gets you a fully-equipped bed in the bunk room of the Mill Inn, (503) 389-9198, cooked breakfast and access to the outdoor hot tub. A private room starts at $35 for two, and a room with private bath is $50. The 10-room inn is well within walking distance of the town of Bend; a free shuttle bus to the slopes, 20 miles away, runs four times a day in each direction. Shuttle service begins Dec.19.
Inexpensive alternatives to skiing include a visit to the Crooked River National Grasslands, (503) 447-9640. It can be very cold in the wildlife viewing blinds, but glimpses of bald eagles, wild horses, antelope and elk are always possible, and free.
For $9, cross-country skiers have access to 55 kilometers of groomed trails that encompass areas declared by Powder Magazine to be "the best close-to-home back-country skiing in America."
Deluxe -- The Sunriver Lodge represents the high end of the Bachelor's accommodations spectrum. On this sprawling complex on 9,600 acres, complete with village mall, there are several hot tubs and a racquetball club as well condominiums. At the lodge's restaurant, Meadows, lunches average $20, dinners $30. Rooms for two are $87, or $110 from Dec. 18 to Jan. 2. (800) 547-3922.
The ultimate rarefied apres-ski experience is a trip to the Pine Mountain Observatory at 6,300 feet above sea-level, and about 45 minutes' drive from Bend. During thin-moon nights, the 15- , 24- and 32-inch telescopes provide a view of local stars, galaxies and planets that is difficult to forget. Visits for groups are organized by special arrangement and by appointment only, (503) 382-8331. A donation of $2 a person is suggested.
Among the little luxuries at Mount Bachelor are the espresso and cappuccino sold at the West Village (base) and Pine Marten (midmountain) lodges and also from a movable vendor wagon. An espresso is $1.50, a cappuccino, $1.75.
 
UTAH
DEER VALLEY
Box 3149, Park City, Utah 84060
Information and reservations, (800) 424-3337 or (801) 649-1000
 Budget -- Deer Valley is indisputably a luxury resort, so even the least expensive package isn't cheap. However, the ambiance can cost as little as $93 a person a night -- a rate based on six people lodging four nights in a luxury three-bedroom condo with fireplace and hot tub. The package includes three days of skiing for each person. The condo will probably not be ski-in, ski-out, but close to the free shuttle bus stops.
If you want to ski Deer Valley for $43, the cost of a one-day lift ticket (or $46 during the more expensive holiday period, Dec. 26 to Jan. 3), but that $93 lodging is still too much, there are lots of less expensive accommodations in the heart of Park City, 12 miles away or 45 minutes away in Salt Lake City. Call (800) 453-1360 for information about lodging in Park City. Contact Ski Utah, 150 West 500 South, Salt Lake City, Utah 84101; (801) 534-1779, for information about lodging in Salt Lake City. Price out the multiday passes at Deer Valley -- example: a six-day-out-of-seven pass is $234 -- and use the shuttle buses moving skiers around Deer Valley and Park City, or the inexpensive ski buses running to and from Salt Lake City.
Breakfast is cheapest if you cook your own in a condo, but McHenry's Grill is a good choice for lunch (on a warm day, join the sun worshipers on McHenry's beach). McHenry's serves grilled sandwiches, chilis, soups and salads, and a couple of these would be $5 to $8. It can be reached through the resort's number. Park City's streets are lined with inexpensive and moderately priced restaurants, such as Mount Air Cafe, (801) 649-8968, the Eating Establishment, (801) 649-8284, and Pastabilities, (801) 645-8898. In all three, dinner can be had for less than $15.
Deluxe -- The options for a luxury stay are abundant. A premium lesson package ($37) includes top-of-the-line skis, boots and poles. A four-hour "style and elegance" clinic is $55. If you really have an unlimited budget, you can plunk down $1,000 and ski with Stein Eriksen for the day. Deer Valley Photography will follow you around the slopes for a fee (approximately $500 for the day) that includes judicious editing.
Book well ahead for fine dining at the intimate Cafe Mariposa (booked through the resort), with its reputation for blending classic and current cuisines. Entrees range from $21 to $30. The seafood buffet at the Snow Park Lodge now runs six nights a week ($34, $17 for 12 and under).
Three nights in the 117-unit Stein Ericksen Lodge and two days skiing at Deer Valley costs $673 a person, double occupancy. The rate drops to $476 a person, double occupancy, in a one-bedroom condo. Amenities include a eated outdoor pool with a glass shield, heated sidewalks, a health club and two restaurants.
The ultimate extravagance might be purchasing a membership in the Deer Valley Club, scheduled to open Dec. 15. This ski-in, ski-out property will have full hotel services for members and guests, including a restaurant (limited service in the first season), lounge, clubhouse and fitness center. Memberships (which range from $82,000 to $124,000) include an interest in the entire project and lodging. It's like a private country club with 82 bedrooms in 30 condominiums. (801) 649-4446.
 
SUNDANCE
Box A-1, Sundance, Utah 84604
(801) 225-4107; information and reservations, (800) 892-1600; snow report, (801) 225-4100.
Budget -- Robert Redford's Sundance, perched on the flank of Mount Timpanogos, is more a retreat than a ski resort. Lift tickets at Sundance are just $25 every day and the skiing is very good. Cross-country skiing on Sundance's Nordic trails, which wind through the pristine Elk Meadows Preserve, is both a budget saver -- costing only a trail fee -- and a visual pleasure.
Two people ski free with stays of three nights or more in the resort's Sundance Cottages. (The offer must be booked at the time of reservations and is not valid Dec. 19 to Jan. 2.) The choice of these adjoining and elegantly rustic privately owned homes directly affects one's budget. The rough-hewn pine buildings are set in the woods, the most expensive of them in the new cottages at the base. Cottages range from $150 to $575 a night from Jan. 1 to March 31, less outside those dates, except for Christmas week. Lodging guests pay $25 a day for the two-hour learn-to-ski group lesson and equipment rental (not valid before Jan. 2).
Cottages have full kitchens and the resort runs a grocery shopping service. Continental breakfast is free to overnight guests. At lunchtime you can go through the cafeteria line at Creekside or have a bowl of soup at Bearclaw's atop the mountain.
There are only two restaurants open in the evening at Sundance, so skiers on a budget often join local residents having burgers or trout at the nearby Chalet, on the Provo River, (801) 224-4850, or drive into Provo for Mexican food at Los Hermanos, (801) 375-5732, and a stop at Johnny B's stand-up comedy club, (801) 377-6910. At both restaurants dinner can be had for $8 to $10. Johnny B's has a $5 cover charge. Other low budget entertainment includes the weekend performances by Sundance Theater, a group of local actors,of Broadway shows at Sundance ($10); and plays at the Hales Center Theater ($6), a theater in the round featuring local talent, in Provo, (801) 226-8600.
Park City, 30 minutes away, has lots of entertaining, inexpensive restaurants, bars and a brewpub called Wasatch. The cheapest entertainment of all is to check out one of the outstanding movies from the Sundance Video Library. Many of the Sundance Institute Films are on file.
Deluxe -- Visitors can book three nights in a Sundance Village Cottage, dinner in the Tree Room restaurant, daily breakfast in the Grill Room, one two-hour ski lesson and daily passes for Alpine or Nordic skiing. Cost: $499 a person, double occupancy, available Dec. 11 to 19 and Jan. 3 to March 31. A private instructor to show you the mountain and help your skiing can be hired for for $175 a day.
Those who like lots of space may reserve one of the luxurious Sundance mountain homes set in the pines. The Bullock "cabin," for example, has all the amenities of a luxury home including a large indoor Jacuzzi bath. Price is $575 a night during regular season, and it sleeps 13. Breakfast can be had in the Grill Room at the base of the slopes, and lunch or dinner in the Tree Room, enriched with native American art and Western memorabilia from Robert Redford's private collection. Most dinner entrees are $16 to $20; lunch will be about $8.
Off-slope activities include snowmobiling in Provo Canyon or around Park City, (801) 222-0882; glider plane rides over Mount Timpanogos, (801) 654-5831, and hot-air balloon rides, (801) 649-1217. A snowmobile ride costs $50 a person for two hours; glider, $95 for an hour; balloon, $75 for half-hour, $135 an hour. Through guest services, one could arrange for a chauffeured limousine ride into Salt Lake City (one hour away) for a symphony and an elegant dinner. The round-trip limo would cost about $150, the concert, $15, and dinner, around $25.
 
THE NORTHEAST
 
MAINE
SUGARLOAF/USA
Sugarloaf/USA, Kingfield, Me. 04947
(207) 237-2000; on-mountain lodging, (800) 843-5623; area-wide reservations, (800) 843-2732
Budget -- At this resort in western Maine, early season and spring skiing offer lower rates: $25 a day for a lift pass until Christmas and the same price most of April compared with the regular price of $38. During White White World Week, Jan. 25 to 29, adult lift prices are $20 a day, and a lift-and-lodging package is $59 a person a day compared with $80 to $100 during most of the season. The package, which includes one of the resort's rooms on the mountain, comes with a group lesson, Alpine or Nordic, and use of health club.
Another possible saving is offered by a midmountain lift ticket that limits the holder to beginning and intermediate trails. That all-day ticket costs $19 and is available all season. So is the minimountain ticket, good for beginner slopes only, at $5 a day.
Restaurants in the area offer two meals for the price of one on a rotating schedule on Sunday through Thursday, and the Seasons Restaurant at the Sugarloaf Inn, (207) 237-2000, has a popular family dinner special every Friday night.
If you still have some spring in your legs after a day of downhill or cross-country, there's always free skating at Sugarloaf Inn. During school vacation weeks, children's festivals and day and night activities -- sliding, movies and such -- are often free.
When slopeside activities pall, visitors may take in the Stanley Museum in Kingfield, about 16 miles away, and get an eyeful of three old Stanley Steamer cars -- 1905, 1910 and 1916 -- produced by the brothers F. E. and F. O. Stanley. These are working cars, not just museum pieces. As an added fillip, the museum also displays photographs by Chansonetta Stanley Emmons (1858-1937), sister of the twins F. E. and F. O. The museum is open Tuesday through Sunday from 1 to 4 P.M.; the suggested donation is $1 and 50 cents for children. Closed in November and April.
Deluxe -- The penthouse suite at Sugarloaf Mountain Hotel has three bedrooms, hot tub and sauna, and the rate is $350 and $500 a night, depending on the season.
A private skiing instructor costs $250 a day. At the Sugartree Health Club, a half-hour massage costs $30, an hour is $48, and an hour and a half is $60. A session with a certified personal trainer is $25; the trainer will also do a body composition analysis. Three sessions cost $65.
Visitors can also take a ride on a two-person dog sled pulled by a team of Samoyeds. A 25-minute trip costs $50.
For dining, try One Stanley Avenue in Kingfield, (207) 265-5541 -- reopening Dec. 1. A memorable meal for two will cost about $80, including a bottle of wine. The classic Maine cuisine includes roast duck with rhubarb glaze, sweetbreads with chives in applejack, maple cider chicken, and dilled lobster in a cream sauce on a bed of shredded zucchini.
Arabella's, in Sugarloaf Village Center, (207) 237-2262, charges about $55 a couple, including wine, for dinner. It blends New England, French and American cuisine, an example being one appetizer, smoked Maine mussel in a cream vin blanc sauce over angel hair pasta.
 
NEW HAMPSHIRE
LOON MOUNTAIN
Loon Mountain, Kancamagus Highway, Lincoln, N.H.03251
(603) 745-8111; snow conditions, (603) 745-8100; lodging, (800) 229-7829, ext. 5262, or (800) 227-4191
Budget -- For skiers who want to save time or money or both, Loon has introduced pay-by-the-run ticketing. With this plan, available on weekdays, skiers buy a quantity of points instead of a regular all-day lift ticket. The points are bar-coded on their tickets and each lift has a designated point value that is deducted by an electronic scanner before riding. This allows skiers to ski for part of a day or take only a few rides, and the tickets are good for the entire season.
Early and late season -- from opening until Dec. 13 and from March 29 until closing -- provide the best lift ticket deals at Loon, with prices at $20 a day for adults and $14 for juniors, versus $32 and $21 during the regular season. Loon also has a new reduced price ticket at $26 for skiers age 13 to 21 for the regular season.
An instruction bargain for advanced skiers who want to perfect their skills is the Hard Core Ski Clinics that specialize in steeps, bumps, powder or hardpack, depending on snow conditions. These classes are $25 for two hours of intensive skiing. For skiers 50 and over, the Flying 50's Plus program is offered on Thursdays and Fridays. Skiers join the program for $15 and for $21 a day get a morning snack, all-day guided skiing and lift tickets.
Midweek during non-holiday periods, skiers can stay at the Mountain Club on Loon (800-433-3413), within skiing distance to the lifts, for $69.95 per person, per night, double occupancy. The packages include daily lift tickets and for an additional $25 per person, breakfast and dinner are also included.
The best meal deals at the mountain can be found in any of the cafeterias in the two base lodges or mid-mountain at Camp 3 or at the top of the Gondola in the Summit Lodge.
Deluxe -- The weekend and holiday rates at the Mountain Club on Loon range from $159 for a room up to $369 for a three-room suite on the top floor with a broad view of the mountain. Both full-price and bargain-package guests have free access to the fitness club in the hotel, which has workout equipment, an outdoor hot tub, racquetball, saunas, steam rooms and an indoor swimming pool.
While the Mountain Club has Rachel's restaurant with dinner entrees ranging from $5 to $15, the Woodstock Inn (603-745-3951) in in North Woodstock about three miles away, is the spot for an elegant evening of leisurely, candlelight dining in the Clement Room. Six-course meals selected from a menu with 45 entrees range from $22 to $60 for two, not including tax, gratuities or wine. For a leisurely lunch, the Granite Bar in the Mountain Club has sandwiches and main courses from $3.50 to $8.95.
In Lincoln, which is just down the road, the Mill at Loon has upscale shopping offering boutiques for women's clothing, leather garments, jewelry, furniture and rugged outdoor clothing.
For women who want a special ski learning experience, Loon offers Wicked Good Women's Ski Weeks with five hours of skiing each day taught by top women instructors. These high-mileage, low-stress programs cost $90 for three days or $150 for five days for the instruction with lift tickets extra.
 
NEW YORK
HUNTER MOUNTAIN SKI BOWL
Hunter, N.Y. 12442
Information: (518) 263-4223; snow conditions (800) 367-7669; lodging (800) 775-4641 and (518) 263-4641
 Budget -- Hunter's daily adult lift ticket went up $1 to $39 this season, but several other prices went down. Children 12 and under, for instance, ski free during midweek nonholiday periods when they are accompanied by an adult who buys a lift ticket; second and third children with the same adult pay half the regular $26 junior price. To give skiers age 13 to 17 a break, a new Youth ticket has been introduced at $32.
The beginner package that includes a lift ticket, class lesson and rental equipment has been reduced from $52 to $48. Seniors, 65 and older, pay the junior price of $26 for a lift ticket, while those 70 and over who are members of the 70 Plus Club (which they can join for a $5-lifetime membership fee) can ski free.
Inexpensive meals in Hunter's base lodge begin with the Pizza Bar ($1.25 a slice) and Colonel Hall's Soup Bar ($1.50) up to the cafeteria with burgers, franks and snacks. Jerry's Deli has sandwiches from $3.95.
The lowest-priced accommodations in the region can be found at the bed and breakfast inns for about $85 a room per night; the resort's new telephone reservation service (number above) can help with arrangements 24 hours a day, seven days a week.
Deluxe -- Luxury is not Hunter's main appeal, but occasionally a bit of elegance is added to the scene. The Gallery in the base lodge, for instance, exhibits arts and crafts of local artists with a few works at higher prices as well as many less expensive pieces. Hunter's deluxe skiing offering is a two-hour private lesson with an instructor, who is proficient enough to be an examiner of other instructors, for $95 for the first person, $30 for each additional student. High-performance demonstration skis can be rented daily for $27.50 or, with boots and poles, for $45.50.
In the base lodge, The Restaurant offers dining with waiter service and wide-open views of the slopes with lunches ranging from $5.50 for burgers to $12.95 for main entrees. The Sushi Bar in the Summit Lounge serves all day with prices beginning at $3 an item. For evening meals starting at around $30 a person, there are La Griglia in Windham, (518) 734-4499, serving Italian food; Chateau Belleview in Tannersville, (518) 589-5525, French, and the Swiss Chalet (formerly Werner's Swiss Chalet) in Hunter, (518) 589-5445, with Continental dishes.
The Liftside condominiums offer ski-in, ski-out access (when there is natural snow on the ground), plus fireplaces, cable TV, washer-dryers and whirlpools. Prices per night are $225 for a one-bedroom unit that sleeps four, $300 for two bedrooms or $375 for three bedrooms. The two and three-bedroom condos both sleep up to six people.
The nearby Scribner Hollow Lodge, (800) 395-4683, has a variety of accommodations ranging from theme rooms, decorated like a hunting lodge or a Southwestern adobe to a penthouse suite. The basic room rate, which includes two meals, is $72 weekdays and $80 weekends, per person, double occupancy. The two-bedroom penthouse suite with a sunken living room, fireplace, stereo and large balcony is $140 weekdays and $175 weekends, a person, double occupancy. Scribner Hollow also has an indoor pool that is designed like an underground cave with four waterfalls, plus a Jacuzzi bath, saunas, a massage room and an adjacent cocktail bar.
 
VERMONT
STOWE
Stowe Mountain Resort, Stowe, Vt. 05672
(802) 253-7311; information and central reservations, (800) 247-8693; reservations for Inn at the Mountain and adjacent condominums, (800) 253-4754; ski conditions, (802) 253-2222
Budget -- One of the best things in Stowe is free. It's the 5.3-mile paved Recreation Path, which links town and surrounds, by bicycle in summer, on cross-country skis in winter. Another 100 kilometers of interconnected cross-country trails can be reached with the purchase of a single ticket costing $8.
While Stowe lift tickets are among the most expensive in Vermont, buying a multiday package -- as at most areas -- brings down the price. Last season Stowe charged $39 for a single day; at this writing it had not announced this season's price for a daily ticket. Multiday tickets this season will be $70 for two days, $102 for three, $134 for four, $165 for five.
This year the ski area is offering free skiing and lodging for each child under 12 accompanied by a parent who buys lodging for at least five days. It also has the Two-Day Guarantee. If the owner of a two-day pass doesn't like the look of conditions on the second morning, and returns the ticket by 8:50 A.M., he or she gets either a refund for the difference between a one- and two-day ticket or a voucher for another full day's skiing.
Lodging at lower cost -- compared with several other local accommodations -- can be had at the Sun and Ski, (800) 448-5223, which will charge $61 for a room on weekdays in January and March, $65 in February. Weekend rates will be $77 in January and March, $81 in February. These rates are for two people and include a home-baked breakfast buffet. The Sun and Ski is five miles from the slopes.
Cheaper still is the simple but comfortable Vermont State Ski Dorm and Hostel, (802) 253-4010, which from Dec 1 to April charges $27.50 a person, including dinner and breakfast, for a bed in a communal room. Book ahead. There are men's and women's sections and a common room with fireplace. Most guests are young people who walk the quarter mile or so to the slopes.
Stowe's best food buys are McCarthy's, (802) 253-8626, for breakfast and lunch; China Garden, (802) 253-7191, for Cantonese and Szechuan; Miguel's Stowe Away, (802) 253-7574, for Mexican, and what must be the most discreet McDonald's in the country for burgers and fries -- it's disguised as a brick Colonial building and has the smallest of golden arches. Breakfast at McCarthy's can include pancakes at $3.09, while for lunch there are hamburgers from $2.39, roast pork and potato, $4.49, and Reuben sandwich, $4.29. China Garden's appetizers are about $4 and main dishes from $5 to $10. At Miguel's a favorite dish is fajitas with beef or shrimp, warm tortillas, rice, beans and a vegetable for $12.50. An enchilada plate is $9.75. You can eat well for about $15. Mexican beers are $3 a bottle.
Deluxe -- Among the top-of-the-line hostelries are Topnotch at Stowe, (800) 451-8686, which houses Stowe's only true spa, and has room rates of $77 to $112 a person a day, depending on size and location of room, in ski season. Another is the Trapp Family Lodge, (800) 826-7000, where rates for a double room in the main lodge are $240 a night, including breakfast and dinner and cross-country trail fees. Three-night packages include room for two, breakfast and dinner and either cross-country or downhill ski ticket. With the cross-country fee, the package costs $597 to $669, depending on day of arrival; the downhill package is from $793 to $865.
The Inn at the Mountain, a New England-style inn that has been modernized, is among the accommodations run by the Stowe Mountain Resort, which owns the ski operation. The Inn can be booked through the resort's number; it charges $195 for two, including breakfast and dinner at H. H.Bingham's, a restaurant owned by the resort (higher at Christmas). The inn has a fitness center and restaurant.
H. H. Bingham's and the Cliff House have the same number, (802) 253-3000, and were refurbished recently. Cliff House is perched at the top of the Mount Mansfield gondola and is reached by riding the lift; the round trip is included in the set price for dinner of $35, excluding drinks. Among the entrees: North Atlantic salmon rolled in fresh herbs and served with a white butter sauce, and grilled marinated south Texas antelope served with a perigourdine sauce. At Bingham's, at the base of the mountain, dishes include roasted Vermont turkey with apricot chutney, and a shellfish stew. Entrees are around $15.
 
STRATTON MOUNTAIN
Stratton Mountain, Vt. 05155
(800) 843-6867; 24-hour information line, (802) 297-2200
Budget -- The $25 Frequent Skier Card saves $17 off the lift ticket price in early and late season, and $10 off in mid-season, except holidays. As at most ski areas, buying a multiday package brings appreciable savings. When skiers reserve lodging, a two-day pass costs $64; a three-day pass is $93; four-day, $120, and five-day, $125.You purchase the pass when you make your reservation; the ticket is waiting for you at the hotel at check-in time. A regular adult lift ticket costs $34 in midweek, $39 on weekends.
Stratton offers additional savings for families. When adults buy a lift pass for three days or more, they can buy a junior ticket for a youngster aged 7 to 12 for $10 a day. Children under 6 ski free. Ordinarily, junior tickets are $24.
Midweek lodging can be had for as little as $39 for two at the Lodge at Trout Pond in Londonderry, (802) 824-6608, eight miles from the slopes. The gray and blue painted lodge is a long low two-story building with 24 rooms, restaurant and bar, and rooms have private bath.
It costs $10 a day to ski the area's 22 kilometers of groomed cross-country trails.
Another diversion is the $5 sleigh rides that leave most afternoons and evenings from the Sun Bowl Base Lodge. A $4 cover charge gains entry to a Tyrolean Night with the Stratton Mountain Boys' oompah band in the Bear's Den at the main base lodge most evenings.
For hungry families, Mulligan's in the Village Square, (802) 297-9293, has sandwiches, steaks, seafood and a children's menu. A full-size hamburger for an under-12-year-old is $1.95. Entrees run from $11.95 to $16.95.
Deluxe -- When it opened in 1960, Stratton had the reputation as a playground for well-heeled travelers, and, by and large, it has retained its upscale atmosphere. The Stratton Mountain Village, which cost $75 million to construct in the late 1980's, is half Kitzbuhel, half Disney
esque Main Street, U.S.A., and while it's not quite as self-consciously posh as it was a decade ago, the finer things in life are still in evidence.
Von Bargen's Jewelry, (802) 297-2975, sells designergold earrings for up to $10,000 a pair. The Bogner Ski Shop, (802) 297-2767, features Melody, a one-piece ski suit that relieves liftline boredom by playing "Old MacDonald" on a sewn-in computer chip. It sells for $2,898. Neither look out of place on Stratton's well-groomed slopes.
Some of the most comfortable accommodations are in the Stratton Village Lodge, behind the base lodge at the mountain, and the nearby Stratton Mountain Inn, which are both Colony Resort properties and have the same number, (802) 297-2500. The inn has a restaurant and a small spa with sauna, Jacuzzi bath, whirlpool and exercise apparatus. Rates for two at both places range from around $109 or $119 a night in midweek to $165 on a holiday weekend. The lodge has 91 rooms, the inn, 120.
One of the resort's own one-bedroom, ski-in, ski-out mountain villas with a fireplace costs from $90 to $290 a night, depending on room and season. Prices are generally around $170 in midweek; the lower rates apply in early December and after mid March, and the top rate would apply on a holiday weekend.
Private ski school lessons are $45 an hour. Really dedicated students can rent an all-day instructor for $245.
The most expensive skiing package at Stratton is the Tyrolean Ski Week. For $275, it includes five days of lift tickets, small-class ski lessons and escorted skiing with an instructor-guide. It also comes with evening entertainment and ski rental, breakfast and lunch.
For dinner, the Birkenhaus, (802) 297-2000, is the top-of-the-line restaurant at Stratton, and it's right on the mountain. The menu is changed daily, the dishes are European in style, and entrees include Wiener Schnitzel, with prices from $17.50 to $20.
 
CANADA
QUEBEC
MONT TREMBLANT
Station Mont Tremblant, 3005 Chemin Principal, Mont Tremblant, Quebec, Canada J0T 1Z0
Resort information, (819) 425-8711; from Montreal, (514) 476-9552; from Canada and the United States, (800) 461-8711
Budget -- Mont Tremblant Reservations, (819) 425-8681 or (800) 567-6760, offers a free, centralized service for rentals of condominiums, chalets (private homes) or hotel rooms (ranging from deluxe to budget). Rates for condominiums and chalets are divided into three categories: low season, before Dec. 25, Jan. 3 to Feb. 13 and March 21 until end of season in late April; regular season, Feb. 14 to March 13, and high season, Dec. 25 to Jan.2 and March 14 to March 20. Among accommodations here in the Laurentians northwest of Montreal is the Auberge le Lupin, (819) 425-5474, a two-story wooden house with shared bathrooms and a cross-country ski trail at its doorstep. Rates, including breakfast, for two people are $56 for the first night, $40 for each additional night. From Dec. 23 until Jan. 3: $72, and $56 for additional nights. (All prices have been converted to United States dollars on the basis of $1 Canadian equalling 80 American cents.)
Auberge Escapade, (819) 425-7311, a three-story, Dutch barn-style lodge, is just under two miles from the mountain's lifts and just over half a mile from the village. The Escapade is favored by families and groups. Its Pub Anglais and Bistro restaurant offer food and drink for all tastes. Rates per person, in double occupancy, are $46.40 for bed and breakfast for two days in low season; $62.40 high season. A room for two nights with breakfast and supper is $70.40 a person low season; five nights, $164. High season is $86.40 for two nights, $204 for five. A Sunday-to-Friday package, with five nights' lodging, two meals daily and a six-day ski pass is $250.40 and $308.80 a person. The inn has shared bathrooms. Ski tickets are available at reduced cost.
Hotel Mont Tremblant, (819) 425-3232, was built in 1918 but has been completely renovated, retaining the long balconies across the front of the three-story building. There are 30 guest rooms. The hotel, in the village two miles from the mountain, is close to ski shops, equipment rentals, restaurants and grocery stores. The two-night package from $129.60 to $136 (according to the date) a person includes two breakfasts and two table d'hote dinners and two-day ski pass. A five-night, six-day package from $290 to $318 a person includes Sunday-to-Friday ski pass, breakfast and dinner and free shuttle service to the mountain.
Deluxe -- One place booked through the service is the Chalet Renwa, a two-story, contemporary house about two and a half miles from Mont Tremblant. It sleeps up to 12 people in five bedrooms, and is equipped with dishwasher, microwave, washer and dryer, sauna, two bathrooms, television with cable and VCR. The house costs $600 for two nights throughout the season. A five-night stay starts at $920 early in the season, rising to $1,340 during the holidays.
The Mont Tremblant resort's condominiums range from one to three bedrooms, and are equipped with fireplace, color cable television, kitchen and views of the mountain. Among these are the Nansenhus three-bedroom condominiums, starting at $520 for two nights throughout the season. A five-night rental is from $772 in low to $1,000, regular, and $1,180, high season.
Gray Rocks Resort, (800) 567-6767, lies at the foot of its own ski area (Gray Rocks) but is only about five minutes from Mont Tremblant. The resort's Ski Week package starts at $734.40 a person and includes six nights' lodging (Sunday through Saturday), three meals a day, seven-day ski ticket for Gray Rocks, 22 hours of instruction, access to the hotel's La Spa fitness center and indoor pool, and social events. Guests who prefer to ski at Mont Tremblant can buy the package for $802.40 but don't get lunch. The hotel also has two-night package deals, starting at $202.40 a person, for Gray Rocks skiing only. The package includes two breakfasts and two lunches, ski tickets for two days, access to fitness center and pool, and social events. The hotel guarantees a 20 percent premium on United States funds exchanged until April 15, 1993.
Among many good restaurants is Kandahar, operated by the Tremblant Club on Avenue Cuttle; (819) 425-2731 or (800) 363-2413. The Kandahar's table d'hote menu -- French and Italian dishes -- is $20; a seafood buffet on Thursday and Saturday evening is $26.40. L'Abbe du Nord, 1112 Rue Deslauriers, (819) 425-8394, occupies a renovated presbytery filled with knotted pine paneling and antiques. One specialty is barbecued back ribs, and dinner is from $16 to $20, not including drinks.
 
ALBERTA
BANFF-LAKE LOUISE
Banff-Lake Louise Tourism Bureau, Box 1298, Banff, Alberta, Canada T0L 0C0
(403) 762-3777, or Ski Banff-Lake Louise, Box 1085, Banff, Alberta, Canada T0L 0C0
(403) 762-4561); snow conditions, (800) 661-888
Budget -- Skiers with plenty of energy should be able to get value for money with all the skiing available. The Banff-Lake Louise resort encompasses three ski areas -- Lake Louise, Sunshine Village, Mount Norquay -- connected by a shuttle bus and accessible with one ticket for a total of 28 lifts. Various rates apply at each of the three areas, including reductions for seniors, students and children, but a basic three-day pass is $91.20. (All prices have been converted to United States dollars on the basis of $1 Canadian equalling 80 American cents.)
Ski Banff-Lake Louise offers several packages, including one, the Super Saver -- available unil Dec. 18 and from April 19 -- that combines six nights' accommodations, unlimited use of lifts at the three areas, free shuttle and a voucher for night skiing at Mount Norquay. Prices vary according to the number of persons per room and the hotel. In the budget category, the six-night program is available at the 47-room Swiss Village Lodge in Banff, (800) 661-1272, for from $221.60 a person in double occupancy. A three-night package is $122.40 a person. The lodge has cable television, hot tub, whirlpool and sauna, swimming pool and restaurant. Most hotels allow children under 12 to stay free in parents' room.
Banff Voyager Inn, (403) 762-3301, has rooms for two with two double beds for $36 until Dec. 24. Third and fourth people pay $4 each a night. For the holiday period the rate rises to $52, then drops to $36 again. A larger room with two queen-size beds and a sofa couch that sleeps two is $44 for two people in early season, rising to $60, with extra people paying another $4 each. The 88-room inn is a five-minute walk from downtown Banff.
Downtown and with 46 rooms, the Red Carpet Inn, (403) 762-4184, has hot tubs, heated underground parking and elevator. A room for two is $36, rising to $60 from Dec. 26 to New Year's.
Banff has some fast-food eateries, such as Kentucky Fried Chicken and the Cafe Alpenglow, a cafeteria at the Banff International Hostel, (403) 762-4122. A main dish at the Alpenglow with soup or salad and beverage is generally $4.76. In Lake Louise the budget skier might try the Bee Line Chicken and Pizza, (403) 522-2006, or the casual R & B's Uptown Eatery, (403) 522-3711, which is a favorite of employees at the Chateau Lake Louise resort. Specializing in fresh fast food, it has burgers, sandwiches and $4.40 subs. From R & B's "recession menu," diners can get soup and half a sub for $4.
Deluxe -- The Banff Springs Hotel and Chateau Lake Louise -- both owed by Canadian Pacific -- have all the resort amenities, plentiful dining choices, and views of the surrounding mountains. At the Banff Springs, (403) 762-2211 or (800) 828-7447, a one-bedroom suite, with whirlpool is $248 a night. The Chateau Lake Louise, (403) 522-3511 or (800) 828-7447, has one-bedroom suites with king-size bed in bedroom, queen or double hideaway in parlor, and with lakeside view starting at $256 a day. Some rooms have whirlpools.
The Buffalo Mountain Lodge in Banff, (403) 762-2400, has some one-bedroom lofts among its 85 townhouse units sleeping from two to six people. The cost of the many skiing packages depend on date; one example: six nights' accommodations and five-day ski pass for two people in January is $676.76. The lodge has a restaurant, spa, meeting rooms, a log fire in the lobby's stone fireplace, and an outdoor hot tub. Most units, decorated with antique or custom pine furniture, include down-filled duvets, fireplaces, and some have kitchenettes.
In Lake Louise Village, the Post Hotel, (403) 522-3989 or (800) 661-1586, offers open fireplaces, split-level suites and views from back rooms across a river to the ski slopes above. The guest rooms and two riverside log cabins are furnished in Canadian pine and country prints. Shoulder season rates apply before and after the Christmas holidays until Feb. 12; then after April 11. Room with whirlpool in tub is $120 ($144 in the holiday season); king-size bed, whirlpool and fireplace, $128 ($152). Economy rooms are $80 ($88) a night for two single beds; $96 ($128) for two double beds. The Post allows 10 percent off rates for stays of three days or longer for any time except between Dec. 23 and Jan 2.
The better dining establishments include the Rob Roy Room at the Banff Springs Hotel, (403) 762-6842, where a three-course dinner runs about $32, not including drinks. A chateaubriand for two is $40.
In Lake Louise the skier may opt for the Post Hotel Dining Room, (403) 522-3989), which serves Continental-style dishes, one specialty being Alberta duck. A three-course dinner is about $26. The Baker Creek Bistro, (403) 522-2182, reopens for the season on Dec. 4 and will serve dinner from 6 to 9 P.M. on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. A three-course dinner -- the bistro describes its French-influenced dishes as classic and original with light soups and sauces -- costs $20 to $24, not including wine sold at from $9.60 to $32 a bottle.
Several helicopter skiing outfits operate daily from the Banff-Lake Louise area. One is R. K. Heli-ski Panorama, (403) 762-3771 or (800) 661-6060, which offers daily trips in the Purcell Mountains at $279.20 a person, including lunch and guide service.
