HEADLINE: Perspectives: Housing Finance;
Freddie Mac Plants Its Flag in New York

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
A BROKER named Marlon Pilossoph on Sedgwick Avenue in the Bronx likens himself to a weeder. "I weed out the people they should not sell to," he says.
The beneficiary of these gardening services is the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, which built a formidable portfolio of multifamily loans in the 80's. This year it has sold 40 properties that it took back in foreclosure actions in New York City. The company says it has been finicky in choosing new owners. Mr. Pilossoph was the broker in 17 sales. 
 But Freddie Mac thinks of itself more as a planter than a weeder. Last June this national mortgage investor, with home offices in McLean, Va., moved its Northeast multifamily office from Crystal City, Va., to New York City, in a recognition of its long-term commitment to financing moderate-income or "affordable" rental housing in the city.
What began more than a year ago as a small office at 575 Lexington Avenue, at 56th Street, to handle problem loans has evolved into a permanent office that is laying the groundwork for the refinancing of so-called performing loans as well. H.L. Van Varick, former manager of the mortgage portfolio of the American Savings Bank, is the director of the office, which has a staff of 42.
The first task has been to "stabilize the portfolio," Mr. Van Varick said. Arrearages of more than two months are running at a rate of 9.08 percent, the company says, in a portfolio of 2,300 multifamily loans in New York City. The loans represent $2.2 billion in mortgage credit, probably the largest investment by any financial institution in the privately owned moderate-income housing stock of an American city.
But beyond stabilization the office is preparing for a second phase -- refinancing existing mortgages, which are just beginning to come due. Most of the loans have five-year maturities but 30-year amortization periods. The refinancings are expected to evolve next year into new methods of lending to moderate-income housing.
For example, the Community Preservation Corporation, a consortium of banks that lends for moderate-income rehabilitation in New York City, may be able to expand its activities by obtaining advance commmitments for "take-outs" on loans they originate, thereby replenishing funds for rehabilitation lending. The take-out loans become the building's long-term mortgage. Low-income housing rehabilitation may get a lift from these advance commitments as well.
Freddie Mac is a stockholder-owned corporation that was established by Congress in 1970 to provide a continuous flow of funds to primary mortgage lenders. It purchases loans from these lenders, called seller-sericers -- in multifamily finance they are usually mortgage-banking firms -- and packages them into marketable securities.
In 1991 alone it purchased $100 billion in home mortgage loans. In the multifamily field it reported last year owning 10,655 multifamily mortgages with a balance of about $10 billion.
Access to mortgage credit is essential to the long-term health of the housing stock and the quality of living conditions for its tenants. The presence of a major investor that wants to "preserve decent, affordable rental housing, consistent with sound business principles," as Freddie Mac's statement of principle puts it, is a plus for New York City's housing supply and its suppliers.
Many rental-property owners in the 80's found Freddie Mac to be the only source of mortgage financing available. Led on by a few seller-servicers and underwriting standards that often proved inappropriate in New York, some owners overindulged in credit. Some expected rents to rise at a rate that proved too optimistic. Others underestimated increases in operating costs or losses from uncollectible rents. Still others expected to be rescued by co-op conversions.
WHAT the Freddie Mac staff is now finding in property-by-property inspections, and what the owner-managers who are inheriting foreclosed buildings are reporting, provides a foretaste of the problems ahead for the housing stock. How city and state government respond is likely to determine whether the abandonment phenomenon of the 70's returns in the 90's.
"Everyone is focused on water and sewer charges," said Joni Brooks, manager of asset resolution in the New York office of Freddie Mac. "They have gone up two or three times from the original underwriting" -- a reference to the economic assumptions about operating expenses made when projects are financed.
Initial underwriting also assumed a rent-loss factor of 4 to 5 percent as a result of vacancies or collection shortfalls. In fact, the loss factor proved to be at least 10 percent in some buildings because of "back-ups" in landlord-tenant court, Ms. Brooks said.
"That has a dramatic impact on cash flow," she said.
Put another way, the failure of many judges in landlord-tenant court to collect and put in escrow tenants' rents during landlord-tenant disputes results in permanent income losses to many buildings. Ultimately this "plays out" in less income available for building operations.
Another major problem in building operations is keeping drug dealers out. To many housing managers, they are the greatest danger of all to housing preservation.
"Each loan is different," said Ms. Brooks, who calls her group at Freddie Mac a "swat team." "Though the building stock is similar on the surface, the outcome is different building by building."
OF the 40 properties sold by Freddie Mac this year, all but three or four went to private buyers for all cash. Three buildings in the Bronx were sold to housing affiliates of the Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition, a nonprofit housing operator.
The buyers tend to be experienced owner-managers who already have properties with Freddie Mac loans. In the Bronx, for example, The Realty Group at 825 East 233d Street, in which Joseph Gershenov and his cousin Joseph Yasgur are principals, bought the building at 735 Mace Avenue in the Allerton Avenue section for $2 million, including a $1.67 million Freddie Mac mortgage, or three and a half times the annual rent roll.
The rent roll includes about 25 apartments renting for $250 to $350 a month, Mr. Yasgur said. The prospect of eventual turnover and rerental at an affordable, but a market, rent provides the financial incentive to the owner.
"Freddie Mac saved the Bronx from ruin," said Mr. Gershenov. His company borrowed conservatively in the 80's on about 25 of the 70 buildings that its principals own, he said, and used the money in part to upgrade them.
Among those who are grateful that the building is out of receivership and in the hands of new owners is Roman Tokar, the 46-year-old superintendent, a mechanical engineer from Ukraine who emigrated to the United States four years ago.
"In one and a half months there have been so many changes -- only for the good," said Mr. Tokar, who was hired by the receiver and kept on by the new owner. He specified one: the computer that operates the oil burner has been repaired. Manual operation has ceased.
One major systems repair that typically was rarely done with Freddie Mac loans was plumbing replacement. An owner who believes in it strongly is Leonard Shindell, who owns 30 Bronx buildings and this year bought the 44-unit walk-up at 1165 Grand Avenue, north of Yankee Stadium, from Freddie Mac.
"If the plumbing is bad it's like a cancer," Mr. Shendell said. He is doing a $170,000 rehabilitation, financed by the Community Preservation Corporation, after buying the building for $450,000 in cash.
In Washington Heights, the Farkas Management Group, based in Forest Hills, Queens, came forward to buy the 31-unit building at 607 West 190th Street for $335,000 in cash, or $10,000 an apartment. The principal, Jeffrey Farkas, said the company owns 15 buildings with 700 apartments.
With a rent roll of $135,000 a year, the price was 2.4 times the annual rent, about the going rate for foreclosed walk-ups in low- to moderate-income areas of the city. But seven apartments rent for $150 to $225 a month, Mr. Farkas said, well below the market rent for vacancies, which is $625 a month for two bedrooms and $725 a month for three bedrooms.
"I'm 32 years old," Mr. Farkas said. "I was able to get a 15-year fixed-rate 11 percent private mortgage on the property. In 15 years I'll be 47 and I'll own the property free and clear."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1270 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Spokane, Wash.;
The Mid-80's Boom Arrives in Time for the Mid-90's

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

DATELINE: SPOKANE, WASH.

 BODY:
WATCHING the downtown core of this isolated city of the inland Northwest spring to life one recent misty morning was like being propelled back to the booming 80's. Cranes and backhoes were cranking out new buildings. Noticeably lacking were "For Sale" or "Space Available" signs.
The conversation of local business leaders as they sipped their morning coffee one recent day was about an article in The Spokesman-Review reporting that Class A office space, now about $18 a square foot, had become so scarce that anyone looking for more than 60,000 square feet might be totally out of luck. 
 Industrial space, at around $2.40 a square foot, was also in short supply, the article noted, and rents in both categories rose compared to what they were three years ago.
In addition, major new retail projects were coming on line barely fast enough to soak up the new money pouring into town from the West Coast and Canada. And hotels were so busy that some had withdrawn their discount programs. At least one, Cavanaugh's Inn on the Park, was in the midst of a $10 million expansion that will almost double its size, adding 136 bedrooms, 3 banquet rooms, conference space and a ballroom.
All of which underscored a growing awareness, both locally and among outsiders, that Spokane, a provincial city of 177,000 people and squat buildings covering 57 square miles, is joining other second-tier cities like Boise, Idaho; Sioux Falls, Iowa, and Omaha as the growth areas of the 1990's.
In Spokane the change is being greeted with a mixture of feelings. Oldtimers, especially those who went through a decade of scarce jobs and hard times, are delighted, although some worry that the boom will turn out to be, as one at the end of the 70's was, no more than a boomlet.
Those who see big profits in their future are also delighted. And there are people who feel that the new activity is but a thinly disguised Armageddon.
The most outspoken advocates for controlled growth are the newest arrivals.
To try to prevent overdevelopment and the deterioration of the quality of life that has been going on elsewhere, Spokane County is making long-range plans.
Sandwiched between the Rockies to the east and the Cascade Mountains to the west and further cut off by national forest wilderness all around, Spokane depended on the vagaries of its three indigenous industries -- logging, mining and farming -- and totally missed out on the prosperity of the 80's.
All three industries coincidentally collapsed during that boom decade, ushering in a period of despair made even rougher by the partying going on in the rest of the nation. Indeed, shabby storefronts and vacant shells still dot many of the peripheral commercial streets. And judging by their chunky, old-fashioned architectural styles, they haven't been improved in years.
But that is changing fast as pollution, overcrowding, traffic congestion, high land prices, the drug culture and violent crime drive people and businesses out of the urban sprawls of the West Coast to seemingly protected inland havens like Spokane.
Between 1981 and 1991, Spokane County's population went from 347,600 to 366,000; the city's population went from 171,200 to 178,500. For both, the bulk of that growth has been in the last few years.
The value of having this growth take place in the 1990's, as far as city leaders are concerned, is that the city has been spared, as other areas have not, backlogs of vacant office towers. Nor are there hordes of lenders riding into town eager to finance speculative office construction.
Developers are kept at bay by relatively low rents, which still preclude high returns, at least for now. So the only buildings that do go up are those that are built-to-suit, said Charles L. Dotson, Spokane's director of planning services.
A particular attraction of Spokane at this time, said Mr. Dotson, also appears to be its strong work ethic, derived from its long history as a place that attracted both pioneers and those with strong, old-fashioned religious views, both of which make for a stable and disciplined workforce.
OTHER attractions have included the abundant water supply, drawn from the adjacent lake region of northern Idaho (a boon for parched Californian companies), large tracts of available land at around $80,000 an acre, utility costs about 50 percent below those of Southern California, a streamlined building permit system that can produce approvals within weeks rather than months and a commitment by the public sector to foster rather than impede growth.
Other observers suggest the recent migrations have also resulted from the energy and commitment of Bob Cooper, the man who took over the city's Economic Development Council in 1987 and pledged to lift the area out of its economic quagmire in short order.
Sitting in his spacious office one recent morning behind a desk piled high with papers, Mr. Cooper checked off some of the results: a massive expansion of local community colleges geared to helping train local workers in needed skills for the new businesses; an influx in the last three years of dozens of high-tech companies, service companies in the medical fields and wholesale distribution centers; contacts with the new Hong Kong money flooding Western Canada less than 100 miles to the North.
The newcomers, he said, are taking space primarily along the plains west and east of the city. Among the most talked-about arrivals has been a division of the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group from Seattle, which Mr. Cooper called "Our Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval."
K. Philip Kelly, the division's general manager, said the company had indeed been attracted by the availability of less costly land here. In 1988 it bought 120 acres of hay fields west of the city. It initially built 216,000 square feet of manufacturing and 22,000 square feet of office space on 35 of those acres for a total building cost of $23 million. Land acquisition costs were not divulged but company officials say they were about one tenth what they would have been in Seattle.
The goal was to hire 80 percent of the 475-person workforce locally. Even so, the prospect of escaping the decay of congested urban areas of the West Coast appealed to so many Seattle residents that 600 of them applied within days of the announced move. "A lot had grown up here and wanted to come back," said Mr. Kelly.
Nevertheless, the policy of hiring locally remained.
The move has been so successful, both in terms of added efficiency and cost-cutting, Mr. Kelly said, that an $11 million expansion is now under way. It will add 108,000 square feet and 100 more workers to the present complex.
In August, Hi-Rel Laboratories moved in. The 23-year-old family-owned business with 13 employees handles analytical testing of advanced electronic equipment. Barbara Devany, comptroller and partner, said its former location outside of Pasadena, Calif., had become untenable.
"All the new taxes and regulations were driving us out," she said. "You can't even breathe there any more."
Here, she said, the company was able to rent 7,200 square feet of single-level space barely one mile from downtown at a cost of $40,000 a year compared to $96,000 for the same amount in Pasadena. The lease also carries an option to buy the property at the end of two years for $400,000. This compares to $900,000 for a similar building in Hi-Rel's former location.
"We'll probably exercise that option," she added. "We have clean air. No traffic. A public school system our people can use. It looks like a good investment in a growing city."

HEADLINE: TIMES SQUARE;
A Sure Winner

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I should like to submit my own proposal for Times Square. Since the area is one of the world's great fantasy lands for grown-ups, I have never agreed with the concept of office buildings being the basis for its renewal and revitalization. Quite the contrary. It seems to me that office buildings, other than bringing in people on a daily basis, would inhibit the fun, which is what the theater district and Times Square are all about. 
 My idea is that the area should be the first in the state with legal casinos. Obviously, the casinos would also be hotels, housing restaurants and shops that would attract tourists to the city. And architecturally, casinos, with their neon and basic garishness, would fit perfectly in this adult playground.
Finally, the revenues that the casinos would generate, both in taxes and tourist spending, would be a godsend to the city's economy.
 
WARREN G. LEHMAN
Wantagh, N. Y.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2944 words

HEADLINE: Executives the Economy Left Behind

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN with JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
JOE COOPER hasn't sold his beloved Corvette yet. But nine months after he was laid off from his $46,000-a-year job as a computer network manager at a Citicorp mortgage-processing center in St. Louis, he no longer sounds like the cocky middle manager he used to be. He has blown through $17,000 in savings, and in the take-it-or-leave-it job market of the 1990's, he blew one good chance when he told a prospective employer that he wanted a company car.
Gloria Walsh was let go in 1990 after 23 years as an advertising promotions manager when British Airways trimmed its ranks in New York. The really hard part begins next month: her severance pay and company-provided health coverage run out. But after 60 job interviews, she is still the odd woman out in the game of executive musical chairs. "It's more difficult the higher you go," she said. It's also more tortuous. One company has called her in time and time again for follow-up interviews. It "is still trying to find the perfect, perfect, perfect person," she said. 
 Martin L. Brown climbed the ladder steadily in 25 years at Du Pont, ending up as a vice president for manufacturing in Korea. But the company made it clear that he would not be granted a transfer back to the United States soon, and offered him an early-retirement package. At the age of 50, he began sending out resumes, something he had not done since college. "I thought I knew about re-entering the job market," he said. But "it was a black hole."
It has been pink-slip time for the white-collar set for several years. Now, even those who used to believe that they'd always have good jobs are being forced to scramble and to scale back their expectations. For managers who ate their vegetables, went to college, stayed sober and phoned home, the sorry-but-times-have-changed reality of the 1990's is hard to swallow. Instead of being wooed by headhunters and tantalized by multiple offers of ever-more-impressive bonuses and benefits, they are poring over want ads and worrying about how long they can live off savings, not to mention whether they can put a turkey on the table.
It's no picnic for former colleagues who still have jobs, either -- often they are burdened with workloads that used to be parceled out among four or five people. But for those still on the job-hunting treadmill, "there's this awful feeling that the rules of the corporate relationship have changed and somebody forgot to tell them," said Gwen Krause, an independent outplacement consultant.
Some job-hunters have become so desperate that they are promoting themselves with the kind of chance-in-a-million publicity blitzes used to sell thigh-thinning exercise videos or Ginsu knives. "You should see the blisters on my hands," said Jackie Hasenstab, of Newport Beach, Calif., who spent much of the last few weeks stuffing and mailing more than 10,000 cover letters and resumes to potential employers, with help from her friends and family. For someone who recently lost her job as a vice president at a large resort company, the price was high: she spent roughly $3,000 on postage alone.
The numbers are the stuff of everyday headlines -- a thousand white-collar workers laid off here, 500 middle managers let go there. They are the casualties of what economists call downsizing and de-layering as corporate America adapts to its ultra-fast crash diet. Even the Postal Service is laying off 40,000 supervisors.
After selling the boat and letting the athletic-club membership lapse, they are scrounging for spare change, letting the car repairs go and wondering how many mortgage payments they can miss before the bank forecloses.
Worse, says Warren Boeker, a professor of management at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, they may never again bring home fat paychecks. In the 1970's, he said, 90 percent of laid-off white-collar workers soon found similar jobs. In the late 80's, only about 50 percent did. Now the figure is down to 25 percent.
That leaves white-collar workers with "a pervasive sense of betrayal that is different than what I heard in previous slow periods," said David Bruce Robbins, a psychiatrist and author. And there may be scars when the economy bounces back. Even if they land on their feet, white-collar workers may never look at their careers or the future in quite the same way again. "The wizard behind the curtain may not be all we thought he was," said Dr. Michael F. Aronoff, an associate professor of psychiatry at Lenox Hill Hospital.
 
'Tarzan' Swings To a Flimsy Vine
 Richard Daenzer believes in what he calls the "Tarzan theory" of employment: "You don't let go of one vine until you have the next one in hand." You don't quit a $125,000-a-year real estate management job in New York in the 1980's and head for Houston. But he did anyway.
"I came here for a great opportunity to work with someone who owned 50 office buildings, beverage companies, had his own Lear jet, and was worth a couple of million dollars," said Mr. Daenzer, a 43-year-old commercial real estate manager, marveling at how much the times and his own expectations have changed. "Three years later, he went broke."
Since then, Mr. Daenzer has changed jobs three times -- more than many people in his parents' generation did in a lifetime -- with his income sometimes shrinking as low as $20,000. He has become something of a professional job-seeker, and from where he sits, the future holds more of the same. As he notes, there is more empty real estate in Houston than all the commercial space in downtown Philadelphia.
"It's not just any old recession," he said. "When you read that General Motors is going to lay off 20,000 white-collar workers, you think, How could they have that many to start with?"
The last time he lost a job, in 1991, he was a senior account executive with a real estate consulting firm. Between plant shutdowns and foreclosures, many of the firm's clients found themselves holding real estate they needed to unload but were bringing the work in-house to save money.
Mr. Daenzer polished his resume, plumbed his Rolodex for leads and answered want ads. Finally, he used more than $10,000 of savings and wrote to 7,000 banks and companies that might have unwanted real estate and be able to use his expertise.
The mass mailing yielded five decent leads, which worked out to roughly $2,000 apiece. The trouble was, they were all out-of-town companies. Hamstrung because his wife had filed for divorce shortly after he lost his job, he dropped out of the running rather than risk losing custody of his two sons, Zachary and Benjamin. Relocating "wouldn't have looked good," explained Mr. Daenzer.
The exhaustive search nonetheless gave him a feel for how tight the job market had become. So when a job finally came through in January, at the Houston office of Breunig Commercial, a Dallas-based real estate firm, he grabbed it. But he's still not out of the woods. The seven suburban buildings he is managing are part of a parcel being sold by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Government agency overseeing the savings-and-loan bailout. Mr. Daenzer's boss has said that if the deal closes he will offer to transfer him to Dallas.
Chances are, though, Mr. Daenzer will be dusting off his resume. "I consider myself a survivor," he said.
 
Whooping It Up, Then Facing Reality
 It took Joe Cooper years to get to the point where he felt he was living the American dream. It took only a few months for the dream to unravel.
Citicorp Mortgage Inc. let him go in February, along with hundreds of others at its St. Louis mortgage-processing center. He whooped it up as if he had won the lottery. At first.
"I thought I was going to make money," said Mr. Cooper, a 34-year-old computer network manager who expected to be re-employed long before the six months of severance pay from his $46,000-a-year job ran out. "Even though the economy was slow, I honestly thought it wouldn't affect me much because I was so talented and in such a good field."
Nine months later, he no longer sounds so optimistic. His family has gone through $17,000 borrowed against the equity in their house, and he raised the $1,200 December house payment only by overdrawing his checking account. He started a lawn-care business and tried teaching at a community college, but the part-time paychecks only reduced his unemployment checks. He says he may have to dip into his retirement account to buy Christmas presents for his wife and two daughters.
His departure came in part because of the computer system he worked on for Citicorp.
The system let the bank respond to mortgage applicants in 15 minutes or less, but Citicorp made too many ill-advised loans. When the Government agencies that buy such loans responded by tightening their own credit requirements, Citicorp quietly shrank its mortgage operations and consolidated them in Weehawken, N.J.
Mr. Cooper had a hint of what was coming, but his colleagues didn't believe him. His boss said: "No way, Joe. I've got 120 people working for me, and they can't fire anyone without consulting me first."
The boss's pink slip arrived that week, as did Mr. Cooper's. But the early warning gave him time to refinance his mortgage at a lower rate and pay off the loans on his-and-her Chevrolet Corvettes. And when he got a call offering him insurance on his two credit cards that would pay off the minimum balances each month in the event of disability or involuntary job loss, he took it. The policy came from another Citicorp subsidiary.
Job leads have been scarce. Networking is practically out of the question. Many of his best friends are in similar straits -- four out of five, to be exact. A local group of Corvette aficionados who meet once a week over lunch now wryly call themselves the Unemployed Corvette Owners Association.
The one solid offer Mr. Cooper unearthed through the classifieds evaporated when he made what would be a modest demand in less demanding times: that the company lease a car for him. The cost was only $1,500 more a year than having him tool around in his gas-guzzling Corvette, he argued, and a less flashy car would sit better with the company's clientele. The company agreed with his reasoning, but retracted the offer.
On Thursday, after four interviews, Mr. Cooper started work at MCI Communications, working with clients in designing telecommunications systems. The position pays $51,000 a year plus an incentive bonus, but the personal triumph was bittersweet. One of two finalists for the job was a good friend. "He was sad but pleased, because he said I needed it more than he did," Mr. Cooper said.
 
Lost Sleep at Night, Inventing by Day
 Henry A. Williams lost his sales job at General Electric at a time when most employees his age are thinking gold watches, not pink slips.
In the 11 months since then, the 63-year-old Mr. Williams has economized: he and his wife, Josette, no longer dine out, and for this year's vacation they drove to Ohio for a prep school reunion. And he has lost a lot of sleep. Mr. Williams says he now wakes up early and ponders his options. Mrs. Williams, who keeps the books in the household, says, "I just wake up in a general panic."
G.E. offered him a new job after it eliminated his old one, but taking it would have meant moving, possibly to Louisville or Cincinnati. He said thanks, but no thanks. His severance package amounted to about four or five months' salary. "The timing wasn't too bad, except for the economy," he said. "It's not easy to sell things these days."
Still, Mr. Williams has stayed busy. He set up a company with the chief of police in Ridgefield, Conn., to sell an invention that increases drivers' awareness of traffic conditions at busy intersections. He has also been selling cedar homes part time, as well as medical equipment for handicapped people. But his take-home pay is roughly 25 percent of what it was at G.E. Mrs. Williams's salary as an administrative assistant at the Juran Institute in Wilton, Conn., raises their household income to roughly 50 percent of what it used to be.
He says he misses the camaraderie at G.E. -- he drops by his old office about once a month, and still gets his hair cut at the company barber shop. But he says he has no hard feelings toward G.E., where he held a variety of computer sales and consulting positions at offices in Fairfield and Bridgeport, Conn. "I made pretty good money at times," he says, recalling all-expenses-paid sales-award trips to Las Vegas and Puerto Rico.
After he was laid off, he initially took things easy. He spent the holidays last year with his three grown daughters. He jogged 5 to 10 miles three times a week and sang in two church choirs, the same as always. He discovered that he liked setting his own pace so much that he passed up two offers to work full time in industrial sales. "Someone would have to be willing to offer me a pretty big chunk of dough to tie myself down like that," he said.
 
 
DEAR I.B.M. (OR CURRENT OCCUPANT): I'D LIKE A JOB, PLEASE
 First there was junk mail. Then came junk phone calls. Now get ready for junk resumes. Borrowing a page from direct mailers, some job seekers are papering the country with their curriculums vitae -- not just dozens, but hundreds or even thousands. And some of those job-seekers turn to Wayne Starr for help.
Like Bill Clinton, another Yale law school graduate (of a slightly later generation), Mr. Starr is a merchant of hope, pitching his message and his services to the people left out in the economic cold. His message: many white-collar workers are too timid. His service: For $500 to $1,000, Mr. Starr and his company, the WSA Corporation of Shawnee, Kan., interview job-seekers, write their resumes and choose potential employers from a data base of 10 million names. Then, for $2 a set, including postage, the company prints resume, cover letter and envelope -- sometimes thousands of them.
"Usually, we're their last resort," said Mr. Starr, who said he receives 300 to 500 inquiries a week. "We send out an obscene number of letters . . . and it works."
Enormous effort camouflages just how impersonal the mailing really is. As Mr. Starr is quick to boast, some 30 college students, working part time, forge clients' signatures in blue ink on the cover letters. A machine attaches a 29-cent stamp to each envelope (no metered mail here). Then the packets are either returned to the client for mailing or driven to a place that doesn't have the postmark of the mall west of Kansas City where Mr. Starr's business is based.
How many resumes is enough? By Mr. Starr's reckoning, anywhere from 250 to 20,000. The higher the executive, the more it takes. "The truth is, there is still some good hiring going on," Mr. Starr said. "It just means the needles are smaller in the haystack."
WSA clients tend to fight shy of identifying themselves by name for fear that their new employers would frown. One lawyer who was making $400,000 a year before losing his job as chief operating officer of a utility paid roughly $40,000 for 19,700 packets -- more than any other client -- and found a job as the top legal gun for a Florida company. A 40-year-old woman who had worked as a manufacturing executive for Becton, Dickinson and Abbott Laboratories shipped 5,250 resumes, a more typical order. Response: 32 job offers and one invitation to a date.
Many people, including direct-marketing experts, remain skeptical about the service. Mr. Starr's sales materials indicate that his clients average one interview for every $1,482 they spend. Telling your spouse that you plan to wire several thousand dollars to a Kansas entrepreneur you've never met "makes for a quiet evening," said Martin L. Brown, an ex-Du Pont executive who found a job through Mr. Starr with the Henkel Corporation.
George Orme, a direct-marketing consultant, said, "The issue is, 'Does he prey on people who are desperate or does he help them?' "
Employers also have their doubts. "They're being taken advantage of," John M. Pepe, chief executive of the hydraulic-gear-pump company John S. Barnes, said of Mr. Starr's clients. Perhaps because his company is in Mr. Starr's data base, Mr. Pepe has seen a noticeable surge in resumes in the last six months.
Robert Carlson, president of Barton Industries in Shawnee, Okla., is also less than thrilled that his oil and gas supply company is in the data base. "I have never hired anyone whose resume was just sent in," he said.
Even Mr. Brown, a fan of Mr. Starr's, says he comes on "like a used-car salesman."
Mr. Starr, who is 53 and partial to walking shoeless around his office, said his 17-year-old business, with 50 employees, will handle some 750 executives this year and gross about $3 million, roughly $4,000 per client. Payment is due in full and upfront. "We won't issue the letters unless we get paid, and yes, that cuts off a lot of people because they can't afford us," he said. "But you'd be surprised by the creative ways people come up with the funds."
ALISON LEIGH COWAN

HEADLINE: All About/Contracting Out Drug Research;
Speeding New Drugs to Market

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
RACING to get their latest products approved, pharmaceutical companies are increasingly farming out much off the crucial testing on people that determines if a new drug is safe and effective. In doing so, the drug makers say they can get reliable results faster and cheaper, and free their own researchers to discover the next lucrative batch of heart pills.
The independent contract research laboratories say that, with the equivalent of standing armies of scientists and experienced administrators, they can shave a year or more off the costly process. Not only can that save millions of dollars, it can also quickly propel the new drug to the marketplace, where it can start earning its keep. 
 In the arcane world of getting a drug to market, the first years are spent in basic research; the middle ones in clinical trials conducted on humans. The final stage in a process that in the United States takes perhaps 12 years is getting the product approved by the Food and Drug Administration.
Just about all drug makers send out some of the clinical work. They range from Merck & Company, the world's largest pharmaceutical company, which spent a total of $988 million on research last year, to smaller biotechnology companies like Biogen Inc. ($43 million on research).
"We do it all the time," said Max Wilhelm, worldwide research director of Ciba A.G., the big Swiss multinational parent of the Ciba-Geigy Corporation.
Dr. Lawrence E. Posner, senior vice president for medical affairs at Miles Inc., said the Pittsburgh-based unit of Bayer A.G. of Germany sent 20 percent to 25 percent of its clinical research to contract labs. Miles spent $237 million for health care research in 1991.
 
Controlling Overhead
Outsiders Handle One-Time Projects
 Some companies are reluctant to discuss how much they use the outsiders. Research projects are the crown jewels in a pharmaceutical company's reputation and there is always a risk in farming them out. But so far, there have been few incidents to shake the drug companies' confidence.
In any case, drug companies typically "outsource," meaning hire outsiders, when their own lab tables and computer files are overflowing.
"The busier the companies are, the more you are going to see outsourcing," said F. Richard Nichol, president of the Institute for Biological Research and Development in Irvine, Calif., an independent contractor owned by the Kuraya Corporation, a Tokyo-based drug wholesaler.
The contracts also help avert expensive surges in overhead costs for one-time projects involving the organizing, tracking and analyzing of the experiences of thousands of patients. "We don't want to staff up for peak demands," Dr. Posner said.
Using company scientists to the best advantage is also a concern. For instance, biotechnology companies "are often selling equity to raise capital to do basic research," said John H. Timoney, a senior vice president of Applied Bioscience International, a contract research company based in East Millstone, N.J. "They would be crazy to spend their capital on things like field research."
And European and Japanese companies are glad to hire Americans expert at speedily fulfilling F.D.A. requirements. Ciba-Geigy saved "significant time," Dr. Wilhelm said, by sending some of the clinical testing for Lotensin, a blood pressure drug, to Besselaar Associates, a contract research unit of Corning Inc. (The process was additionally smoothed because there were a half dozen similar drugs approved or in the pipeline.)
Even a 30-day jump in getting a drug to market can add $10 million to the profit-making potential over the life of a product with eventual sales of $200 million a year, Dr. David A. Kessler, F.D.A. Commissioner, said recently. He was testifying on a new Federal law that requires the drug companies to pay user fees to the F.D.A. to finance speedier handling of new drug applications.
 
'Time Is Money'
Contractors Offer The Needed Edge
 With pressure to restrain health care costs mounting, and with competition multiplying from lower-priced copies of drugs as patents expire, it would be hard to overstate the importance of saving time and money.
The companies have long justified soaring drug prices by pointing to their heavy research spending. American, European and Japanese prescription drug makers plowed at least $24 billion into research and development last year, about 14 percent of their worldwide sales.
Industry analysts estimate that $6 billion to $8 billion of that went for clinical testing. They said independent contract laboratories had about $1 billion of this work, and their combined sales are growing by at least 15 percent a year.
Contractors boast that they are often quicker off the mark than their customers. Rick Hawkins, a founder of Pharmaco, a research company acquired by Applied Bioscience last February, says pharmaceutical company research divisons "are like the Queen Mary, with two men standing on the bow, saying, 'Stop the boat.' We look at ourselves as the U-boat," he continued, "that can move in and out very quickly. We understand the time-is-money concept."
But Dr. W. John Powell Jr., Merck's worldwide clinical research chief, says some contract research organizations, or C.R.O.'s, can be pricey. After receiving approval on Proscar, a breakthrough prostate drug that the F.D.A. gave the nod to in record time, Merck asked for bids from a number of C.R.O.'s for the follow-up studies it often contracts out.
"Some wanted twice as much as the lower ones," Dr. Powell said. "They were looking for an enormous profit margin. One can dissect out the critical parts of the cost," he added, and still allow for a decent profit. Eventually, the contract went to Basselaar.
 
The Top Players
In a Little-Guy Industry, 3 Big Guys
 The contract industry has seen some consolidation. Eight American companies have about $300 million in sales, nearly one-third of the business, according to Dr. Jean-Pierre Tassignon, a drug development consultant based in Brussels who until recently was Besselaar's executive vice president for Europe.
Applied Bioscience, one of the three largest contractors, acquired Pharmaco for $101 million. Jerry Treppel, an analyst with Furman Selz in New York, said the parent company, traded over the counter, would have sales of $178 million this year, of which $47 million will be from Pharmaco.
Corning became one of the top three by acquiring Besselaar for $55 million in 1989 from Dr. G. Hein Besselaar, a scientist who had worked at the National Institutes of Health and at Merck. Corning, a $3 billion company, does not break out results for Besselaar, but industry executives estimate the unit's 1992 sales will exceed $75 million.
There are also at least half a dozen privately held independent contractors, chief among them the Parexel International Corporation, based in Waltham, Mass.
A special advantage boasted of by all of the big three is simultaneous testing in Europe and the United States. Josef von Rickenbach, chief executive of Parexel, said such a double-barreled approach on a breakthrough drug can take just eight years. And that, he added, represents a two-year savings.
 
 
 
THE CONTRACTORS' FAMILIAR FACES

SEVERAL hundred small clinical research laboratories have sprung up across the country in recent years.
"All you need in the beginning is a telephone, a fax machine, a computer and a filing cabinet," said Dr. John Urquhart, a California-based consultant. Dr. Urquhart used to be head of research at the Alza Corporation, a maker of patented drug "packaging" that controls the release of a drug into a patient's system.
"If you get work," Dr. Urquhart explained, "you can staff up with people who have experience with monitoring and so on."
Most of the small outfits were set up by people who learned the ropes working for major pharmaceutical companies like Merck and Johnson & Johnson but then were forced out onto the market in a wave of consolidations that, for example, saw SmithKline merge with Beecham and Bristol-Myers with Squibb.
"The mergers threw a lot of clinical researchers on the street,"said Dr. Urquhart. "A lot try to jump into contract research."
That's just fine with the drug companies, which naturally prefer to work with people they know and trust. With the frequent use of outside testing, "the reputation of the pharmaceutical company is somewhat dependent on that contract shop," said Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, director of the University of Minnesota's Prime Institute of Pharmaceutical Management and Economics.
There was consternation in the industry last year when the Institute of Clinical Pharmacology, a Dublin-based contract laboratory with 300 employees, declared bankruptcy. Dr. Jean-Pierre Tassignon, a Belgian drug development consultant, said that at least a dozen important projects were temporarily plunged into limbo. "Investigators in numerous hospitals were not being monitored," he said. "Adverse events were not transmitted."
Dr. Tassignon said most of the defunct institute's clients took charge of their own projects. But some switched to other contractors, mainly to the Besselaar unit of Corning Inc., which bought the institute's assets in Europe and Nashville.
The continuing faith in contractors reflects the common experience built up in similar backgrounds.
"They know what we want," said Dr. W. John Powell Jr., Merck's worldwide clinical research chief. "Their statistical methods tie into ours. It is very easy for us to approach organizations like that and get really quality data."

PUB-DATE: November 22, 1992

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1722 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/November 15-20

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
THE ECONOMY
 
Waiting for France 

There is Europe and there is France and the question now for Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, is whether the agreement she negotiated with the European Community last week includes them both. Under her prodding -- and Washington's threat of imposing a 200-percent duty on European white wine -- the community agreed to deep cuts on its subsidies of agricultural goods. The agreement sets the stage for the resumption of negotiations on world trade. But while the community as a whole favors the treaty, France -- Europe's largest agricultural producer -- may not go along. With parliamentary elections set for March, the French Government is sensitive to the concerns of its farmers. How France will react to the pact -- and how the community will react to France -- is still unclear. "At first sight of this accord, I cannot accept it," said Jean-Pierre Soisson, France's Agriculture Minister.
 
The Numbers Favor Clinton Plan
 
The number-crunching economists at the University of Michigan -- led by Saul Hymans -- had some good news for President-elect Clinton. They ran a simulation of his economic stimulus plan through their computers and concluded that if Mr. Clinton's package cleared Congress more or less intact, the economy would move onto higher ground. They said Mr. Clinton's plan would increase growth to 2.7 percent next year -- from about 2 percent this year -- and to 3.4 percent in 1994. That much growth, the economists said, would bring unemployment down to 6.5 percent in 1994 from its current rate of 7.4 percent. Best of all, they concluded that while the Clinton plan would increase the deficit initially, it would not be a budget buster. "Including the added revenue growth coming from the resulting gains in income and employment, the net effect on the fiscal 1994 budget will be essentially a wash," the report said.
 
Fewer Jobs, More Overtime
 
Output at the nation's factories advanced last month, but not by much. According to the Federal Reserve, industrial production inched up 0.3 percent in October after losing ground in four of the last five months. The employment picture was mixed, too. Though the nation's industrial companies laid off 56,000 workers last month, for those still employed, overtime actually grew. "The industrial sector still, at this stage, has to be considered feeble," said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "Gains of this size are not adequate to bring us employment gains in manufacturing," he said.

Freedom to Syndicate
 
Television reruns are a $5 billion business. Trouble is, the networks say, they have been prevented from owning the shows they air and the rights to the reruns by the Financial Interest and Syndication Rule, which the Federal Communications Commission adopted in 1970. For years the networks have been trying to get that rule overturned. Last year, the F.C.C. modified it slightly, but not enough to make the networks happy. Then Judge Richard A. Posner, of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, wrote an opinion for the three-member panel that overturned the F.C.C.'s modification and much of the syndication rule. That ruling paves the way for the networks to own and syndicate shows. Last week a group of TV producers and local broadcasters, which control reruns, cried foul. They filed a brief with the appellate court arguing that Judge Posner was not impartial. The group pointed out that Judge Posner, while a law professor in 1977, had written a brief for CBS favoring network ownership of shows. Though the court is likely to uphold Judge Posner's ruling since it was unanimous, it may preclude Judge Posner's involvement in any other hearings on the issue.

Take That Tariff Back, Please
 
Last year, OIS Optical Imaging Systems of Troy, Mich., told the Commerce Department it was being hurt by cheap imports of flat-panel computer displays made in Japan. The department slapped a 62.67 percent duty on the products. But American computer makers protested, saying domestic suppliers could not meet their demand. Some Japanese manufacturers shifted production abroad to avoid the tax. Last week, OIS told the Commerce Department to cancel the tax. OIS was now "on solid enough footing," said Charles C. Wilson, its chief financial officer. While the Commerce Department usually lifts an import tax if the complaining company says so, that may not happen now. Because of the duty, several American companies began developing flat-panel displays of their own, which they feel should be protected.

Greenspanspeak
 
Not wanting to spook the markets, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, prefers generalities to blunt talk. Those generalities reached new heights last week when he addressed the Tax Foundation in New York. Mr. Greenspan told the group that despite lower interest rates, robust growth has eluded the country because banks are reluctant to lend and borrowers are reluctant to borrow. That has taken much of the punch out of the economy, he said. So when will it end? The credit crunch "has shown no evidence of worsening in recent months and may finally be retreating," he said.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Trying to Save the KLM Deal
While KLM Royal Dutch Airlines has been attempting to merge with Northwest Airlines -- the deal received the backing of the Transportation Department last week -- Northwest has simply been trying to remain financially aloft. Northwest has been hurt by the recent fare wars in the airline industry, and has lost about $800 million since it was taken private in 1989. Worse, the carrier has already used up the last of its $600 million line of credit, prompting rumors that it could soon be forced to file for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code. Tumbling into Chapter 11 could cause delays in its merger with KLM. But last week word leaked out that a syndicate of banks, led by Bankers Trust, was trying to patch together a new $300 million line of credit for the carrier. To secure the credit, KLM said it would kick in $50 million -- it invested $400 million in Northwest in 1989. The money "will allow Northwest to meet its near-term financial needs," KLM said in a statement.

Neo-Nazi Fallout
 
As Germany's economy slows down -- the German council of economic advisers forecasts no growth next year -- tensions continue to rise as neo-Nazis take to the streets. That prompted a series of anti-Nazi, anti-racist rallies attended by leading German politicians, including Chancellor Helmut Kohl. But the ugly side of Germany's economic downturn is likely to have its own economic costs. According to a survey conducted by Meeting News, a monthly trade publication, of 200 randomly selected travel and meeting planners from government, businesses and associations here, 39.5 percent said they "would not feel comfortable planning a meeting in Germany," said Malcolm Abrams, editor in chief. "You might see attendance at some events fall. We know meetings pulled out of Arizona -- including the Super Bowl -- for not recognizing Martin Luther King's birthday, and Miami lost business for snubbing Nelson Mandela."
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Art Un-Appreciation
 
Back in the 1980's, when Masters of the Universe roamed Wall Street and advertising moguls were desperate to go global, the art market soared. But since then, sales have fizzled. Last week, at Sotheby's in New York, 77 works were offered for sale -- but only 51 found new homes. And while the auction house estimated the works would go for a total of $31.5 million to $40 million, the proceeds from the auction came to just $21.3 million. The major seller was Charles Saatchi, the London advertising executive. Mr. Saatchi, whose Saatchi & Saatchi advertising agency lost $103.3 million last year, put works valued by Sotheby's at $17 million on the block. But while many of those works went for half the auction estimates, at least Mr. Saatchi had one big hit: Andy Warhol's 1962 silk screen "Marilyn X 100" fetched $3.7 million, just under the artist's record price of $4.07 million for "Shot Red Marilyn."

Elbowing In on European Deal
 
While the European Community and the United States squabble over trade, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation is doing deals. Last week the Italian Navy said it would buy 13 AV-8B Harrier fighter jets at a cost of $392 million. Harrier is a British-engineered and produced jet, but McDonnell will get the job of overseeing how the planes are snapped together in Italy. British Aerospace and Italy's Alenia will serve as subcontractors.

Putting Cars First . . .
 
Nationsbank, the scrappy, acquisitive North Carolina banking company, said last week it had reached an agreement to buy almost all of Chrysler First, the consumer finance subsidiary of the Chrysler Financial Corporation. It will buy $4 billion of Chrysler First's loans and pay a $100 million premium. For Chrysler, which did not disclose its profit from the sale, the deal allows it to focus on cars and reduces its borrowing in the markets.

. . . And Putting G.M. First
 
Chrysler isn't the only car company trying to focus its financing operations. G.M.A.C., the financing subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said it would no longer finance non-G.M. cars sold by G.M. dealers. About 2,000 G.M. dealers nationwide carry other name plates. Non-G.M. vehicles now account for about 10 percent of G.M.A.C.'s $60 billion in worldwide wholesale and retail financing. With G.M.'s commercial paper downgraded -- raising the prospect that it would cost G.M.A.C. more to borrow -- the nation's No. 1 car company wants to focus on its own name plates. "We're focusing our assets primarily on G.M. products," said John Rines, president of G.M.A.C.
 
As roadsters go, it was something else -- a sleek Italian body married to an American chassis, propelled by a red-blooded Detroit V-8. But sales of Cadillac's Allante never took off. And while it was pricey -- $62,000 -- the sleek Italian-American hybrid was also a little too plebeian for the price (it had a manual convertible top). Loss-plagued G.M. said it would stop making the Allante next year.

HEADLINE: At Work;
And Now the 'Sticky Floor'

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
THEY are the workers who dispense driver's licenses, take care of the mentally ill and keep the paperwork moving. Some of what they do is the most difficult or aggravating work around -- utterly essential jobs that twirl the wheels of state and local government, yet pay badly and provide little hope of a better future.
Many of these workers are women, and the glass ceiling that so frustrates their female professional counterparts is for most of them irrelevant, a realization that prompted researcher Catherine White Berheide to offer a more appropriate building part to serve as a metaphor for the occupational frustrations of women. Ms. Berheide, a sociologist of work at Skidmore College in upstate New York, proposes the "sticky floor" as an image to encapsulate the plight of hundreds of thousands of women trapped in low-wage, low-mobility jobs in state and local government. "There are barriers to women at the top, but that's not the only problem," she said. "We're overlooking the bulk of women." 
 Ms. Berheide, in research done for the Center for Women in Government at the Albany campus of the State University of New York and released earlier this month, reports that 55 percent of the three million or so women in state and local government jobs across the nation work in the lowest-paying employment categories. Only a quarter of all men -- and just a fifth of white men -- work in those categories.
The employees in question are paraprofessionals, like home health care aides and child support workers, and "administrative support" or clerical staff. Women of color occupy the lowest classifications in disproportionate numbers: 63 percent of Hispanic women working in local and state government hold lower-level jobs, while the number is 61 percent for African-American women and 57 percent for Native American women, figures that Ms. Berheide believes reveal the persistence of racial barriers, even at government agencies that have worked hard to eradicate them. The "sticky floor" includes a third, male-dominated category, service/ maintenance workers, in which men of color are overrepresented. Workers in the three lowest categories typically make less than $20,000, even when they've been on the job full time for as long as 10 years.
The numbers have improved since 1980, but mostly because of a drop in the relative number of low-paying jobs and not commensurately with attempts to reduce inequality. "If you think of the efforts since 1965 and the Civil Rights Act, it suggests the problem is more difficult and intractable than anyone thought," Ms. Berheide said. "Occupational segregation is very resilient. It responds to efforts to change it by reconstructing itself in a new way."
THAT is at least in part because of something anthropologists, as observers of human behavior, have known and tried to tell economists, mere students of markets, for years: "women's work" -- jobs typically filled by women -- is valued less and rewarded less because it is done by women, not primarily because of market forces or the law of supply and demand.
Ms. Berheide argues that much government work is seen as "women's work" in part because it taps skills that are thought of as female: the ability to handle difficult people or to work with children and the elderly. "We have sets of norms about the jobs and the people who can fill them," Ms. Berheide said. "Who is good at making angry people calm down? Women."
Yet "people skills" are not in job descriptions. "We don't recognize or compensate for the grief workers take from the public: angry citizens in line or on the phone," Ms. Berheide said. "They are relatively powerless to do what the citizen wants them to do."
Although Ms. Berheide's study is based on data collected from state and local governments by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, she thinks it can be generalized to the Federal Government and to large corporations that have the same well-defined career paths and job classifications as government. She warns that the employee's point of entry into an organization sets a career trajectory. Only an employer willing to beat down structural barriers -- and there are some, especially in government -- is likely to provide upward mobility to employees who begin in the lowest categories. "It requires acknowledging the socio-emotional content of work," Ms. Berheide said. "We have to go outside of the way we've usually thought about these things."

HEADLINE: Sound Bytes;
Riding Into the Multimedia Digital Age

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
AS corporate vice president and general manager of the multimedia division, Lucie J. Fjeldstad is one of the highest-ranking women in the International Business Machines Corporation. Raised on a cattle ranch in California (which is still in the family), she now lives in Stamford, Conn., and rides herd over I.B.M.'s worldwide strategy for interactive multimedia and high-performance network computing.
Question: We're told we're entering the digital age. What does that mean? 
 Answer: The digital age is when all information gets translated into the same language of ones and zeroes, the language of the computer. There will be a new medium; you'll be able to mix text and graphics and audio and full-motion video to really get the information you need, wherever, whenever you need it.
Q: Is education the prime use?
A: We're now coming into the knowledge age. When my grandparents were growing up, what you learned, you learned for a lifetime. Now it lasts you about 27 nanoseconds. American businesses spend $45 billion a year on training and retraining, and that's just for the basic skills. So any way you can do it cheaper. . . .
Q: What technologies are needed?
A: You need a network infrastructure, a national data highway, which we believe will come on stream in the next two to four years, wired and wireless. You need switching and routing capability that allows you to send mixed media over the network at gigabit speeds, to be able to manage the quality and the guts of full-motion video, and to make it interactive. You also need a user interface, probably a combination of voice and touch.
Q: Thanks to cable TV, 60 million American households are now wired with coaxial cable. Can we use that for the network?
A: Yes. Five years ago, people thought that this would require rewiring America. We don't have to change the wire. You have to put some electronics on it, but you don't have to rewire. That's important.
Q: Five years from now, how will this technology change the way you do your job?
A: Well, I don't think I'd be stationed in Kenya yet. But I'd very much like to operate from the ranch. The short answer is that I don't think we know how we're going to operate. But I believe that we're heading toward a time when knowledge -- not brick and mortar, not guns -- is power. It's a journey, not an event. But we can get there.

Ideal escape: Tanzania. "I shoot animals, with a camera."
 
Typical workday: "On an airplane."

HEADLINE: Tech Notes;
Bubble, Bubble, Less Soil and Trouble

BYLINE: By ROBERT E. CALEM

 BODY:
What can a washing machine learn from a seltzer bottle? More, perhaps, than you might think.
While technology has rapidly remade so many products, washing machines have basically just kept spinning along the same old way. But the Sharp Corporation has a different idea. The Japanese company is selling a novel washing machine that uses scrubbing bubbles and an advanced computer to get clothes cleaner while economizing on water. 
 The bubble technology cleans by forcing bubbles from the bottom of the machine's bin up and around clothing in vertical and horizontal swirling motions. The horizontal swirls are generated by a computer-controlled pulsator on the bottom of the bin. In addition, the bin itself is smaller, with no holes along its sides and no central agitator. The design cuts water usage by 30 percent per wash cycle, says Sharp, which also asserts that the new washer gets clothes about 20 percent cleaner than with traditional machines. And it operates almost silently.
The machine has been available in Japan since March for about $800, roughly 20 percent more than what a traditional washer sells for there. It is Sharp's third machine to use the bubble-cleaning technology, which was introduced in August 1991.
In addition to the company's bubble-cleaning technology, the new washer can analyze the wash load in various ways, weighing the clothes, for example, to determine how much water and detergent is needed and how long the wash time should be.
Matsushita has also sold washing machines with such features for several years, and it says its washer can also detect the amount and type of dirt in laundry and automatically adjust the wash cycle accordingly.
Both companies now sell their machines only in Southeast Asia. Sharp holds patents on the bubble-cleaning technology in Taiwan, Thailand, Hong Kong and Singapore, with patents pending in China, Korea and the Philippines, the company said.
Neither company would say when its machines might be brought to the United States, if ever.

HEADLINE: CAMERA;
For Three Whole Days, Everything That's New

BYLINE: By John Durniak; John Durniak is a freelance writer, editor and consultant on photography.

 BODY:
PHOTO '92, the big photographic trade show at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center from Dec. 4 to 6, promises to be a crash course on what's happening in the kaleidoscopic photography world. The programs and displays cover topics ranging from economic changes in photography to digital imaging technology, from new products to copyright law.
For the serious photographer, careful planning is advised because more is offered than one can easily handle. The $25 three-day general-admission badge permits entrance into the four exhibition halls: Computer Graphics, Pro Lab, Presentation Products and Professional Photography. In all, more than 60 events and programs are planned for the show, which is being sponsored by the magazine Photo District News. T 
 There are additional fees for single courses and combinations of programs ranging from $65 to $465. They include these:
* "The Art of Photography and Computers with Master Photographers Ryszard Horowitz & Gregory Heisler." Mr. Horowitz and Mr. Heisler are among the most interesting photographers using computers today. They will lecture on the subject and show some of their pictures, describing how they were made.
* "Adventures in Location Lighting." Jon Falk will offer an expanded version of the popular crash course on multiple lighting that he teaches at seminars around the country. It is for photojournalists and photographers who shoot on the go. Mr. Falk is known for offering ingenious solutions for using equipment.
* "The On-Site, No-Prep People Picture." The opposite side of the Jon Falk concept presented by Ray Fisher, who tells how to solve problems with no special lighting, props or equipment. He will show you how to think on your feet and come back with smashing pictures.
* "Pricing and Negotiating Your Stock Photography," by Vince Streano. A nationally known photographer who stays on top of new photo business technology, copyright and law practices, Mr. Streano travels the world informing photographers about the changes in the technology and rules and helps formulate standards.
* "Color Vision: Color, Graphics and Travel Photography," by Joe Marvullo. Mr. Marvullo will offer an analysis of how to find outstanding color subject matter.
* "Lighting on Location: Making Something Out of Nothing," by Jim Karageorge. Fascinating explanation of how he adopted motion picture lighting techniques for use in still photography.
As usual, there will be new products at the show, from maufactureres like these: CANON will show the A2E camera, with automatic-eye focusing, for the first time in America.
SILK TWIN CAMERA PLATE will demonstrate a device that allows two cameras to be attached to a single tripod.
BRONCOLOR will introduce the HMI 575 lamps, continuous-source, cool-burning, daylight balanced sources with built-in meters that tell if the life of the lamp is fading.
MAMIYA will show its 6MF, a multiple format camera, in the United States for the first time. It can take panoramic, square or traditional format images.
FUJI will introduce an improved version of its Fujichrome 400 professional D color transparency film, which features improved red (warmer) rendition.
CALUMET will present the Zone VI 5 x 7 enlarger.
LOWEPRO will show a redesigned line of all-weather camera bags. The bags feature a built-in raincoat to protect equipment from a downpour.
THE RAPTURE GROUP will present the Toolbox, a high-tech selection of laser-and-sound-triggered modules for stopping action, like a diver hitting the water or a pin breaking a balloon. It is distributed by Foto Care.
Photo '92 will be open Dec. 4 and 5 from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and on Dec. 6 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. A copy of a catalog that lists all lectures, workshops, seminars and special events is available from Photo/CMM, 200 Connecticut Avenue, Norwalk, Conn. 06856-4990; or by calling (203) 852-0500; or by fax from (203) 838-3710.

HEADLINE: HOME CLINIC;
Right Sandpaper Smooths the Way

BYLINE: By JOHN WARDE

 BODY:
VIRTUALLY all home-repair and improvement projects involving wood also involve smoothing it. But smoothing wood can be as much a question of choosing the right materials or tools as using the right technique.
Sandpaper probably comes to mind first as the material of choice. For use on broad flat areas, it often is the easiest way to achieve good results. When choosing sandpaper, consider the grade or relative coarseness, the type of abrasive and the density of particle coverage. 
 These are the most common grades, with their grit size and typical uses:
*Extra coarse, 24 to 36 grit, for removing thick paint or other heavy finish.
*Coarse, 40 to 60 grit, for removing large amounts of wood.
*Medium, 80 to 100 grit, for removing small amounts of wood.
*Fine, 120 to 180 grit, for final sanding before painting.
*Very fine, 220 to 360 grit, for sanding between coats of finish and for producing an exceptionally smooth surface on unfinished hardwood.
*Extra fine and super fine, 400 to 600 grit, for the smoothest possible surface between coats of clear finish on wood furniture.
Sandpaper coated with flint as an abrasive is usually the least expensive. It dulls rapidly, and because the particles are not uniform in size, it can seldom produce a surface smooth enough for staining or applying clear finish. But the low price of flint-coated paper makes that a good choice for removing paint, a task that quickly clogs, and therefore ruins, all types of sandpaper.
Garnet-coated sandpaper stays sharp longer than flint-coated and is also relatively inexpensive. Although its particle sizes are not as uniform as other abrasives, it is an economical choice for smoothing wood for painting.
Aluminum oxide and silicone carbide coatings are the best abrasives to use for obtaining the smoothest surfaces. Both outlast the other varieties and have extremely uniform particles.
Silicone-carbide paper is best for use with power sanders. Aluminum oxide, while longer lasting, dulls as it wears. Also, because of friction, it can create a glazed surface on power-sanded wood. Glazed wood looks shiny and smooth, but does not absorb stain evenly.
Silicone-carbide particles break when rubbed, creating new cutting edges. Therefore, the paper stays sharp until the coating wears completely away. Also, because the sharper particles generate less friction, the heat that develops is not enough to cause glazing.
The density of particles in a sandpaper's coating is described as either close or open. Sandpaper labeled close-coat has 30 percent more particles than open-coat and cuts faster. But close-coat sandpaper clogs more readily than open-coat. Although close-coat paper is suitable for most jobs and produces a smoother surface, open-coat is best for soft or resinous wood and removing finishes.
For smoothing the edges of wood, particularly after sawing, consider using a file instead of sandpaper. A flat or half-round smooth-cutting mill file, either single- or double-cut, is preferred. To avoid injury and to control the file, it should have a handle.
A single-cut file has one row of ridges along the blade and the same advantages and disadvantages as open-coat sandpaper. A double-cut file, which has a second row of ridges crossing the first at an angle, behaves like close-coat sandpaper.
To use a file, grasp both the handle and tip and push the tool away from you while sliding it across the surface. Make sure that the file rests flat on the surface, but angle the tool so that the handle is behind the area being smoothed and the tip is ahead of it.
Raise the file after each forward stroke. When the ridges clog, clean them with a file card or a brass-bristle brush. If the file is half-round in the cross-section, use the curved side for smoothing curved surfaces.
For the smoothest possible surface on hardwood and for removing paint or other finishes without sanding or resorting to paint remover, try a metal hand scraper. It is a piece of thin flexible steel, like a handsaw blade.
Although curved scrapers are available, the most common and easiest to use are rectangular, measuring about two and a half inches wide and six inches long.
The edges of a scraper are sharpened in a way that creates hook-shaped ridges, called burrs, along each side. To use the tool, hold the scraper at an angle to the wood and push or pull it so that the burr acts like a blade, slicing tissue-thin shavings.
A scraped surface is smoother than a sanded one and absorbs finish better. That is because the fibers are not shredded, as with sanding, nor do the pores become packed with dust and sanding particles.
Hand scrapers require frequent sharpening. That is done by first filing the edges square with the sides and then forming the burrs with a hardened steel rod called a burnisher.
To form a burr, place the scraper in a vise with the filed edge up. Lubricate the burnisher with oil and then hold it like a file across the edge of the scraper. Tilt the shaft of the burnisher down at an angle of about 5 to 10 degrees and slide the tool, while bearing down on it, along the scraper's edge five or six times until you can feel a burr on one side with the finger. Then tilt the scraper in the opposite direction and create a burr on the edge's other side.
Reburnish a scraper when it produces sawdust instead of shavings. When burnishing no longer forms a burr, resharpen the scraper from scratch.

GRAPHIC: Diagram: Choose sandpaper grades, type and density carefully for best results. Use a file for smoothing edges. Hand scraper produces a smoother finish than sandpaper. (Edward Lipinski)

HEADLINE: ENGAGEMENTS;
Terry L. Phelps, John V. Miller

 BODY:
Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Phelps of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Terry Louise Phelps, to John Varner Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Miller of Columbus, Ohio. An April wedding is planned.

He graduated from Duke University and received a master's degree in economics from Northwestern University. His mother, Lanah Miller, is the executive assistant at the Ballet Met, a dance company in Columbus. His father is a senior partner in the Columbus law firm of McNamara & McNamara.
