HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
With a New V8, Lincoln Introduces an All-New Mark VIII

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
If you are a manufacturer, New York is a good place to introduce a car. You can always find a backdrop that connects with your vehicle, as Dodge did last month when it trotted out its new Intrepid on the pier next to the carrier-cum-museum of the same name.
On Wednesday, it was Ford Motor Company's turn, and the introduction of the '93 Lincoln Mark VIII jammed traffic at 77th Street and Madison Avenue, which is the location of -- what else? -- the Hotel Mark. 
 That traffic, of course, is the downside of introducing a car in Manhattan, and the crowd of writers and photographers got to test Lincoln's five-passenger luxury coupe in the cut and thrust of East Side snarl. Not good.
But then, it should be said, there were those laps of Central Park, allowing impromptu tests of acceleration and braking, and affording the extra joy of scaring normally blase pedestrians. Much better.
Even if the clogged and potholed streets won't be the new Mark's main milieu across the country, the brief drive did show that Lincoln has come up with a quick and able competitor to the likes of Acura, BMW, Infiniti and Lexus and its traditional rival, Cadillac Eldorado.
Lincoln's advertising campaign, the biggest in the division's history, faces up to that competition by challenging buyers to "Drive Everything Else First," and one television commercial expresses the theme this way: "You have until Dec. 26 to test-drive every luxury coupe in the world. After that, there is no comparison."
As the ad indicates, the Mark will go on sale the day after Christmas, which is kind of a shame for those who like to give $36,640 coupes as gifts. But the date will also signal something of a new course for Detroit, which for the first time in a long time will be fielding both a Lincoln and a Cadillac that can compete with the best in the world.
Like Cadillac, which has put its 4.6-liter Northstar V8 into the Eldorado Touring Coupe and Seville STS, Ford has put a new 4.6-liter V8 into the Mark. The four-cam, 32-valve engine produces 280 horsepower, 15 less than the Northstar, and it drives the rear wheels through a new four-speed automatic transmission.
In traffic, the V8 is so quiet that it is hard to tell if it's running. But a heavy right foot produces a pleasant howl of power. The engine is the first all-aluminum V8 produced by Ford, and it does its part in making the new Mark 41 pounds lighter than last year's car, while adding 55 horsepower.
The engine resides under a weight-saving plastic hood that slopes to a gleaming urethane grille, one whose vertical bars look like cast metal, but also one that flexes easily, avoiding damage from minor bumps. The headlights flanking the grille are among the narrowest anywhere and they contribute to the clean look that extends from front to rear.
One slightly jarring note in all that is the vestigial bump on the trunk that is a nod to the "spare-tire" image of older Lincoln Continentals. The bump now looks nothing like a tire and might well have been eliminated from what is otherwise an exercise in slick sheet metal.
Inside the Mark (the hotel, not the car), Jack Telnack was holding forth on just such problems, talking about creating a fresh look while keeping the styling cues from the past. Telnack is Ford's chief of design, and he noted that the stylists were going for softer and more flowing shapes.
"We do have that slight indication of the Mark tire on the rear deck," he said. "But I think if we didn't put that on the car it would be like a Rolls-Royce running around without a Rolls-Royce grille."
The bump on the trunk, it turns out, acts as something of a spoiler and actually aids the aerodynamics. But the streamlining gets further help from technology. Whenever speed exceeds 55 miles an hour for more than 45 seconds, the suspension lowers the car by almost an inch, cutting wind resistance and fuel consumption.
With the new engine, economy is estimated at 18 miles per gallon, city, and 25, highway. Zero-to-60 acceleration takes 7.6 seconds, according to the company, and top speed is electronically limited to 130 m.p.h. Unlike previous incarnations and some of the competition, the '93 Mark will have no performance packages, and what you see is what you get. Mercifully gone, too, is the occasionally tacky "designer" series of Marks.
"Designer styling began with the Mark IV in 1975," Telnack said. "It was exemplified I guess by those oval opera windows, which is interesting because they were inspired by Raymond Loewy. He took the '40 and '41 Continentals and did a series of opera windows in the rear window pillars way back then. Of course, Loewy was also designing Owens cabin cruisers and he put portholes on everything. But he did it on those early cars, and I think it had some influence on us."
One area where a bit more of the designers' touch might be welcome to buyers is the interior, which seems a bit Spartan in a luxury car. To be sure, there is plenty of leather, but the sweep-around dash presents the driver and front passenger with a vista of vinyl.
There is no wood and little other relief from what appears to be relentless technology. "I think somebody described this as being straight out of 'Star Trek's' Enterprise," Telnack said. "However, we spent a considerable amount of time on ergonomics, as we are doing with all our cars, and I think it's one of our best."
The center console, with its sound system and information display, is indeed canted thoughtfully toward the driver, but gauges, switches and digital readouts abound. In this, as in its exterior styling, the Mark takes a distinctly different approach from the Eldorado, which is less aggressively "sporty."
Telnack said Cadillac's designers had gone for a traditional look with the Eldorado, and he is happy that they did. "They stuck with the formal roof line," he said. "But we've been more successful in the past when we didn't follow our competitors, when we went off on our own."
In terms of foreign competitors, he said, Lincoln attempted to cover all the bases: "We wanted to make sure that the buyer in America was happy, and we wanted to attract people who were buying European or Asian imports. I think we've done that, and I really believe there shouldn't be anything anymore that is just American or just European or just Asian. We're living in a global society, and I think this car feels very much at home on an autobahn in Germany or an arterial in Australia, or in the United States."
He added that the typical Mark VIII buyer will be 45 years old with a household income of $100,000. About 65 percent will be men, and 60 percent will be college graduates. And Ford is optimistic that sales will be better than those of the Mark VII, totaling perhaps 35,000 a year.
"I just took delivery on one myself," Telnack said. "It's black, all black. When it shows up in my parking spot, it'll drive the color and trim guys nuts."

HEADLINE: As the Steel and Iron Age Ends, Let's Turn to Lighter Materials

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Forty years ago I became concerned about the population explosion and environmental degradation because we in America subscribe to the notion that bigger is better and more is better. We continue on that course. The world population, then 2.2 billion, is now 5.8 billion and climbing.
As a result, we have more than 300 million automobiles and approximately 34 million trucks contaminating the air, and the water too, in their manufacture. If we use our heads we should understand we are coming to the end of the Steel and Iron Age, and the sooner we come to the age of composites, the better off we will be. The Voyager spacecraft, which circumnavigated the globe, should have taught us this lesson, but didn't. It was built with composite materials. 
 Composites are a combination of glass fibers, or boron fibers, depending on how light and strong we want the end product to be, bonded with a small amount of resin. This material would permit us to make an M-60 tank (60 for 60 tons) become an M-30 tank. It would cut the weight in half, cutting fuel consumption in half and the engine size in half.
This material could be used to build boxcars, flatbeds, tank cars and locomotives on the railroads. It would also apply to trucks, tractors and the transport used in the delivery of goods and people over the highways to whatever their destination.
And if we relaid the rails of the country's 40,000 miles of rail transit, we could employ every able-bodied person now unemployed.
The black gold of petroleum must be conserved for pharmaceuticals and fertilizers and not be wasted meeting the basic needs of the world's population. Our next President must keep these matters seriously in mind.
 
HAROLD BOSTROM
Milwaukee, Nov. 5, 1992
 
The writer formerly made suspension seating for trucks and tractors.

HEADLINE: Inefficient Soviet Economy Halted Cold War

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The G.O.P. Won the Cold War? Ridiculous" (Op-Ed, Oct. 28), George Kennan argues that the Republicans cannot claim credit for ending the cold war. In "Credit Where It's Due for Cold War's End" (letter, Nov. 6), Prof. Richard Pipes asks why deny President Bush recognition for an "event that occurred on his watch." 
 Those who believe, like Mr. Pipes, that the United States and its allies were responsible for ending the cold war usually argue that our arms-race policies forced such a diversion of resources from the Soviet civilian economy that it went into an extended tailspin and had to sue for peace.
While there is an element of truth in this, it is not the real explanation. It fails to recognize that rising rates of military spending in authoritarian centrally planned economies need not lower rates of investment. Unlike the United States experience, Soviet rates of investment peaked at 32 percent to 33 percent in the late 1980's when military spending peaked. Despite the very high rate of investment, Soviet growth hit a trough of around 2 percent. Why?
Because the real causes of the continuously declining growth rate of the Soviet Union, of the poor quality of its products and of its many other deficiencies are to be found in central planning by direct controls. The Soviet economy was an economy run by bureaucrats without information provided by real market prices, without the incentives to be efficient enforced by market competition and without much incentive to develop and introduce new technology.
Recognition that Soviet planning was a failed system led Mikhail S. Gorbachev to introduce perestroika; along the road he also introduced glasnost and democratization, and by refusing to obstruct similar revolutions in Eastern Europe, effectively dissolved the Soviet bloc. These ended the cold war and earned Mr. Gorbachev the Nobel Peace Prize. The Republicans should learn not to look a gift horse in the mouth.
Mr. Gorbachev, with the extraordinary power at his disposal, could have lived out his life without reforms. He had great vision and courage, and one might wonder how such a person could have emerged from the pre-perestroika Soviet Union. Asked this question in an interview two or three years ago, George Kennan said, "It's a miracle, simply a miracle."
 
FRANKLYN D. HOLZMAN
edford, Mass., Nov. 9, 1992
 
The writer, a professor of economics at Tufts University, is a fellow at Harvard's Russian Research Center.

HEADLINE: Passaic Flood Tunnel: Some Questions

 BODY:
It's still going on! The Army Corps of Engineers is pushing another of its pork projects to destroy another part of our environment. This time it's a gigantic tunnel that puts floodwaters underground and shoots them out into Newark Bay ("Passaic Flood Tunnel: A Turning Point," Nov. 8).
Are we to ignore the fact that the floodwater is an integral part of three river ecosystems? And do we forget that the corps solutions to other of our problems, like the erosion at the beaches, haven't solved any problems but continue to blemish the environment? And what about all that money? 
 There's been $30 million admitted to in the studies. There's another estimated $2 billion to build this tunnel. Aren't we in a recession? Aren't people homeless and hungry because there's no money? Aren't we closing mental institutions and laying off health workers because there's no money? How come there's money for boondoggles but not for people?
Then we are told that the Federal Government will pay most of the bill, so New Jersey doesn't have to. What an insult! Don't all levels of government get their money from our taxes? Except for politicians, who would try to tell us that a different pocket in the same pair of pants is different money?
The estimate is that it'll take 10 years to build. Of course, that's also a corps estimate. Is that 10 years of patronage, padded accounts and sweetheart contracts? Is that 10 years of business as usual? And what if these estimates are wrong? What if it's $6 billion and 20 years?
What about maintenance after it's built? Who can maintain a 40-foot-wide, 20-mile-long tunnel hundreds of feet underground? Who repairs the environmental damage this lack of floodwater does to the river basin and to the water table?
Is all this to protect people who haven't figured out that if you live in a flood basin, you will get wet? Maybe it's time our elected politicians took a good look at the direction and purpose of the Army Corps of Engineers.
 
RAYMOND E. WILLIAMS
East Brunswick

HEADLINE: Setting Record Straight On Affordable Housing

 BODY:
Frank Denniston [Letters to the Westchester Editor, Nov. 8] ought to do his homework before lashing out at my opposition to government-subsidized middle-income housing in Westchester County. It's easy to take a few words out of context, to mischaracterize another's opinion in as poor a light as possible and then to attack it.
Let me set the record straight. 
 I have never opposed helping our young, our elderly or our infirm find suitable housing at an "affordable" price. That's a straw issue.
I consistently have opposed government-subsidized middle-income housing. I do not believe government, particularly county government, belongs in the housing business, nor do I believe it is in our interest to give counties the power to override home rule.
Sure, you won't find anything affordable in Scarsdale, but most people start more modestly. Indeed, according to figures from the Westchester County Board of Realtors, during the third quarter of 1992, 32 percent of residential sales countywide were for less than $200,000, including 7 percent for less than $100,000. Just ask anyone trying to sell their co-op or condominium whether their price is affordable. Dozens of cooperatives, for example, are available in Mamaroneck for under $50,000, and many single-family homes in the northern areas of Westchester County are available for under $150,000.
Let's get the debate back on track. Our problem is not that housing prices in our most desirable communities are too high. Our problem is that we have lost thousands of jobs to the recession and to New York State's failure to keep its tax burden in line with the rest of the country.
Government can build all the so-called affordable housing it wants. But if we don't make this state and this county a more attractive place to do business, that subsidized housing will soon be competing with a lot more affordable housing as our residents flee this area for those states that are attracting our businesses and our jobs with their more rational tax structures and their more rational conceptions of what areas government ought to be staying out of.
 
BOB WEININGER
Harrison

HEADLINE: NOV. 15-21: The Balkans;
The U.N. and the West Get a Little Tougher With Serbia

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

 BODY:
A month ago motorists in Belgrade had to wait two days in line for gasoline. Now it's a matter of minutes. That, in short, is why the United Nations Security Council decided last week to crack down on violations of trade sanctions against Yugoslavia, and why the United States and Western Europe decided to enforce a naval blockade.
Whether such methods would have the desired political effect on the Serbs who lead Yugoslavia, and the forces they back in Bosnia, remained a question, however. Once last week, Serbs fired on French troops convoying supplies to a besieged town outside Sarajevo. The French fired back and got through unhurt. 
 The trade embargo, voted last May, has three aims -- to show that the world won't tolerate "ethnic cleansing" and the acquisition of territory by force; to encourage Slobodan Milosevic, Serbia's hard-line nationalist President, to stop backing Bosnia's extremist Serbs, and to induce Serbs to vote Mr. Milosevic out of office in elections Dec. 20 if he remains defiant.
All three tasks seem difficult. Bosnia's Serbs, who hold 70 percent of the land in that former Yugoslav republic, have achieved their basic territorial aims, and President Milosevic has shown no sign of wishing to bring them to heel. Indeed, he is using sanctions to rally his people around him by proclaiming that they stand alone against an unfair world.
What might get rid of him and undermine the Serbian extremists, most Western diplomats in Yugoslavia believe, is to persuade Serbia's weak and divided opposition to unify and campaign effectively in the coming election. But this, too, seems a distant goal.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
For Vietnam, Settling the Past Could Be Good Business

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam

 BODY:
A generation ago, the Vietnamese learned how American public opinion could help end a war that bullets and bombs and the sacrifice of hundreds of thousands of lives seemed incapable of drawing to a close.
Now they are trying to apply that lesson in reviving a peacetime economy that remains among the most backward in Asia -- backward in no small part because of a 17-year-old trade embargo that is one of the last vestiges of the Vietnam war. 
 The Vietnamese want the embargo lifted. And this time, on the battlefield of public relations, Hanoi enjoys the support of former adversaries in the American Government and business establishment; many there think it is time to normalize relations. This time, Hanoi's leaders know, it is elements of the American public who must be persuaded.
The Vietnamese say their decision last month to open up war museums and military archives to inspection by the United States Government was entirely a humanitarian gesture intended to help the Defense Department determine what happened to 2,265 Americans still unaccounted for in Indochina.
But as they met with a delegation of senators and Pentagon officials who traveled to Vietnam last week to discuss the search for the missing, Vietnamese leaders pressed hard for the Americans to urge President Bush to lift the trade embargo before he leaves the White House in January.
Vietnamese officials don't deny that they sometimes choreograph events with an American audience in mind.
The most poignant moment for the Senate delegation came at Hanoi's central military museum, as an aging Vietnamese army colonel, surrounded by American television cameras, turned over memorabilia taken from American soldiers during the war: prayer booklets, high school identification cards, family photographs, as well as the airman's helmet worn by Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican who spent five years as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam.
The colonel also gave the senators his wartime diary, which appeared to hold answers to the disappearance of four American soldiers in a central Vietnamese province in 1967. The diary says the soldiers were ambushed, their bodies hidden from rescue teams.
What has gone largely unmentioned in the excitement over the archival treasure trove is that the Vietnamese, after years of saying they were cooperating fully in the search for missing Americans, are making this material public only now.
 
Adventurer in the Archives
 Diplomats in Hanoi and American officials offer no single theory about why Hanoi took so long to open the archives and why the first of the artifacts were given months ago to an American adventurer, Ted Schweitzer, instead of to Defense Department investigators.
According to accounts from American officials, Mr. Schweitzer received permission from Hanoi's central war museum to go through its archives for material on a book on the war. Mr. Schweitzer came across thousands of black and white photographs of Americans captured or killed during the war. He turned the photos over to the Pentagon, apparently with the knowledge of at least some elements of the Vietnamese Army.
"Vietnam has a factionalized, bureaucratic Government," said an Asian diplomat, "I think one faction within the military wanted to hold on to this material while another faction wanted to get the photos out in time for President Bush to lift the embargo. They saw Schweitzer as a means of getting around official channels." Another theory says the Vietnamese just didn't realize the value of the photos until Mr. Schweitzer saw them.
Whatever the explanation, the Bush Administration, Congress and American business leaders seem eager to use Vietnam's full-access pledge to ease the American economic embargo imposed after South Vietnam fell in 1975. In a letter last week to President Le Duc Anh, President Bush hinted strongly that he would relax the embargo in exchange for continued cooperation.
Senator John F. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat and Vietnam veteran who is the chairman of the Senate Select Committee on P.O.W.-M.I.A. Affairs, said it would be counterproductive now to protest over Vietnam's long delay. "If we shut down our investigation because we get angry about what we didn't get in the past, we deny our families the answers they want," he said.
American investigators say they, too, have no desire to feud with the Vietnamese. "We're delighted with this new cooperation," said Lieut. Col. Jack Donovan, the senior Defense Department investigator now in Vietnam. "I'm too busy to be angry about the past."
The Vietnamese want to talk and, more important in Hanoi, they want to trade -- a desire shared by scores of American corporations that see Vietnam as the last great untapped business opportunity in Asia, a nation of 70 million people known for their industriousness and high educational standards, and whose labor is as cheap as any on the continent. The average household income in Vietnam is still less than $300 a year.
Boeing wants to sell jets to Vietnam. Citibank wants to do banking. Mobil Oil wants a chance to bid on tracts for offshore oil drilling. All have sent representatives to scout out future business. An end to the embargo would also permit the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to pour billions of dollars into basic service projects in a nation still largely without telephone service, reliable electricity and paved roads.
This month Japan said it would resume development aid to Vietnam. Business people from Taiwan, Hong Kong, South Korea, Malaysia, Thailand, Australia and France have been investing in Vietnam for years. If the United States does not move quickly to establish diplomatic ties, American business leaders fear, they will lose the Vietnamese market forever, surrendering a country once thought so important to American interests that the United States went to war over it.

HEADLINE: TRANSITION;
Hi. Goodbye. This Takes 11 Weeks and $3.5 Million?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AFTER four years in the splendid isolation of the Presidency, George Bush is finding the 11-week hiatus between his defeat and Bill Clinton's inauguration stripped of splendor, but still plenty isolated. Moody, fidgety, maybe a little bitter, he has fallen out of the hyperactive, quirky character that even critics found endearing. Instead, he steals unannounced from the White House for midnight visits to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial; spends long stretches out of public view; proclaims that he is putting the Government on ice, in effect, until Bill Clinton takes over.
The President's moodiness is certainly understandable: just after losing a race he expected to win, he also saw his mother die of a stroke. But well before her illness, at a meeting on Tuesday that he had thought was private, he hinted at one source of his discontent. "I've concluded that the interregnum is too long, too ungenerous and too long," he said. "The gears are already beginning to shift, as they should," he added, and he is determined to transfer his power with grace. But he had a word for long goodbyes: "laborious." 
More visibly than many of his predecessors, the President suffers from what he characteristically described to Larry King early this month as "lame duckness." A uniquely American anemia, it afflicts every President who lives to see his authority and celebrity siphoned off by some smooth-cheeked naif who doesn't even own the nuclear-strike codes yet, for Pete's sake.
Still, Mr. Bush's perception that his case is worse than most is not so far-fetched. What he calls the interregnum, and everyone else has bureaucratized into the toneless noun "transition," is indeed laborious, and becoming more so. A mere post-election breather a generation ago, it now is vast, costly, labyrinthine, self-important, and rife with opportunities for back-stabbing.
It has become a sort of Presidency in utero, a cute little swelling in the belly of the system that now exceeds in size the Presidency itself.
This is a recent development. To prepare to succeed Harry S. Truman, Dwight D. Eisenhower simply dispatched the management consultant McKinsey & Company into the Government to find out for him what it did. John F. Kennedy essentially drew his transition advice from two men, Richard Neustadt and Clark Clifford, both of whom drew paychecks from the outside. By comparison, the last vanquished-to-victor handoff of the White House -- Ronald Reagan's takeover from Jimmy Carter 12 years ago -- had a Federally approved budget of $2 million, ran $1 million over that, and filled a Federal office building for two months with better than 1,000 Republican advisers, job-seekers and political groupies.
Mr. Clinton campaigned hard on a pledge to pare billions in wasteful spending and featherbed jobs from the Federal bureaucracy. His Congressionally authorized budget for the transition totals $3.5 million, but now his staff is saying they will, like Mr. Reagan, accept private donations to supplement that sum.
"It's grown along with the Presidency itself," said Theodore Lowi, a professor of government at Cornell University. "Once you get an institutional Presidency, which we've had since Truman, everything about it gets institutionalized, including the transition."
Is this really necessary? It depends. On one hand, most great democracies plug along famously without three-month hiatuses between leaders; two years ago, Britain's Margaret Thatcher was voted out of office and vacated 10 Downing Street in only four days. Helmut Kohl needed no more time to oust Helmut Schmidt and replace his Cabinet in Germany in 1983.
 
Transition Was Once in March
 Even American interregnums are briefer than they used to be. The Constitution, drafted when trips to Washington took weeks instead of hours, delayed Presidential swearings-in until March 4 and kept Congress out of session even longer, until December. The 20th Amendment changed that in 1933, after the endless wait for Franklin D. Roosevelt to succeed Herbert C. Hoover contributed to fiscal uncertainty and a bank panic.
On the other hand, Britain and Germany are parliamentary democracies, in which opposition lawmakers stand as shadow leaderships trained to step in quickly. Policies and personnel are ready, more or less, to be plugged in as required. Alone among major nations, the United States regenerates its leadership root and branch with every transfer of power, drawing largely from outside the Congress. As power has accreted to the Presidency, that has become an increasingly lengthy, messy and combative process, like it or not.
"Bush may think it's too long, but from Clinton's standpoint, it may not be long enough," said Carl M. Brauer, who has studied modern interregnums.
But many do not like it one bit. Mr. Neustadt, an adviser to Truman and Kennedy who is an emeritus professor of government at Harvard University, argued that an incoming President faces three signal challenges: to sketch the outlines of his programs and budget; to hire and indoctrinate the 50 to 100 people at the core of his Government, and to make the symbolic journey from campaigner to leader. None of them demands a huge, clanking transition apparatus, he said.
"Transition teams are nothing but large groups of ex-campaigners on the Federal payroll for a temporary period, wandering around Washington terrorizing civil servants," Mr. Neustadt said this week. "They all turn in reports to the people you've ultimately appointed to lead the departments, and those reports usually get filed in a wastebasket. And that's the end of that."
Mr. Neustadt feels a special responsibility for the process. Moved by the plight of a Kennedy aide who worked without pay and at substantial personal cost, he asked House Speaker Sam Rayburn to support legislation providing Federal funding for transitions. Unfortunately, he said, the bill passed.
"If there were no money, it wouldn't happen," he said. "And I'm sorry, but I'm responsible for it."
All but lost in the parade, meanwhile, is the inconvenient fact that someone else is still President, and will be until the succeeding Jan. 20. Every so often, an outgoing administration tries to make a little mischief: Mr. Carter, for example, used his waning hours to issue sheaves of "midnight regulations" for Democratic programs that Mr. Reagan promptly nullified. Some Presidents hide pet projects in their final budgets and defy newcomers to root them out. Mr. Truman, the father of smoothly integrated transitions, so opposed such skulduggery that he invited Eisenhower's fiscal experts to witness the preparation of his last budget.
As for Mr. Bush, he may be of two minds. He has publicly dedicated himself to relinquishing power "with style," using his remaining days in a non-partisan fashion to tie up loose ends. On Friday, he did that and capped his own tenure with a flourish, sealing a European trade agreement that may well hasten the realization of the only real vision of his re-election campaign: a new global economic order. On the other hand, Mr. Bush nearly saddled the Clinton Administration with a trade war over wine.
But Mr. Bush cannot dodge some highly partisan decisions, and indeed, he may relish making them. Atop that list is the question of whether to pardon major figures in the Iran-contra affair, a scandal with which Mr. Clinton bludgeoned the President in the campaign's last hours. Staff work on the pardons has reached high levels within the White House.
The President also is scheduled to decide within weeks whether to allow British Airways to buy a 44 per cent stake in a major American air carrier, USAir. He has taken no official position, but British Air's offer dovetails with his view of a global economic village, while it has aroused Mr. Clinton's more protectionist instincts.
Meanwhile, some of Mr. Bush's own aides are quietly discussing whether the White House should use other issues to rub a thumb in Mr. Clinton's eye, if only as a statement of principle. Especially tempting is a pending decision by the Environmental Protection Agency on the definition of protected wetlands.
Vice President Quayle wants one that eases development on millions of acres, and some Bush aides think this would be a fitting parting shot at Mr. Clinton and especially at his Vice President, Al Gore, an environmentalist. Their problem, and their boss's, is the anemic nature of interregnums: an outgoing President may still lead the world and control vast armies and billions of dollars, but the power has largely shifted to the new man.
"It's a question of whether to put our view down on paper so people will see the differences between us, or whether that would be viewed as grandstanding," one aide said. But the President, he said, "is not fighting to the last moment." Of Mr. Clinton, he added wearily: "He'll change it anyway."

HEADLINE: NOV. 15-21;
Oo-wah, Moo-lah

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
In 1956, two 15-year-olds, Jimmy Merchant and Herman Santiago, doo-wopped their way to fame as members of the Teen-Agers, with the smash hit "Why Do Fools Fall in Love?"
What followed for them was 37 years of mostly singing the blues: Mr. Merchant is a New York cabdriver, and Mr. Santiago is unemployed. 
 But last week a Federal District Court jury in Manhattan decided that they were the true authors of the often-recorded song -- entitled to a share of millions in royalties.
The two said they were cheated by George Goldner, the producer of the record, who put his own name and that of the 13-year-old lead vocalist, Frankie Lymon, on the copyright. For years, they said, they were intimidated into silence.
Indeed, the jury ruled they are to share royalties dating back not the usual three years but all the way to 1969, the year of a death threat against them by a promoter who later acquired the copyright.

HEADLINE: FRANCE CRITICIZES FARM TRADE PACT AS 'UNACCEPTABLE'

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 21

 BODY:
The French Prime Minister called a new farm trade agreement "unacceptable" today, warning that it posed a "grave threat" to French farmers but pointedly avoiding mention of a veto.
In a statement, Prime Minister Pierre Beregovoy noted that "difficult negotiations" lay ahead on the accord concluded on Friday by the European Community and the United States, but he left the door open to compromise. 
 Community officials have expressed relief that, so far, France has not threatened to exercise this right of veto in the name of "national interest." If France were to do so, the move would provoke a far deeper crisis in its relations with Germany and other major nations in the community.
European diplomatic efforts were also being made to resolve currency problems. [After hours of talks, European Community central bankers and finance officials agreed in Brussels early Sunday to devalue two of the weaker currencies, the Spanish peseta and the Portuguese escudo, by 6 percent to maintain the system of semi-fixed exchange rates. Page 14.]
 
France Leaves Itself an Option
 Prime Minister Beregevoy chose to refer to the agricultural accord as a draft, stressing that while the community's executive agency, the European Commission, was authorized to negotiate on trade matters, the 12 Governments would have the last word. And he hinted at the sort of concessions that might make the accord acceptable to France.
Mr. Beregovoy's carefully worded statement was a stark illustration of the French dilemma. The country is caught between provoking an angry and potentially violent backlash from its million farmers and standing in the way of an agreement considered essential to priming Western Europe for economic recovery.
"We are dealing with the defense of France's interests, our agriculture, our economy, our rural way of life," Mr. Beregovoy said, adding that "the result of this negotiation will affect us for a long time."
After the agreement was announced in Brussels and Washington, French farmers immediately began mobilizing against it. But the deal was welcomed in every European capital except Paris as the key to unlocking long-stalled talks on global trade liberalization.
France stands to lose more than most countries from such an accord. Export revenue would be threatened, and officials fear a revolt by the farmers, who in the past have expressed their dismay by paralyzing traffic, dumping produce and pelting officials with eggs and vegetables.
Most telling, perhaps, is the deep connection between France's national identity and its rural heritage. France clung to an agriculture way of life longer than many other industrial countries. As the population ages, tens of thousands of farms are closing each year, but the affection for the countryside has not diminished with the shrinking number of farms.
At the heart of the French position is its reluctance to further cut farm subsidies, price supports and cultivated acreage after France accepted one round of concessions in May.
Calling the farm trade pact unacceptable today, Mr. Beregovoy confirmed the position stated on Friday night by his Agriculture Minister. Looking ahead to a Parliament debate on Wednesday, he also called for "national cohesion" regarding the dispute.
"We agreed to the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy," Mr. Beregovoy said of the concessions France made when the policy was overhauled. "That reform is the limit of what we accept."
Put differently, France believes that any farm trade agreement with the United States must conform with the community's new policy.
 
Makes No Sense to French
 "We have good sense on our side," Mr. Beregovoy said today. "Europe cannot reform its common agricultural policy in May only to dismantle it in November."
Friday's agreement requiring the community to cut back the volume of its agricultural exports by 21 percent, he said, "is not compatible" with the Common Agricultural Policy. France has now asked the European Commission to prepare a report comparing the new pact with the community's agricultural policy.
The commission's president, Jacques Delors, said today that he expected "a battle of figures" when the commission meets on Wednesday to study the details of the agreement thrashed out by its agricultural negotiator, Ray MacSharry, and its external affairs spokesman, Frans Andriessen.
Mr. Delors, a Frenchman who in the past has been criticized for seeming to defend French interests rmore than those of all Europeans, nonetheless sought to reassure French farmers today that the community's negotiators "managed to wring important concessions from the Americans."
Britain's Agriculture Minister, John Gummer, also argued that the agreement was more favorable to Europe than France had expected. "I think, on mature reflection, the French Foreign Minister will feel that, although this is not exactly what he would like, it certainly does go a very long way to meet the requirements," he said.
Political experts here said that the French authorities, in the next political stage, will be in the position of having to establish that the farm deal with the United States and the community's own policy are not contradictory.
To cover itself and not risk being voted out of office, the Government seems certain to take a tough stance during Wednesday's legislative debate. Yet in the end, the experts say, its objective will be to demonstrate to the rest of the European Community that France is united.
That would, in turn, strengthen the Government's hand in negotiations on the meaning of the farm accord with Washington and the Common Agricultural Policy. And, the experts say, that could pave the way for the community to grant additional concessions to French farmers. To press its European partners, Paris may try to use the farmers' planned demonstrations as a bargaining tool.

HEADLINE: Clinton Treading Cautiously As Trade Talks Move Ahead

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton is holding off on embracing the agreement on farm subsidies between the United States and Europe that was announced on Friday, recognizing that the broad and complex world trade talks are fraught with political dangers for him.
The farm subsidies compromise, unless it is vetoed by France, is expected to allow global trade talks involving 108 nations to move forward quickly, seeking to reduce trade barriers in a broad range of goods and services, including banking and telecommunications. 
 In Little Rock today, Mr. Clinton was asked about the agreement and replied, "I haven't reviewed it. I've got to look at it." Dee Dee Myers, Mr. Clinton's press secretary, added today in an interview, "He's encouraged by the progress" in the farm subsidies agreement. "He just wants to be sure about the details."
She said Mr. Clinton would take the same cautious approach that he took to the free-trade agreement with Mexico and Canada, carefully reviewing the text of the agreement before deciding whether to endorse it.
The farm compromise, if it holds, will certainly allow Mr. Clinton to breathe a lot easier when he takes office by averting a trade war that could send world trade and stock prices tumbling. The breakthrough would also bring to the forefront other issues on which Mr. Clinton is likely to face considerable pressure from Capitol Hill as well as from groups that supported him, including textile and steel workers and the Hollywood film industry.
"The agricultural breakthrough is good, and the Bush Administration deserves credit for having achieved that," the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, said Friday night. "But I'm worried that now that we've spent a lot of capital to get that, the Europeans will demand a lot of changes on other provisions in the trade talks that will be to our great disadvantage."
In the coming weeks, the Bush Administration will be negotiating such sensitive issues as ending restrictions on apparel imports, reducing Europe's restrictions on broadcast of American films on television and responding to Europe's demands that Washington weaken its antidumping laws. The talks are being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which oversees world trade.
If the agreement is not completed by Jan. 20, Mr. Clinton's team would take over these difficult negotiations. It is a matter of debate whether it would be a good thing for the President-elect if the trade talks are completed before he takes office.
If Mr. Bush oversees completion of the talks, and Congress is dissatisfied with the agreement, President Bush and not President Clinton will take most of the heat. On the other hand, if Mr. Clinton is dissatisfied with some provisions, he could push for additional changes, as he did with the North American Free Trade Agreement. But with so many more nations involved, change would not be easy.
 
Some Change Can Be Difficult
 Many trade experts in Washington predict that Mr. Clinton will be compelled to embrace whatever pact the Bush Administration might negotiate, even if he has reservations about several parts of it. To reject an accord negotiated by his predecessor would no doubt lead to harsh criticism from American allies and other countries, as well as to complaints domestically that Mr. Clinton was a protectionist and not a free trader.
"The talks have been going on for six years, and we would like to see them resolved," Ms. Myers said.
Although President Bush sometimes acts as if his Administration has closed shop, the trade talks may well become a highly charged issue for him over the next few weeks, as his Administration strains to finish the talks by Jan. 20.
Democrats in Congress are already warning that they do not want to see the Administration rush an agreement so Mr. Bush can boast of it as another accomplishment.
"We want an agreement -- a good agreement," said Representative Sander M. Levin, a Michigan Democrat who has often criticized the Administration on trade. "We want something that isn't a rush to the finish line, but something that can stand up for decades hence."
Bush Administration trade negotiators, led by the trade representative, Carla A. Hills, say they hope to have a basic agreement on all issues in the world trade talks by mid-January. After that, they say, it will take several more weeks to work out hundreds of details.
The Administration still hopes to meet the March 3 "fast track" deadline for notifying Congress of a completed accord. Under fast-track rules, Congress must vote on the agreement without being able to amend it. The fast-track concept is intended to prevent the 535 members of Congress from picking apart bit by bit agreements with foreign governments that have been painstakingly negotiated.
 
Accords Don't Always Help
 "I frankly hope the Bush Administration isn't going to cap its four-year term with an agreement for the sake of an agreement," said Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana. "I also hope it's not trying to reach an agreement which it knows will represent a lot of problems which will then be dumped into the lap of the new President and Congress. I hope that's not part of the Administration's calculus."
For their part, Administration officials say they have done Mr. Clinton a major favor. "Getting this off of the President-elect's plate so he does not have to deal with it is a major benefit to him and the people with him," Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan said in an interview.
If there was no agreement heading off a trade war, Mr. Clinton might have entered office facing poisoned relations with the European Community, and immense political pressures to resolve the crisis.
The farm subsidies agreement "is about the nicest present that Bush can leave Clinton," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs International, a trade and international economics specialist in the Carter and Reagan Administrations. "I don't think Clinton wanted to inherit a complicated and acrimonious trade negotiation. This paves the way toward a much more open global trading system in which competitive American firms will have opportunities to expand."
During the campaign, Mr. Clinton said he favored taking a tougher approach with countries that engage in unfair trade practices, like exporting products at unfairly low prices, a practice known as dumping.
As a result, he may be unhappy with the current draft text in the trade talks, which would limit the ability of American companies to bring antidumping cases. With the talks starting to focus on areas other than farm subsidies, the American steel industry and the steelworkers union are expected to increase their lobbying against this provision.
Textile companies and unions are also increasing their protests about a proposal in the draft that would, over 10 years, eliminate an arrangement in which the industrial nations restrict apparel imports from poor nations. The American textile industry wants the phase-out to take at least 15 years.
The filmmaking industry also took a higher profile on trade this week. In a letter to Mrs. Hills, the trade negotiator, top Hollywood executives voiced fears that after getting Europe to make concessions on farm subsidies, the Administration might not push as hard to end Europe's quotas on how many American movies and television programs can be broadcast on television.
 
A Lot of Wild Cards
 "I assume that people concerned about these areas will step up the pressure if they see a quick agreement coming," John J. Ziolkowski, trade and foreign policy adviser to Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican minority leader, said. "If there is no agreement by Jan. 20, then Clinton will face all these pressures."
Although a final trade agreement appears to be at least several months away, members of Congress predict that it will probably pass the Senate and the House. But they say they cannot be sure because there are more than 100 new members of the House and because very few members follow trade issues closely.
Mr. Clinton might face an uncomfortable situation in which he has to defend a pact inherited from President Bush against criticisms from his fellow Democrats, who generally take a harder line on trade than the Republicans. Many want the Administration to push harder to reduce trade barriers that face American banks, telecommunications services and manufactured goods.
"I think the President-elect wants a trade agreement," Mr. Gephardt said. "I want one. But it can't come at the expensive of giving up too much in areas important to our standard of living, like manufacturing, high technology and financial services."

HEADLINE: The Burdens of Being Overweight: Mistreatment and Misconceptions

SERIES: Fat in America/First of three articles.

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
Aleta Walker never had any friends during her childhood and adolescence in Hannibal, Mo. Instead, she was ridiculed and bullied every day. When she walked down the halls at school, boys would flatten themselves against the lockers and cry, "Wide load!" But the worst was lunchtime, she said.
"Every day there was this production of watching me eat lunch," Ms. Walker said. She tried to avoid going to the school cafeteria. "I would hide out in the bathroom. I would hide out behind the gym by the baseball diamond. I would hide in the library." 
 One day, schoolmates started throwing food at her as she sat at a table at lunch. Plates of spaghetti splashed onto her face, and the long greasy strands dripped onto her clothes. "Everyone was laughing and pointing. They were making pig noises. I just sat there," she said.
 
Surrounded by Abuse
 Ms. Walker is fat. And, like most fat people, she has been dogged by ridicule and abuse throughout her life. She has felt discrimination on the job. She is constantly subjected to rude remarks and ugly noises, like pig grunts or moos, when she goes out, and she has had a hard time making friends.
Despite the consistent findings by obesity researchers that most people actually have little control over their body weight, researchers find and fat people confirm that society continues to deride fat people for their condition.
Studies have found that fat people are less likely to be admitted to elite colleges, are less likely to be hired for a job, make less money when they are hired, and are less likely to be promoted. One study found that businessmen sacrifice $1,000 in salary for every pound they are overweight. Fat people tell researchers that they are accosted on the street by strangers who admonish them to lose weight. Often, their own children are ashamed of them. Studies have shown that even many doctors find fat people disgusting, and some refuse to treat them.
 
They'd Rather Be Blind
 In a recent study of formerly fat people who had lost weight after intestinal bypass surgery, researchers at the University of Florida reported that virtually all said they would rather be blind or deaf or have a leg amputated than be fat again.
"Overweight people have a condition that is unacceptable in our society," said Dr. Kelly Brownell, an obesity researcher at Yale University School of Medicine. And, he added, unlike the blind or the deaf, fat people are told that they could be thin if they really wanted to. "It's kind of a double punishment," Dr. Brownell said.
Dr. Albert Stunkard, an obesity researcher at the University of Pennsylvania, agreed. "There's that implicit assumption that you really could lose weight if you settled down and stopped being such a fat slob," he said.
Fat people are the last group that it is acceptable to discriminate against blatantly, said Dr. Esther Rothblum, a psychologist at the University of Vermont who studies the social consequences of being fat. Sally E. Smith, the executive director of the National Association to Advance Fat Acceptance, an advocacy group in Sacramento, Calif., said Michigan is the only state that prohibits discrimination against fat people. Ms. Smith added that fat people have sued employers and sometimes won on the basis of discrimination against the handicapped but not on the basis of discrimination against the obese.
 
Desperate Fight Against Weight
 An estimated 25 to 30 percent of Americans are obese, defined as 25 percent or more above their ideal weight. Most have tried and tried again to reduce. Often the fatter they are, the more desperately they tried.
Ms. Walker, who is 36 years old, went on her first diet when she was 12. An osteopath prescribed amphetamines and 500 calories a day. In the intervening years, she has tried virtually every weight loss program that has come along -- the Cambridge Diet, the rice diet, the Dr. Atkins Diet, Weight Watchers, Optifast (twice). But every time she would gain back the weight she so painfully lost. "I currently weigh about 300 pounds," she said.
In April, Ms. Walker and other fat people were, in a sense, vindicated by the findings of experts at a conference called by the National Institutes of Health. The group looked at data on success rates of weight loss programs and concluded that diets, including expensive commercial diet plans, have an abysmal success rate in long term, with virtually all dieters regaining the weight they had lost. The panel wrote, "There is increasing physiological, biochemical, and genetic evidence that overweight is not a simple disorder of willpower, as is sometimes implied, but is a complex disorder of energy metabolism."
But these findings are hardly new, obesity researchers said. For example, Dr. Jules Hirsch and Dr. Rudolph L. Leibel of Rockefeller University discovered years ago that when obese people lose weight, they often have symptoms of chronic starvation -- they feel cold all the time, are always hungry, and are obsessed with food. Women stop menstruating. The formerly obese feel an overwhelming compulsion to eat until they are fat again. Those few who do manage to to keep the weight off usually do so by making it a career to stay thin. They become Weight Watchers lecturers, for example, and fanatically monitor every bite of food that passes their lips.
 
Refusing to Accept Fat
 Dr. Susan C. Wooley, director of the eating disorders clinic at the University of Cincinnati, said that it is one thing to say that most dieters fail to lose weight and keep it off and another to really accept, emotionally, that fat people cannot help it. Scientists themselves are as guilty as the rest of society, Dr. Wooley said.
"It has been clear in the scientific community that diets fail, yet scientists have been extremely reluctant to let go of diet programs," she said. "Why should we expect the general population to be any quicker than scientists in releasing prejudice?"
Scores of research studies have documented the staggering social and emotional cost of being fat. And fat people, with their achingly sad stories, confirm what the cold statistics say.
One hint of the daily agony of being fat came in a survey by Dr. Rothblum and her colleagues of 367 women and 78 men who were members of the National Association to Advance Fat Acceptance. A third of the men and about a fifth of the women in the study were not fat. The rest were at least 20 percent above their ideal weight. Dr. Rothblum found that the fatter the respondents were, the more likely they were to report that they suffered discrimination and abuse because of their weight.
More than 40 percent of the fat men and 60 percent of the fat women said they had not been hired for a job because of their weight. More than 30 percent of the fat people said they had been denied promotions or raises because of their weight. One person wrote, "I was told by upper management that I would never be promoted until I lost weight and the union took management's side."
 
Linking Poverty and Obesity
 The survey seems to explain why it is that fat women, in particular, so often are poor, Dr. Rothblum said. The National Center for Health Statistics reports that 29.2 percent of women with incomes below $10,000 a year are obese, while 12.7 percent of those with incomes above $50,000 a year are obese. Dr. Rothblum argues that fatness leads to poverty, rather than the reverse.
Dr. Rothblum said fat women are less likely than thinner women to be hired and if they are hired they are less likely to be promoted. Although there is also discrimination against fat men, positions where women predominate, like flight attendants, waitresses, receptionists and secretaries, are also jobs that place a premium on being "attractive, meaning thin," Dr. Rothblum said.
Further, she said, fat women are much more likely than their thinner sisters to marry men lower on the social or economic ladder. And since a tendency to be fat is inherited, their children, born to a lower social class, would be likely to stay there.
But Dr. Stunkard is not ready to discard the idea that being poor increases your chances of being fat. Though a tendency to be obese is inherited, he said, "you have to have the environment to bring it out." Apart from differences in diet, he said, there are looser sanctions in lower social classes against being fat.
 
Scorned and Snubbed
 Dr. Rothblum's survey also showed the social consequences of being fat. Ninety percent of the fat men and women said that friends or relatives had ridiculed them or made nasty comments to them about their weight and three quarters of them said they had been laughed at or derided by fellow employees. One of the survey participants wrote, "While attending a lecture in college, a professor stopped speaking in the middle of a sentence and said, 'When are you going to lose weight? You are really fat.' There were over 100 people in the class."
A quarter of the fat men and 16 percent of the fat women reported being hit or threatened because of their weight. A third said they had been derided by health professionals and a quarter said they had been refused treatment because they were fat.
Dr. Colleen Rand, an obesity researcher at the University of Florida, has similar findings. She studied 50 obese women and 7 men who had intestinal bypass surgery and subsequently lost an average of 100 pounds each. Before surgery, the patients reported overwhelming embarrassment about their appearance and said they faced constant prejudice and discrimination. For example, 77 percent said that their children had asked them not to attend school functions.
In another study, Dr. Rand asked 47 formerly fat men and women whether they would rather be obese again or have some other disability. Every one of the 47 people said they would rather be deaf or have dyslexia, diabetes, bad acne or heart disease than be obese again. Ninety-one percent said they would rather have a leg amputated. Eighty-nine percent would rather be blind. One patient said: "When you're blind, people want to help you. No one wants to help you when you're fat."
Dr. Rand cautioned that her study group consisted of people who had gone to the extreme length of having surgery to become thin, so they might have suffered more from obesity than others. But fat people's stories offer testimony to the observation that life is a constant struggle for the overweight.
"We elicit an extreme emotional reaction from people," said Ms. Smith, the director of the fat acceptance group.
 
Constant Stares
 Julia House, a 39-year-old office manager in Mesa, Ariz., said she cannot go grocery shopping without facing the stares of other shoppers who want to see what she puts in her shopping cart. And when she eats in a restaurant, other diners cannot resist peering at her to see what and how much she is eating. When Ms. House and a thin friend ordered hot fudge sundaes recently, "A little old lady looked at me and said, 'My, don't you think you should be eating something else?' " Ms. House said.
Pamela Hollowich of Los Angeles said one of her most humiliating moments came when she tried to board an airplane. Ms. Hollowich, who weighs 350 pounds, was waiting to board when an attendant "pulled me out of the line in front of all the other passengers and said I had to buy two tickets. It was humiliating. It was degrading," she said. But she ended up buying the extra ticket. Later, she sued the airline. Her suit is in litigation.
Lynn Meletiche, a 48-year-old nurse who is chairwoman of the health committee for the National Association to Advance Fat Acceptance, said she often helps fat people whose doctors disparage them. One woman, she said, was told she had cervical cancer. But her doctor refused to operate on her unless she lost 100 pounds, even though the added risk of surgery was overwhelmed by the risk of living with cervical cancer. She found another doctor who did the operation, Ms. Meletiche said.
The abuse is "overwhelming," said Laura Eljaiek, a 35-year-old temporary office worker in New York. "It affects you every day. It's hard to go out there feeling good about yourself."
But Ms. Eljaiek, like more and more many fat people, has decided not to be passive in the face of blatant insults.
The other day, she said, she was getting off a bus when a man behind her said, "You could use some Slim Fast." Ms. Eljaiek whirled around to face him. "You," she shot back, "could use some manners."
Next: Why weight is so hard to lose.

HEADLINE: U.S. Mine Inspectors Charge Interference By Agency Director

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUNLAP, Tenn.

 BODY:
Federal mining inspectors here and in five other states say the head of the agency that oversees the $20 billion coal industry has repeatedly interceded on behalf of coal companies to thwart enforcement of the law regulating strip mining.
The inspectors, who head regional offices of the Office of Surface Mining, Reclamation and Enforcement, said in interviews that the director, Harry M. Snyder, had ordered them to end investigations of violations, reduce fines, eliminate penalties, divert prosecutions and prevent inspections. Such intervention, they said, has also made them reluctant to enforce the law aggressively. 
 The inspectors as well as several ranking officials in the Office of Surface Mining said Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. knew of Mr. Snyder's actions and, by not interfering, in effect sanctioned them. The employees question the propriety of Mr. Snyder's interference and, in some cases, the legality of what has occurred.
 
'Development," Not Regulation
 Mr. Lujan has been a staunch advocate of eliminating restrictions on developing the nation's coal, mineral, oil and timber resources. He indicated as much in September, when he traveled to Norton, Va., for a speech to coal industry executives and at a news conference later, when he discussed what he expected from the strip mining agency and other Interior Department divisions. He was quoted at the time as saying: "We don't want to be a regulatory agency. We want to be a development agency on our national lands."
Mr. Lujan would not respond directly to repeated requests for comment on the inspectors' assertions. Steven Goldstein, a spokesman for Mr. Lujan, said the Interior Secretary was carrying out the Bush Administration's overall goals. "The Secretary is briefed on major actions which occur in the department," said Mr. Goldstein. "He does not micromanage the way the bureaus are run. He could have been aware that there were disputes involving these companies, but he did not give directions as to how these disputes should be resolved."
Mr. Snyder, who has directed the Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement since 1989, said the attacks on his leadership were undeserved and came from employees jockeying for position in the Clinton Administration. "What's the point of this exercise?" he asked in an interview. "I'll be out of here in a few weeks. The whole thing makes me sick."
 
Seeking Clinton's Attention
 The inspectors said they chose to make their accusations public to draw the attention of President-elect Bill Clinton to a pollution problem that they say can be eliminated if they are allowed to enforce the strip mining law.
The law, adopted in 1977, sets tough standards for operating strip mines and protecting streams from erosion and drainage from the strip mines. It sets up stringent requirements on how coal companies fill in the mines after their work is completed. And it sets standards on what land can be mined and what land cannot.
"The strip mining law was one of the most important environmental laws ever passed by this country," said Willis L. Gainer, 44 years old, a career employee who is branch chief in the Office of Surface Mining field office in Knoxville, Tenn. "But under Reagan and Bush we never had the support from Washington that we needed to be a strong regulatory agency. It's gotten worse in the last year. Maybe that will change in the Clinton Administration."
To some extent, the inspectors' decision to talk about the mining office's internal workings reflects the tensions that have built up over the last 12 years between political appointees and career employees in all the Government's environmental agencies.
 
A Role in Bush Strategy
 The tensions have been especially acute in the Office of Surface Mining, mainly because the office played a central role in President Bush's campaign strategy to increase jobs in rural areas by accelerating the development of mineral resources.
This policy was developed by Mr. Lujan, and he began to execute it in July 1991, by proposing that more than 40 million acres of park, national forest and private lands be opened to strip mining by coal companies, a plan blocked by Congress. Last January, Mr. Lujan joined with the coal industry in a lawsuit in a Federal appeals court aimed at dismantling a computer system that was the surface mining office's chief weapon in enforcing the strip-mining law. It is still pending. And in March, Mr. Lujan proposed a rule, since put into effect, to weaken the public's long-standing right to block strip mining on Federal land.
Mr. Snyder, for his part, interceded on behalf of coal companies to prevent his agency's regional offices from enforcing the strip mining law, the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act, the mining inspectors said.
In one case, Arch Minerals, owned in part by Ashland Oil Inc., Kentucky's largest corporation, had been cited and fined $22,500 by the state for mining too close to a reservoir near Rollins, in southern Wyoming.
Guy Padgett, the director of the Casper field office, sent two inspectors to determine if the violation was serious enough to warrant an order to shut down the mine. But the company heard about the impending inspection, called Mr. Snyder and after the agents arrived, company executives told them to check with their office before taking any action, Mr. Padgett said.
As the agents awaited further instructions, Mr. Padgett called Mr. Snyder in Washington. "He told me that on the basis of discussion he had already had with the company, he did not believe an imminent harm existed and no action should be taken," Mr. Padgett said in an interview. "I protested to the director that I felt that was my decision to make."
But he said he obeyed Mr. Snyder's order.
Mr. Snyder said in the interview that his action on behalf of Arch Minerals was a normal part of his job. "It was a paperwork violation and somebody wanted to make trouble for somebody else," he said. "I intervened. Does the title director indicate anything?"
Here, on the ridges overlooking the Sequatchie Valley 125 miles southwest of Knoxville, Tenn., it is easy to find streams the color of dried blood, the result of iron seeping from operating and abandoned strip mines. Moreover, the water is so acidic from sulfur, manganese, aluminum and other heavy metals seeping from the mines that fish cannot survive and stream banks are scoured clean of plants.
"The animals won't drink it; not even the dog will drink out of it," Raymond Brown, a retired 63-year-old mechanic, said as he walked along the edge of Smith Creek, which runs behind his home in Brayton, east of here.
In Kentucky, 90,000 of the 100,000 acres of abandoned mines that awaited cleanup before 1977 have still not been reclaimed, according to state figures.
 
'It's Gotten Worse'
 A study earlier this year of 12 mines in Tennessee by Save Our Cumberland Mountains, an environmental group in Lake City, Tenn., found that eight were causing severe water pollution in violation of the strip-mining law.
"Back in the late 1970's, when the law was first put into effect, I can remember a period when Federal inspectors in the field did what the law required," said Maureen O'Connell, the director of Save Our Cumberland Mountains. "In the last 12 years, this agency has done everything possible to foil its purposes and it's gotten worse in the last year or two."
Federal inspectors said coal operators had learned that regional offices could be bypassed by appealing for help directly to Washington. That is what has occurred at the Skyline Coal Company strip mine near Dunlap, 40 miles northwest of Chattanooga.
Here at Tennessee's largest strip mine, a huge shovel heaves aside tons of rock and earth to lay bare a seam of black coal. But mixed with the discarded material are deposits of sulfur and iron, manganese and aluminum that with moisture form a red acid brew that finds its way into streams and destroys fish and plant life for miles downstream. The Federal strip mining law was meant to eradicate it, but countless mountain streams in the mining regions of West Virginia, Kentucky and Tennessee have been polluted in this way.
Last July, after the streams around the Skyline mine turned red, Federal inspectors from Office of Surface Mining's Knoxville office ordered the mine closed until the company came up with a plan to stop the pollution. The stop-work order, one of the strongest penalties available to Federal officials, followed more than two years of effort by the Knoxville office to compel Skyline to deal with the problem.
Under the strip-mining law, when a stop-work order is issued the company must either eliminate the problem or seek temporary relief from a Federal judge before resuming operation. Such relief can be granted, though, only if the company can prove that continuing to mine will not harm the environment.
But three days after the stop-work order was issued, say mine inspectors here, Skyline was back in business without having taken either step. Federal officials in Knoxville were directed by their superiors in Washington to lift the order, an action that meant Skyline and its 60 employees could continue mining more than 1,400 tons of coal, valued at more than $38,000, a day.
 
Questions on Agreement
 The mechanism used to lift the stop-work order was a one-of-a kind agreement prepared by lawyers for the Government and and Skyline and which they named "interim temporary relief." Experts on strip-mining law in and out of the Government said there was no such thing as "interim temporary relief" either in the Federal strip mining law or its regulations.
"Let's put it this way," said George C. Miller, the director of the Knoxville office. "I have serious questions about its legality."
Mr. Snyder said in an interview that he had nothing to do with the effort to help Skyline resume mining. "I didn't even know about it," he said. "If they tell you otherwise, I challenge them to prove it."
But Kevin Feeney, a spokesman for Skyline's parent company, Amax Coal Industries of Indianapolis, the nation's third largest coal company, said the company had alerted Mr. Snyder of its troubles in Tennessee through the National Coal Association, the industry's Washington-based lobbying group.
And Mr. Snyder's chief of staff, Tom Williams, said in an interview that he was in the room last summer when James Hemphill, one of the Interior Department's top lawyers (who died of a heart attack in September) discussed the Skyline case with Mr. Snyder and asked for guidance. "Hemphill called Harry," said Mr. Williams. "He asked Harry about specifics about Skyline. Harry told Jim to do what's right."

HEADLINE: A Familiar Tone in Race To Lead South Korea

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 21

 BODY:
The campaign officially began today for the dissident who went mainstream, the dissident who remains on the outside and the tycoon turned politician in what is shaping up as a heated presidential race and a test of democracy.
To the victor will go the task of reviving South Korea's push to become an industrial powerhouse and, perhaps, of presiding over a reunification with North Korea. 
 The election, set for Dec. 18, is the second presidential vote since South Korea shook off military rule in 1987, but to some analysts, this vote represents the first truly democratic transfer of power.
 
Moving Away From Military
 The winner in 1987, Roh Tae Woo, had been a general and a close associate of his predecessor, Chun Doo Hwan, the military ruler. This time, none of the candidates has a military background.
The race is expected to be a close battle between two of the candidates: Kim Young Sam, 65, the moderate candidate of the majority Democratic Liberal Party, and Kim Dae Jung, 67, a firebrand who heads the opposition Democratic Party.
Polls have shown Kim Young Sam to be slightly ahead, with at least 30 percent of respondents undecided.
A third candidate, Chung Ju Yung of the United People's Party, a wealthy industrialist, is often likened to Ross Perot. Mr. Chung, 77, who founded the huge Hyundai conglomerate, is considered to have little chance of winning, but attracts voters fed up with professional politicians and could influence the outcome by taking votes from the frontrunners. There are several minor candidates as well.
Mr. Roh will not be running because the Constitution limits candidates to one five-year term.
Kim Young Sam and Kim Dae Jung were both longtime opponents of the military rule. But, unable to put aside personal rivalries, they both ran as opposition candidates in 1987, splitting the vote and allowing Mr. Roh to win.
In 1990, Kim Young Sam merged his party with that of President Roh, creating the Democratic Liberal Party and positioning himself to become the mainstream candidate.
 
Campaign Season Opens
 The official 28-day campaign period began with candidate registration on Friday. Today the three major candidates held their first outdoor rallies in cities near Seoul, attracting thousands of cheering and chanting supporters.
Besides featuring a billionaire businessman, the Korean race is similar to the recent American one in that the economy and other domestic concerns are the main issues.
Indeed, President Roh is sometimes compared to George Bush. Critics say he made major foreign policy achievements, such as establishing relations with China and the Soviet Union, while neglecting domestic issues.
The concentration on the economy might be surprising in that South Korea's is growing at an enviable rate of 6 percent a year and its unemployment rate is low.
Still, the growth rate is lower than the 10 percent that used to be common, a trade surplus has turned into a trade deficit and inflation has been at 10 percent until this year, when it moderated somewhat. Those problems, combined with a feeling that the traditional work ethic is ebbing, has set off a period of hand-wringing.
"Korea, once touted as a role model of the newly industrializing countries, is on the verge of downfall due to economic stagnation, rampant corruption and the collapse of traditional value and authority," Kim Young Sam said at a press conference on Friday, according to a translation by The Korea Times. "Excessive spending, extravagance and decadence now sweep our society, and people are gripped in frustration and defeatism."
 
Vague or Repetitive
 All three candidates have economic policies that are either vague or similar, with linchpins like stimulating small business and gradually deregulating the financial system.
Indeed, observers say, it is hard to clearly separate the candidates along policy lines. The candidates all favor a continued United States military presence, but all also want to see reunification with North Korea.
"People are voting not for issues but for the personalities," said Yang Sung Chul, a professor of political science at Kyunghee University. Voters also pay extraordinary attention here to where a candidate is from, he said.
As the majority party's candidate, Kim Young Sam tends to appeal to those who want stability. He has had trouble, however, holding his merged party together, and many politicians have left to support Mr. Chung or other candidates.
Kim Dae Jung has more appeal to those who want change. He stresses upholding personal liberties and supports public funding of elections to limit the influence of business on politics. He accuses his rival of selling out to the ruling party.
Almost as important to Korea as the question of who will win the race is whether the election will be honest.
The concern is not with fraud on election day but with the tactics candidates use to influence voters beforehand.
Already, prosecutors have charged about 150 people, some from every party, with violating election laws by campaigning before the official period or by giving voters money or gifts.
 
Mystery Over Disappearance
 To allay fears that the current administration would use its power to influence the election in favor of Kim Young Sam, President Roh resigned from the ruling party in September and appointed a neutral Cabinet. But that has not completely eliminated suspicions on the part of opposition candidates.
Among the events that have tended to keep suspicions inflamed is the temporary disappearance of Kim Bok Dong, a member of the National Assembly and the brother-in-law of President Roh. He was on his way to his hometown of Taegu on Tuesday to announce his departure from the Democratic Liberal Party when plainclothes police officers, acting on a presidential order, stopped Mr. Kim's car, took him out and whisked him back to Seoul, where he was not seen in public for several days.
There followed a press release, purportedly from Mr. Kim, although it was later challenged as a fake his aides, saying that the legislator had changed his mind and would stay with the majority party.
Opposition politicians accused Mr. Roh of meddling in the election by kidnapping Mr. Kim to prevent his defection. The Administration maintained it was merely a family affair.
Late this week, in an effort to quell the controversy, the majority party accepted Mr. Kim's resignation. He joined Mr. Chung's party.
