HEADLINE: The Transition: Political Memo;
New Tune for Clinton: Sounds of Compromise

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
As if trading in the saxophone of the election season for a cello, Bill Clinton seems to be modulating the direct and even brassy oratory of his campaign into a Presidential tune.
As a candidate, Mr. Clinton's task was to distinguish himself as sharply as possible from President Bush. Listening to him this week on his first trip to Washington as President-elect, it was clear that as President, his aim will be to prevent conflict abroad and build consensus at home so he can concentrate on the economy. 
 After meeting with Congressional leaders he played down his campaign demand that Congress slash the size of its staff and that he be given new powers to veto spending, which Congress complains would diminish its authority. He offered to negotiate on his plan to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military in the face of opposition from Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. And after a session on foreign policy in the Oval Office with Mr. Bush, he sounded a less aggressive note about getting tough with China.
John Brummett, editor of The Arkansas Times Magazine, said Mr. Clinton seems to be adapting his style in the Governor's Mansion for the Oval Office.
"He does have a tendency to promise as a candidate and then once elected, suddenly become very realistic," Mr. Brummett said. "It is bravado versus realism, and it is a pretty clear pattern we have seen before. It is just the difference between getting elected and governing."
 
Room for Compromise
 This style has its obvious risks: it could simply reinforce Mr. Clinton's image as a politician who has a tendency to dance around sensitive issues to get the support of all sides. But it could also allow him to stake out a far-reaching position while leaving room for a compromise down the road.
During the campaign, for instance, Mr. Clinton lacerated President Bush for "coddling" the "tyrants" in Beijing and promised he would never do that. On Thursday, when he had to speak about China as President-elect instead of Presidential wannabe, Mr. Clinton chose his words carefully. He repeated his support for human rights, but gave Mr. Bush credit for making progress with Beijing when he got "tough" on the Chinese and said he did not want to "isolate" China, the very formulation Mr. Bush has often used.
Mr. Clinton may have been signaling that he took too absolute a position in this area as he was fighting to get elected and is now using the grace period of his transition to retreat a bit. The last thing he wants during his first days in office, after all, is a fight with China or with Congress over his China policy.
In a similar manner, and perhaps for a similar purpose, Mr. Clinton has lowered his voice about Congress cutting Congressional staffs and cutting middle-class taxes. He is on the record for both, but can push them loudly or quietly depending on what tradeoffs he needs later.
 
Feeling His New Role
 Beyond political calculations, there may be something unconscious going on. The American public is watching as Mr. Clinton absorbs the weighty reality of the office he is about to inherit. When he arrived to meet Mr. Bush at the White House this week, he seemed intent on striking a Presidential stance, rather than giving in to the natural instinct to crane his neck and look around at his new house.
Mr. Clinton spent almost two hours with President Bush in the Oval Office on Thursday. According to a Clinton aide, Mr. Bush gave the President-elect a tour of each problem spot in the world. Mr. Clinton then asked Mr. Bush how he would respond if events spun out of control in each area. It may have been no accident that after this conversation, Mr. Clinton found a softer voice on China.
Similarly, Mr. Clinton began his transition period with a strong statement of his intent to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military. As Democrats in Congress and generals in the Pentagon protested, Mr. Clinton backed off just a bit, saying he still intended to carry out his campaign promise on the issue, but was prepared to discuss it and find common ground. Last week, Mr. Clinton met with General Powell and said wryly that the nation's highest-ranking uniformed officer did not hold back on any subject.
 
A One-Man Polling Operation
 In both cases, Mr. Clinton seems to have been displaying one of his particular managerial traits. Clinton aides during the campaign often complained about his democratic style of decision-making -- how he would ask the opinion of everyone from his top strategists to the flight attendant on his campaign aircraft before making up his mind.
Mr. Brummett said, "Sometimes he is just too prone to agree with the last person he talked with."
Several years ago in Arkansas, the Arkansas legislature was considering a bill granting tax credits for private donations to Arkansas's badly underfinanced colleges and universities. Mr. Clinton was torn between wanting to support higher education and not wanting to drain his budget of tax revenues.
The bill was passed and he had five days to decide whether to veto it. He agonized for five days, consulting with all sides, and on the evening of the fifth day he finally decided to veto the bill, stamping on it in big black letters: "DISAPPROVED."
A Clinton aide was sent over to file the veto with the House clerk and slipped it under the door of her office. Mr. Clinton then and telephoned Arkansas college presidents to explain what he had done. Instead, they persuaded him to change his mind.
So the Governor summoned a state trooper in his security detail and asked him to go back to the clerk's office and retrieve the vetoed bill. The trooper could see through the locked glass door that the bill was lying on the floor. He took a coat hanger, slipped it under the door and slid the bill out. He brought it back to Governor Clinton, who simply crossed out a few letters and sent it back as "APPROVED."
"The most unnerving thing about Clinton," said a long-time friend, "is knowing when he's made a decision. He'll look you in the eye to get your advice and for that moment, it seems like you're the only person in the world whose opinion he cares about. And then a second later, he'll turn to the waiter here and ask him his opinion."

HEADLINE: Kaysone Phomvihan, Communist Who Ruled Laos, Is Dead at 71

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
President Kaysone Phomvihan of Laos, the longtime guerrilla who led the Communist takeover of his nation in 1975 and ruled as its dictator ever since, died yesterday, the Laotian state radio announced. He was 71 years old.
He died of an unspecified illness, said the broadcasts from Vientiane, the Laotian capital. The announcement was monitored in London and Bangkok. 
 The reports gave no indication about a successor to Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan, who led both the Government and the Communist Party. He had been reported ill for some time.
Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan's death could mean a period of uncertainty for Laos, one of the world's most isolated and secretive countries, especially considering his long domination of the country and his role as its nationalist hero.
 
Gave Up Post of Premier
 Last year, under a new Constitution, he gave up the Prime Minister's post to assume the new post of President and remained the party's Secretary General. Gen. Khamtay Siphandon became the Prime Minister, but it is uncertain whether he will succeed Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan.
A spokesman at the Laotian mission to the United Nations said it had just received word of the announcement and therefore had no immediate comment. The State Department said it would have no comment until Monday.
The death of Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan -- a man with Vietnamese links by birth, marriage, language, education and politics -- also raises the issue of what direction Laos will move in its politics, economy and foreign relations.
It shares a long eastern border with Communist Vietnam, which until 1987 stationed tens of thousands of troops in Laos. But Laos also has growing commerce along its equally lengthy western border with Thailand, which has thriving capitalism, a more open society and ties to the West.
To the north sits China. Historically wary of its giant neighbor, Laos relied on the Soviet Union as its prime benefactor until it collapsed. Since then, Laos has been friendlier to China, the world's last major Communist nation. But Laos is also reaching out to Japan, Asia's democratic and capitalist power, and has even courted its old Western foes, France and the United States.
The short, stocky Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan was one of the last of Indochina's old-guard revolutionary leaders from the generation of his Vietnamese comrade, the late Ho Chi Minh.
Credited as both a brilliant political theoretician and a crafty military chief, Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan for years led the rebel struggle from secret mountain caves.
 
Royal Dynasty Falls
 His Pathet Lao forces survived formidable opposition, including carpet bombing by the United States, before eventually toppling the 600-year-old Laotian dynasty in 1975.
Under his leadership, however, Laos remained among the poorest and least developed of countries. The small landlocked nation and its four million people were largely isolated from the outside world. Once known as the the Land of a Million Elephants, Laos had few exports other than timber, hydroelectric power and illicit opium and heroin.
But in the late 1980's, Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan's Government sharply altered the country's ideology. Its controlled economy finally resorted to privatized farming and commerce. Looking abroad, Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan actively sought foreign aid and trade.
Reconciling with old foes, he traveled to France and Japan in 1989, his first trip to non-Communist counties other than Thailand. He also won an $8.7 million grant from the United States for roads, dams, communications, farming, health care and education.
The changes were forced by a combination of continuing stagnation in the local economy, the collapse of international Marxism and the disintegration of the Soviet Union, the longtime backer of Laotian Communism.
Laos's official slogan changed from "socialism" to "prosperity" and the hammer-and-sickle disappeared from the national emblem, replaced by a Buddhist shrine.
Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan's explanation was that Laos was too undeveloped to begin socialism.
 
One-Party Rule Persists
 Despite those changes, political authoritarianism remained. "Our Laotian party does not yet see any need for establishing other political parties," Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan said in 1990.
Born in the southern panhandle province of Savanakhet, Mr. Phomvihan was the son of a Lao peasant mother and a father who was a Vietnamese civil servant for French colonialists.
Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan ( pronounced guy-sohn POHM-vee-hahn) said he became radicalized at the age of 16. Explaining his credo of liberation from outside forces, he once said Laotians "prefer to live a miserable life as masters of their own country than to live a happy life enslaved by foreigners."
While studying law in Hanoi, Vietnam, he was recruited by Ho Chi Minh.
The young student demonstrated against both Japanese World War II occupation and French colonial domination of Southeast Asia. In later years, he jousted politically with China and fought against United States forces, accusing them of imperialist intentions. When France's control of Indochina ended at Dien Bien Phu in 1954, an internal and international struggle for control of Laos ensued.
 
Always the Top Leader
 With Vietnamese training and support, he began organizing rebels in Laos in the 1940's. By the mid-1950's, when he was in his 30's, he became the Defense Minister and Commander in Chief of the Pathet Lao forces and chief of the Laotian Communist Party. As alliances and names of organizations constantly shifted, he held a variety of titles but was always considered the movement's top leader.
Although he was fluent in Thai, Shan, French, English and Vietnamese as well as his native Lao, he was reticent, even secretive. He was not seen in public from 1958 until he took power in 1975. Even then, when a reporter asked if he had a wife, the evasive answer was "Do you?" After that introductory appearance, he disappeared from view again for more than a year.
Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan was married, according to the International Who's Who, which identifies his wife as Thongvin, a Vietnamese. But little else is known about his private life. His secrecy and tight security were not merely personal idiosyncracies. He survived at least three assassination attempts.

HEADLINE: Brazilians Fret Over New Chief's Slow Start

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Almost two months after Brazil's Congress impeached President Fernando Collor de Mello, politicians and the press are expressing concern that his successor is failing to take charge.
Vice President Itamar Franco assumed the powers of the presidency after Mr. Collor was impeached on Oct. 2, and it appears inevitable that Mr. Collor will be convicted in the impeachment trial scheduled to conclude in the Brazilian Senate by Dec. 22, allowing Mr. Franco to serve out the remainder of Mr. Collor's term. 
 But Mr. Franco has made no effort to harness the extraordinary unity with which the Chamber of Deputies voted to oust Mr. Collor. Criticized for not making a single policy speech since assuming presidential powers, he holed up in his hometown last week to care for his ailing mother. On Friday he left on his first overseas trip, to Senegal.
Mr. Franco has promised to reduce his nation's chronic inflation by selling money-losing state companies. But on Thursday he personally suspended the auction of one state company.
"Itamar is sending confusing signals, and signals are important in Brazil," said Roberto Campos, a conservative member of the Chamber of Deputies. "He is a 1950's populist nationalist who is lost in the 1990's."
From the left, Luis Ignacio (Lula) da Silva, president of the Workers Party, charged on Friday that Mr. Franco had proved to be "very vulnerable, vague and very slow."
"I think Itamar's ambiguity could make him very quickly lose the prestige and trust society has deposited in him," Mr. da Silva said.
If Brazilians vote to adopt a parliamentary system in a plebiscite next April, the nation could have a Prime Minister as early as one year from now. Otherwise, the nation will have to wait until the October 1994 presidential elections.
But it is unclear whether Brazilian society will withstand even one more year of ineffective government. In the two and a half years of Mr. Collor's presidency, Brazil's real per capita income dropped by 7 percent. In Sao Paulo, the nation's economic heartland, unemployment doubled to 15.5 percent, or 1.5 million people.
With prices rising about 1,000 percent a year, Brazil is now Latin America's only nation with annual inflation over two digits. "Brazil is at the edge of hyperinflation," warned Norman Gall, an American economist in Sao Paulo. "The situation is far more dangerous than people assume it to be."
Mr. Franco's economic ministers vow to reduce Brazil's inflationary deficit gradually by improving tax collection and by selling state companies.
"We expect that Congress will approve most of the tax reform by the end of December," Planning Minister Paulo Haddad said on Friday, referring to a tax package intended to raise $16 billion by creating new taxes and improving the collection of old taxes. "We are going to sell 12 state companies by March."
The 61-year-old Mr. Franco, who served 16 years in the Senate before becoming Vice President in 1990, describes his Government as "pre-parliamentary" and argues that Congress is responsible for his success or failure.
Mr. Franco, who does not belong to any political party, presides over a Cabinet stitched together with representatives from seven center-left parties. Almost one-third of his Cabinet comes from Congress, but his slow start seems to be eroding his political capital there.
"Itamar is enjoying a period of political grace that will only last until the Senate verdict on Collor," said Jarbas Passarinho, a conservative senator who once was Mr. Collor's congressional liaison.
Mr. Franco's post-impeachment honeymoon with Brazil's press is already ending. Noting Mr. Franco's habit of contradicting his own ministers and his reluctance to assert leadership forcefully, Jornal do Brasil recently wrote, "He seems like an American at a carnival ball."
"He doesn't know the tune," continued the Rio newspaper. "He doesn't understand the lyrics, he doesn't have rhythm, he doesn't know how to dance, and he came without a costume."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 28; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1404 words

HEADLINE: The Transition: Political Memo;
Tiff Over Governor's 'Christian' Remark Underscores Fault Line in G.O.P.

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Despite the sudden skirmish over whether the Republican Party thinks the nation is "Christian" or "Judeo-Christian," this has been a peaceful post-defeat post-mortem, as such things go.
The argument identified unstable political fault lines, potentials for deep, angry divisions. But now most Republicans blame their defeat not on ideological excesses or inadequacies but on a poor economy and a poor campaign by President Bush. 
 Those scapegoats do not arouse the sort of fury that Republicans vented at conservatives after the 1976 election, complaining that they had loafed through the campaign, or that Democrats felt for unenthusiastic liberals in 1980 or too-enthusiastic liberals in 1972.
Indeed, because Mr. Bush has given so many years of his life to his party, there is not even the personal rancor toward him that Democrats directed toward a relative outsider, Michael S. Dukakis, when he lost an election they thought they could win in 1988.
 
The Fordice Flap
 Even so, the short-lived dispute spurred by Gov. Kirk Fordice's demographic and historical concepts is instructive about the state of the Republican Party. When the Mississippian told other Republican Governors in Fontana, Wis., on Tuesday that it was a "simple fact of life" that the United States was a "Christian nation," he stepped into a political minefield.
He was promptly rebuked. First, Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, who has experience that Mr. Fordice lacks in national politics, said Republicans needed to realize it was the "Judeo-Christian heritage" that established the nation's values.
After Mr. Fordice responded tartly that he would have said that if he had meant that, various Jewish organizations and moderate Republicans got angry. So Richard N. Bond, the departing chairman of the Republican National Committee, organized a statement, joined in by his potential successors, to insist on "Judeo-Christian." That is the term used in the party platform, and Mr. Fordice swallowed it, apologizing Friday to Mississippians whom he might have offended.
At one level, the argument deals with how badly the Republicans look to Jewish voters, who this year gave Mr. Bush only 12 percent of their votes, one percentage point more than he got from blacks.
Obviously, there is a potential for significant gains among a chunk of the electorate that matters a lot in several states. Mr. Bush drew 35 percent of Jewish votes in 1988, when his party's convention did not focus on "Christian values" the way the 1992 meeting did.
 
Questions of Openness
 But even more important to Republican operatives is their fear of seeming biased to other voters, who may be generally friendly to the party's ideas but uncomfortable with thinking of themselves as part of a bigoted institution.
And though his name hardly came up in Wisconsin, this dispute was part of a larger Republican concern about the Rev. Pat Robertson and his evangelical followers. Lots of Republicans worry that even though the Robertson forces energize new supporters, the cost of identifying the party with them may repel even more voters and make the party seem fatally narrow-minded.
And while the Christian Coalition, Mr. Robertson's organization, is pleased with hundreds of victories it recorded this year in legislative, councilmanic and school and library board elections across the country, regular Republicans are not. Not only do they often disagree with coalition candidates on issues, they often find that the Christian right's candidates win Republican primaries in light turnouts but then lose to Democrats where more moderate candidates might have won.
As one consultant who refused to be quoted by name put it, many party officials fear Mr. Robertson's influence. "If we limit our party to evangelicals, to people who live straight lives and to people who are pro-life," he said, "we're looking at a steady 33 percent" and steady losses.
Above all, the skirmish was a reminder of the potential for division within the party and a distraction from the economic messages that not only unify Republicans but also win elections.
 
Fears of a Distraction
 Retiring Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota, a leading conservative and anti-abortion voice in the party, says it is typical of Republicans, after disappointments at the polls, to worry about the religious right. "It seems to be the first thing we focus on to explain any defeats," he said.
Mr. Weber argued that while the party had made a mistake in allowing the Republican convention in Houston to present a "narrow, theocratic message," its bigger failure was not campaigning with unifying themes on economic issues and foreign policy. And he said that if voters think a party's real concern is off the economy and on issues like abortion or homosexuals, that party loses.
That sense of the right's issues as a fatal distraction for Republicans can be found across the party's ideological range. Nancy Sinnott Dwight, a moderate consultant in Connecticut who once ran the National Republican Congressional Committee, said she wanted her party to stop fighting about abortion and similar issues. To attract more voters, she said, Republicans "need to be concerned about what they're concerned about: jobs, domestic issues, education."
There are moderates whose view of the religious right's influence, past and future, is much more severe.
Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon said the effort to woo the right over issues like abortion and an equal rights amendment had cost Republicans the chance to become the nation's majority party. He said that the convention tone was of "crabbed, mean-spirited narrowness" and that Republicans should instead understand, quoting Judge Learned Hand, that "the true spirit of liberty is that spirit that's not sure it's right."
John Deardourff, a Republican consultant, said appealing to evangelicals might win some offices in Southern states, as it plainly did in Georgia this year, when Republicans added three House seats. But, he said, "with this perception of the party as far to the right as it is, it's impossible to win major states."
 
The Robertson Factor
 To many Republicans, Mr. Robertson is the center of their problems at both local and national levels. He did poorly when he sought the party's Presidential nomination in 1988. But his followers won control of several state parties last spring and summer, and then dominated the 1992 Republican platform deliberations.
Eddie Mahe, a consultant who was an early advocate of party efforts to enlist evangelical Christian support, argued that Republicans were worrying too much, that it had basically been Mr. Bush and not their party that had been repudiated. And if party members had any cause to fret, he said, they were complaining about the wrong Pat.
Mr. Robertson, he contended, was neither racist nor isolationist, but the really damaging speech at the Republican convention was instead that of Patrick J. Buchanan, with his talk of a "holy war."
These concerns are important because they show both what Republicans might fight about and what they are, so far, restraining themselves about.
It will be hard to maintain that restraint. Abortion is likely to become a significant part of the race to succeed Mr. Bond. The Christian Coalition is bound to worry more and more traditional Republicans. And in California, a critically important state, the odds are that some conservatives will mount a primary challenge against Gov. Pete Wilson in 1994, accusing him of insufficient doctrinal purity.
 
A Wealth of Candidates
 All of these developments are likely to distract the party from concentrating on a clear economic message of less government and lower taxes.
And they will all come before the 1996 Presidential campaign. Even now, it is possible to identify a serious Republican problem, the odd curse of too many strong candidates.
A strong field could produce a prolonged contest. That usually leads to defeat, as emotions harden and arguments narrow, sometimes to the point where the ordinary voter wonders why grown men and women would argue about such questions.
In particular, says Professor Marty Wattenberg of the University of California at Irvine, Republicans have to fear having candidates who can raise enough money to survive early defeats. He calls them "Timex candidates, who take a licking and keep on ticking."

HEADLINE: Ripples of a Pathologist's Misconduct In Graves and Courts of West Texas

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
he prairie graveyards of West Texas are giving mute testimony to the misdeeds of a circuit-riding pathologist who left a trail of faked autopsies, botched blood samples and missing organs from the Panhandle to the Rio Grande.
According to defense lawyers' estimates, as many as 20 capital murder cases and dozens of other prosecutions will be appealed because of accusations that crucial evidence was ghoulishly or criminally mishandled in autopsies performed by the pathologist, Dr. Ralph R. Erdmann, who worked as a contract medical examiner in more than 40 rural Texas counties since the early 1980's. 
 As evidence of Dr. Erdmann's malfeasance piles up, a fracas has broken out over defense lawyers' accusations that prosecutors sanctioned his practices to win cases and are now trying to cover it up.
On Sept. 21 Dr. Erdmann, 65 years old, pleaded no contest to seven felony counts involving falsified autopsies in Lubbock, Hockley and Dickens counties. Under plea agreements he was sentenced to 10 years of probation and 200 hours of community service and was ordered to pay two counties nearly $17,000 in restitution for autopsy fees and costs of exhumations, medical re-examinations and reburials.
Dr. Erdmann, who surrendered his medical license in August, after his indictment, still faces criminal investigations, lawsuits and demands for testimony in many other cases.
"The botched autopsies he's been indicted on so far are just a small sample," said Tommy Turner, the special prosecutor in a Lubbock court of inquiry that investigated Dr. Erdmann last summer.
 
'This Guy Was a Liar'
 Mr. Turner said a fairly quick and narrow examination of Dr. Erdmann's work turned up evidence of about 100 faked autopsies.
"We started digging up bodies," Mr. Turner said, "and when we were seven for seven we decided that in the interests of judicial economy we didn't have to go further to prove that this guy was a liar."
Don Hurley, a Lubbock lawyer who is appealing a murder case in which he said Dr. Erdmann falsified a toxicology report, said, "I believe as I believe that the sun will come up tomorrow that there was a conspiracy between the prosecution and Erdmann to say whatever was necessary to get a conviction, and I don't have any doubt that there is a cover-up now."
 
Prosecutors Deny Guilt
 Prosecutors have angrily denied such accusations. Even though the Randall County District Attorney, Randy Sherrod, said, "I wouldn't use Erdmann again, ever, based on what I know now," he insisted, "I never saw an autopsy by Erdmann that was not correct on the basis of other evidence."
Repeated attempts over four days to reach Dr. Erdmann at his home in Lubbock were unsuccessful.
When a person dies during a crime or under questionable circumstances, law-enforcement authorities routinely order an autopsy by a medical specialist. In criminal cases an autopsy is often presented as evidence by the prosecution and the examiner is called to testify as an expert witness.
In many cities the autopsies are performed by medical examiners or coroners who are full-time government employees, but jurisdictions in rural areas contract with pathologists for such services. Lubbock County paid Dr. Erdmann more than $140,000 a year under such a contract, and he collected as much as $600 per autopsy elsewhere.
Dr. Erdmann, who claimed to have a medical degree from a university in his home country of Mexico, performed as many as 400 autopsies a year in West Texas. His practice consisted basically of his contract work doing autopsies, and, all the while he worked in close collaboration with many prosecutors and police officials, some of whom are now prominent in politics.
Defense lawyers say their suspicions of falsified autopsies and a cover-up have been heightened by the way law-enforcement authorities reacted to the initial accusations against Dr. Erdmann.
Prosecutors in Lubbock learned on Feb. 14 that the doctor was about to be indicted in a neighboring county, said Steve Holmes, chief administrator of the Lubbock District Attorney's office, but they did not open their own investigation into his activities in their own county until April 3. County officials explained that they had had no complaints of criminal wrongdoing by him in their jurisdiction, but defense lawyers dispute that.
 
Talk of 'Fantasies'
 In a review of criminal cases involving Dr. Erdmann's autopsies, independent pathologists concurred with Dr. Erdmann's findings every time, Mr. Holmes said. But he could not say how many cases had been reviewed.
"There are clear indications," Mr. Turner said, "that a number of people in law enforcement considered him weird and questioned his competence because he regularly messed up evidence and he did strange things like handing people organs to hold. But no one blew the whistle."
Dr. Erdmann's dealings with the authorities were not within the scope of the special inquiry last summer, but the prosecutor, Mr. Turner, said, "From what I learned about the man, it seemed Erdmann had fantasies aggrandizing his role in law enforcement to the point that he may have shaded things to follow along with the police theory of a case."
As an example, Mr. Turner noted the case of Craig Newman, which led to the indictment of Dr. Erdmann last February.
When Dr. Erdmann arrived to perform an autopsy of Mr. Newman, a 41-year-old Levelland man found dead in his home, Mr. Turner said, a police officer made a casual remark speculating that drugs were involved. When the autopsy later stated that Mr. Newman died of a cocaine overdose, his family was incensed, insisting he never used drugs.
Then, one family member noted that the autopsy listed the spleen as ane internal organ that had been examined and weighed, although Mr. Newman's spleen had been removed years earlier.
Mr. Newman's body was exhumed, but no autopsy incision marks were found on it. Another autopsy was then performed and showed that Mr. Newman had died of a heart attack.
 
New Turn for a Trial
 District Attorney Sherrod, who used Dr. Erdmann in dozens of criminal cases in his Panhandle county over many years, described the doctor as "a weird kook" and acknowledged that Dr. Erdmann exaggerated his qualifications, for example by falsely claiming to be an expert on ballistics. As a trial witness "he'd confuse left with right," Mr. Sherrod said, "and say 'up' when he meant 'down' because he wouldn't prepare for trials."
In the past weeks, defense lawyers have transformed a seemingly straightforward murder being prosecuted by Mr. Sherrod in Canyon into a test case for the accusations that Dr. Erdmann's incompetence was tolerated or even abetted by prosecutors and the police.
In the Canyon case, Douglas Palmer, 19, is charged with capital murder in the beating death of an elderly man during a botched burglary. His lawyers argue that Mr. Palmer should not be on trial for capital murder because he never intended to kill the man. But the facts of the case have almost been forgotten as the pretrial hearing has become a battleground over Dr. Erdmann, whose autopsy supported the prosecution's case.
Mr. Sherrod has opened grand jury proceedings against Dr. Erdmann for falsifying tissue samples in the Palmer case, but he insists the findings of the autopsy of Mr. Palmer's victim are correct.
Two lawyers nationally known for their work in fighting death penalty cases, Millard Farmer of Atlanta and Steven Losch of New York, joined Mr. Palmer's defense team and have used the pre-trial hearing to explore Dr. Erdmann's career, issuing subpoenas to more than 50 law-enforcement officials to testify about their relations with him.
That has sparked a storm of motions, charges and counter-charges that is still going on.
So far, two police officers have testified in support of the charges of prosecutorial misconduct. Both have since been indicted for perjury, one for his testimony on Dr. Erdmann and the other in an unrelated case.
Last month, Mr. Farmer was indicted on a charge of tampering with a witness -- in this case threatening Dr. Erdmann to get favorable testimony out of him.
Defense lawyers say all of the indictments are a vindictive effort to derail the investigation of Dr. Erdmann's relations with law enforcement. Prosecutors argue, however, that they are defending the legal system from maliciously overeager lawyers.
All of this has simply excited the defense bar's appetite for appealing almost any case that Dr. Erdmann touched.
"The state is either going to have to make great deals with prisoners or it's going to have to be digging up a whole lot of bodies," said Rod Hobson Jr., president of the Lubbock Criminal Defense Lawyers Association."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Ralph R. Erdmann, center, who has been accused of malfeasance in autopsies in as many as 20 capital murder cases while working as a contract medical examiner in rural Texas. He was led to court to testify recently about his autopsy of a 72-year-old man who had been beaten to death. (David Bowser for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Transition: Reporter's Notebook;
Shaping Nation From Little Rock Cafe

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 21

 BODY:
Anyone who doubts that a power dinner could be held in this riverside capital about 1,100 miles from the Potomac should have been at Cafe Saint Moritz on Friday evening.
Barely noticed in a dimly lighted dining room as they shared a modest bottle of Clos du Bois chardonnay were two of the most influential figures on President-elect Bill Clinton's team working to assemble a new government: Warren M. Christopher, director of the transition, and Eli Segal, the chief financial officer. 
 After Mr. Christopher finished the blackfish and Mr. Segal had the chicken and linguine, they paid the tab (embarrassingly small by Washington standards, $39.61), and slipped out as quietly as they came, leaving no clues as to who might be named the Secretary of Anything. Flies on the Little Rock walls never had it so good.
Such is life in and around the transition these days: decisions are being made, but the power is so closely held that even most people on the transition staff are buzzing with uninformed speculation as to what those decisions are.
Historians call it the gradual transfer of power. Perhaps more precisely, Bruce Reed, the transition's deputy for domestic policy, calls it "the adjustment from the campaign to reality."
 
How to Address the Boss

It is a time of awkward limbo for Mr. Clinton and his advisers, let alone the country itself. Mr. Clinton may not be a candidate anymore, but he is not the President quite yet either. In fact, he is still Governor. So everyone who is part of the Government-in-wait here seems to be having a hard time figuring out just how to behave.
Betsey Wright, a longtime aide to Mr. Clinton who is director of public outreach for the transition, is even struggling over how to refer to her boss. "I called him Bill but now I realize I need to change that," she said. "I don't know if you're supposed to refer to him as 'the President' or what. Right now, I just say 'he.' "
Ms. Wright is not alone. Reporters who have covered Mr. Clinton for months are now finding themselves tossing in a respectful "sir" as they question him at news conferences.
As they wander about this town, only one thing sets the powers-to-be apart from the wannabes: handwritten name tags that identify them as members of the transition. The stickers are less official looking even than the ones aides wore during the campaign, but they allow staff members to glide past the tight security on the fourth and fifth floors of the Atkins building here, the antiseptic home of the transition office.
The few outsiders who are allowed entry can immediately spot a big change from the campaign: the same people who for nearly a year never dared put on a tie or a dress are now outfitted like stockbrokers.
"People look different and they act a little different," said Jeff Eller, a press aide in the transition. "It's a nice time to talk and dream. What happens is another matter."
Though many staff members are nervous about what jobs they will get in the new Administration, or whether they will get any job at all, there is a perceptible calmness to the transition that is far different from the chaotic atmosphere of the campaign.
One transition official said the best way to describe the difference is to compare Mr. Christopher, a sober-minded, dark-suited elder statesman of the party, with James Carville, the campaign's fidgety chief strategist who favored T-shirts, jeans and outbursts. "Imagine the difference," he said, "between having a wild Cajun being your boss and Warren Christopher."
 
From Campaign to Reality
 Perhaps the biggest adjustment for Mr. Clinton is that every word he utters, every move he publicly makes, takes on unfathomed new significance, particularly since there is a vacuum of real news out of the transition. Why else would the First Kitty To Be, Socks, have made it onto the front page of newspapers across America?
Today, Clinton watchers here were wondering why the next Chief Executive played golf on a dreary drizzling day (he lost two balls in the fog). What does that portend for how he will use his leisure time? Will Mr. Clinton follow President Bush's lead and play aerobic golf, rushing from hole to hole?
Mr. Clinton stirred the most controversy since the election in a seemingly offhand comment to a reporter about protecting homosexuals in the military, something he had pledged to do many times during the campaign. His remark set off a firestorm that shows no sign of subsiding. One Clinton adviser likened the issue to the Clinton draft controversy during the campaign: it just will not go away.
"We learned from that that anything the President-elect says is news, even if it isn't new," Mr. Reed said. "Every action is no longer conditional. We're no longer in the business of managing expectations; we have to bring about results."
After holding hundreds of news conferences as a candidate, Mr. Clinton's first one as President-elect was scrutinized for both style and substance, as if he had never spoken to reporters before. It is as if he did not mean what he said when he was a mere candidate.
As important to people as what Mr. Clinton says is what he does not say. After he fielded questions during a news conference about Haiti and Korea, the transition office's switchboard lit up with calls from people representing other nationalities: Why didn't the next President mention them?
When Mr. Clinton addressed campaign finance legislation but did not specifically mention curbing the use of so-called "soft money" by the political parties, that left some interest groups buzzing. And whenever Mr. Clinton neglects to mention a middle-class tax cut as part of his economic package, that sets off another round of speculation.
The President-elect's advisers are also hanging on his every public utterance. Grousing that all the deals are being cut at "The Mansion" and that their access to Mr. Clinton has been limited of late, many aides are seeking other sources of guidance on drafting legislative proposals.
To that end, probably the most popular reading among the transition staff is "Putting People First," the compendium of campaign promises by Mr. Clinton and Vice President-elect Al Gore. And several aides said they were relieved at the President-elect's first post-election news conference when he reeled off his initial priorities.
Transition officials said they are well aware how even their comments carry new weight. "We sat and talked about it -- how life was going to be very different," Mr. Eller said. Choosing his words carefully, he went on, "What you say can have an impact on the economy of a foreign country or the stock market."
 
Dissension in the Ranks
 It was bound to happen sooner or later, even as Clinton aides are still giddy over victory: rumblings of dissension in the ranks.
While no one dares register a complaint for the record, several Clinton aides admit that they were not altogether pleased that at a time when populous symbols could not be more important, Mr. Clinton attended a Washington dinner hosted by Pamela Harriman, probably the most elite of the elite Democratic fund raisers.
Asked about the dinner, several Clinton aides rolled their eyes, and some did not even try to defend their boss. Seeking to put the best face on the dinner, one aide said he could only hope that the dinner was not a sign of things to come.
"I wouldn't want official Washington to be lulled into a false sense of security," he said. "Anyone who thinks that Bill Clinton is going to be co-opted is pretty naive." But the aide was not confident enough to be quoted by name on the matter.

"People look different and they act a little different," said Jeff Eller, a press aide. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Once-Soviet Jews Again Find Their Way to Israel

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21

 BODY:
After hitting a low point last spring, immigration from former Soviet territory to Israel has gained new life, bolstered by a spurt of arrivals from troubled regions and the predominantly Muslim states of Central Asia.
The numbers are far from what they were two years ago, when the present wave of immigration reached a peak and 15,000 to 20,000 arrivals a month were routine. 
 But since spring, and then gathering momentum after the advent of a Labor-led Government in mid-July, each monthly immigrant total from the former Soviet Union has been higher than that of the previous month.
In May, there were 3,361 newcomers, the lowest figure since this wave got rolling in 1989. It climbed to 6,832 in October, and Israeli officials say it should end up at least that high in November, remaining consistently in the monthly range of 8,000 to 10,000 through 1993.
 
100,000 a Year
 The projections translate into 100,000 or so new arrivals a year. If these forecasts hold up, the raw figures will continue to be unusually high by historical standards and, for this country of five million, would be the equivalent of five million immigrants to the United States. Actual legal immigration to the United States was 1.8 million in 1991, the latest year for which official figures are available, and the number of illegal immigrants is unknown.
As in the past, most of the immigrants are Russian and Ukrainian Jews. But a rising number -- about 2,900 in October, more than 40 percent of the total -- come from strife-torn areas like Georgia and Tajikistan or from basically tranquil Islamic republics where nationalism and religious fundamentalism have made inroads.
It is thus far not so much a problem of rampant anti-Semitism and violence, although there have been incidents like graveyard desecrations, said Simcha Dinitz, chairman of the Jewish Agency, the quasi-governmental body that oversees immigration to Israel. Rather, he said, it is a historical fear that aggressive anti-Semitism will not lag far behind if wobbly post-Communist structures tumble.
"We have many signs of growing anti-Semitic sentiments being expressed both in the Asian and European parts of the former Soviet Union," Mr. Dinitz said in an interview.
 
Burden and Blessing
 The Russians, as the newcomers are generally called here regardless of their origin, are both a burden and a blessing for more established Israelis -- a burden because tending to them is expensive, a blessing because heavy immigration is the only way that the country's Jewish majority has avoided losing ground to a faster-growing Muslim minority.
About 400,000 immigrants have arrived from former Soviet territory since the start of 1989, accounting now for 10 percent of the Jewish population and, when combined with earlier Russian arrivals, forming the largest single group by area of origin.
Given the large percentage of scientists, musicians and physicians among the new arrivals, they are widely viewed here as raw material for a future cultural flourishing. But Israel has not been able to generate enough work for all the arriving violinists and engineers.
It was in part because of the high unemployment rate here -- over 10 percent for all Israelis and over 30 percent for new immigrants -- that tens of thousands of Russians holding exit visas decided earlier this year that they were better off staying put for a while.
 
Two Factors Cited
 Mr. Dinitz and his agency's chief of immigration, Uri Gordon, say Labor's rise to power last summer may help explain why the monthly arrival totals have started to climb back up again -- that and the Bush Administration's decision to reward the new Government with $10 billion in United States loan guarantees to stimulate the economy.
"The expectations of this Government, in the peace process and other areas, are very high," said Mr. Gordon.
But Mr. Dinitz, a leading Labor Party figure, acknowledges that Government promises still exist largely on paper and that hoped-for economic breakthroughs have yet to occur. A more likely reason for the increased immigration, he says, is a worsening situation in Russia and other states, including rumors of possible coups and concern about the firmness of President Boris N. Yeltsin's grip on power.
Once arrived, many newcomers say work is their main worry. Housing, once a serious problem, is no longer a dominant issue, although thousands of Russians still live in shabby apartments and cheek-to-jowl trailers in Beersheva and Ashdod.
 
Businesses Started
 Nor is the situation entirely bleak even in regard to jobs and business opportunities. Yuri Shtern, who is in charge of immigrant issues for the Federation of Israeli Chambers of Commerce, says Russians have begun between 2,000 and 4,000 new businesses in the last two years, each employing an average of three workers, usually fellow Russians. As for unemployment, it is most conspicuous among older people and the most recent arrivals. The Finance Ministry says that after two years here, 90 percent of the men and 85 percent of the women have found work.
But immigrants say the figures are misleading because at least two-thirds who are working have failed to find jobs in their professions, especially the nearly 10,000 physicians among them.
Alex Berkowitz, 29 years old, was a veterinarian in Ukraine. After a year and a half in this country, he makes car windows on a kibbutz near Jerusalem. "I want to work in my field, but there's nothing for me in it here," he said. "You need pull and a lot of luck."
It is the same for Marina Buger, 40, who came from Moscow last year and could not find a job as a construction engineer. She is a cleaning woman now.
"Israelis ask us how we are, and now we say, 'O.K., O.K.," Mrs. Buger said. "But it isn't O.K. They tell us to have patience, that it will be all right. But they don't understand that there is no time for patience."
 
Employment Is Paramount
 For Russians, employment means almost everything, says Dr. Jacob Schultz, a psychiatrist who directs psychological services for the Soviet Jewry Zionist Forum, an advocacy group for immigrants.
"Work was one of the greatest values in the Soviet Union," he said. "How else could a Jew prove his worth? Suddenly, here, in their own country, they lose it, and so they lose a major part of their identity. There is a feeling of helplessness."
Thus far, Dr. Schultz and others say, the unhappiness has been mostly internalized. The number of recent arrivals who have given up on Israel and moved elsewhere is low -- below 5 percent, according to Mr. Dinitz.
Now and then, there is a news report about aberrant behavior, like the Russian father who killed his daughter. More than a few Russian women have become prostitutes.
 
'Depression Is Inside'
 But these extreme forms of trouble are the exceptions. "The depression is inside," said Mussya Greis, an economist with the Zionist Forum.
Israeli officials insist that they are well aware of the need for swift action. One idea, Mr. Dinitz says, is to encourage increased immigration by teen-agers, and he says his agency has identified 10,000 youngsters in the former Soviet Union whose parents are ready to let them come here while they themselves stay behind.
Teen-agers can be expensive because they require schooling and shelter, Mr. Dinitz said. But among other benefits, they relieve the immediate burden of providing jobs.
"When they will finally enter the work force," he said, "they will be full-fledged Israelis, trained here and speaking the language. In the long run, that may be the best kind of immigration for us."

(Nitsan Shorer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 2 Top Iraqis to Ask U.N. Again to End Economic Sanctions

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Iraq's Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahhaf, and the Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, plan to appeal to the Security Council on Monday that it end the economic sanctions imposed on Iraq after the invasion of Kuwait in August 1990, Western diplomats said today.
But the diplomats said the officials would probably be rebuffed. 
 In a letter to the president of the Security Council released today, Mr. Sahhaf said his Government "firmly believes that it has fully discharged the substantive obligations" imposed by the Council for lifting the sanctions. "It is incumbent on the Council," he said, "to begin to lift the embargo and all the exceptional measures imposed on Iraq."
Among those measures was the demand that Iraq accept and assist United Nations specialists in dismantling its remaining weapons of mass destruction and the means for producing them. Almost two years later, United Nations weapons specialists contend that Iraq continues to thwart their efforts to find and destroy nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and conventional long-range missiles, and the programs that develop them.
Rolf Ekeus, chairman of the United Nations commission in charge of effort, said last week that Iraq continued to ignore requests for a list of foreign suppliers of expertise and materiel for its nuclear program.
Mr. Ekeus and Hans Blix, director of the International Atomic Energy Agency, are also scheduled to address the Security Council on Monday.
United Nations officials have also complained frequently about Iraq's lack of cooperation in efforts to bring humanitarian aid to the Kurds in northern Iraq and to the Shiite Muslims in the south.
Although the Security Council regularly reviews Iraq's compliance with the cease-fire, diplomats here suggested that this particular visit by two high-level Iraqis was timed to attract the attention of the new Democratic Administration in Washington. They noted that before leaving Baghdad, Mr. Aziz told the Iraqi news agency that the Security Council had acted against Iraq "under the pressure of the Bush Administration" and that he hoped the situation would improve after President-elect Bill Clinton takes office.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Will Impose Longer Factory Shifts

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 21

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. said Friday that it would begin scheduling its factory workers to 10- and 12-hour shifts on an involuntary basis.
The move, putting many employees on workweeks of three or four days, whether or not they prefer it, imposes the last batch of terms in a contract offer that had caused an unsuccessful 163-day strike. 
 Caterpillar, the world's largest manufacturer of earth-moving equipment, defeated the strike in April by threatening to hire replacement workers. It then immediately began operating under some terms of the rejected contract. Its latest changes will also increase employee pensions and alter the nature of the company's profit-sharing program. They take effect on Dec. 1.
"We need to move ahead with business," Gerald Flaherty, the company's president, said Friday in announcing the changes.
Officials of the United Automobile Workers, which waged the strike that was brought to its knees last spring, said the scheduling of longer, involuntary shifts was "further evidence of top management's blatant antiworker, union-busting agenda."
Caterpillar, based here in Peoria has long wanted the flexibility to schedule factory workers to four 10-hour days a week or three 12-hour days. The company will now have that flexibility in plants where production schedules demand round-the-clock operation.
And, in a departure from the terms of the company's old contract with the U.A.W., there will be no premium pay for employees who are scheduled to work on weekends or holidays. "But overtime will be paid for extra hours worked," said Jerry Brust, Caterpillar's labor relations director.
The U.A.W.'s international secretary-treasurer, Bill Casstevens, responded to the changes by issuing a statement that said the involuntary flexible schedules would disrupt workers' lives and take away "long-established economic rights to overtime pay" for weekend and holiday work.
"Caterpillar has turned into a many-legged monster that keeps dropping shoes that trample workers," the statement said.
The end of the union's strike came last spring through an accord worked out with Federal mediators. Under its provisions, the union agreed to send its members back to work, and the company, although saying it would impose the terms of its contract proposal, agreed to continue bargaining with the U.A.W. for a new pact. Those negotiations have reached a stalemate, however, and no new talks are scheduled.
The contract provisions put into effect by the company in April included higher wages, a six-year moratorium on plant closings and improved pensions. The new changes will again increase pensions, in 1993 and in each of the following two years. They will also scrap the company's old profit-sharing arrangement, so that a given worker's bonus will be tied to the performance of the worker's profit center, or division, and not to the performance of the company as a whole.
Charles Harris, an industry analyst at Oppenheimer & Company in New York, said Caterpillar was now working directly with employees and making the U.A.W. "irrelevant" to the bargaining process.
"The U.A.W. is in the dust," Mr. Harris said. "The U.A.W. has lost control. They're out of it. How do they get back in? Only if people violently disagree with what Caterpillar has put into place."

HEADLINE: Robert S. Jenkins, 71, Recruiting Executive

 BODY:
Robert Spurgeon Jenkins, a retired managing partner and director of Eastman & Beaudine, a New York management recruiting company, died on Thursday in a hospital in Greenville, S.C. He was 71 years old and lived in Salem, S.C.
He died of pneumonia at Greenville Memorial Hospital, said his daughter, Roberta Jenkins Dias. 
 Mr. Jenkins retired from the New York office of Eastman & Beaudine last year after 20 years. He retired to Salem from Darien, Conn.
Born in Wellston, Ohio, he received a bachelor's degree in 1946 from Denison University, and received both a master's degree, in 1949, and a doctorate in economics, in 1951, from Ohio State University.
In 1952, he joined the Ford Motor Company as an economist, and he remained there until his 1965 appointment as senior director-personnel at Trans World Airlines, in New York. After spending five years with T.W.A., Mr. Jenkins founded Jenkins Associates, Management Consulting/Executive Search Firm. In 1971, he joined Eastman & Beaudine.
Mr. Jenkins held posts in numerous civic organizations. He was president of Plymouth Symphony Board in Michigan and an elder of the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Connecticut.
In addition to his daughter, Mr. Jenkins is survived by his wife, Margaret Kennard; three other daughters, Deborah Jenkins of San Francisco, Priscilla Hodgson of Wyckoff, N.J., and Cynthia Bernard of Atlanta; a sister, Caroline Jenkins Martin of Westerville, Ohio; four grandchildren, and two nephews and a niece.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
Badillo Is Considering His 4th Mayoral Race

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

 BODY:
Politics isn't baseball, which may be why, after three strikes since 1969, Herman Badillo says he expects to decide for certain early next year whether to take a fourth swing at the mayoralty of New York.
"Increasingly, a substantial group of people say they will raise money for a campaign because they're concerned about the city going downhill -- especially in terms of jobs," said Mr. Badillo, the former Housing Commissioner, Bronx Borough President, Congressman and Deputy Mayor to Edward I. Koch. 
 "Nobody at City Hall will insist on tough standards," said the 63-year-old ("but I still run marathons") elder statesman of Hispanic politicians. "With Andy Stein, there's nothing forceful. Rudy Giuliani is forceful, but in the wrong way. I can say to a black or Puerto Rican, 'You're doing something wrong,' and nobody's going to call me a racist."
Mr. Badillo figures he would draw enough votes in a Democratic primary to force Mayor David N. Dinkins into a runoff -- and then Mr. Badillo would inherit enough of Council President Andrew J. Stein's support among Jewish voters to win.
"It's plausible," said Mr. Koch, who added that if Mr. Badillo runs he will support him. What about their bitter feud that led to Mr. Badillo's resigning as Mr. Koch's deputy? "He thought he was the mayor," Mr. Koch said. "Now he can be."
 
Revving Up for '93
 It is nearly a year before the next gubernatorial election in New Jersey and six weeks before any candidate can officially enter the race, but by all indications the political camps have already begun trying to outflank the other.
Cary Edwards, a Republican and former State Attorney General, opened the maneuvering last week, with a mass mailing of videotapes that featured him promoting his ideas on state government. The 20,000 tapes went to executives, campaign contributors and every elected Republican official in the state.
"I hope you will take a few minutes to watch this tape," said an accompanying letter. "If you like what you hear, please join this effort to bring new ideas and new solutions to state government."
In a countermove, one of Mr. Edwards's likely challengers for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, Christine Todd Whitman, announced the formation of a political committee "for the purpose of raising funds to cover the expenses associated with my exploration of running for governor in 1993."
"Though I have not yet made a final decision to become a candidate, the expenses of supporting a staff and exploratory activities necessitates creating this new committee, which will be known as People for Whitman '93," said Ms. Whitman, who came within two percentage points of defeating Senator Bill Bradley in 1990.
Ms. Whitman also announced that she had hired Edward J. Rollins, the political strategist who managed Ronald Reagan's 1984 Presidential campaign, as a consultant.
Mr. Rollins's counterpart in Gov. Jim Florio's campaign is expected to be James Carville, who most recently served as the senior campaign strategist for President-elect Bill Clinton and who for the last year has been an adviser to the Democratic State Committee.
Governor Florio, a Democrat, is expected to run for a second term in 1994, even though he has not announced his intentions.
Ms. Whitman has also hired Hazel F. Gluck, a former State Assemblywoman and Transportation Commissioner with a reputation as one of the toughest campaigners in New Jersey, to manage her day-to-day campaign and to head her exploratory committee.
Although Ms. Whitman has not made a final decision on whether to run, the Democratic State Committee took a pre-emptive strike as though she was a declared gubernatorial candidate, focusing on her choice of Ms. Gluck as an adviser.
"Whitman is trying to make people believe she is an outsider because that is a popular thing to be this year," said the Democratic State Chairman, Raymond J. Lesniak. "In reality, she is the ultimate insider."
 
Take the Bus, Maybe?
 Cash-strapped New Jersey may have to depend on automobile tire retreads to help pull itself out of a budget hole.
The Assembly last week approved and sent to the Senate for a vote a bill that would require the state to purchase retread or remanufactured tires for its fleet of motor vehicles. And like most issues in Trenton, the debate and the vote was heavily partisan.
"I think we're asking for a lot of trouble to save a few bucks," said Assemblyman Thomas Dunn, a Democrat from Elizabeth.
But the bill's Republican sponsors, Assemblyman Robert C. Shinn Jr. of Hainesport and Maureen Ogden of Millburn, defended the idea as not only safe but economically and environmentally sound as well.
"This legislation makes good environmental sense as well as good budget sense," said Mrs. Ogden, who heads the Assembly Environmental Committee. "This legislation will create a market demand for tires that would otherwise become part of the waste stream, contributing to the state's environmental and solid waste problems."
Officials said they have not figured how much money retreads would save.
Some states require retread or remanufactured tires for government-owned heavy trucks. But if the retread bill is approved by the Senate and signed by Gov. Jim Florio, New Jersey would be the only state in the nation to make such purchases required by law for state-owned passenger vehicles, said Robert A. Stuart, a spokesman for the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, which has lobbied for the bill.
The legislation would affect about 7,300 vehicles, but not the cars of the governor and other senior government officials whose vehicles are state-owned but not a part of the fleet.
 
Audit Limbo
 For eight months, legislators in Hartford have been wrangling over two of the sweetest jobs in Connecticut government: the co-auditors of public accounts. The auditors, one Democrat, one Republican, are paid up to $94,000 a year to act as watchdogs over how well state agencies function, and the last two auditors liked the work so much they stayed at their posts for 25 years until their retirements this year.
One major wrinkle has been that under state law, members of the General Assembly cannot even be nominated. But with the passing of the Nov. 3 elections, every Representative and Senator who was elected -- even incumbents -- are now in limbo between being elected and being officially seated.
And last week, one of the jobs fell into that breach. The Democratic legislators' caucus announced that State Senator Kevin P. Johnston, a Democrat from Putnam, and an 18-year veteran in the Legislature, was the party's choice for one job. He will resign his Senate seat so that a special election can be held in time for the start of the legislative session on Jan. 6.
The Republicans, some of whom have sniffed that the Democrats were not respecting the spirit of the law in choosing someone from the Legislature, declined to name their choice, and said they would wait until January to do so.

HEADLINE: A Few More Harsh Words for the Payroll Tax

 BODY:
In "The Payroll Tax Is Getting Out of Hand" (Viewpoints, Nov. 8), Norman Ornstein, a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, discussed shortcomings in the Social Security system. Basically, he wrote, F.I.C.A. taxes earmarked primarily for Social Security and Medicare have become a large burden on working people. The payments are not only a hidden tax, he argued, but a very regressive one. Mr. Ornstein's criticism drew a heavy response from readers. Some of their thoughts and suggestions follow.
 
Pity Poor F.D.R.
To the Editor: 
 Mr. Ornstein is looking at the wrong end of the problem. Better to drop the tail of the beast and face the issue head on.
When the original Social Security law was being drafted, serious consideration was given to requiring employers to pay the entire tax.
President Roosevelt wisely insisted that employees contribute, implying that each worker had a stake in the plan that would be impossible to take away. I think F.D.R. would be appalled at the monster created by Social Security bureaucrats with the obeisance of Congress.
As Mr. Ornstein points out, the whole system will collapse in 25 or 30 years, breaking Mr. Roosevelt's compact with the people and ultimately dividing the country while destroying our freedom.
The program is and always has been a transfer payment wherein workers contribute a portion of their pay to provide benefits to other qualified citizens. The program is not, cannot and never will be funded like annuities.
The maximum benefit should be frozen until the minimum benefit equals the current maximum. The covered salary should be reduced to, say, $50,000 and also frozen until the benefit is level. Furthermore, all of the benefits should be subject to tax when a recipient's income from all other sources is, say, $75,000. All tax revenues realized from benefits should be credited to the Social Security fund. Because liabilities will be reduced -- gradually but significantly -- funding requirements could also be reduced, cutting the payroll tax from the current 15 percent to 12 percent, or even 8 percent.
Ultimately, the entire Social Security entitlement should be taxed away when income from all other sources is, say, $250,000. It is insanity to take money from people who are contributing to our economy and give it to people who don't need it.
 
EDGAR W. SWANSON Jr.
Savannah, Ga., Nov. 9

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Releasing Veterans: Not Just for Economy

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
In 1976, Charlie Finley tried to sell some of his best players to other teams, but Bowie Kuhn, then the commissioner, wouldn't let him, saying the Oakland Athletics' owner was liquidating the team. Sixteen years later, teams are trading some of their best players, some admittedly because the players make too much money.
Is this practice questionable? By shedding star players, are these teams saying they don't care if they win? Should someone step in? 
 "You can't make that judgement until you see what the ultimate makeup of the team is," Donald Fehr, head of the Players Association, said when those questions were posed to him. "Teams go in cycles. There's always a trade or two or three where people wonder what's going on, but it's too early to tell."
Two recent examples of what appear to be fire sales have been the San Diego Padres' trade of Tony Fernandez to the Mets and the Pittsburgh Pirates' trade of Jose Lind to the Kansas City Royals.
 
Lind's Successor Ready
 Joe McIlvaine, the Padres' general manager, has acknowledged that he has instructions to reduce the payroll, and he made the best trade he could for the team's talented shortstop. Ted Simmons, the Pirates' general manager, provided an eloquent explanation for his move with Lind.
Simmons acknowledged that salary arbitration for Lind was one of the factors he considered, but other, equally important elements of the makeup of the Pirates dictated the move. It has nothing to do with a disregard for winning, he added.
"I don't feel that way at all," Simmons said, "because if I didn't have Carlos Garcia, if I didn't have Kevin Young, if I didn't have Albert Martin as young major-league ready, top-notch talent to replace these people, I couldn't do this. This actually is the second year in row for Garcia. He was ready last year. We have to make room for these people."
Simmons compared the Pirates' current circumstances to a time five years ago when they traded Johnny Ray to make room for Lind at second base. "Now, five years later, Carlos Garcia is ready," Simmons said. "He has to get on the field. We're not blowing it out because of money."
Garcia, a 25-year-old shortstop, had the best season of his six-year minor league career. Playing for Class AAA Buffalo, he batted .303, hit 13 home runs, drove in 70 runs and had 21 stolen bases. He will get a chance to play second next season.
Young, 23, will have a chance to win the third base job. Martin, who will be 25 tomorrow, is expected to succeed Barry Bonds in left field.
 
Even Odds on Drabek
 "You've spent $6 million to get these three kids here by developing them through the minors," Simmons said. "You have to make the decision, are they ready or not?"
Rumors have circulated that the Pirates also plan to trade shortstop Jay Bell, but Simmons denied that he has such plans.
"Everybody wants Bell and Garcia," he said. "If I do Bell, it's got to be bowl-me-over time. If I can't sign Bonds and Drabek and I've traded Lind and then if I trade Bell, how am I going to explain that to this town? If you're interested in Bell, you'll have to make it bigger than life."
Simmons said his chance of signing Bonds, on a scale of 1 to 10, was zero. Doug Drabek, he said, is a 5. "I'm hoping it's a five," he added. "I may find out it's a 2."
Last May, the Pirates offered Drabek $20 million for four years, basically meeting his asking price, Simmons said. "He changed his mind, and I understand why," the former catcher added. "I realize how compelling free agency is."
Besides trading Lind last week, Simmons jettisoned five players from this year's team by releasing them -- relief pitchers Bob Patterson, Roger Mason and Vicente Palacios, and outfielders Cecil Espy and Gary Varsho.
Explaining his reason for the wholesale moves, the general manager said: "People think the expansion draft is over. We're halfway through it. Everybody was focusing on the 15-man list. What people are missing is there's a 40-man list."
Clubs had to submit their 40-man major league rosters by midnight Friday. National League clubs had to be particularly careful about the players they left off the 40 because a one-time rule for the two expansion teams will be in effect for the draft of minor league players in two weeks.
The Florida Marlins and the Colorado Rockies will be permitted to draft players from N.L. clubs (at $50,000 each) and, contrary to the regular rule, send them to the minor leagues any time next year without offering them back to the team they had been with.
Each team can select two players in the draft itself, then pick an additional six players each (no more than one from a team) in the 24 hours after the draft. A club could conceivably lose more than one player.
In compiling the roster, General Manager Al Harazin of the Mets said: "You had to be mindful of the fact they had these additional rights. You have to be more conscious of how you shape your list. If you were wavering on a player, you'd err on the side of protecting somebody."
One deterrent to drafting a player under the regular rule is that he must be kept in the majors the entire following season or else be offered back to his former team. The Marlins and the Rockies won't be so restricted.
"Chico Lind is as much related to that as it is to salary arbitration eligibility as it is to Carlos Garcia," Simmons explained. "They're inseparable. All National League teams were going through this. I wanted the expansion draft over so I could begin to think in the tangible or literal context as opposed to nine months of the hypothetical. I knew you'd have only three days to do it."
He released veterans, Simmons said, "not because they were bad players, but I couldn't afford the roster spots. We couldn't afford to risk them and lose a kid."
Roster sizes could change between now and the Dec. 7 draft with trades or signing of free agents, but as of now, Florida has four open spots and Colorado two.
 
The Walt Weiss Mystery
 One of the more curious developments of last week's expansion draft was the trade between Florida and Oakland that sent shortstop Walt Weiss to the Marlins and catcher Eric Helfand back to the Athletics hours after the Marlins drafted Helfand from the A's.
Explaining the trade and its derivation, Sandy Alderson, the Oakland general manager, said it began with the difficult decision of whether the team would protect Weiss from the draft. "We wound up protecting him for a possible role next year and because he was more valuable than giving him up in the draft," Alderson said. "We felt we could sneak through a couple of prospects in the first round."
Alderson also said: "The night before the draft, it became clear we were going to lose someone we valued. We talked with the Marlins about the possibility of trading Weiss for someone they would draft from us in the first round that we would identify. In addition we would like another player they would pick in the third round."
"The whole thing was contingent on the player we identified being taken in the first round," the general manager said. "Had Colorado taken someone else before Florida had had the opportunity, the whole thing would have been off."
Helfand, a 23-year-old catcher, was the player the Athletics wanted the Marlins to draft. The Marlins had planned to take a different Oakland player, but with their ninth pick in the first round they selected Helfand.
"By doing that," Alderson said, "we were able to protect an additional five players without losing one," meaning Helfand and the four players (including two other catchers) the Athletics pulled back after the first round.
Why didn't they just leave Weiss unprotected? "He might not have been the player taken," Alderson said.
 
Ultimate Bonus Baby
 Otis Nixon of Atlanta wound up earning the largest amount in bonuses this year, receiving $2.05 million for being on the Braves' roster at six specified dates during the year. His contract was structured that way because of his drug suspension last year. Other top earners in bonuses were Rick Sutcliffe of Baltimore, $1.2 million ($1.1 million for number of games started, $100,000 for being comeback player of the year); Orel Hershiser of Los Angeles, $1 million (for starts), and Doug Jones of Houston, $1 million ($450,000 for number of games, $350,000 for roster time, $100,000 for being comeback player of the year, $75,000 for second place in the Rolaid relief standings, $25,000 for making the All-Star Game).
With all of the post-season bonuses determined, the major league average salary, based on figures compiled by The New York Times, wound up at $1,014,213, a 19.5 percent increase over last year's $848,499.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2; Column 2; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 292 words

HEADLINE: NOV. 15-21: Referendum Defeat;
Panama's Leader Loses The Expectations Game

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN

 BODY:
Panama's economy is growing rapidly and its people are better off than those in most of Latin America. So how to explain the Government's embarrassing defeat in a constitutional referendum last Sunday? In part it reflects a tradition in which Latin Americans expect presidents to be involved in solving everybody's problems, or at least to talk passionately about them.
With the United States perceived as the father of the laissez-faire presidency of Guillermo Endara, the new Administration in Washington can't ignore his weakened status without seeming to avoid the responsibility tacitly assumed with the 1989 American invasion. 
 Before that, Panamanians were being beaten in the streets in their heroic effort to end 21 years of military rule. Mr. Endara, victorious in the May 1989 elections but prevented from taking office by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, was installed by the United States when it invaded on Dec. 20, 1989. General Noriega was taken to Florida and tried and convicted on drug-trafficking charges.
One of the constitutional amendments put before the voters would have prohibited the rebuilding of a Panamanian military force. But it and 57 other reforms were rejected by a 2-to-1 margin in a vote seen as an expression of dissatisfaction with Mr. Endara.
Aside from a serious crime problem, Panama has adjusted smoothly to an open, democratic society, but the populist military regimes had conditioned Panamanians to the idea that there is a payoff for supporting a government. Today, most people expect more spoils than they are getting from democracy, and are not impressed by the argument of President Endara and his supporters that individual liberty means they have to create their own economic opportunities.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Guillermo Endara (Associated Press)
