SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 358 words

HEADLINE: Inefficient Soviet Economy Halted Cold War;
The Costs at Home

 BODY:
To the Editor:
George F. Kennan (Op-Ed., Oct. 28), one of the major architects of containment, writes with insight of the cold war: "Nobody -- no country, no party, no person -- 'won' the cold war. It was a long and costly political rivalry, fueled on both sides by unreal and exaggerated estimates of the intentions and strength of the other party. It greatly overstrained the economic resources of both countries, leaving both, by the end of the 1980's, confronted with heavy financial, social and, in the case of the Russians, political problems." 
 We are left with "sober re-examination," a doleful price to pay. It seems now one innocent casualty of that war was Alger Hiss. Gen. Dmitri Volkogonov, chairman of the Russian military intelligence archives, declared the allegations against Mr. Hiss "completely groundless."
Unreconstructed cold warriors in this country are unconvinced. According to Mr. Hiss, Whittaker Chambers, his accuser, was a "psychopath" and Richard Nixon, his political prosecutor, an "opportunistic politician." Their careers catapulted, while his plummeted. Chambers, who died in 1961, was awarded the Medal of Freedom by President Ronald Reagan, and Mr. Nixon was President between 1969 and 1974.
Hundreds, perhaps thousands, of American lives and reputations were ruined as a result of the cold war. Everybody else lost in the witchhunt hearings of the House Un-American Activities Committee.
More important, the whole rancid affair caused an American generation to develop grotesque, indelible images of a twisted drama based on a hysteria about some alien ideology called Communism invading their country. Such cold war hysteria only fueled a "mistake" later in Vietnam.
Most of us are puzzled by the rapid demise of the Eastern European bloc. We are left unprepared for the unanswerable questions about the future. A generation in limbo and fear, many of us lost trust in our politicians. Some even felt robbed of their innocent youth to judge for themselves the meanings of hostile beliefs such as socialism.
 
ANATOLI ILYASHOV
Los Angeles, Nov. 4, 1992
 
The writer is a historian.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 6; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Inefficient Soviet Economy Halted Cold War;
U-2 Saved the Peace

 BODY:
To the Editor:
George F. Kennan, in asserting that the U-2 represented the militarization of United States cold war policy (Op-Ed, Oct. 28), ignores that in the late 1950's hard intelligence developed from U-2 flights over the Soviet Union tended to discourage an acceleration of the arms race. U-2 photographs contradicted fears of a bomber and missile gap and convinced American policy makers that the United States enjoyed strategic superiority over the Soviet Union. 
 Thirty years ago, U-2 intelligence warned the Kennedy Administration that the Soviets were building a strategic missile base in Cuba, with far more missiles than even a nuclear tripwire against invasion entailed. Through the use of this evidence, the United States was able to muster international condemnation of Soviet actions and bought the time to respond prudently. Evidence of the missiles' operational status, derived from U-2 photographs and confirmed by other intelligence, convinced the President not to risk an air strike on the island, an option recommended by the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
Thus a crisis that might well have resulted in a hot war in the 1960's was resolved peacefully: the opposite of what one would have expected with Mr. Kennan's thesis about the effect of the U-2 on United States-Soviet relations.
 
TIMOTHY J. NAFTALI
John M. Olin Natl. Security Fellow
Harvard University
Cambridge, Mass., Oct. 28, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 346 words

HEADLINE: Inefficient Soviet Economy Halted Cold War;
What Khrushchev Did

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While I heartily agree with George F. Kennan (Op-Ed, Oct. 28) that "nobody -- no country, no party, no person -- 'won' the cold war," I nevertheless take exception to his revisionist assertion that Nikita S. Khrushchev "offered the greatest hope for international political liberalization and relaxation of international tensions" and that "downing of the U-2, more than anything else, put an end to this hope . . . humiliated Khrushchev and discredited his relatively moderate policies." 
 In 1955 at the Geneva summit, President Eisenhower offered the Soviets an open skies proposal to help overcome the problems engendered by reciprocal fears. This would have brought the relaxation in tensions Mr. Kennan states Khrushchev sought. But the Soviets rebuffed the idea.
Worse, under Khrushchev's leadership, the Soviets engineered a program of strategic deception, designed to exaggerate Soviet nuclear strength: the infamous long-range bomber fly-over that portrayed the Soviets as having twice as many strategic bombers as they did; Khrushchev's false proclamation in 1956 that his country had operational intercontinental ballistic missile capability, which propelled the idea of an impending missile gap; his bluffed threat to use nuclear-tip missiles against Israel, France and Britain during the Suez crisis of 1956; his assertion in 1960 that ballistic missiles had made other forms of warfare obsolete, and his attempt to deploy missiles secretly to Cuba in 1962.
The U-2's overflew the Soviet Union more than four years before the Soviets found means and opportunity to down a plane in 1960. Surely, Khrushchev and his Politburo were not surprised. The incident hardly discredited Khrushchev's "moderate" policies; they weren't moderate. Indeed, Khrushchev seized on the event to embarrass Eisenhower and scuttle the Paris summit meeting that Khrushchev's Berlin threats caused to be convened.
 
DAVID W. TARR
Director, Center for International
Cooperation and Security Studies
University of Wisconsin
Madison, Wis., Nov. 4, 1992

HEADLINE: The House Inflation Built

 BODY:
To the Sports Editor:
Receiving my renewal notice for a Yankees partial season-ticket package, I found that the Yankees are putting an additional squeeze on their fans. Ticket prices have been raised from $14.50 a year ago to $16 for 1993, a $3.50 increase since over 1991. 
 Being able to afford a few games matters greatly to some of baseball's most ardent supporters. Baseball shouldn't be only for the elite, who sparsely fill the corporate boxes. It belongs to the most loyal fans in the right-center field bleachers where a ticket for a seat on a plank now costs $6.50.
I'm not asking Yankee management to feed the world, just to stabilize ticket prices at 1992 rates. In this, the 70th anniversary season of the House that Ruth Built, Yankee Stadium seats should remain affordable for the loyal fans who cheer in good seasons and bad.
 
STUART SHEINMAN
Paramus, N.J.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1290 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Southwestern Bell's Move: Gloom and Glee

BYLINE: By LETTICE STUART

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, TEX.

 BODY:
Two months ago Southwestern Bell Corporation sent spirits flying in San Antonio, spread dejection in the St. Louis area and demonstrated again Mexico's importance to the economy of the Southwest.
The mixed reaction came on the heels of an announcement by Edward E. Whitacre Jr., its chairman, that the $9.3 billion communications giant, which has had a long presence in St. Louis, would move its corporate headquarters and 500 jobs to San Antonio. 
 The decision to move to this city of 955,000 residents was based in large part on San Antonio's close ties with Mexico, where Southwestern Bell has a major investment in the Mexican telephone company.
Mr. Whitacre said the move would also put the company in the midst of its largest customer base. Texas accounts for almost 60 percent of Southwestern Bell's 12 million access lines in a five-state area that embraces Missouri, Oklahoma, Kansas and Arkansas. By the year 2000 the company expects 70 percent of its business to be in Texas.
News of the relocation -- the largest corporate move in San Antonio's history -- has electrified this city's real estate and business communities. Southwestern Bell already has leased a nearly empty downtown office building and the influx of so many home buyers is expected to jump-start the city's long-depressed residential market. The Texas Department of Commerce estimates that the move will have an overall economic impact in Texas of more than $140 million a year.
Mayor Nelson W. Wolff called the news of the relocation the most significant economic development for the city since the opening of the University of Texas Health Science Center in 1968. Southwestern Bell is the 29th-largest company in the nation, according to Forbes Magazine.
"This sends a strong signal to other companies doing business or interested in doing business with Mexico that San Antonio is the place to be," Mayor Wolff said.
San Antonio was chosen over three other Texas cities, Dallas, Fort Worth and Austin, primarily because it is 150 miles from the Mexican border -- closer than the others -- and because of its cultural and historic ties with its southern neighbor.
Known as the Alamo City for its downtown fort besieged and finally overrun by Mexican forces in 1836, it has become a major tourist attraction in recent years. The two-and-a-half-mile Riverwalk winding through downtown on the San Antonio River has a profusion of shops and outdoor restaurants, many of whose customers arrive by barge.
Much of the bilingual city's architecture and many of its shops and restaurants have a distinct Mexican flavor.
Southwestern Bell, along with two partners, Grupo Carso of Mexico and France Telecom, bought controlling interest in Telefonos de Mexico, Mexico's telephone system, in 1990. The consortium plans to spend billions rebuilding the telephone system over the next few years.
Southwestern Bell's 10 percent equity interest in Telmex, bought at a cost of $953 million, already has nearly tripled in value as a result of rises in stock prices, said Julia Kearney, a corporate spokeswoman.
The relocation will begin in December with senior management and continue through April as office space in the company's new headquarters is readied. Ms. Kearney said most of the 500 jobs would be filled by employees transferring from St. Louis. The corporation will pay their moving costs, interim living expenses and closing costs. It also will buy any home in St. Louis that a transferred employee is unable to sell within 60 days, she said.
The new headquarters will be in a 13-story building overlooking the San Antonio River. Bell has leased 250,000 square feet of the 273,000-square-foot structure, which has had only a handful of tenants since its completion in 1985. Most of the space was left unfinished.
International Bank of Commerce of Laredo, Tex., bought the high-rise and an adjacent five-story building for $7.5 million from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation the day before the relocation announcement on Sept. 29. Within 72 hours of the sale, the bank signed a lease with Bell and the occupancy of the complex, renamed I.B.C. Centre, shot from 27 percent to 100 percent.
The lease has had a significant impact on the downtown office market, said Robert W. Hunt, president of Trinity Asset Management, which negotiated the lease for the bank. Half of the available inventory of class A space was taken off the market in one transaction and the occupancy rate of downtown Class A space increased from 74 percent to 87 percent, he said. Class A space downtown totals 1.9 million square feet.
Mr. Hunt predicted that by the end of the second quarter of 1993 occupancy of prime downtown office space would increase to more than 90 percent as companies serving Bell moved downtown and expanded. "Then we'll see a modest increase in rental rates from their current level of $12.75 per square foot a year," he said.
The downtown area is also expected to benefit from the opening of stores and restaurants aimed at attracting business from the new Bell employees, Mr. Hunt said.
Residential real estate agents say the prospect of hundreds of home buyers coming into a market that has more than a year's supply of homes for sale has generated considerable activity. They say they expect Bell employees to buy houses for $125,000 to $300,000.
But Ms. Kearney cautioned against the possible perception that most of the Bell employees transferring from St. Louis would be highly paid executives looking for expensive homes. In fact, she said, only 5 percent are senior management. Most workers will be support staff, many of whom will be renters or first-time home buyers.
In St. Louis, news of the headquarters relocation has cast a pall, even though more than 10,000 Bell employees will remain in the area. The loss of 500 jobs is a blow to the city, which already has been hard hit by major layoffs at other large firms.
Since 1990, McDonnell Douglas has laid off more than 5,000 workers in the St. Louis area because of cutbacks in the defense industry, and thousands of other jobs have been lost at Chrysler, Trans World Airlines, General Dynamics, Citicorp and I.B.M.
The move will empty out one-fourth of Southwestern Bell's million-square-foot headquarters building in downtown St. Louis. The corporation moved into the $120 million One Bell Centre in 1985. The 42-story tower is part of a complex of four buildings totaling 2 million square feet of office space owned by Bell. But, according to Ms. Kearney, the vacant space in One Bell Centre will be filled by Bell employees now scattered throughout 330,000 square feet of downtown office space leased from outside landlords.
R.A. Herrington, senior vice president of CB Commercial Real Estate Group in St. Louis, said that despite a 21.5 percent office vacancy rate downtown, the space Bell will vacate was not of major concern right now.
"There certainly is a feeling of lost prestige in losing a corporate headquarters, but we're more concerned that other divisions of Southwestern Bell will relocate to Texas down the line as leases here expire," Mr. Herrington said. Bell currently occupies 19 percent of the 11.4 million square feet of Class A office space in downtown St. Louis and 5 percent of the 19 million square feet of suburban Class A space, he said.
Sonny Brockman, president of the St. Louis Association of Realtors, said the relocation would not have a dramatic impact on the residential market because the houses to be sold were spread out across the metropolitan area, varied greatly in price and would come on the market over a five-month period, not all at once.
"Nevertheless, we really hate to see them leave," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Southwestern Bell's new headquarters building in San Antonio. (Craig Stafford for The New York Times)

Bell currently occupies 19 percent of the 11.4 million square feet of Class A office space in downtown St. Louis and 5 percent of the 19 million square feet of suburban Class A space, he said.
Sonny Brockman, president of the St. Louis Association of Realtors, said the relocation would not have a dramatic impact on the residential market because the houses to be sold were spread out across the metropolitan area, varied greatly in price and would come on the market over a five-month period, not all at once.
"Nevertheless, we really hate to see them leave," she said.

HEADLINE: Off-Price Stores: Retailing Impetus

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
IT looked as if the store might have been giving something away. The parking lot was so jammed that cars waited outside for spots. Inside, the lines of shoppers at each cash register seemed endless, and the store hummed with activity.
Recession? Slow economy? Not reflected in the activity at some recent store arrivals on Long Island. 
 The crunch was not for a blowout sale, but for a recent opening at T.J. Maxx, a scene repeated at the Price Club, two of the many off-price companies changing the face of retail shopping on Long Island.
The concept of off-price shopping -- selling brand names at 20 to 60 percent less than department and specialty stores -- is taking the Island by storm, as evidenced by the crowds spilling out of stores like Syms, Marshalls, the Home Depot and T.J. Maxx; membership clubs like B. J.'s and the Price Club, and the Island's first outlet mall, which opened this year in Bellport.
Off-price shopping is the only activity keeping the Island's economy alive, said the Suffolk County Planning Director, Arthur Kunz.
With a poor economy and consumers' reluctance to spend, Mr. Kunz said, the time is right for off-price stores.
By off-price, Mr. Kunz was including a growing number of value-oriented membership clubs, warehouse-style stores that sell in large quantities at discount prices.
Price Clubs have been doing very well in high-income areas and draw from middle-class as well as affluent neighborhoods, a spokeswoman for the company, Debbie Greenhill, said. The opening of a Price Club in Westbury last month drew such large crowds that extra police officers were hired to direct traffic.
In the last six months a majority of construction applications on the Island have been for off-price retailers.
The sole applications for traditional retail stores, Mr. Kunz said, have been for an A.&S. store that opened last month at Roosevelt Field, replacing an Alexander's department store, and for a Bloomingdale's in the Walt Whitman Mall, which has experienced delays by the Town of Huntington.
Four construction proposals are pending in Suffolk for warehouse-type stores. In Westbury, on the site of the former Roosevelt Raceway, plans are being made for a 32-acre shopping plaza to include two membership clubs new to Long Island, Sam's Warehouse and Costco.
Shopping trends seem to move in cycles, Mr. Kunz said. In the 50's and 60's discount stores like Korvettes and the Times Square Stores succeeded by catering to young families on the Island, he said. But that disappeared in the 70's and 80's, when consumers looked for better quality and turned to department stores and boutiques.
"The 90's marks the next phase in shopping trends," he added. "With harder economic times, the public wants better goods at off prices. Shopping patterns are changing, and there is more appreciation for discount. This is a trend that's here to stay."
One of the first off-price retailers on the Island was Syms, which opened alongside the Long Island Expressway in 1974. Syms used the phrase "off price" in an advertising campaign, a spokesman for the company, David Bernard, said.
"Shopping off price became so popular that we outgrew our first store in Roslyn and two years ago moved to a much larger space in Westbury," Mr. Bernard said. "The trick is to sell brand names, so the customer can compare. He can see that the regular retail price of the same item at Syms would be 40 to 60 percent higher elsewhere."
After Syms, the first Marshalls opened, in Stony Brook in 1978. There are now 17 Marshalls clothing stores on the Island. The newest opened in Melville in August 1991. A spokeswoman for the company, Hannah Hosom, said Marshalls was successful because consumers had become more educated and looked for good quality at a value.
 
Fewer Family Run Businesses
 Despite the sales-tax revenues generated by the successes of off-price retailers, the Island's economy has felt losses as well as gains, Mr. Kunz said.
"Basically it's a wash," he explained. "While these stores are doing very well, we're losing other retail establishments that can't compete in these kinds of markets. Home Depot has driven out a number of other businesses. Blockbuster Video has put smaller video stores out of business. Ikea has done the same to smaller furniture stores. With the shift to high-volume low-priced shopping, small family run operations will be far less a part of our future."
For downtown shopping, that will mean a growing emphasis on service, Mr. Kunz said, adding: "Changing shopping trends won't put downtowns out of business. Shoppers will still need local drugstores, dry cleaning, restaurants and beauty parlors. The local hardware store will still be important for service, but for bigger purchases the homeowner would be more likely to go to Home Depot."
The economic outlook for the small retailer, said Steve Greenberg, president of the Greenberg Group in Hewlett, is more favorable. The group is a real-estate adviser company to national retailers. Mr. Greenberg said that although it was more difficult for the smaller retailer to compete, there was still room for the small specialty store.
"We're seeing a segmentation in retail," he said. "There are the big-box large retailers, and there are the niche specialists, who will compete by being aggressive and being very good at one little thing. There's not a lot left in the middle. A downtown hardware store may not carry the volume or offer the prices of a Home Depot, but if it can become a specialist in one thing, paint, for example, it has an edge. A small 3,000-square-foot bookstore would have trouble competing with one of 30,000 square feet. But if the small bookstore owner knows his customers by name, as well as their preferences in books, he, too, can compete in today's market."
 
Jaguars and Mercedes at Price Club
 Mr. Greenberg added that although there was still a market for boutiques, a majority of consumers wanted two features, convenience and good prices. "They want to be able to pull up to one store and do all their shopping," he said. "Even the most affluent shoppers are finding it chic to be price sensitive and shop off price, as evidenced by the Jaguars and Mercedes in the parking lots of Price Clubs and other off-price stores."
The membership clubs include a B. J.'s in East Farmingdale and the Price Clubs, in Smithtown, Copiague and Westbury. To shop in a Price Club, customers have to be willing to shop in an unglamorous warehouse environment, Ms. Greenhill said, adding that customers were looking more for value than for status.
T.J. Maxx, a newer off-price addition to the Island, has opened nine stores in the last year. The first two, in Islandia and Oceanside, opened in the fall of 1991, followed by five on the same day last May. The two newest, in Selden and Carle Place, opened two weeks ago.
"The buzzwords for the 90's are off-price, bargains and value," a spokeswoman for the company, Sandy Keating, said. "For T.J. Maxx, coming later to the Island was an advantage, because consumers had a few years to get used to the off-price concept, to understand that they don't have to go to department stores and pay their prices to get value and quality, and to get ready for us.
"There's nothing hidden. Designer labels are not cut out. Consumers can see that the merchandise is the same that would be found in department and specialty stores."
 
Private and Brand Labels
 The difference between off-price and discount stores, Ms. Keating said, is in the relative value of the merchandise that each type of store carries. "For example," she said, "a private-label blouse selling at a discount store for $12.99 was manufactured to sell at that price. At T.J. Maxx a brand-name or designer blouse selling for $12.99 was manufactured to sell at about $24."
Off-price retailers buy in large volume, often obtaining better prices by buying at the end of one season and selling the merchandise the next and building less glamorous stores with lower overhead, Ms. Keating said.
Other successful retailers also known for their wide selections and good values are chains like the Gap, the Limited and the Pottery Barn, which are usually in shopping malls. Their success has been enhanced by the demise of many department stores, once the foundation of retailing.
As trends are changing for shoppers, the customer base is changing for vendors. Harmon Stein, president of Excel Cutlery of Garden City, an importer of fine tabletop merchandise, said that over the last few years the number of department stores had dropped 30 to 40 percent and that many of those that had not closed had merged. Vendors who formerly sold primarily to department stores are increasingly selling to off-price retailers and membership clubs, he said, which increases the quality of the merchandise in those outlets.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Shoppers at the Price Club, above, in Westbury, and T.J. Maxx in Greenvale. The two off-price retailers have attracted large numbers of shoppers. (Photographs by Michael Shavel for The New York Times) (pg. LI1); Shoppers at the Price Club in Westbury, one of the off-price companies changing retail shopping on Long Island. (Michael Shavel for The New York Times) (pg. LI10)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1759 words

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: Energy Policy;
CLINTON TO REVAMP ENERGY DEPT. ROLE

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton is prepared to give the Department of Energy a dominant role in his efforts to marry the goals of creating jobs, making industry more efficient and reducing environmental damage, transition advisers say.
Those working on the plans say they reflect Mr. Clinton's desire to transform a bureaucracy largely ignored for most of the Reagan-Bush years into an aggressive player in integrating environmental goals into economic policy. 
 The blueprint being put together by industry executives as well as staff members close to Mr. Clinton and Vice President-elect Al Gore conforms with the promises Mr. Clinton made during the campaign. He said he wanted to wean the nation from its reliance on coal and oil by converting to cleaner, less costly alternatives like natural gas, using tax incentives and research money to encourage development of renewable resources and expanding the American role in the global market for pollution control equipment and services.
The longer-term goal is to revitalize industry and make the United States more competitive with Japanese and German manufacturers, whose energy efficiency gives them far lower production costs.
Staff members close to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore said that to signal the new direction they had identified several actions the President-elect could take immediately by executive order or policy change. Among the proposed actions are these:
*Converting hundreds of thousands of Federal vehicles to compressed natural gas, which burns more cleanly than gasoline and is less expensive. President Bush issued such an order, but it covers only a fraction of the vehicles in the fleets operated by the Postal Service, the military and other Federal agencies.
*Accelerating a long-delayed program requiring more efficient energy use in buildings and appliances. Besides encouraging the development of new technology, this would save money as well as fuel, especially for the Federal Government, the advisers say. They added that it would showcase new techniques and provide a market for them.
*Shifting the Government's research priorities to conservation technologies and renewable resources like wind, sun and water. The department's research program now favors development of nuclear energy and coal.
* Making available to private industry the new technologies the department is developing in its $5.5-billion-a-year program to clean up the environmental damage from nuclear weapons plants across the country.
The planning underscores the potential influence of Mr. Gore, one of whose main interests is the environment, as a guiding force behind the new approach. One important figure on the environment-economy transition team is Kathleen McGinty, a 29-year-old lawyer from Philadelphia who became Mr. Gore's chief environmental specialist when she joined his Senate staff in 1989.
"There is no question that Governor Clinton is prepared to make the Department of Energy an integral component of our long-term economic strategy," said George Stephanopoulos, the director of communications for the transition. "He has not made any final decision on personnel or specific policies. These are options prepared by his staff, and he is reviewing them."
The advisers on the transition team said Senator Timothy E. Wirth of Colorado, the chairman of the Senate Energy subcommittee on conservation, who did not seek re-election, and Thomas F. McLarty 3d, chairman and chief executive of Arkla Inc., a natural gas utility in Little Rock and one of four board members of Mr. Clinton's transition, head the short list of candidates under consideration by Mr. Clinton for Energy Secretary. Mr. Wirth is also under consideration to be as Secretary of the Interior, the advisers said.
Both agencies have been lumped together with several others in the transition planning in an effort to integrate the economic, environmental and natural-resource issues they encompass. Others in the group are the Environmental Protection Agency, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, the Department of Agriculture, and the Department of Commerce.
Mr. McLarty went to kindergarten with the President-elect in Hope, Ark., and has been a close friend ever since. He is well regarded in the industry, and Mr. Clinton touted him as a possible energy secretary during campaign swings through Texas when he discussed energy policy with oil and gas industry executives. Mr. McLarty did not respond to messages left with the transition staff and his company.
Mr. Wirth is also well versed on the considerable environmental problems that plague the Energy Department's nuclear weapons industry, which includes the Rocky Flats plutonium plant near Denver. Mr. Wirth was in Europe last week on vacation and could not be reached. Friends in Congress and in Colorado said he was reluctant to talk about his plans but might be interested in becoming Energy Secretary given Mr. Clinton's desire to make the Energy Department central to his economic and environmental policy.
"From Day 1, you'll see an Energy Department moving very aggressively, and the reason is that a new direction makes sense for jobs, for the economy, for our balance of trade and for a cleaner environment," said Bill Burton, a lawyer in Austin, Tex., who coordinated the Clinton-Gore campaign's strategy on energy issues. "An energy policy based on cheap foreign oil is shameful, and it will change."
Mr. Clinton himself signaled the change in a news conference 10 days ago. "I have read, at least in my history books, that some Cabinet appointments are considered major and others are considered minor," he said. "I don't know how you would consider the Departments of Commerce and Energy in that regard, but from the kind of economic policy I have laid out, and the things that I think we have to do to change this country economically, those are very major appointments."
Among other candidates on the list for Energy Secretary, the advisers said, are Gov. David Walters of Oklahoma, a national co-chairman of the Clinton-Gore campaign; Garry Mauro, the Texas Land Commissioner and chairman of the Clinton-Gore campaign in Texas; Michael L. Beatty, executive vice president and general counsel of the Coastal Corporation in Houston who was an important fund-raiser for Mr. Clinton, and Daniel H. Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Massachusetts and a research associate at Harvard University who won a Pulitzer Prize this year for his history of the oil industry, titled "The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money and Power."
The Department of Energy was established in 1977 to help solve the problem of America's dependence on imported oil, but it has been a largely forgotten bureaucracy.
In the late 1980's, for reasons that neither President Reagan nor President Bush anticipated, the department became the focus of attention for its mismanagement of the Government's nuclear production plants, laboratories and testing grounds. The end of cold war has produced new opportunities for reordering the department's mission while at the same time advancing Mr. Clinton's agenda for jobs, new technologies, and environmental protection.
Ms. McGinty is helping to select teams to interview officials in the Department of Energy, the Department of the Interior and the other domestic environmental agencies beginning early next month. That research is intended to help the incoming Cabinet members and their deputies understand which policy decisions made by the Bush and Reagan Administrations should be kept or rejected.
Requiring Federal vehicles to convert to natural gas is one of an array of measures that Mr. Clinton is preparing as an attempt to strengthen energy production and exploration in this country. The American industry lost 500,000 jobs during the 1980's, more than the auto and steel industries combined, the Department of Commerce has reported.
Industry executives said roughly 20 trillion cubic feet of natural gas, all of it domestically produced, is used each year in the United States, and each increase of a trillion cubic feet in production could result in 50,000 to 70,000 additional jobs. It is not known how many jobs might be lost in the coal and oil refining industries, which would suffer declines in sales as use of natural gas increased.
The acceleration of the long-delayed program to raise the energy efficiency standards for buildings and appliances would both conserve fuel and save money, especially for the Federal Government, which spends $4 billion annually to heat and cool its buildings, said James Wolf, executive director of the Alliance to Save Energy, a research group in Washington.
"The highest priority for new technology is to develop a market," said Mr. Wolf, who helped to write a blueprint for energy policy that was requested by Mr. Clinton's energy advisers. "The new Administration has the opportunity to make Government buildings showcases for new energy technology."
Mr. Clinton's advisers also said the President-elect wanted an aggressive Energy Secretary who would use the office to change energy research priorities. Of the $3 billion that the Department plans to spend this fiscal year on civilian research and development programs, $1.3 billion is set aside for the development of coal and nuclear energy. Just $212 million is devoted to inventing new machines to take advantage of wind, sun, water, and other renewable energy sources, while $310 million is to be spent of energy conservation measures.
"A different philosophy will be exercised in the Clinton Administration," said Christopher Flavin, vice president for research at the Worldwatch Institute in Washington. "It will look more like the European industrial strategy where governments work with different industries and accelerate the commercialization of technologies."
The department's research budget, particularly the program for developing new methods of restoring land contaminated by toxic materials, is spurring the American industrial sector for new pollution control equipment and services. Michael Silverstein, an environmental economist from Philadelphia, said the American share of the $50 billion international market for such equipment and services is $6 billion a year and growing.
"The salient point, one that is just as important as the technology, is how much political capital Clinton and Gore are willing to invest to make America one of the dominant players in the international environmental cleanup market," Mr. Silverstein said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Timothy E. Wirth of Colorado, who advisers on the transition team say is one of two candidates on the short list under consideration by President-elect Bill Clinton for Energy Secretary. (Paul Conklin) (pg. A14)

HEADLINE: As H.I.V. Patients Stay at Work, Problems, and Solutions, Emerge

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
Jason Worth, a Housing Court judge in Brooklyn who is infected with H.I.V., comes to work only one day a week because of fatigue and because he wants to avoid the risk of exposure to diseases like tuberculosis from the dozens of people who come through his courtroom every day.
But the 42-year-old judge recently asked state court officials to allow him to use a telephone equipped with a television screen so he could handle settlement conferences from home. Working, he says, is as crucial to staying alive as any precaution he can take to protect his health. 
 "I believe that in order to survive one has to have goals," he said. "My goal is to be a judge with my medical condition."
As more people live longer and stay healthier because of advances in the treatment of the AIDS virus, many, like Judge Worth, are trying to hold on to jobs. Some work despite symptoms of illness because they have no choice -- they need the income or the health-insurance benefits. But many others work as long as they can for the vitality, camaraderie and sense of self-worth a job can provide.
What these workers are finding in the work place varies greatly. Some companies have issued policies stating that AIDS will be treated like any other life-threatening disease and have accommodated employees with H.I.V. with flexible work schedules and other measures. At other companies, the response is to dismiss the worker, although most states have laws prohibiting dismissing employees simply because they have AIDS.
 
Illness Often Hidden
 As a result, many people with H.I.V. believe they must hide their infection if they want to work. Many worry about being discriminated against or written off and losing, if not their jobs, at least promotions. Many do not disclose their condition until they really must, such as when they have to explain frequent absences.
Some show up for work even while sick. Others do not file claims for H.I.V.-related treatments to hide their condition from employees or out of fear of being dropped from health plans.
"I don't want to feel ostracized on the job," said a 49-year-old clothing salesman in Manhattan who has kept his status secret for four years.
He tells fellow employees he is taking vitamins when he takes AIDS medication, and he uses his lunch hour for doctor's appointments.
"I don't want to be deprived of duties or responsibilities until the time I have to relinquish them," he said.
AIDS is a personal issue shrouded in secrecy even for some advocates for people with H.I.V. Thomas B. Stoddard, 44, former executive director of the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, a public-interest law firm that handles H.I.V.-related litigation, said he revealed his H.I.V. status to only three close assistants. He kept his staff in the dark even when he decided to leave last January because he found his job too draining.
"I didn't want to be a victim," he said. "I would have been treated differently."
For their part, employers who encounter a worker with H.I.V. for the first time usually grapple with questions like: Will customers be driven away? Will insurance rates go up? Will the worker's productivity suffer? How will others in the work place react? Can the privacy of the worker be maintained?
There may also be technical questions. In Judge Worth's case, for instance, court officials are now weighing whether the telephone arrangement he is proposing would satisfy the legal rights of litigants to be physically present before the court.
On a more personal level, AIDS can redefine working relationships in painful ways. Gary E. Banas, director for administration for the northeastern district of the Federal Comptroller of the Currency in New York City, said he was torn between compassion and professional duty when he dealt with two subordinates in the advanced stages of the disease.
Mr. Banas reassigned both workers to lesser duties when their performances declined. One of the workers objected. Mr. Banas said the man, who has since died, was a supervisor and staff morale had sunk as co-workers needed to cover for him.
But realizing that he had to put the agency first was not an easy choice, Mr. Banas said.
"I had a lot of sleepless nights over it," said the 44-year-old manager. "I was able to deal with it because I recognized that I had other employees I was responsible for."
 
Conditions Are Changing
 Business groups say that most private or public employers have not prepared for the fears, risks and disruptions AIDS can cause, but that is changing. One reason is a new Federal law to be phased in through 1994, the Americans with Disabilities Act, which prohibits discrimination against disabled workers, including people disabled by AIDS, and will require employers with more than 15 workers to make "reasonable accommodations" for them.
Another reason is that AIDS mostly affects the working-age population: 76 percent of the 242,146 AIDS cases reported as of last September in the United States were in the 25-to-44 age group.
Fear of transmission is still a worry for co-workers even this far into the AIDS epidemic, employers say. In settings where most Americans work, like offices, some reactions indicate a lack of basic knowledge about how infection with the virus occurs.
"Can I catch AIDS from the telephone? Can I catch it from the bathroom?" said Celia Ussak, director of personnel for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad. "They still ask those questions."
Next year, Ms. Ussak said, Metro-North plans to start a companywide AIDS-education program. Other companies have offered or required similar training for employees, business groups say.
 
Employers Respond
 In addition, many employers have already responded to the needs and impairments of infected workers.
A marketing-project manager with Pacific Bell in San Francisco said he revealed his H.I.V. infection to his company four years ago when fatigue and other symptoms forced him to take time off for hospitalizations. He said the company offered not only flexible hours -- he works at home one day a week -- but support groups where he could meet with other H.I.V.-positive employees.
The 43-year-old manager said that several times over the years he has had to explain to a new boss that he has H.I.V.
Two bosses cried, he said. But in recent years, he said, the exchanges have acquired the semblance of normalcy.
"They're used to it," he said. "There are a lot of employees with the condition."
Judging from complaints to civil-rights watchdogs and AIDS organizations, however, workers with H.I.V. sometimes are simply dismissed. In New York State, allegations of employment-related discrimination accounted for 90 of 161 complaints filed by people with H.I.V. with New York City's Human Rights Commission and the State Division of Human Rights last year.
One man appealed to the state agency last November when a supermarket in Rockland County laid him off from his job as a baker. A few months earlier, he said, he had confided to a co-worker that he had tested positive for H.I.V.
He said he did not suspect discrimination until another co-worker asked him one day if it was true he had AIDS.
"It clicked," the 34-year-old man, who has no symptoms of illness, said. "I knew right then that everybody knew."
He settled the case for $7,500 and now works as a cook for a food-service company that knows about his infection, he said.
 
Benefits Costs Cited
 But civil-rights groups say that, increasingly, employment-related discrimination against people with H.I.V. is based not on fear but on cost. Business leaders say some companies have faced higher health-insurance premiums or have had policies canceled because of H.I.V.-related claims by their employees.
Mark Scherzer, a health-benefits consultant in New York City, said he knew of at least five recent instances in New York and New Jersey in which self-insured union health plans have capped benefits for people with H.I.V. at $5,000, $25,000 or, in one case, $100,000. In a similar case in Texas, a self-insured plan capped an employee's benefits after he began filing claims for treatment of AIDS-related conditions. The United States Supreme Court refused this month to hear an appeal of lower court decisions upholding the cap.
Such efforts often stem from a perception that AIDS is more expensive than other types of major illnesses, but health economists say there is no evidence that this is the case.
New treatments and improved survival have undoubtedly raised costs, experts say. Officials from Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the largest private payer of AIDS claims in the country, say the average lifetime cost of a person with H.I.V. has risen to about $200,000 today from $60,000 in 1986.
But at the same time, others note, preventive drugs have cut down on hospitalizations.
"Some of our employees on these drugs are doing better than some people who have cancer or severe heart conditions," said Carl Pope, benefits director for Time Inc., which has about 6,000 employees.
Whether to work or to devote time to other endeavors is an overriding question for people with H.I.V., according to psychotherapists and other professionals who work with this population. Many, they say, ponder questions like whether job pressures could be harmful to their health or whether they could set realistic career goals.
 
Special Problems for Women
 The burden is often heavier for women, many of whom are less well paid than men and have children they must support.
"You stress yourself more out," said a 35-year-old sales clerk from the Bronx who is the mother of a 13-year-old boy. "You have to worry about a baby sitter. If my skin breaks out, I can't say some things around him. I have to be careful I don't make him nervous about my condition."
Women are also more likely to keep their infection secret because they feel they would be judged more harshly than men, counselors say.
But for many people with AIDS, work can also become a means to prove that they can still lead productive lives. It also offers solace, and an escape.
"I don't think I could stay home and just worry about the virus," the sales clerk said.

HEADLINE: Haitians See a Renewal of Hope With Clinton

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PETIT-GOAVE, Haiti, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Although President-elect Bill Clinton has carefully qualified his campaign promises of more generous treatment of Haitian refugees, warning that he is not throwing the doors open to mass immigration, his victory has been greeted here with such enthusiasm that many Haitians are preparing renewed attempts to reach the United States.
In conversations with dozens of people along the Caribbean coastline, Haitians spoke with giddy conviction that Mr. Clinton's Administration would either quickly restore democracy and set things right in their poor and broken country, or welcome them with open arms when they set out in small boats to reach American shores. 
 In bays and coves along the coast, boat builders, anticipating a heavy demand, are readying the wooden hulls that some freely admit are being built to carry Haitians away from their country.
"Nov. 3 and Jan. 20," said Luc Salomon, an unemployed 34-year-old father of four, reciting like many others the dates of Mr. Clinton's victory and inauguration. "As far as I am concerned, after the good Lord comes Bill Clinton, and as soon as Bill Clinton is sworn in, you'll see me go."
Others in a crowd that had gathered in the shade of a small seaside house said they would wait, briefly, to see if Mr. Clinton restored their elected president, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who was violently overthrown by soldiers 14 months ago. But failing that, nearly all of them, including a handful who had already been twice returned by Coast Guard cutters, said they would try to flee.
"It's both repression and poverty that makes us want to leave," said Fleury Prophete, a 22-year-old who, like most in this slumbering port town, has been left idle by an economy that scarcely functioned even before a hemisphere-wide embargo was imposed on Haiti soon after the coup.
"If there's no work in this country, I have to get out," said Mr. Prophete. "Since the morning I haven't eaten. Look at the waste we have to wade through every day. We don't have a government that cares about us. All they know how to do is beat and torture people."
In the last year, nearly 40,000 Haitians have scraped together their life savings, often selling their land or homes, to secure passage aboard the rickety boats setting out for the United States. After months behind barbed-wire fences in a sweltering tent city at the United States Naval Base at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba, or quick interceptions by the Coast Guard, more than 70 percent have been returned to Haiti. The other 30 percent have been admitted to the United States while their asylum applications are reviewed.
Last May, after the Pentagon warned that Guantanamo had been stretched beyond capacity, President Bush authorized the summary repatriation of Haitians without an asylum hearing. Advocates for the refugees say such hearings are guaranteed by national and international laws that were intended to distinguish between those fleeing political repression, who have a right to asylum, and economic refugees, who have no such right.
Although the legality of Mr. Bush's order is being challenged before the Supreme Court, its effectiveness in stopping the refugee wave is uncontested. Since May, the number of boat people setting out to sea has gone from a rush to a trickle.
 
A Warning From Clinton
 During the Presidential campaign and since, Mr. Clinton has expressed disapproval of the Bush Administration's policy. But after aerial surveillance by the Coast Guard found hundreds of boats being readied on Haitian shores after his election, Mr. Clinton warned, "It would be unwise for anybody to think that I am going to articulate a policy that would promote mass migration."
In a news conference in Washington on Thursday, Mr. Clinton promised to spell out that policy clearly before his inauguration, saying, "This is about giving Haitians a chance to make a case that they should be granted asylum in this country temporarily until we see a democratically elected government restored to Haiti."
Although hundreds, perhaps thousands of Haitians have been killed since the September 1991 coup against Father Aristide, diplomats say that most Haitians cannot demonstrate the reasonable fear of being singled out for attack that is required to qualify for political asylum under American law. But Haiti's poverty, its proximity to the United States and the presence there of large numbers of Haitians make the hemisphere's richest country a powerful magnet for the people of the poorest.
 
Seeking Regional Help
 After expressions of alarm in Florida over the prospect of a renewed wave of Haitians, which State Department officials said could easily number in the tens of thousands, aides to Mr. Clinton have said that refugees would probably not be screened in the United States. Instead, they said, Washington would seek to persuade another country to harbor the refugees during their screening.
Failing that, Mr. Clinton's aides said, screening of refugees would take place aboard United States ships or at Guantanamo.
United States diplomats noted that repeated attempts by the Bush Administration failed to persuade any other country to receive large numbers of Haitians. Diplomats also said that the Guantanamo base's capacity is 12,500 refugees, and they add that the base would be unable to handle a much larges number. Naval vessels, they said, are unsuitable for harboring refugees for more than brief periods.
Because of constraints like these, many have concluded that Mr. Clinton's best option would be to increase pressure on Haiti's military leadership to accept Father Aristide's return to office.
 
The Logic for Aristide
 "There is a sort of inexorable logic here that unless you return Aristide, there will never be civil liberties in the country, meaning many of those who try to reach the United States will continue to have a plausible argument that they are political refugees," said Robert White, a former United States diplomat. He visited Haiti this week with a group of Democratic Party figures led by Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York City. "If Aristide comes back, however, the United States could say that all of these people are economic refugees."
Advocates for the refugees also say that Mr. Clinton should concentrate on settling Haiti's political crisis while urging the United Nations and other countries to play a larger role in handling the refugees.
"There are a number of things the United States still hasn't tried yet," said William G. O'Neill, deputy director of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, "from freezing the assets of individuals already identified as supporters of the coup, and urging places like France and Canada to do likewise, to unilaterally revoking the visas of these people. These are things which could be done right away, which would send a very different signal about the resolve of the United States to restore democracy, and would give some hope again to Haitians that we are serious about change."

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Although Trade Is Trickier, 'More Is Better' Is Still True

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
The end of the trade spat with Europe, if France can be persuaded to go along, is certainly good news for Americans who prefer to drink real Chablis with their oysters or who export soybeans. But in an era in which everything from cars to cheese already seems to come from another country, does the apparent breakthrough in negotiations on a grand world trade deal really matter?
The answer, say most, if not quite all, economists, is a resounding yes. International trade has been a great engine of prosperity for the last century and shows every promise of remaining one in the next. And while the gains from trade have become far trickier to analyze than the old textbooks make them out to be, the basic logic -- more is better -- has not changed. 
 In fact, say the experts, the likely alternative to moving forward is regressing to a world in which politicians rather than markets have the last word on what people buy and sell.
 
Losers, as Well as Winners
 The gospel according to Econ 101 says free trade makes each party to a transaction better off because it allows each to specialize in what it does best. All the bananas Americans eat could probably be grown in Florida, but it is only common sense -- and cheaper -- to buy them from Costa Rica, and let the Costa Ricans spend the revenues on imported computers.
What the gospel sometimes brushes by is that trade creates losers as well as winners. If some hapless farmer actually planted a banana plantation in Florida he would not look forward to competing with fruit that practically jumps off the trees in Central America.
Generally, trade hurts those who must compete against resources, human and physical, that are relatively abundant abroad. For the United States, that largely means unskilled workers in manufacturing. Thus, while the overall gains from opening ports to all those cheap clothes and shoes and electronics from abroad have been enormous, apparel workers in Manhattan are less enthusiastic than, say, aeronautical engineers at the Boeing factory in Seattle.
For the first few decades after World War II, America dominated world trade policy and its exporters had the biggest say in what the country demanded from its trade partners. Hence the organization created to negotiate trade rules, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, was used as a tool to open markets in the industrialized countries and keep them open. Tariffs, which historically served to protect home markets, are no longer a major impediment to trade in most manufactured goods.
But since the early 1970's the economics of trade have been changing, and the geopolitics have followed. It is no longer clear which country or even which companies have a natural edge in producing which goods. Intangible factors like technological savvy and organizational skills seem to matter more than where the cheapest labor or materials are. So, too, do "non-tariff barriers," -- rules as subtle as health regulations and red tape at the dock -- that are often written by governments with an eye to favoring the home team.
This has weakened the old coalitions of exporters in the industrialized countries, who stood as one against protectionist interests. Economists have also muddied the waters by theorizing that countries might be better off protecting some home markets, like those needed to give local manufacturers a foothold in new products.
And while these theories are too clever by half -- the most prominent new theorist, Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, acknowledges that, as a practical matter, protection hardly ever pays -- the theoretical challenge to the old orthodoxy has bolstered the case of interest groups fighting to protect their turf.
That dismays most economists, even many who agree that the simple, century-old concept of gains through international specialization is no longer much consequence. Trade, they argue, is more important than ever.
 
Non-Tariff Barriers a Target
 First, it sustains competition that forces innovation: Hardly anyone, after all, believes that Chrysler and Ford would be producing excellent cars today if Toyota and Honda were not breathing down their necks.
Second, it speeds the diffusion of technology. With the potential for technological breakthroughs anywhere from Finland to Israel to South Korea, open global markets are more than ever the ticket to rapid progress.
It was in this context that the latest GATT negotiations, began in 1986 in Uruguay. The basic idea was to clean up old business, notably trade in agriculture, and get on with the job of writing ironclad rules for new business before protectionist coalitions grew too powerful to be stopped.
One urgent target was all those pesky non-tariff barriers, particularly those that affected trade in services like banking, insurance and construction. Another was protection of intellectual property, everything from patents on new drugs to copyrights on rock music.
In the late 1980's there was widespread optimism that a deal would soon be struck. The industrialized countries would get access to markets for services and legal protection on patents and copyrights, granting in return a phase-out of restrictions on trade in agriculture and apparel.
But the talks bogged down badly on what may be the least important issue on the agenda: grain. The European Community now protects its woefully inefficient farmers at the expense of Americans, Australians and Argentines, not to mention its own consumers and taxpayers. But efforts to phase out the protection as part of the Uruguay Round of negotiations have been complicated by the internal politics of the Community. With the grand issue of European currency integration teetering in the balance, Community leaders were reluctant to shove a grain deal down the throats of French farmers, who are both noisy and politically active.
Under the compromise announced Friday, the United States will settle for far less than the rapid demise of agricultural subsidies that it hoped to get. And other issues could still keep negotiators very busy for a while longer. As Jeffrey Schott, an economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington puts it, European farm subsidies were "the glue, not the guts, of a much bigger package."
 
Deal Within Months
 Jagdish Bhagwati, a Columbia University economist and senior adviser to the GATT staff, predicts a broad world trade deal within months. And while it will not come anywhere near meeting the ambitious goals set in the mid-1980's, Mr. Bhagwati thinks it will make a big difference.
Perhaps most important, a world deal will sustain the momentum toward free trade that has clearly been slowing for two decades. Every country will presumably get something from the agreement. And Mr. Bhagwati's expectation is that it will thus give every country a stronger incentive to follow the letter and spirit of GATT rules that it doesn't like.

HEADLINE: Fujimori Winning Both Peruvian Votes, Counts Show

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 22

 BODY:
A survey of voters leaving polling places today showed strong backing for President Alberto K. Fujimori's candidates for a Congress that will rewrite the Peruvian Constitution.
Early and unofficial vote tallies also indicated that Mr. Fujimori had won a legislative majority. 
 The voting, seven months after Mr. Fujimori seized near-dictatorial powers by disbanding Congress and the courts and suspending the Constitution, apparently consolidated his control over government. He had said that he would interpret a victory today as a ringing endorsement of the steps he took on April 5.
Analysts said that despite the refusal by several large parties to take part in what they called illegal elections, a victory would give the administration a new measure of legitimacy with foreign governments, which have been highly critical of Mr. Fujimori's seizure of power.
 
Full Tally to Come
 Official results are expected on Monday.
"I voted for the Chinese," said Pedro Rosales, a retiree in Lima, using a nickname that supporters give Mr. Fujimori, whose parents were, in fact, Japanese. "He's the only politician who has done anything in this country for years. The others just promise to get rid of corruption and terrorism, but do nothing."
Guerrilla organizations had threatened to disrupt the elections. But Peruvians turned out in large numbers, and guerrilla violence was minor.
Around Lima, rebels set off several small bombs and threw sticks of dynamite near polling stations. Two people reportedly suffered minor injuries. No deaths were reported.
 
Polls Well Guarded
 The army and national police posted 100,000 troops around the country to guard polling stations. During the day, 250 observers from the Organization of American States were at voting centers around the country, trying to detect fraud or other irregularities.
According to an unofficial vote tally tonight by the Apoyo group, the coalition slate made up of two pro-Fujimori parties had won 38.3 percent of all ballots, which it said would give them 44 of the 80 seats in Congress. But two smaller polling organizations had said earlier that Mr. Fujimori narrowly failed to win a majority of seats.
Of the 17 other parties running, the closest, according to the Apoyo count, was the Popular Christian Party, with 8 percent. Apoyo found that 22.7 percent of voters left their ballots blank or voided them.
In Villa el Salvador, one of the largest shantytowns and a place where the far-leftist Shining Path rebels have a strong presence, thousands of residents walked the sandy streets to a voting station in a rundown school. Many of those willing to express an opinion said they had supported Mr. Fujimori.
In the fashionable sector of La Molina, the setting was different. Mercedes-Benzes, Volvos and Nissan sports cars were parked outside the immaculately clean Newton School. Sentiment there, too, was in Mr. Fujimori's favor.
"My husband and son voted for Fujimori," said Pilar Portero. "But I didn't. Still, the thinking here is that we need a strong hand."
Voting is mandatory. Failure to vote can lead to a $17 fine, a large sum for a worker who earns the minimum wage of $45 a month.
 
Economic Thicket
 For Peru, organizing an election in which 11 million were expected to vote was a logistical nightmare. Many polling places opened late. At the National Stadium in downtown Lima, many voting tables had not been set up by 1:30 P.M., even though the polls officially opened at 8 A.M.
And while Mr. Fujimori can say he won a mandate, there were some who doubted that he could live up to his promises to improve their bleak economic state.
In Villa el Salvador, a group of women complained that they could not feed their children and that a Government program to provide food and milk had been shut down.
And Alejandro Medrano, a 32-year-old painter, who said he had invalidated his ballot in protest, declared: "This Congress is a fraud of Fujimori. As long as we don't have a redistribution of wealth, this Congress will not be able to solve any of our problems of poverty, unemployment and hunger."

HEADLINE: Refugee Burden Is Impoverishing Croatian Hosts

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Faced with enormous economic problems and an influx of Bosnian refugees, people from across this former Yugoslav republic are looking with resentment and bewilderment on a world they see as too slow to send help and too quick to slam its doors shut.
"The kindest thing you can say is that this is hypocritical," said Croatia's Vice President, Mate Granic. 
 The republic's 4.5 million or so people are now host to 627,000 registered displaced persons, including 333,000 refugees from Bosnia and Herzegovina, most of them Muslims, according to United Nations statistics. The Zagreb Government estimates that more than 100,000 unregistered Bosnian refugees also live in Croatia.
 
Appeal to Take Even More
 This month and last, international relief agencies urged Croatia to open its borders to thousands of new refugees driven from Sarajevo and and from Bosnian towns. At the same time, Britain refused entry visas to 180 Bosnian refugees for whom a private British charity had already arranged housing with families.
About 1,500 Bosnian men released from Serbian prisons and camps also remain in a squalid, "temporary" shelter in the Croatian town of Karlovac because Western Governments are reluctant to accept them. Thousands more prisoners and internees are stuck in the Serbian camps.
"It is as if 40 million Mexicans picked up and fled to the United States," said Michael Keats, a spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Zagreb.
But despite the refugees' problems, Croatians say they face adversity themselves. "I am sorry for these people, but they are a burden," said a 70-year-old Croatian housewife from Zagreb, whose $23 monthly pension and welfare check does not cover her food costs, much less housing and utilities. "We are ourselves in great difficulty."
 
Severely Shrinking Economy
 Unable to make ends meet, many of Croatia's people, who include Croats and Serbs as well as ethnic Hungarians, Albanians and Italians, have simply stopped paying their rent and electrical bills.
Croatia's total economy has slipped from about $13.5 billion in 1990 to $7.5 billion this year, Mr. Granic said. He estimated that the cost of maintaining the displaced persons and refugees exceeds $50 million a month.
Croatia finds 25 percent of its territory, including critical road and rail links, controlled by rebel Serbs and 37 percent of its production facilities either in Serbian-occupied lands or in ruins. Some here complain that the war with Serbia last year and the flood of Bosnian refugees this year have damaged this country more than United Nations economic sanctions have damaged Serbia and Montenegro, the truncated Yugoslav federation.
"My God, this is devilish," said a man who gave his name only as Matija, a 78-year-old retired postal worker.
"When Tito was alive we weren't given the freedom to talk," he said, referring to postwar Yugoslavia's longtime leader. "But at least people had something to eat. To hell with this kind of freedom."
 
Idle Hands, Devil's Playthings
 In Zagreb, hard-pressed pensioners line up at night to buy cheap black bread before prices go up. Growing numbers of prostitutes haunt dark side streets. And idle young men and women, who have little prospect of finding employment anytime soon, linger for hours in cafes, nursing espressos.
"I am psychologically lost," said Tomislav Provic, an electrician who fled from the city of Vukovar when it fell to the Serbs a year ago and now lives in a Zagreb hotel. "We cannot get permanent jobs because we lack residency cards, and we can't even apply for residency cards."
In addition to the 633,000 displaced persons and refugees, Croatia's Government must support 267,000 jobless, 120,000 police and military personnel, 800,000 pensioners and 150,000 others on some kind of welfare, according to Government statistics.
So far the Government has paid its bills only by printing unbacked currency. Consequently, the monthly inflation rate has increased from 15 percent in July to 40 percent in November, Government statistics and estimates say.
"We are just below the designated level of hyperinflation," said Ante - Cicin-Sajn, a financial expert. "That's when money becomes practically unusable."
"It is incredible that Croatia has held out so long without social unrest," Mr. Cicin-Sajn said, adding that despite the hardship the country has maintained payments on its $3.5 billion hard-currency foreign debt.
Croatia estimates that it has received $1.5 billion in aid, including assistance from Croatian emigres, international organizations and foreign governments since the war began here in July 1991.
"This has helped us maintain stability," Vice President Granic said.
"But Croatia needs help now to deal with the refugees and displaced persons," he said, estimating that the Government requires about $50 million just to house the refugees.
The Government, he said, may soon be unable to pay to keep the refugees in hotels and private homes. In any event, it desperately needs to free up the hotel rooms they occupy, especially along the Adriatic coast, to have a chance of earning desperately needed hard currency from the 1993 tourist season.
"People here will soon be unable to provide the refugees housing," he said. "They will put them out, and this will create an uncontrolled movement."

HEADLINE: Churchill Journal;
Social Season for Bears: Not in the Kitchen, Please

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHURCHILL, Manitoba

 BODY:
November is polar bear season in Churchill, a town of 800 on the gray and rocky western shores of Hudson Bay. One of the town's busiest men is Laury Brouzes, keeper of the bear jail.
"My job is to protect people from bears and bears from people," he said early one recent morning while inspecting traps around the dump where the now ravenous bears, the largest nonaquatic carnivores on earth, prowl. 
 The traps are not designed to injure but to intercept bears headed for town and trouble, like the 700-pound male that broke into the home of Lorraine Allen at Spruce Ridge the other day as she was baking cupcakes.
The bear forced entry by ripping screens from the bathroom window, then lumbered into the kitchen as Mrs. Allen retreated, calling for help. Her husband, Dan, rushed over with his rifle and killed the bear with one shot as it hovered over the kitchen table, eating cupcakes.
 
A Trip by Helicopter
 A happier fate awaits those in the traps of Mr. Brouzes. After a month or two in the jail, depending on the space available in the 20-pen Quonset hut, they are released on a first-in-first-out basis.
Sedated, they are transported four at a time in nets dangling from a helicopter 50 miles back into the pristine wilderness along the North Knife and Seal Rivers.
Although they are not technically an endangered species, polar bears are protected by law. Indian and Eskimo groups are permitted to kill a certain number of bears a year; others may kill bears only in self-defense.
Situated near denning areas where bears give birth, Churchill calls itself the polar bear capital of the world. It is one of the rare places where the normally aloof, seal-eating polar bears have significant contact with people.
 
Tourists by the Thousands
 That contact has increased lately as thousands of tourists pour into Churchill to see the bears in their natural habitat.
"I saw about 15 today, including a mother and cub play-fighting and running around, and it was wonderful," said a New Yorker named Irene Greenberg, who manages a veterinary hospital in the Bayside section of Queens.
While conflicts are inevitable as people inhabit and visit places that polar bears call home, Churchill is doing all it can to keep such conflicts to a minimum, both for safety and economic reasons.
To Doug Webber, the town's two-term Mayor, there is no question Churchill needs the bears.
"To the run of the mill resident, bears are a pest," said the Mayor, who owns hunting and fishing lodges and offers flying tours with money-back guarantees if his guests fail to see polar bears. "But because of tourism, people also realize bears are a cash crop and don't want to do anything to harm them."
Since the mid-1980's, three local entrepreneurs have had licenses to carry tourists in "tundra buggies," big-wheeled buses, to observe the bears in their natural state.
Such tourism, with the spinoff in T-shirts and other souvenir purchases, motel bookings, restaurant meals and employment as guides and drivers, now represents about 30 percent of the town's economic activity, which was severely affected in the early postwar years by the shutdown of a big military base and later a rocket testing installation.
The threatened closing of the port of Churchill, which in the short three-month shipping season sends Manitoba and Saskatchewan grain to Europe, would be another heavy blow.
Cape Churchill, about 30 miles east of town, is the staging point for the bears' winter feed. Forced off the Hudson Bay ice by the spring melt and thus denied their staple food, the bears now have eaten little for months. Their body weight is down by a third.
"By instinct, they know that cold weather means freeze-up time, and they'll soon be able to get out on the ice again and gorge on seals," said Dr. Charles Jonkel, a bear biologist at the University of Montana, who since the mid-1960's has been coming here to study Ursus maritimus, as the polar bear is classified.
Bears choose Cape Churchill, he said, because fresh water flowing from the mouth of the Churchill River, site of the town, freezes first. The prevailing winds push that ice toward the cape.
 
Bears Give No Warning
 "Polar Bear Alert," signs warn. "Don't Walk In This Area." If you must, you are urged to peer cautiously around corners and always look behind. "Polar bears that hunt and kill do not give warning," writes Lance Olsen, a reporter for Bear News.
Anyone sighting suspicious-looking shapes is urged to dial 675-BEAR, the hot line that sends Mr. Brouzes or one of his five Manitoba Department of Natural Resources deputies out with a rifle that shoots tranquilizing pellets. The comatose animal is then hauled off to jail.
In 1984 on Kelsey Street, Churchill's street, a polar bear killed and partly ate a man. Since then there have been at least three maulings, though none of the victims have been tourists. Several days ago, a bear ate a dog.
Eugenia Talbott, an artist who works here and in Mayhew, Miss., looked up from a polar bear she had sketched to comment: "I'm not walking so much now. The bears are hungry."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Churchill, Manitoba, a meandering ursus maritimus, or polar bear, is not uncommon. "My job is to protect people from bears and bears from people," said Laury Brouzes, left, of the Manitoba Department of Natural Resources, who prepared to airlift a tranquilized bear to the North Knife River. (Clyde H. Farnsworth/The New York Times)
 
Map of Manitoba showing the location of Churchill.
