HEADLINE: Los Angeles Schools Face Insolvency and a Takeover

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24

 BODY:
The nation's second-largest school system stands on the verge of fiscal collapse.
The system, the Los Angeles Unified School District, says it will declare itself insolvent on Wednesday if a state judge permanently orders it to reverse a 12 percent pay cut imposed on teachers. The State of California would then take over the system. 
 If that happens, it will be by far the largest school district in the United States to go bankrupt, and the ultimate cry of agony from the far-flung system of 641,206 pupils and 651 schools that has been struggling for years against overwhelming forces of urban decay, racial division, bitterly divided school-board politics and now financial ruin.
These problems have been aggravated by the fiscal problems of the state, which has been forced to cut the funds it gives to local districts.
In a last-ditch bid to avert insolvency, the California State Board of Education in Sacramento held an emergency meeting today, its first ever, and agreed to waive three provisions of the state education code. By doing so the board hoped to change the opinion of Superior Court Judge Stephen E. O'Neil, who precipitated the crisis on Nov. 5 when he issued a temporary restraining order holding that the district had illegally cut teacher salaries and ordering it to issue supplemental paychecks totaling $20 million by today.
 
Strike Authorized
 Judge O'Neil is expected to rule Wednesday on the teachers' union motion to make the order permanent.
The 34,000-member union, the United Teachers-Los Angeles, has authorized a strike over the pay cut, which was imposed last month by the district's seven-member board to bridge a $400 million shortfall in its $3.9 billion budget. Teachers have been working without a contract since Sept. 30.
In an interview, the president of the board, Leticia Quezada, said schools would run out of money before the school year ends if Judge O'Neil rules against them. "Then we will be in bankruptcy," she said. "This whole issue has tremendous implications for the entire State of California."
While a state takeover would not mean padlocking schoolhouse doors, it would have devastating effects on the struggling system and its pupils, half of whom enter kindergarten without speaking English and half of whom live in poverty.
The state, itself hobbling along with almost no reserves, is almost certain to order further stringent economies and would probably abrogate union contracts, cutting pay and laying off staff. Under a new state law, an insolvent school district must cede authority on all financial matters to the county superintendent of schools, who acts for the state. In the case of Los Angeles County, that person is Stuart E. Gothold, and he informed the district last Thursday that he would intercede if the judge rules adversely on Wednesday.
When the Richmond Unified School District, near San Francisco, went bankrupt in 1991, the state took over and lent the district money but ordered a 9 percent pay cut for all employees, shortened school hours and reduced staff and support services.
In the past five years, states have taken over 10 school districts for financial reasons, and another five districts for deficient academic performance, said Chris Pipho, an analyst at the Education Commission for the States in Denver. In New Jersey, Paterson and Jersey City are under state authority.
Los Angeles teachers maintain they are being made to pay for inefficiency and a sluggish administrative bureaucracy, and that sports and other extracurricular activities should be cut first. In an interview, Helen Bernstein, president of the union, said pay would drop from 9th-highest to 42d-highest among the 43 school districts in Los Angeles County.
"Why are we taking such a massive pay cut?" she said, noting that it would discourage good teachers from teaching in the city's schools. "It does not take a wizard to figure out that the priorities are all mixed up."
 
Frustration at School
 The teachers won a total of 24 percent in raises between 1988 and 1991, leaving the district facing high salaries and declining revenues now. According to the American Federation of Teachers, the salaries for veteran Los Angeles teachers rank 11th among major American cities, at $45,239 a year, and first for beginning teachers, $29,529 (compared to $49,353 and $26,238 for New York City, which has the nation's largest school system). The cuts would reduce the pay to about $40,000 for experienced teachers and $26,000 for beginners, and health benefits would be trimmed, too.
The frustration of teachers was apparent this morning at the Ulysses S. Grant High School in the Van Nuys section of Los Angeles.
"The union is jumping up and down for money that the district doesn't have, that the state doesn't have, and that the country doesn't have," said Jonnie Johns, a third-year English teacher who takes home about $19,000 a year after taxes. "Everybody is putting their head in the sand, bickering over dollars, and they're not facing the truth, that the system is collapsing. We're out of money, we're out of morality, we're out of everything."
Ms. Quezada, the board president, said that the board had been very generous with teachers in the past. "Our track record does not say we like to cut pay," she said. "But given the financial conditions, this was the last resort."
A state takeover would damage the union, because further budget cuts would presumably be imposed said Ms. Bernstein, but many teachers would prefer that to the fractious board. "Most teachers will tell you they'd want someone to come in and reorganize it," she said.
In Sacramento, the State Board of Education, meeting at the request of the Los Angeles district, voted 9 to 0 to waive three provisions of the education code that union lawyers had used to win the restraining order. One of them states that local boards can reduce salaries before the beginning of a school year but not after that.
The district argues that the matter should be settled by the Public Employment Relations Board, a state agency, not the courts, and urged teachers to use "caution" in spending the supplemental salary checks distributed today under court order because the money would be recovered by deductions from future checks should the board prevail in court.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Caroline Effertz, left, and Jonnie Johns, who teach at Ulysses S. Grant High School in Los Angeles, reacted to a note attached to their salary refunds. "This payment is made by the district under protest," it said. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Mostly Lower On Rumors of Devaluations

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly lower yesterday after a day in which traders were confused by conflicting rumors that various European currencies would be devalued.
Gold prices settled little changed. On the Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $334.43 an ounce, off 10 cents from Monday. A late quote from the Republic National Bank put gold unchanged at $334.50. 
 The dollar is normally sought as a haven from European currency turmoil, but the current high European interest rates checked the flight.
Andrew Hodge at Bank Brussels Lambert in New York said the European tension would not subside until Germany made its interest-rate policy clear. "Would the Bundesbank cut rates Wednesday in its money-market operation or after its council meeting on Thursday?" he asked. "The market waits to find out."
Rapid growth in Germany's M-3 money supply, reported yesterday, threw some doubt at those who believe a cut will be coming soon. That M-3 figure rose an annualized 10.2 percent in October. The 1992 target was 3.5 percent to 5.5 percent.
In New York, the dollar finished at 1.5942 German marks in late trading, down from 1.5972 on Monday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124 yen yesterday. The market was closed on Monday. Later in London, it rose to 124.08 yen. At closing in New York, the dollar was quoted at 123.85 yen, down from 124.05 on Monday.
In London, the British pound eased to $1.5155 from $1.5165.
In New York, the dollar edged up to 1.2878 Canadian dollars, from 1.2875. Several major Canadian banks raised their prime lending rate to 9.75 percent from 9 percent.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.4293 Swiss francs, down from 1.434; 5.4115 French francs, down from 5.4265, and 1,383 Italian lire, down from 1,384.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Turns to Industry Experience to Lure Films Back to City

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
New York City turned yesterday to a member of the film industry to head the Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting to draw back major television and film production, which has largely abandoned the city in search of cheaper locations.
The selection of Richard Brick, a 47-year-old New York native, ends a long and troubled search, led by Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. 
 His mandate was to find a director as familiar with Hollywood as with the problems affecting the industry in New York, which at least remains in the hearts of studio executives in one sense. Many are disguising their new locales to look like New York.
The former chairman of Columbia University's graduate film division and a member of the Directors Guild of America, Mr. Brick was chosen for his diverse background in production, his work as a creative artist on several acclaimed feature films, his connections in the entertainment industry and his familiarity with New York, Mayor David N. Dinkins said.
 
'I Am Not the Messiah'
 But it might ultimately be his marketing skills that determine whether he succeeds in a job that city officials say had helped generate up to $3 billion a year.
Understandably, the expectations surrounding this appointment have become enormous, Mr. Brick said at a news conference with Mr. Dinkins.
"But I have to be frank; I am not the messiah," he said. "But what I do offer is an appreciation of the complexities of the problems facing this industry." Once a great magnet for attracting producers to its neighborhoods and landmarks, the city has been caught between a sagging economy and several labor disputes, a combination that has driven most of the larger studios, like Universal and Columbia, to locations that studio officials say are more economically hospitable.
And from a New Yorker's perspective, imagine the impudence of it all, using urban backdrops in places like Chicago and Baltimore as the streets of New York.
"Even my son can tell the difference," said Mr. Brick, an adjunct professor at Columbia, whose wife, Sara Bershtell, and 11-year-old son, Noah, accompanied him. Among his more recent credits, Mr. Brick produced "Hangin' with the Homeboys," a 1991 release filmed in the Bronx and Manhattan.
Although he cautioned not to expect miracles, Mr. Brick is taking an office with widely expanded responsibilities, so critical has the schism developed between major production companies and the city. Beyond serving as liaison between the municipal government and the studios, the principal task of his predecessors, including Nina Streich, the acting director since May 1, Mr. Brick is being charged with taking a more aggressive role in marketing and promoting to attract business back to the city.
 
Cost and Cooperation
 "The film and television industry in New York City is not as strong as it once was, and we're facing competition," Mr. Sullivan said. "New York City is perceived to be expensive or uncooperative. The task before us is to figure out how specifically we can bolster the production levels of the city."
It might require more patience than energy. A major studio executive in Los Angeles, who spoke on condition of anonymity, cited several reasons that New York should remain the primary choice for major projects of urban motif, but he overstruck them with the grimmer realities of current economic conditions and the cost of doing business in New York that he claimed was higher than elsewhere.
In effect, he concluded, it might not matter who serves as chief of the department.
While Mr. Sullivan and Mr. Brick said that higher production costs in New York were more perception than reality, they both acknowledged the ugly landscape that mutes the difference. As the sluggish economy was nibbling away at New York's relations with the major production companies through last year, a seven-month labor dispute between studios and several theatrical unions through May of last year devoured almost everything else. A result was a virtual shutdown of all major projects in the city, leaving independent producers as the chief operators.
Even now, a dispute between studios and Teamsters Local 817 in New York remains unresolved, although an agreement is expected shortly.
The choice of a new head for the relatively low-budget office became the subject of intense controversy after local film makers protested that four finalists chosen in June by a nine-member search committee simply were not up to the job.
Mr. Brick's long career includes work as a sound technician and boom operator -- both union jobs -- followed by positions as a location manager for the 1980 film "Ragtime"; production manager in 1982 for the film "Silkwood" and the television mini-series, "Little Gloria . . . Happy at Last," and unit production manager on the 1983 film "Places in the Heart."
Along the way, he befriended all sorts of important people in the entertainment industry, the kind of people he wants to attract by convincing them, as he said, that the issue of cost has been misperceived.
Jaynne C. Keyes, who held the post until seven months ago, hailed Mr. Brick's selection.
"Richard has a great understanding of the industry," she said. "I've worked with him when he was producing, and he understands the business as few who work in film do."
Ms. Keyes, who now is a motion picture agent with the William Morris Agency here, said of Mr. Brick's challenges:
"Film is an industry that is movable back, as it was movable away. We can get 'em back as well as we've lost 'em. New York is the film capital of the world; it has the power and the location."
Citing the many quality actors and technicians in the metropolitan area, Mr. Brick said studios need to be shown that they can produce projects in New York at levels comparable to cities that have siphoned off projects that might have otherwise been produced in New York.
He will need more than luck to succeed, the studio executive said.
"New York has a strong labor pool, and a lot of talented people live there," he said. "People like Martin Scorsese and Spike Lee are committed to doing movies there. But it's the general economy that's going to have more to do with it than anything."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I have to be frank; I am not the messiah," said Richard Brick, the newly appointed head of the New York City Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting. "But what I do offer is an appreciation of the complexities of the problems facing this industry." Mr. Brick spoke yesterday at a news conference at City Hall, accompanied by Mayor David N. Dinkins. (Diane Bondareff)

HEADLINE: Ambitious Talk on College Loans

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Throughout the Presidential campaign, it was one of Bill Clinton's biggest applause lines: junk existing loan programs and replace them with a new plan that gives every American the chance to go to college, if he or she is willing to give something in return.
It was a classic Clinton message of benefit and sacrifice, and it also played to the hearts of middle-class voters worried about paying for their children's college educations. 
 As he makes the transition from candidate to President, Mr. Clinton has signaled that he intends to pursue his plan to revamp the college loan program -- a plan whose central feature would allow students to wipe out their loans by performing public service -- even though early analysis shows it is not as generous, innovative or inclusive as he has made it out to be.
At his first post-election news conference, on Nov. 12, Mr. Clinton put the college plan just behind economic growth, the deficit, health care and political reform on his priority list.
 
Details to Be Decided
 Later in the session he leveled with reporters about how much work still needed to be done on the loan plan. "How much money should everybody be able to borrow a year?" he asked. "What contributions should people's families be expected to make, if any? If you put this into effect, how are you going to keep the colleges and universities of this country from using it as an excuse to explode tuition even more? I mean, there are lots of factual questions."
For all the political capital Mr. Clinton has invested in the loan program, and all the enthusiastic response, the details remain sketchy.
At its most basic, the President-elect's plan sets out to do three things:
*Make tuition loans available to everyone, regardless of income.
*Allow students to pay back the loans at rates that vary with their incomes.
*Give students the option of repaying all or part of their loans by taking community-service jobs that provide stipends for living expenses.
In one form or another, the provisions have been tried before or are available in a limited way now. What makes the Clinton plan different, and what gets college administrators excited, is that it brings together several ideas that have had wide support and proposes to carry them out full tilt with the solid backing of the President.
At a recent meeting at New York University, several college presidents expressed support for the Clinton plan, which they predicted would be Mr. Clinton's major higher education initiative. But they worried about its cost.
Mr. Clinton has said the plan will cost around $12 billion a year when it is in place, more than double that of the current program, which has a price tag of $4 billion to $5 billion a year.
 
Doubt on Cost Projections
 The incoming Administration figures that the loan part of the program will roughly pay for itself; that is, loan repayments would cover the cost of new loans over time. Education experts say this may not be true, and experience has shown loan programs to be more expensive than their backers intended.
Mr. Clinton's advisers also assume that loan defaults, which now cost around $3 billion a year, would be reduced because the repayments would be collected by the Internal Revenue Service along with Federal income tax returns.
The new costs, about $8 billion a year, would cover the creation of a National Service Trust. Clinton officials said students could wipe out $10,000 a year or more in loans, up to a maximum of $20,000, by working after graduation at a reduced salary in some aspect of public service, say, as a teacher in an inner-city school or as a police officer in a tough neighborhood.
Currently, students who use a type of Government loan called a Perkins Loan have the option of working as teachers or in the Peace Corps to have their loans forgiven. Since 1972, the Government has canceled $238 million in loans to students who have become teachers in hard-pressed neighborhoods. But this represents a small percentage of the $15 billion in student loans made each year.
 
Participants Are Few
 Some medical schools also forgive loans if the graduate works as a doctor in a poor area, but, again, few have participated.
Service is the heart of the Clinton proposal, but many people are unsure about how well it would work. Franklyn G. Jenifer, president of Howard University, said that the volunteer service would have to be tightly restricted and that the jobs would have to constitute real service and sacrifice. L. Jay Oliva, president of New York University, said he wondered how much it would cost to train, transport and keep track of the thousands of volunteers.
There is also the cost of paying stipends, which Mr. Clinton said would be borne by the Government, not local employers.
Members of Mr. Clinton's staff said the community service program would probably be limited to about 250,000 participants, but they see little likelihood that even that many would participate, given the record of involvement in similar programs.
How attractive would it be for students to give up two years of income -- around $35,000 for an entering teacher in many places -- to wipe out a $20,000 loan that they could pay back over 20 years at a cost to them of roughly $1,000 a year? How many would be willing to live in inner cities or poor rural areas and subsist on a small stipend to cover room, board and all other costs?
 
Level of Interest Questioned
 "I suspect there are some people who will look at this and say, I don't want to do that," said Dallas Martin, president of the National Association Student Financial Aid Administrators.
While service repayment makes up the bulk of Mr. Clinton's estimated cost, the more traditional loans will affect far more students. Here Mr. Clinton has adopted the same basic idea proposed by his chief economic adviser, Robert Reich, and Senator Bill Bradley, and tried by at least 11 universities on a small scale.
In essence, the plan allows college students to pay back tuition loans at different rates, depending on how much they earn after they graduate. For example, if two university students each borrow $40,000 while in college but one becomes a social worker after college and the other a corporate lawyer, the lawyer would have to make larger payments. To insure that the loans are repaid, Mr. Clinton has said he would have the Internal Revenue Service collect the payments.
The idea of income-contingent loans has been tried. In 1973, Yale University, using its own money, began offering students the option of repaying loans at interest rates based on their incomes after graduation. Donald McM. Routh, university director of financial aid, said that between 1973 and 1978, Yale made 3,602 such loans to undergraduates, graduate students and students in professional schools.
 
'Very Complex Program'
 "What we learned is that this is a very complex program to administer," Mr. Routh said. The biggest single problem was getting the tax returns from the borrowers each year to determine their income. It also proved difficult to make fine distinctions about income, like whether to take into account all or part of a spouse's income.
Yale discontinued the program, he said, because it was more expensive than expected and took longer to reach the break-even point where loan repayments equaled new loans.
In the late 1980's, the Federal Government selected 10 colleges and universities and ran the same type of loan program with the same results. A study showed that collecting income information was an administrative nightmare.
Officials in the Department of Education are already working on such details because the Higher Education Reauthorization Act passed last summer experiments with loans in several ways, including keying repayments to income. In one project a group of universities will be allowed to lend money directly to students, bypassing the banks that now make most loans.
Education officials said they would need a year to draw up the regulations that will govern the new program. The first loans will not be available before the spring of 1994.

HEADLINE: Bank Money Market Yields Mixed for Coming Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
New yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit will be set today at levels flat with last week in the New York area and up slightly from those in other areas.
Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor said the average certificate of deposit yield last week rose 2 to 3 basis points. Last week marked the fifth consecutive week of rises in the five-year C.D., a sign that the downslide of the last 43 months has ended. (The latest rate will be posted today.) 
 But the recent results suggest this will be more of a quiet rise than a sharp upturn, analysts say, adding that a more substantial rise is not likely until next year. Right now, with the economy weak and inflation low, these analysts said, the Federal Reserve knows that if it raises rates too soon, it will risk derailing the recovery and perhaps pushing the economy back into recession.
 
Another Rise at Treasury Auction
 At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday, average discount rates moved up for the seventh consecutive week. The auction is often viewed as a harbinger of how banks could set their savings rates in the weeks ahead.
The average discount rate at auction for a three-month bill jumped to 3.27 percent, from 3.13 percent at the previous auction, while the six-month bill rose to 3.45 percent, from 3.37 percent.
Few changes are reported in the New York area: the combined average yields of both commercial and savings banks show a money-market account and three-month C.D. both unchanged at 2.77 percent and 2.85 percent, respectively. Meanwhile, the six-month certificate slipped a basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point, to 3 percent.
The largest changes this week will be at European American Bank, which pared its money-market account 11 basis points, to 2.58 percent; at Bank of Tokyo, which recently cut its three-month certificate 6 basis points, to 2.96 percent, and at Midlantic of New Jersey, where a six-month certificate sank 15 basis points, to 3.25 percent.
Outside New York, yields at 20 large banks tell a different story. An average money-market account is up a basis point, to 2.68 percent, and the average six-month C.D. has risen 2 basis points, to 2.98 percent.

HEADLINE: Man Guilty Of Murder Of Woman In Brooklyn

BYLINE: By ARNOLD H. LUBASCH

 BODY:
An unemployed handyman was convicted yesterday of murdering a Hasidic woman, who was stabbed to death during a burglary in her apartment in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.
More than 30 spectators, many of them women from the Hasidic community in Crown Heights, sat quietly in the small, fourth-floor courtroom as the jury found the defendant, Romane LaFond, guilty of killing Phyllis LaPine while committing a burglary in her home on Feb. 6. 
 In a corridor outside the courtroom moments after the verdict, the victim's husband, Dennis LaPine, said his wife's death left "a big void" for him and their four children, but "at least now there's justice." He added softly, "The soul of my wife can have a complete rest."
"I want to thank the jury for doing justice," Mr. LaPine said. And he said the verdict provided "a resurgence of hope in the American jury system."
 
Tensions in the Community
 He was apparently alluding to the acquittal of Lemrick Nelson Jr. in the killing of Yankel Rosenbaum, a Hasidic scholar stabbed to death in August 1991. He was slain in a racial disturbance after a black child, Gavin Cato, was accidentally killed by a car driven by another Hasidic man in Crown Heights.
The murder of Mrs. LaPine was not considered a racial incident, but it increased tensions in Crown Heights because the defendant was black and the community remained troubled in the aftermath of the racial disturbances last year.
Mr. LaFond, a 24-year-old resident of Crown Heights, faces a maximum sentence of 25 years to life in prison for Mrs. LaPine's murder. Justice Francis X. Egitto, who conducted the eight-day trial in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, scheduled the sentencing for Dec. 14.
The prosecutors, Michael Vecchione and Jon Besunder, presented evidence by a fingerprint expert that a bloody palm print found on the wall next to Mrs. LaPine's body was the print of Mr. LaFond.
 
Identification by a Witness
 "LaFond convicted himself when he left that palm print," Mr. Vecchione observed after the verdict. He praised the police investigation for providing the prosecution with "the tools to do the job."
The defense lawyer, Samuel Gregory, said he would appeal the conviction. He said the palm print showed that Mr. LaFond had been in the apartment but that it did not prove he committed the murder.
Mrs. LaPine was killed when she returned to her home at 680 Lefferts Avenue after shopping at a supermarket. Her assailant stabbed her repeatedly, spattering a wall with blood. A credit card was missing from her pocketbook.
Testifying for the prosecution, a 16-year-old student, Odino Brown, identified Mr. LaFond as a man he saw running through a backyard near the LaPine home on the afternoon of the murder. Mr. Brown said that the defendant was holding a stick in his right hand and that "he had blood on his hand."
 
Seven Hours' Deliberation
 The trial's most poignant testimony came from a witness who recalled finding Mrs. LaPine's 2-year-old daughter singing a children's song, alone in a bedroom next to the hallway where the victim's body lay on the floor.
The jury deliberated for seven hours on charges that included a legal distinction between an intentional murder, which means deliberately intending to kill someone, and a murder committed as part of a felony, such as burglary. Either murder charge carries the same sentence.
There was a brief gasp from the spectator section when the jury announced that the verdict was not guilty on the first count, intentional murder, but that was quickly followed by a guilty verdict on the second count, murder in the course of a felony. The verdict on the third count, burglary, was also guilty.
One man in the rear of the courtroom started to applaud after the verdict. But the judge, who maintained strict order throughout the trial, quickly ordered a court officer to remove him from the courtroom.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dennis LaPine, whose wife, Phyllis, was stabbed to death during a burglary in their Crown Heights apartment on Feb. 6, spoke with a neighbor, Feige Jacobson, yesterday after a jury found an unemployed handyman guilty of the murder. "The soul of my wife can have a complete rest," he said. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Air Rivals Matching Fare Cuts

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Delta Air Lines agreed yesterday to match the winter discounts America West Airlines disclosed on Monday.
All the major airlines have now agreed to offer the discounts, which average 30 percent, on competing routes. The debt-plagued industry thus finds itself holding another sale less than a week after it retreated from an attempt to raise fares as much as $30 on connecting flights. 
 "It used to be that people made travel plans well in advance, but now the carriers are vaccinating the public to wait for the next white sale before they travel," Richard P. Friese, publisher of Travel Agent magazine, said. While such sales are a bonanza for travelers, he added, in the long run they could prove disastrous for passengers and carriers alike.
 
Conditioning Travelers
 The notion that passengers have become conditioned to wait for each new sale before buying tickets has been widespread within the travel industry since last summer's half-price sale. That sale generated record boardings but in trimming margins added to the financial woes of an industry that according to the chairman of American Airlines, Robert L. Crandall, "has lost $7 billion since Jan. 1, 1990."
The new nonrefundable fares will be available in 475 of America West's 1,000 markets. They require a 14-day advance purchase by Dec. 11 for travel between Dec. 7 and Feb. 4 and require a Saturday night stay. Round-trip fares between New York and Los Angeles, for instance, will fall to $348 from $500 previously, and fares between Boston and Las Vegas, Nev., will drop to $338 from $490.
If the fare cuts are not as deep or as wide as those of last summer, some travel officials say they were prompted by similar concerns about the economy. The industry's load factor, the percentage of available seats filled by passengers, through October 1992 increased only 1.3 percentage points from the period a year earlier.
 
'Some Sticker Shock'
 Yet Kevin Murphy, airline analyst for Morgan Stanley, noted that average revenue per passenger mile on domestic fares rose to 13.2 cents last month from 10.6 cents in August. "That means that when the airlines raised prices after the fare wars, they probably created some sticker shock," Mr. Murphy said. "And with the economy still not recovered, they probably felt they had to offer this week's excursion fares to get people back on planes."
The real test of whether the airline industry is on the road to recovery, Mr. Murphy said, will occur by the end of next summer. "Without a profitable third and fourth quarter next year," he said, "even some of the well-known better-capitalized carriers may have to make major structural changes."
The AMR Corporation's American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, is already studying such changes. It recently laid off 1,000 managers, and a recent issue of the weekly World Airline News quotes Mr. Crandall as telling employees that American is considering closing hubs, paring domestic operations and possiblly selling off parts of the company.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Midmonth Vehicle Sales Up by 4.8%

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built vehicles rose 4.8 percent in mid-November, led by a sharp increase in sales of pickup trucks, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles. But car sales remained sluggish.
The outcome of the Presidential election does not seem to have motivated consumers, as was expected by many retail dealers. "The slightest thing stops a deal from going through," said Scott Lawson, general manager of Island Chevrolet-Buick-Pontiac in Fernandina Beach, Fla. 
 Domestic light-truck sales rose 14.4 percent, to 116,171, while domestic car sales fell 1.3 percent, to 157,452. Overall vehicle sales were 273,623 for the period of Nov. 11-20, compared with 260,968 last year.
 
Annual Selling Rate
 The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales was 5.8 million, up from 5.6 million in early November. Last year in the period, car sales were running at an annual rate of 5.9 million.
"November is clearly weaker than October," said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York. "We're seeing one step forward, one step back. The recovery remains gradual."
The National Automobile Dealers Association called mid-November sales unimpressive. Citing positive consumer confidence numbers released today, the trade group said it hoped "numerous small-ticket purchases in December" would lead "to a stronger economy and more big-ticket purchases in our industry's all-important spring selling season."
The General Motors Corporation, the No. 1 auto maker, whose corporate restructuring has produced somber headlines, reported a strong gain in the sales of light trucks but a sharp drop in car sales. Every G.M. car brand but Cadillac and Saturn posted declines. Overall car sales fell 14.4 percent, to 67,144, while light-truck sales rose 11.5 percent, to 42,738.
The Ford Motor Company's car sales gained 21 percent, to 44,645, while light-truck sales fell a scant seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 36,492. Sales of the Ford Taurus rose 50 percent for the period, with the company providing sales incentives on the model in an attempt to overtake the Honda Accord as the top-selling model in the United States.
Sales for the Chrysler Corporation, which does not report 10-day figures, were estimated at 18,500 cars, up 15.3 percent, and 29,200 light trucks, up 34.3 percent, by Ward's Automotive Reports. Chrysler reports sales only once a month.
 
Japanese Companies
 The Honda Motor Company suffered a 13.8 percent drop in sales of American-built Accords and Civics, to 10,125. The Toyota Motor Corporation reported a 9.2 percent drop in car sales, to 7,764. Sales of domestically built Toyota pickups were 2,545, compared with 74 last year, when production was starting.
Sales of the Nissan Motor Company's American cars rose 62.9 percent, largely on the strength of the new Altima model, which competes with the Accord and Toyota Camry. Nissan's domestic light-truck sales dipped 9 percent, to 2,715.
The Mazda Motor Corporation posted a 43.8 percent increase in car sales, to 2,542, and a 47.4 percent slide in light-truck sales, to 181. Sales of the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation's cars fell 47.8 percent, to 1,243.
Sales of Subaru, the United States sales arm of Fuji Heavy Industries Inc., dropped 14.4 percent, to 513. The Isuzu Motor Corporation's car sales rose 81.4 percent, to 2,300.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
THIS, in case you didn't know it, is champagne time. Or, to be precise, sparkling-wine time. By the end of the year, Americans will have polished off some 173 million bottles of champagne and sparkling wine, 57 million of them from now to the end of December. Not bad for a recession year.
What's more, Americans are probably going to drink more this year than last. Only a tiny bit more, to be sure, but then, sparkling-wine consumption had been dropping steadily since 1985. That year, we popped almost 220 million champagne corks. 
 These numbers come to you courtesy of the Jobson Beverage Group, which puts out a batch of trade publications for the wine and spirits industry. The figures for 1992 are Jobson's projections. Industry economists follow this stuff religiously, of course, but what can the rest of us learn? A steady decline through the late '80s and a modest turnaround this year: the stock market is said to follow hemlines, so maybe champagne can tell us something about the economy.
According to Jobson's number crunchers, consumption this year will be up a minuscule eight-tenths of 1 percent, about 1.3 million bottles. And the increase will all be in domestic wine. Sales of imported sparkling wine continue to drop, but only about 2.6 percent for the year. Last year, imports were off 16.6 percent, and the year before, 12.3 percent.
Domestic sparkling wines will show a gain of about 2 percent, Jobson says. They were up a bit last year, too: eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Jobson estimates consumption of domestic sparkling wines to be about 11 million cases, or 130 million bottles, and that of imports to be about 3.6 million, or 43 million bottles.
Americans drink better than three times more domestic sparkling wine than they do imported. It's not hard to understand why: price and distribution favor the local product. There are drinkable domestic sparkling wines for under $5, and the people who produce them, like E.& J. Gallo, make sure they are in every corner of the country. The imports -- even the least expensive, roughly $7 -- start with a Federal excise tax and duties of 92 cents.
The big surprise, assuming Jobson's figures are on track, is in French imports, which it expects to show a 14 percent increase. Much of that is in non-Champagne sparkling wines, mostly from the Loire Valley, but Champagne figures are expected to show an improvement, too. The big drop is in Spanish sparkling wine -- cava -- which is expected to be down 25 percent.
Some of this loss may be attributed to the fact that the biggest Spanish companies, Codorniu and Freixenet, are competing with themselves. Both now have large sparkling-wine operations in California. But then, so do some of the Champagne houses, among them Mumm, Moet & Chandon, Deutz, Roederer, Piper Heidseick, Taittinger and Lanson.
Price may account for the improved showing by domestic sparkling wine, but only partly. Jobson suggests new brands may have helped and mentions Gallo's Eden Roc and Domaine Ste. Michelle from Washington State.
Quality has to be a factor, as well. Domestic sparkling wines have improved markedly in recent years, to a point where the best of them can best lesser Champagnes in blind tastings. They are helped by the fact that the quality of Champagne has suffered in recent years. Some of the obscure labels turning up in wine shops should never have been allowed to leave France. They compromise the reputations of the good Champagnes.
The best American sparkling wines -- most of them, anyway -- come from California. And now, even some of the best are getting better.
Domaine Chandon, Moet & Chandon's American cousin, has introduced l'Etoile, a non-vintage special cuvee, or blend, in a special bottle, costing about $25. Domaine Chandon's best regular bottling, Chandon Reserve, sells for about $17.
New this year is J. Schram, a special cuvee from Schramsberg Vineyards that will be released only in the best vintages. On sale now is the 1987 vintage, a very elegant wine, beautifully packaged in a special bottle. The price: a hefty $50. For more modest budgets, there is Schramsberg's lovely Blanc de Blancs 1987 for about $25.
One of the surprises of the year is a sparkling wine from, of all places, New Mexico. It's called Gruet after its producer, Laurent Gruet, who came to New Mexico from Champagne. The wine is good to drink, and an excellent conversation piece. It is about $13 for the brut, a bit more for the blanc de noirs.
The various French branches, if that's the proper term, and the Spanish companies, as well, all produce good sparkling wines. In a recent tasting, Domaine Carneros, Taittinger's American venture, came off particularly well. It sells for about $17. There are those who insist that Codorniu and Gloria Ferrer, Freixenet's California winery, do better than their mentors back in Spain. Codorniu's Napa Brut is around $15 and the Gloria Ferrer Royal Cuvee Brut is around $13.
Year in and year out, some of California's best sparkling wines are from Iron Horse, in Sonoma County's Green Valley. The top of the Iron Horse line is a blanc de noirs called Wedding Cuvee, but the regular vintage brut, a pinot noir and chardonnay blend, is a particularly agreeable wine at about $19 for the 1988.
Up in Mendocino County, Roederer Estate makes a delightful brut that sells for about $16 and, just down the road, John Scharffenberger makes a variety of sparkling wines, including a cremant, which is softer than a regular champagne, a blanc de blancs and a brut. The brut is easiest to find, and it sells for about $13.
 
TASTINGS
Chateau Gloria, St. Julien 1989, in double magnum. About $85.
 Want to make tomorrow's dinner truly memorable? Pick up this bottle of Chateau Gloria and dazzle everyone at the table. A double magnum is the equivalent of four regular bottles, and it is a striking sight on anyone's sideboard. The wine itself needs no introduction to Bordeaux fans. Henri Martin, who died last year, created Gloria virtually single-handedly, and the wine has never lost its popularity. It has all the attributes of a good St. Julien: medium body, richness, never harsh or tannic and ready to drink at a fairly young age. That's important with big bottles; they hold so much wine in proportion to the amount of air under the cork that they age a bit more slowly than smaller bottles. Don't buy a big bottle unless you are sure the wine will be consumed. Leftover wine does not keep well in a large bottle: there is too much air in it. The wine should be decanted into a smaller bottle and tightly corked.

HEADLINE: Theater in Review

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
On the Bum, or the Next Train Through
Playwrights Horizons
416 West 42d Street
Clinton
Through Dec. 13
 
Written by Neal Bell; directed by Don Scardino; set by Allen Moyer; costumes by Sharon Lynch; lighting by Kenneth Posner; sound by John Gromada; production stage manager, Dianne Trulock. Presented by Playwrights Horizons, Mr. Scardino, artistic director; Paul S. Daniels, executive director.
 
WITH: Bill Buell, William Duell, Jim Fyfe, Kevin Geer, John Benjamin Hickey, Robert Hogan, Cynthia Nixon, James Rebhorn, Joyce Reehling, Ross Salinger, Campbell Scott, Maureen Shay and J. Smith-Cameron. 
 Eleanor Ames (Cynthia Nixon), the protagonist of Neal Bell's comedy "On the Bum, or the Next Train Through" is an unemployed actress in Depression-era New York City who hops a freight train to the Middle Western town of Bumfork to work in a production sponsored by the Federal Theater Project. The play turns out to be a ludicrous verse drama by a local matron named Jessie Mae Burst (Joyce Reehling). "And then again she may not," goes the running joke after each mention of her name. Jessie Mae's play memorializes an actual flood that devastated the town many years earlier when a dam collapsed.
Some of the funniest scenes in "On the Bum" are the poor actors' singsong recitations of Jessie Mae's "Pyramus and Thisbe"-style verses, with rhymes like "struggle" and "gluggle."
But beneath its raucous humor, "On the Bum" reaches for deeper connections between the depressed cultural climate of 1938 and present-day America, and especially the wary relationship between the Federal Government and the theater. The plot assumes undertones of a thriller when Eleanor begins to suspect that the flood was no act of God but involved skulduggery and a cover-up by people in high places. But because the play's political implications aren't developed until late in the second act and are treated so cursorily, the savage edge of Mr. Bell's humor fails to register.
What the play shows in abundance, however, is the playwright's ear for the poetry of idiomatic American speech. The language of the play is a torrent of colliding styles elevated to a comic poetic rhetoric that is as energized as it is self-conscious. The vernacular game-playing begins in the opening scene where Eleanor, supervised by a pretentious pseudo-English director (Campbell Scott), is rehearsing a rustic comedy whose characters speak in a cartoonishly twangy "L'il Abner" dialect.
"On the Bum" is the inaugural production of Playwrights Horizons under its new artistic director, Don Scardino. In his ingenious and economical production, designed by Allen Moyer, 13 actors assume 35 roles. Ms. Nixon makes an appealingly feisty Candide-like figure. Mr. Scott is commanding in dual roles as the pompous director and as Eleanor's married sweetheart in Bumfork.
The play's staging as a sort of thinking person's vaudeville show echoes the language's riotous ring, as the actors are rolled on and off on giant platforms draped with Edward Hopper-like paintings of rural America. Wonderfully acted with oratorical flourishes that recall the glory days of network radio, and spiced with a soundtrack of vintage swing music, "On the Bum" boldly reimagines an era when people, stimulated by magic voices on the airwaves, really cared about how they spoke.

M.C.C ORGANIZES GROUP FOR FLAT-PANEL DISPLAYS

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation said yesterday that it had set up a nine-company working group to quickly develop flat-panel displays for use in high-definition television and advanced personal computers. The Field Emission Display Consortium plans a six-month technology review, followed by exploration of an assembly line to make the new displays for television screens and computers. 
 M.C.C. is a research company owned by 62 high-technology companies and the Federal Government. The companies that joined the consortium are: the Ceridian Corporation, the Digital Equipment Corporation, the Harris Corporation, the Hewlett-Packard Company, the International Business Machines Corporation, Litton Industries, Schmidt Industries, the Zenith Electronics Corporation, and Field Emission Devices, an affiliate of Microelectronics Center of North Carolina.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Six for Women

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
So much is contained in a small story Bishop P. Francis Murphy recounted recently in Commonweal magazine. The Auxiliary Bishop of Baltimore asked a class of first graders the number of sacraments, a question as elementary to Catholic schoolchildren as the ABC's.
"One little girl promptly responded: 'Six for women and seven for men,' " the Bishop wrote. 
 What a smart little girl. The gender-specific sacrament is ordination, the one that makes men Catholic priests. Bishop Murphy believes that is wrong. Of the ordination of women he writes, "Justice demands it."
But he is still in the minority, and last week, when the American bishops rejected their own pastoral letter on the role of women, the dis-ease of the Catholic hierarchy with half its people was made painfully manifest.
Since the National Conference of Catholic Bishops was founded in 1966, it has wrestled with issues of social welfare, armed conflict and economic justice. But the pastoral letter on women is the first in its history on which the conference has been unable to reach consensus, falling far short of the two-thirds majority needed for approval. By the time it had been drafted and redrafted, homogenized and Vatican-vetted, its vitality was gone and its supporters nearly outnumbered by those who thought it more divisive than illuminating.
And while many of the bishops preferred to focus on other issues, the pastoral letter had at its heart what has become for some Catholic women the most obvious symbol of church patriarchy, the refusal to consider the ordination of women.
The new catechism reads, "The Lord Jesus chose men to form the college of the 12 apostles. . . . The Church acknowledges that it is bound by this choice of the Lord Himself." As though the single-sex Congress of the early days of the Republic inevitably dictated that Congress should remain so today, the church, at its most literal-minded, considers the New Testament in a vacuum, divorced from the mores of its times, the larger lessons of Christianity and the overarching issue of humanity.
Stretch this, and you can argue that stories that Christ was a carpenter dictate that only those skilled with hand tools shall be called to the priesthood. It ignores the fact that Catholicism is not powered by the literal facts of Jesus' life alone, facts that vary from gospel to gospel. Its engine is its ethos, an ethos at odds with discrimination that, no matter how cloaked in unbroken tradition, is nothing more than gender prejudice made theological writ.
This is precisely what those who oppose the ordination of women would expect me to say. The Auxiliary Bishop of Fort Wayne-South Bend, John R. Sheets, recently described some proponents of ordination for women as "those whose stridency hints at something more at work than theological clarification." And the failed pastoral letter itself took aim at radical feminism. How much easier to dismiss us as fringe elements than to consider in a thoughtful fashion the more troubling question of exclusion as tradition.
The remarkable thing is how many of those seen as malcontents have stayed within the church of our mothers. In an earlier, more vivid version of the pastoral letter, many women were quoted. One said, "As I reflect upon my experience as a Catholic woman what stands out the most for me is that I choose to participate in an institution that is discriminating against me as a woman."
That child Bishop Murphy quotes cannot even be an altar girl. That is indefensible. Defend it the hierarchy does, by saying that women can serve in ways just as valuable but not identical. It is a classic separate-but-equal argument; the separation is real but the equality illusory.
"Jesus inhabited a world which was utterly different from our own," A. N. Wilson writes in his uncommonly intelligent new book, "Jesus: A Life," an exploration of both the historical figure and the Christ of faith. While some prefer to think our position is political, the truth is that it is precisely in that nexus of spirit and gospel story that many of us find the argument for the ordination of women in the Catholic Church. For it comes down to this: Can we imagine that, carrying out his mission today, the Christ of charity and unity would have restricted his circle to men alone? No. So crabbed a spirit would not have survived so long.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Germans, Hazy About Past, Distrust the Future

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Where Are Germany's Leaders?" (editorial, Nov. 12) is right on target, but a recent business trip adds some dimensions to the call for a look within, rather than at foreigners. 
 I was told by a number of people older than 50 that from 1945 to 1966 German high school textbooks mentioned nothing about the Hitler period from 1932 to 1945: it was simply too controversial a topic. No wonder that 10 percent of the German people, according to recent polls, do not believe the Holocaust happened.
Several of my informants consider nationalism a recent reaction to a prolonged lack of German identity in the postwar period. For this some blamed the feeling of guilt harbored by a generation that lived passively through the war years. Others felt that until their recent economic pre-eminence, Germans could not hold up their heads among Europeans.
The stridency of the calls of Germany for the Germans is in part attributable to an overcompensation for the earlier feelings. What is striking is how widely it is shared by all social classes. While the tones in an upper-class household are more muted and in a suburban train more obvious toward the several Africans and Asians aboard, you encounter the emotion wherever you go.
There is an ahistoricity about all this anger toward foreigners. Not a single person within Germany -- although several Swiss mentioned this to me -- recalled that xenophobia was precisely the way that post-World War I Germany responded to its problems, and the use of that feeling Hitler made in galvanizing the country around the Nazi Party.
Lastly, there is a revulsion among ordinary citizens of every social class against politicians. No one I met had a good word for Chancellor Helmut Kohl, whose lying about the cost of unification and refusal to increase taxes so that his party would get re-elected, have clearly brought on the draconian monetary measures of the Bundesbank. Many other politicians came in for much the same drubbing.
No wonder that Germans sense things are not going well economically in their country and that they may be entering a recession within a year. The liberal asylum policy has brought in many people whose lack of language and other skills make them much harder to integrate than other Germans, although we have faced similar problems in Florida and California. Even East Germans -- who are still arriving at the rate of 1,000 a day -- are looked down on and discriminated against west of Berlin.
Yes, Germany needs new and better leadership. However, the followers of the new leaders will have to reckon with their own feelings and energies. It is said that people get the government they deserve. Perhaps we've just rediscovered that in the United States. Is it possible that Germans will come around to the same conclusion?
 
WALTER P. BLASS
Warren, N.J., Nov. 12, 1992

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
History's Pendulum Defeats Custer Again

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
It has been more than a half-century since movie audiences first saw Errol Flynn, as a dashing Gen. George Armstrong Custer, die with his boots on at the Little Big Horn, along with all those extras playing the 262 other United States cavalrymen who fell with him on June 25, 1876. That has been enough time for Americans to be made aware of a point of view other than the settlers-against-savages version long promoted by Hollywood, the popular press, traveling shows and some histories. In recent decades, it has been the Indians' turn to be romanticized.
"Last Stand at Little Big Horn," written by the producer Paul Stekler and the Blackfoot novelist James Welch, is in accord with the revised consensus without getting sappy. For the Plains Indians, says the narrator, N. Scott Momaday, the encounter with Custer was "one of many battles to prevent the theft of their land." Their hour of success was just a passing episode in a profound defeat.
The accounts of the white side come largely from the usual historical sources, embellished by photographs. The Indian version is told in stories and songs handed down through generations and is accompanied by drawings. That alone suggests the nature of the differences between the Lakota and Cheyenne peoples, who made their homes in the Montana Territory, and the pioneers and gold-seekers from the East. Yet the irreconcilable points of view have been fitted together in a coherent hour that goes beyond the brief battle at the Little Big Horn to what America's westward expansion meant for those who were simply in the way.
The program has no criticism of the cavalrymen, described as impoverished young immigrants and farm boys, who did not ride or shoot nearly so well as western movies would have it and who endured miseries in unwelcoming territory. The program makes the case that they were serving the political and economic interests of grander classes and the imperatives of an expanding nation.
As for Custer, whose image his widow, Elizabeth, dedicated herself with considerable success to polishing for more than 50 years after his death, tonight's program contributes to his debunking as a swaggering, egotistical self-promoter who rashly led his men to their deaths. Yet at the time, he was portrayed as a martyr, and the massacre of his outnumbered troopers became a pretext for wiping out the Plains Indians. A son of the Lakota leader Crazy Horse, speaking for his people, says, "Wherever we went they came to kill us."
Much of the nation seems to understand now that no just compensation is possible for what was done to America's Indians, but it is possible, at least, to tell their story in a way that treats them as human beings. Narrowly avoiding a popular tendency to demonize whites and glorify Indians, the latest offering from "The American Experience" makes an intelligent and moving contribution to that cause.
 
The American Experience
Last Stand at Little Big Horn
PBS, tonight
(In the New York area, Channels 13 and 49 at 9)
 
Written by Paul Stekler and James Welch; produced and directed by Mr. Stekler; Margaret Drain, senior producer for "The American Experience"; Judy Crichton, executive producer for "The American Experience"; N. Scott Momaday, narrator.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Boeing to Slow Output, Leading to Job Cuts

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

 BODY:
The Boeing Company said yesterday that it would slow production rates on its 757 and 767 jetliners next year, resulting in the loss of an estimated 2,000 jobs in the Seattle area and 500 jobs in Wichita, Kan.
"The decision takes into account the cumulative recent requests of a number of our customers for changes in their delivery stream," said Dean Thornton, president of Boeing's commercial aircraft group. 
 Boeing's production cuts, which analysts said had been anticipated, are a reflection of a steep downturn hitting the commercial aircraft industry, which in 1989 had booked a record 1,662 orders.
Every major airline is putting orders on hold. Pratt & Whitney, one of the nation's two principal aircraft engine makers, said that in the last year $9 billion in commercial airline orders for planes using its engines alone have been deferred or canceled because of declining air travel, reduced profits and price competition among carriers.
Boeing, the industry leader, like other commercial aircraft makers, McDonnell Douglas and Europe's Airbus Industrie, is stretching out deliveries of new commercial airliners because buyers are in difficult straits. The airline industry has lost $6 billion in the last two years. The Persian Gulf war along with a sluggish world economy and half-price fare wars have left the airline industry with huge losses in recent years.
The announcement yesterday represents yet a new round of cuts by Seattle's largest manufacturing employer. Over all, Boeing's work force of 144,000 has declined by 9,000 this year. Of those, 4,900 jobs have been cut on military work and 2,500 in commercial plane building, said Russell D. Young, a company spokesman. In the Puget Sound area, 5,700 jobs were cut, but most were achieved through attrition, he said. About 2,000 jobs were eliminated by layoff.
 
Cuts to Trim Production Levels
 The new cuts will trim 757 production by 42 percent, to 5 planes a month from 8.5 a month by November 1993. Production will decline by 20 percent on the wide-body 767 to four planes a month from five.
So far, the only commercial production line left unhurt has been the company's wide-body 747, used most often on international flights. Earlier, the company had cut production of its best-selling short-range aircraft, the 737, by 33 percent, to 14 planes a month from 21.
Cai von Rumohr, an aerospace analyst with Cowen & Company, expects further production cuts by Boeing. "The total market is in disarray," he said. "The question is, is '95 going to be a rebound? That's the earliest chance."
Susan J. Davis, a Boeing spokeswoman, said expected job losses in commercial plane-building would be higher except for the anticipated start of production next year on Boeing's new 777 long-range jetliner. The first 777 deliveries are not expected before 1995.
Boeing has so far this year delivered 373 commercial airliners and received 165 new orders. Since peaking in 1990, Boeing's backlog has declined by 20 percent. The company's backlog on Oct. 31 stood at 1,449 aircraft, compared with 1,658 as of last Dec. 31.
Separately, Boeing and its second-largest union, the Seattle Professional Engineers Employees Association, are apparently close to reaching an agreement on a new three-year contract.
The new contract calls for technicians to get a 9 percent total wage increase for the first year and engineers to get 6 percent. Both groups would receive 5 percent in the second and third years.
The union representing Boeing's engineers and technicians recommended the new contract to its membership.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday Boeing stock fell 37.5 cents, to $34.625.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Boeing plans to slow production next year on its 757 and 767 jetliners. Above, a line of 757s in the Seattle area, where an estimated 2,000 jobs will be lost. About 500 jobs are also expected to be lost in Wichita, Kan. (Doug Wilson for The New York Times)

OZONE DEADLINE NOW 1996 
 Spurred by recent evidence that the earth's protective ozone layer is being depleted even more extensively than feared, the nations of the world agreed to bring forward again the deadline for halting production of the most important ozone-destroying chemicals. Representatives of 87 countries moved up the deadline from 2000 to Jan. 1, 1996. A1
 
NO CIGARETTES IN ITALY
It may be true that at no time since tobacco was introduced to Europe in the mid-16th century has a small group of people forced an entire country to contemplate giving up smoking. But that is what has happened in Italy after 20 days of a strike by the workers who control distribution from the state tobacco monopoly. There are no cigarettes to be had anywhere except from smugglers. A1

HEADLINE: A STRONG UPTURN FOUND IN ECONOMY IN THIRD QUARTER

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
The nation's economy grew by a surprisingly robust 3.9 percent in the third quarter, the Government reported today, and President-elect Bill Clinton said the news might cause him to rethink his short-term plans to spur the economy.
The Commerce Department report represented an unusually large upward revision of its previous third-quarter growth estimate of 2.7 percent, which was already stronger than economists had predicted. It was by far the strongest three months of growth since President Bush took office. 
 Although Mr. Clinton said the report could change his short-term plans, he left the door open to a spending program intended to stimulate the economy. Mr. Clinton said he feared that growth could slow once again.
 
No Long-Term Change
 The President-elect also seemed anxious not to foreclose the option of short-term deficit spending if he needs to give the economy a jolt or keep his campaign promise to create jobs.
"It could have some impact on short-term judgments," Mr. Clinton told reporters in Little Rock, Ark. "But we're going to have to see if these figures tell us anything about what is likely to happen for the next year." He added that the report "won't change my long-term plans at all" to try to strengthen the nation's industrial competitiveness.'
Several other economic reports released today underlined the sense that a recovery was taking hold after three years of sluggish growth. But many economists said it was still too early to declare a turning point and a stronger recovery.
 
White House Hails News
 Nevertheless, the White House immediately trumpeted today's news as a belated confirmation of Mr. Bush's campaign assertions that the economy was doing better than other candidates acknowledged or the American people seemed to believe.
"The Bush recovery is coming on strong," Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, shouted over the roar of the President's helicopter on the South Lawn of the White House as Mr. Bush headed to his family home in Maine for the Thanksgiving weekend. "I'm talking about this economy that is showing signs of life and looking good, looking strong, living up to our predictions of the last several months."
The economic news provoked wistful speculation among some Republicans who suggested that if the good economic news had come in the second quarter rather than the third quarter, President Bush might have won on Nov. 3. "President Bush's Thanksgiving turkey arrived too late," said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
The Commerce Department frequently makes upward or downward revisions in its initial estimates of gross domestic product -- the value of all goods and services produced in the nation -- as it gathers information that was not available when the first estimates are released.
Today's report raised growth estimates after more complete statistics showed that exports, business inventories and consumer spending were all higher than October's less-complete statistics showed.
The G.D.P. figures and the unemployment rate are the nation's two most closely watched statistics, providing businesses, investors and elected officials an important gauge for the health of the economy.
 
Other Healthy Reports
 In addition to the Commerce Department report, several other reports today showed the economy picking up. Sales of existing homes jumped 9.1 percent in October, to their highest level in four years, the National Association of Realtors said. New applications for state unemployment benefits fell by 12,000, to 374,000, during the week ended Nov. 14, the sixth decline in eight weeks, the Labor Department reported.
And those come after surveys by the Conference Board and the University of Michigan showed a significant jump in consumer confidence, which could portend a strong rise in consumer spending. In addition, on Tuesday the Government reported that orders for durable goods rose 3.9 percent in October, their biggest increase since July 1991.
"I think now we've turned a corner," Commerce Secretary Barbara H. Franklin said in an interview. "This is a big present to President-elect Clinton as we go out the door."
But Mr. Clinton and his aides took a different view, arguing that the strong third quarter did not necessarily signal a robust recovery.
George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director, called the report "good news, but still probably not good enough," He said economists were "not at all clear on whether or not we're going to have real growth in the fourth quarter."
He added, "We have to wait and see and see if it's necessary" to have a stimulus program "at the beginning of the year."
 
 
Reich Is Cautious
 In an interview, Robert B. Reich, the head of Mr. Clinton's economic transition team, added, "To the extent that it's a one-time blip turning on new investments resulting in larger inventories and additional exports due to a low dollar for that particular period, then we probably can't count on that figure to signal the beginning of a buoyant recovery."
The stock market reacted favorably to today's news, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 17.56 points on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at 3,266.26.
Today's report on gross domestic product seemed to contradict suggestions by the Clinton camp that the Bush Administration had, with an eye to Election Day, overstated growth in its preliminary estimate in October, which said that output rose by 2.7 percent in the July-through-September period. Coming in the heat of the campaign, that figure stunned most economists, who were forecasting feeble growth of around 1.5 percent in the third quarter.
A final report on third-quarter gross domestic product will be issued on Dec. 22.
"These numbers show an improving economy, but hardly a booming one," Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, said in an interview. "The economy has grown at a rate averaging 2.75 percent over the last three quarters, that's certainly better than the last three quarters of 1991 when it averaged 1.25 percent."
 
Slower Quarter Seen
 Most economists predict that growth will slow down in the fourth quarter. "I don't think 3.9 percent is sustainable," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley, the investment bank. "The fourth and first quarters will be relatively sluggish. There won't be a measurable improvement in jobs and fortunes of average Americans. We're still not on Easy Street."
He predicted growth of 2 percent in the fourth quarter and the first quarter, saying the third-quarter numbers included some one-time positive factors. Inventories grew for the second consecutive quarter, government spending, especially military spending, was up sharply, partly to carry out certain expenditures by the end of the fiscal year on Oct. 1. He also suggested that some businesses are deferring investments that had been planned for the fourth-quarter because they want to wait until Congress approved Mr. Clinton's proposed income tax credits.
"There are a lot of conflicting things here," Mr. Clinton said as he was leaving what aides described as a routine checkup by his internist. "There's some increased activity. But manufacturing is still in some trouble. There's still a lot of structural layoffs planned and Boeing announced another layoff today."
Even though Bush Administration officials and many economists expect growth to be weaker in the fourth quarter, the strong third-quarter numbers could persuade Mr. Clinton to scale back any plans to create jobs through increased deficit spending.
Today's report said output rose by $47 billion in the third quarter, fueled principally by growth in consumer spending, exports and government purchases. Consumer spending was up a robust 3.7 percent, or $29.9 billion, $2.3 billion more than the October estimate. Business inventories rose by $12.4 billion, up $5.5 billion from the October estimate. Government purchases rose $7.6 billion, up 3.3 percent overall and up 6.7 percent in just military spending. Exports rose $12.8 billion, which is $10.2 billion more than the October estimate.
The Commerce Department also reported today that corporate after-tax profits, in their biggest fall in six and a half years, slumped by 6 percent, or $14 billion, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $218.8 billion. The main reason for the decline was that Hurricane Andrew in Florida and Louisiana and Hurricane Iniki in Hawaii devastated insurance company profits and caused many companies to write off nonrepairable damage. Without the hurricanes, corporate profits would have increased by more than $20 billion.

HEADLINE: Clinton Names Team to Probe U.S. Agencies

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 25

 BODY:
Beginning the real back-bending work of digging through the impacted, encrusted layers of each Federal department and agency to find out what, and who, is buried there, aides to President-elect Bill Clinton today announced the appointment of nine chief diggers, called "cluster coordinators."
The appointments come as Mr. Clinton's transition operation moved from the initial business of organizing itself to the more daunting work of actually organizing a new Government. 
 In this regard, the President-elect has begun the process of personally interviewing applicants, with a small parade of Democratic notables making its way to the Governor's Mansion Tuesday and today.
The meetings were private, and Mr. Clinton emerged in public view only once all day, to make two visits to doctors. The Governor spent about an hour in the office of Dr. Santa Cruz, an internist, before going to the office of Dr. Andrew Kumpuris, a cardiovascular specialist.
 
Ranking Cabinet Candidates
 George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's director of communications, described both doctors' visits as "just routine check-ups." Mr. Stephanopoulos said he did not know why neither appointment was listed on the President-elect's schedule. Asked specifically if the visits had come in response to any specific malady, he said no.
Three of the politicians who met with Mr. Clinton -- Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico, former Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona, both of whom visited today, and retiring Senator Tim Wirth of Colorado, who came Tuesday -- are considered the ranking candidates for the job of Secretary of the Interior. Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, who was a Tuesday arrival, has been mentioned as a contender for Secretary of the Treasury.
All the visits this week were cloaked in as much secrecy as possible in the intimate confines of a small city overly populated by reporters. No visits were announced, and no statements were made afterward. Transition officials will say only that discussions are at least in part real job interviews, not merely exercises in ego-stroking. The official said more discussions were planned next week, after the Clintons return from a trip to California.
Mr. Stephanopoulos said it was safe to assume that Mr. Clinton was discussing the positions of Secretary of the Interior and Secretary of Energy with Mr. Wirth, Mr. Richardson and Mr. Babbitt, and that he "wanted to discuss the economy and other issues" with Mr. Bentsen.
Mr. Clinton also took the unusual step today of recording the kind of ceremonial Thanksgiving address traditionally issued by Presidents, not Presidents-in-waiting.
"My fellow Americans, as we celebrate Thanksgiving this year, we have, as always, much to be thankful for," Mr. Clinton said in a brief speech released for radio broadcast on Thanksgiving Day. "I am especially thankful this Thanksgiving. During this last year, Hillary and I have been given the opportunity to meet many, many thousands of you all across America from all walks of life. We are forever grateful to all of you for your help, for your example, for your courage and for your friendship."
Today's appointments to the transition operation were the second wave of such. In the first, on Nov. 12, Mr. Clinton named an array of people to what were called "policy pods." Each pod oversees a specific policy area.
In today's round, nine "cluster coordinators" were named, each assigned to lead a group studying the departments and agencies in a specific area of the Federal bureaucracy.
Those named and their speciality areas were:
Franklin Delano Raines, the vice chairman of the Federal National Mortgage Association, to study economic and international trade.
Samuel R. Berger, a senior foreign policy adviser to Mr. Clinton, foreign policy and national security.
Frederico F. Pena, the former Mayor of Denver, transportation.
Sally Ride, the former astronaut, science, space and technology.
James Gustave Speth, the president of the World Resources Institute, natural resources.
Johnetta B. Cole, an anthropologist and the president of Spelman College, education and labor.
Representative Tom Downey of Long Island, health, human services and housing.
Peter B. Edelman, a professor of law at Georgetown University, and Bernard W. Nussbaum, a New York corporate lawyer, justice.
Dietra Ford, a staff member of the Committee on the District of Columbia in the House of Representatives, government operations.
