HEADLINE: Trenton Faces Deadline on Health Care

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Forced into action by a Federal judge and the need to repair a system near collapse, the Legislature on Monday will consider a complicated and untested package of bills that may produce one of the most comprehensive programs in the nation for paying for hospital care for the poor.
The plan was shaped largely by political considerations and almost no one likes it entirely. But if the proposed measures are adopted -- and the outlook is uncertain -- the changes will be sweeping. They range from deregulating hospitals to requiring that insurance companies enroll everyone who applies, regardless of age, sex or health. 
 "It is an experiment," said Dr. Bruce Siegel, the state's acting health commissioner. "We are entering a brave new world of less regulation. No one has been in this territory before, and I hope that the Legislature will listen very carefully to the concerns that have been raised by the urban hospitals."
A senior state official described the legislation as "a political crapshoot."
"I don't think anybody knows what the effects will be," the official said. "The Legislature says it will make changes if they are necessary. But who knows what the political climate will be like in six months."
 
Debate Against a Deadline
 The package includes four bills. The most controversial, the Health Care Reform Act of 1992, would deregulate hospitals in New Jersey. It also would divert $1.6 billion over the next three years from the state's unemployment trust fund to pay for the hospital bills of the uninsured poor.
Under the old system, in operation since 1980, hospital care for about 823,000 uninsured and indigent patients in New Jersey has been paid for through a 19.1 percent surcharge on every hospital bill for an insured patient, except for those covered under Medicare. That plan was outlawed in May in a ruling by Judge Alfred M. Wolin of Federal District Court in Newark.
Supporters of the proposed changes say they could serve as a national model for health care reform, but critics say it could mean the ruination of urban hospitals and much of New Jersey's health-care system.
There is ample support for either view, and both sides today continued to amass information in preparation for a legislative debate on Monday and a vote that will come only hours before a 12-year-old plan under which New Jersey provided hospital care for its poor is due to expire.
 
A Bipartisan Effort
 Working as much under the shadow of next year's gubernatorial race as they were under that of the Federal court, Gov. Jim Florio and the Republican legislative leadership, Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco and Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, opted for a bipartisan effort at health-care reform.
Some labor groups and business organizations had lobbied for raising the sales tax to 7 percent, barely six months after it was rolled back to 6 percent, to help pay for hospital care for the poor. Others favored an increase in so-called sin taxes on tobacco products, liquor and beer.
But both Mr. Florio and the Republicans rejected such an approach.
The unemployment trust fund became the most politically pleasing target, despite concerns from the Federal Department of Labor and others that tapping into it would risk its solvency.
The fund, which is used to pay benefits for people who lose their jobs, has a reserve of $2.4 billion and annual income of $1.2 billion from employer and employee contributions and interest.
To appease some critics, including the Federal Department of Labor, the negotiators added language to the bill that said if the unemployment trust fund balance fell to $1.5 billion, employers would pay a new payroll tax of 0.6 percent. But mindful of next year's gubernatorial race, even that provision does not kick in until 1994.
 
City Hospitals See Danger
 No matter where the money comes from, urban hospitals have argued that the Health Care Reform Act will be their ruin.
Under the bill, hospitals will be able to set their own prices after a one-year transition period.
Urban hospitals, which currently serve about 80 percent of the indigent uninsured, said they would be forced to increase prices steeply for their insured patients. This increase, urban hospital officials say, would drive insured patients to hospitals that are able to hold their costs down because they serve fewer poor patients. Urban hospitals fear that such a move would eventually put them out of business.
Under the current law, costs to insured patients at urban hospitals are offset by the surcharge on hospital bills, distributed through the Uncompensated Care Trust Fund. This year the fund doled out $750 million.
The bill before the Legislature on Monday would allocate $600 million for uncompensated health costs in its first year, 1993, and $500 million each of the next two years. After three years, the fund would end and hospitals would be forced to deal with the problem of uncompensated health costs on their own.
If Monday's deadline passes with no new legislation in place, the state's health-care system will be thrown into chaos, with hospitals required to serve uninsured poor patients, but with no idea how they would be paid. In addition, the state stands to lose $350 million in matching Federal funds for the money it spends on uncompensated care.
 
Republicans Bolster Support
 Without an alternative plan before him and faced with a Monday deadline and a two-thirds Republican majority in both chambers of the Legislature, Mr. Florio has given his grudging support to the plan and has said he will sign it.
If the health care act is approved, it will be over the objections of two of the most powerful lobbying groups in the state, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the State Chamber of Commerce, and without the support of some influential members of the Legislature.
"Fear of the 'T-word' has thrown the discussion of a funding source down into a cowardly level of semantics," Senator Richard J. Codey, a Democrat from West Orange, said on Monday.
"There are too many unanswered questions about what happens to the urban hospitals, what will happen to outpatient services for the poor, and what incentives there will be to provide charity care."
The Republicans spent today trying to bolster party support for the bill, especially in the Senate, and responding to a flood of criticism.
Senator C. Louis Bassano, the sponsor of the bill, issued a news release in which he responded point by point to what he described as "myths" and "complete fiction" about his bill.
"This is consumer- and provider-friendly legislation that has been crafted over the course of many months with input from lawmakers, providers, insurers and consumers," Mr. Bassano said. "While it may not be perfect, we've still not seen a viable alternative."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls in Light Day Despite Economic Reports

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined on world currency markets yesterday in extremely light pre-holiday trading.
Gold prices also lost ground after rising in Asian markets. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $333.50 an ounce, off 80 cents from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold slid 90 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $333.70. 
 The currency markets seemed to shrug off several favorable reports about the United States economy. The Commerce Department said the economy grew at a brisk 3.9 percent annual rate during the third quarter, far better than the original report and better than analysts had expected.
Separately, the National Association of Realtors said sales of existing homes soared 9 percent in October, and the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing new claims for jobless benefits fell by 12,000 in mid-November.
"The numbers were good, and the market tried to react," Kevin Lawrie, a trader at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said. But "the market just seemed to die a slow, natural death."
Mr. Lawrie attributed the lack of interest to a dearth of participants ahead of Thanksgiving Day.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 123.60 yen, down 0.40 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 123.83 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 123.75 yen, down from 123.85 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5245, from $1.5190 late Tuesday. In New York, it cost $1.5295 to buy one pound, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.5255.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5865 German marks, down from 1.5945; 1.4265 Swiss francs, down from 1.4290; 5.3750 French francs, down from 5.4135; 1,373.50 Italian lire, down from 1,382.00, and 1.2838 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2864.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5940 German marks, down from 1.6020; 1.4310 Swiss francs, down from 1.4370; 5.3940 French francs, down from 5.4475; 1.7895 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8025; 1,377.50 Italian lire, down from 1,389.50, and 1.2831 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2888.

HEADLINE: Dow Advances by 17.56; Other Indexes at Highs

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Signs that the United States economy is picking up steam helped carry stocks higher yesterday for a second consecutive day.
The Nasdaq Combined Composite, Standard & Poor's 500-stock and New York Stock Exchange Composite indexes all closed at record levels. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 17.56, to 3,266.26, led by Westinghouse Electric. 
 The broader market averages were led by shares of economically sensitive automobile, electrical equipment and long-distance telephone companies. The Nasdaq composite advanced 2.39, to 648.33; the S.& P. 500 rose 1.60, to 429.19, and the New York Stock Exchange composite increased 0.86, to 236.13. The three indexes eclipsed all-time highs set on Tuesday.
Advancing common stocks outnumbered declining issues by about 4 to 3 on the Big Board. Trading was heavy considering that it was the day before Thanksgiving, with about 208 million shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Everybody seems to be getting optimistic about the economy and that's what the market wants," said Sid Dorr, head of institutional equities at Charles Schwab & Company in San Francisco.
The United States Commerce Department said the economy grew 3.9 percent in the third quarter, up from an originally reported 2.7 percent and the largest gain since the final quarter of 1988. The Government reported that the number of Americans filing first-time unemployment claims fell 12,000, to a seasonally adjusted 374,000, in the week ending Nov. 14.
Two private groups released additional positive news about the economy. The University of Michigan reported to clients that consumer confidence is up this month, while the National Association of Realtors said sales of existing homes rose 9.1 percent in October.
Michael Lenahan, head trader at James Capel Inc., said: "The economy finally seems to be making some progress. At the same time, interest rates are low and that's really helping the stock market." The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond is at 7.54 percent, down 22 basis points since Nov. 6. Comptronix fell 15 7/8, or 72 percent, to 6 1/8, on news that the company's board had formed a special committee to investigate allegations that senior officers intentionally overstated profits.
Westinghouse Electric rose 1 1/2, to 12 1/2, in response to a broad restructuring and management reshuffling at the financially pressed company. An analyst at Paine Webber raised his rating on Westinghouse's stock to "attractive."
Glaxo Holdings declined 1/4, to 24, after a decision by the European Patent Office in Munich to give SmithKline Beecham certain patent rights for its Kytril anti-nausea drug.
Networth Inc. doubled in its first day of trading to 16, bid up by a stampede of investors who want to own shares of a company in the sizzling market for computer networking. The stock was priced for sale at $16 a share through a group of underwriters led by Robertson, Stephens & Company. The price was artificially low because Networth's controlling shareholder, Ungermann-Bass, a wholly owned subsidiary of Tandem Computer, insisted on the $16 price.
BankAmerica soared 2 3/8, to 45 1/4, on optimism tied to the bank's decision to close about 450 of its California branches by April. Gap Inc. fell 1 3/8, to 36 1/4, after analysts at Goldman, Sachs & Company. and the First Boston Corporation reduced earnings estimates for the retail store chain.
Berlitz International Inc. surged 3 5/8, to 20 7/8. Berlitz and the Fukutake Publishing Company agreed on amended merger terms that would reduce the cash portion of the consideration that Berlitz shareholders will receive to $19.50 from $21.62 a share.

HEADLINE: A Campaign Needs Help to Give Help to the Neediest;
From Struggling Business Owners to Strapped Parents, Charities Find Many Require Aid

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
When clients first stopped calling her employment service last spring, Mitzie G. thought that the telephone was out of order. Every few hours she checked for a dial tone or crawled under her desk to examine the wiring. Sometimes she had friends ring her to make sure that the lines were working.
The truth, as she finally admitted to herself, was that the recession was destroying her business. After nearly a decade of finding jobs for the unemployed, she was joining their ranks. Would she lose her house, which symbolized how hard she had struggled for her children? 
 Mitzie G. and dozens of other single mothers walked the aisles recently at a newly opened distribution center run by Catholic Charities in Jamaica, Queens. They picked free cans of beef, chicken broth, string beans and other food off the shelves as they sought some relief from an economic slump that has often sapped them of their savings and their spirits.
"There were some days when I just locked myself in my office and cried and cried," Mitzie G. recalled, giving voice to the fears -- of hunger, homelessness and illness -- felt by many New Yorkers out of work for the first time in their lives.
Faced with seemingly endless need sowed by a stubborn recession, groups like Catholic Charities harbor their own fear: that New Yorkers will feel so overwhelmed by the despair around them that they will turn away, that each new round of discouraging statistics will only numb them even more, that they will come to accept the state of their city instead of trying to better it.
But these philanthropies prefer to believe that stories of people like Mitzie G., who has received money from Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, to pay her mortgage and is now trying to restart her business, show that even when times are tough, New Yorkers will not abandon each other.
Against this backdrop of misery and hope, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund begins its 81st annual appeal on Sunday. The seven charities that receive grants from the fund have formed a bulwark against the recession in New York City, while also continuing to care for thousands of people suffering from a host of ills, including drug addiction, AIDS and child abuse.
Despite the lingering regionwide slump, the fund mounted its most successful campaign ever last year, raising $5,083,550.81. That represented large contributions from wealthy executives, movie stars and foundations; even more, it represented a surprising surge in modest donations, gifts from minimum-wage workers, shopkeepers, office raffles and children who squirreled away pennies.
The gifts seemed to reflect the spirit of renewal that is at the heart of the fund's mission.
Last Thanksgiving, Chris Mouzon and Patricia Vincent were living in a ramshackle one-bedroom apartment in Harlem with their seven children and two other people. Fire had damaged their building, leaving their cramped apartment with poor plumbing and crumbling walls. The rooms were infested with rats and cockroaches; addicts smoked crack in the hallways.
They lived there because they had no choice.
Mr. Mouzon, 26, had lost his job in construction, an industry where the unemployment rate has skyrocketed because of the recession. His search for work had proved futile.
"I thought that pretty soon we would be out on the street," he said earlier this week.
But the Children's Aid Society soon found his family an apartment and provided them with clothing, day care and after-school care for their children, using money from the Neediest Cases. In an interview at their new home on West 118th Street in Harlem, the children said they never want to return to their old apartment.
"There was no room over there, so we couldn't play at all," said James, 8 years old, as he cuddled on the couch with Christina, 7 months; Chris Jr., 18 months, Shameka, 2, Shanna, 3, Judy, 4, and Jermaine, 7.
Mr. Mouzon smiled broadly, as if energized by the joy of his children.
"This apartment is a blessing for me," he said. "My morale is really high. It makes me feel good to see my kids happy. I feel like I've been rescued."
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was born in the early years of this century. Then, as now, New York City seemed a striking paradox of poverty and wealth. In 1911, that contrast troubled Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The Times, after he gave a beggar a few dollars so he could find a place to sleep on Christmas night.
Ochs soon decided that if his readers knew about the suffering around them, they would be eager to help. The next year, The Times published an article with the headline: "Santa Claus, Please Take Notice! Here are New York's 100 Neediest Cases." Within a few months, 117 contributors gave $3,630.88.
This year, with the unemployment rate in New York City at more than 10 percent and the welfare rolls at more than one million people, the seven charities aided by the fund are stretched thin. They say they must focus on basic services like food, clothing and shelter.
"What we've returned to is much more reminiscent of what this agency did during the Depression," said Thomas DeStefano, executive director of Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens.
The United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York has cut 5 percent of its programs in each of the last three years because donations have not kept pace with inflation and the growing need. That means that social workers no longer visit more than 100 homebound elderly people in Queens.
"We are no longer doing any preventive work," said Stephen Solender, the group's executive vice president. "We're in a constant triage mode. That is going to mean high costs to our society down the road."
The Children's Aid Society is so worried about hunger in poor neighborhoods that it is now serving full meals at many of its after-school programs instead of milk and cookies. The society is conducting twice as many dental exams for children as it did only a few years ago.
"People who were borderline, more and more of them have slipped below the safety net," said Philip Coltoff, the society's executive director. "Those are the people who ordinarily might not need us. Now they are at our doorsteps."

HEADLINE: Put Communities Back in Community Colleges

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Community colleges, you report Nov. 11, are being forced to restrict access, as well as their goals. You point to the need for more capacity and funds in community colleges throughout the country. 
 You present a somewhat inaccurate perspective when you declare that "with the new focus on jobs, many of the colleges seemed to have lost sight of their original academic mission," and "Now just 24 percent of community college students transfer to four-year colleges."
I remember throughout my high school and college years hearing my father, who for 25 years was president of Yuba Junior College in Marysville, Calif., and for a time president of the Northern California Junior College Association, tell me of his battles to preserve his presidency against insurgents who argued that community colleges should concentrate on academic courses in preparation for four-year colleges.
He was steadfast in holding to what he said were the primary reasons community colleges were created. They were twofold: (1) to provide the finest academic training available to prepare any student who wanted to transfer to a four-year college, and as a foundation for citizenship through more enlightened understanding of society, government and the economy, and (2) to provide practical skills and training that relate directly to the needs of local businesses and, thus, the economy.
An ancillary purpose was to serve as a center for cultural and sports events in which the community could participate, and to provide an opportunity for all who live there, no matter their age, to gain knowledge in a broad variety of subjects.
The community college in California was intended as an open system that had a continuing, dynamic relationship with its local economy and society. It has stimulated those economies and has helped weave the social fabric that unifies communities.
Unfortunately, in the inner cities there are limited numbers of community colleges and community college seats. In north Brooklyn, where I work as an urban planner, there is a population of more than one million, most of whom are poorly educated, lower-income people of African-American and Latin descent, and there is not one community college. The only institution of higher education in north Brooklyn is Medgar Evers College, a four-year institution.
In the neighborhood of Bushwick, there is an opportunity to create a new campus that might include a community college. The site is on approximately 15 acres of vacant, city-owned land unused for more than 10 years. It is adjacent to Bedford-Stuyvesant and Williamsburg, and has been the subject of discussion at various levels of government and with nonprofit organizations.
The community college is the missing link in attempts to revitalize poor and working communities of America. Expanding the community college system should become a central element of President-elect Bill Clinton's efforts to strengthen education and rebuild American cities.
It should include coordination of Federal, state and local government budget priorities. Local industries, unions and nonprofit organizations should play an integral role in the planning and programming of these new institutions.
It is not necessary to build new campuses to begin an expansion of the community college system. Public schools can be used at night and on weekends, as now occurs in Bushwick, to start these college programs with extension courses from existing institutions.
 
JON T. COLLINS
New York, Nov. 13, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
